      NK=not known 
      OAS=oral allergy symptoms with 2 sips of red wine 
 
None of the 15 individuals challenged thus far has reacted adversely to the isinglass challenge.  
Therefore, consumption of a cumulative dose of 50.5 mg of isinglass or an upper dose of 30 mg 
of isinglass occurred without provocation of any adverse reactions.  One subject had a mild 
adverse reaction (skin rash) to placebo but not to isinglass.  This response was the only objective 
symptom encountered during the oral challenge trials.  Three subjects each experienced mild 
subjective reactions (e.g. palatal itching) to placebo and isinglass at initial doses used in the trial.  
However, these symptoms resolved quickly and further doses of either placebo or isinglass were 
administered without these or other symptoms developing.  Thus, these subjective reactions do 
not appear to be related to the challenge trial.  
 
D.  Discussion: 
 
While our ultimate aim is to enroll 29 fish-allergic patients in the isinglass challenge trial, only 
15 subjects have completed the challenges so far.  However, none of these patients has reacted 
adversely to the administration of a cumulative challenge dose of 50.5 mg of isinglass.  This 
amount of isinglass is far in excess of the amount that might be achieved with beer and wine 
consumption.  Cask ale, under certain circumstances, may allow higher levels of isinglass 
exposure but the 50.5 mg cumulative dose was intended to represent a worst-case scenario that is Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 15 of 15 
  
even beyond the exposure levels that likely occur with cask ale.  Thus, this challenge trial 
confirms that fish-allergic individuals may safely consume alcoholic beverages that have been 
treated with isinglass. 
 
III. References:  
 
Gerday Ch, Collin S, Gerardin-Otthiers N.  1989.  The amino acid sequence of the parvalbumin 
from the very fast swimbladder muscle of the toadfish (Opsanus tau). Comp Biochem Physiol B   
93:49-55.  
 
Taylor SL, Kabourek JL, Hefle SL.  2004a.  Fish allergy: fish and products thereof.  J Food Sci 
69:R175-R180. 
 
Taylor SL, Hefle SL, Bindslev-Jensen C, Atkins FM, Andre C, Bruijnzeel-Koomen C, Burks 
AW, Bush RK, Ebisawa M, Eigenmann PA, Host A, Hourihane JO’B, Isolauri E, Hill DJ, Knulst 
A, Lack G, Sampson HA, Moneret-Vautrin DA, Rance F, Vadas PA, Yunginger JW, Zeiger RS, 
Salminen JW, Madsen C, and Abbott P.  2004b. A consensus protocol for the determination of 
the threshold doses for allergenic foods: how much is too much? Clin Exp Allergy 34:689-695.

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Food Allergy Research and Resource Program (FARRP) 
Determination of the Allergenicity of Isinglass in Fish Allergic Individuals 
 
Isinglass is a product composed principally of collagen derived mainly from the swim 
bladders of certain species of tropical and subtropical fish (corvina, threadfin, croaker, 
and others), although cod, sturgeon and hake swim bladders may also be used 
occasionally (1).   
 
Isinglass is a processing aid used to clarify beers, ales, wines, and champagnes of  
yeasts, proteins, and other macromolecular components used or created during the 
fermentation process (1).  Without use of clarifying agents, these alcoholic beverages 
would be cloudy rather than clear.  Because the collagen molecules are amphoteric, the 
negative charges attract and bind to yeast cells while the positive charges attract and 
bind to proteins.  Furthermore, isinglass is highly insoluble and its addition results in 
immediate clarification of the liquid.  Clarification can be achieved with a rather low level 
of addition of isinglass, typically in the range of 0.001% to 0.002% (2).  In most cases, 
the isinglass and the components that precipitate with it are removed by filtration or 
centrifugation before packaging of the beverage.  In those situations, exposure to 
isinglass in the beverage as consumed would be quite low because the majority of it is 
likely removed.  Residue levels in filtered beer have been measured in the range of 0.02 
– 0.16 parts per million (ppm) or mg/l (2).  Cask ale, a popular beverage in the U.K., is 
an exception where the precipitated mass is left in the bottom of the cask.  In this case, 
isinglass exposure can be higher for consumers of cask ale especially as the cask is 
tipped and some sludge from the bottom of the cask may be intermixed with the ale.  
The levels of residual isinglass in cask ale have not been measured and, as noted, are 
likely to be variable from glass to glass. 
 
Because it is derived from a major allergenic food source, namely fish, the allergenicity 
of isinglass to fish-allergic individuals is a question of interest.  Fish are considered to 
be one of the most commonly allergenic foods in the human diet (1).  Fish and 
ingredients derived from fish are included on lists of commonly allergenic foods in 
countries in which such lists exist including the US, EU., Canada, and Australia/New 
Zealand (1).  Isinglass is certainly an ingredient derived from fish although its 
allergenicity has not been established.  Thus, regulations in these countries and regions 
would require that isinglass be labeled on the alcoholic beverages and that its fish origin 
also be declared unless an exemption could be granted.  Some countries and regions 
including the EU and US provide for the possibility of labeling exemptions in cases 
where the lack of allergenicity of the ingredient can be established. 
 
Fish-allergic individuals are typically advised to avoid ingestion of all species of fish and 
ingredients derived from fish.  While it has been observed clinically that some fish-
allergic individuals are tolerant of certain species of fish, the basis for this tolerance has 
not been elucidated (3).  In other clinical studies, fish-allergic individuals appear to be 
sensitive to all species of fish (4,5).  The major allergen of fish has been identified as 
parvalbumin, a muscle protein (6).  Parvalbumin appears to be a pan-allergen that 
exists in the edible muscle tissue of all fish (7,8).  Parvalbumin has been described to 
 1also occur in the swim bladders of some fish species (9) but the level and allergenicity 
of this parvalbumin has not been determined.  A few reports exist of other higher 
molecular weight protein allergens from fish (7, 10).  Collagen isolated from fish muscle, 
not swim bladder, has been identified as one of these allergens (10).  However, only a 
few Japanese patients have thus far been identified with IgE reactivity to fish collagen 
(7) and its allergenicity by oral challenge has not been documented.  Furthermore, the 
comparative lack of allergenicity of another fish collagen product, fish gelatin made from 
fish skins, in fish-allergic subjects has been documented (11). 
 
Isinglass may contain residual parvalbumin although the level of parvalbumin in 
isinglass has not been determined analytically (this is another research objective that is 
being simultaneously pursued).  Despite centuries of use in wines, ales, and beers, 
allergic reactions to isinglass have not been reported in the clinical literature (1).  The 
objective of this clinical trial is to determine the potential allergenicity of commercially 
produced isinglass in fish-allergic individuals. 
 
Objective:  Determine the allergenicity of isinglass by performing double blind placebo 
controlled food challenges in fish allergic individuals. 
 
Overview:  Twenty-nine fish allergic individuals will be selected and challenged based 
on the guidelines put forth in “A consensus protocol for the determination of the 
threshold doses for allergenic foods:  how much is too much?” (12).   Oral food 
challenges will be performed according to the following protocol by clinical collaborators 
with challenge materials supplied by FARRP.  The amount of isinglass used for the 
challenges will reflect typical exposure amounts. 
 
Clinical collaborators will be required to submit protocols and receive approval for the 
use of human subjects at their specific institutions.  
 
Statistical Design:  The proposed sample size of 29 subjects is based upon the 
assumption that no subjects will react at the lowest challenge dose and assuming that if 
a subject reacts to one dose, then they will also react to higher doses.  If 29 subjects 
are challenged and a dose is identified where 0/29 subjects reacts, then there is 95% 
confidence that 90% of fish-allergic individuals will not react to this amount of isinglass 
or less.  The sample size of 29 is based upon the hypothesis that the reaction rate is 
equal to 10%. 
 
Data analysis plan 
We will attempt to set a no observed adverse effect level (NOAEL) as well as estimate 
the false positive rate and the proportion of truly sensitive individuals.  Data will be 
captured as reaction / no reaction for each dose of active challenge material. The 
placebo reaction rate will be taken into account as follows: 
 2 
Subject ID Placebo 
1 
Placebo 
2 
Placebo  
3 
Placebo  
4 
Isinglass 
0.5 mg 
Isinglass 
5 mg 
Isinglass 
15 mg 
Isinglass 
30 mg 
1 - - - - - - - + 
2 - - - - - - - - 
3 - - - + - - + NA,+ 
4 - - - - - - - + 
…29 - - - + - - - - 
Total 
Reactions 
0/29 0/29 0/29 2/29 0/29 0/29 1/29 3/29 
NA= not administered, assuming that if a subject reacts to one dose, then he or she will 
also react to higher doses, these are scored as + 
 
The number of positive and negative placebo and active reactions will be tallied and 
entered into the formula of Briggs et al. (13) and calculated as outlined in Hansen et al. 
(11) and illustrated below. 
 
 
The structure of data for calculations 
    
      
  Active  
  negative positive  
negative a b a + b 
Placebo positive c d c + d 
  a + c b + d a + b + c + d 
      
    
    
c + d 
The estimate of the false positive rate:  a + b + c + d 
    
    
b - c The estimate of the proportion of 
Truly sensitive subjects:  
a + b 
 
 
The above formula will allow for an estimate of a false positive rate (0.069 in the above 
example) and an estimate of the proportion of truly sensitive individuals (0.037 in the 
above example).   None of the 29 subjects in the above example reacted to the 5 mg 
challenge dose therefore 5 mg would be the no observed adverse effect level (NOAEL).  
 
 
 
 
 3Subject Criteria:  Potential subjects must have: 
 
1. Convincing clinical history of a Type I allergic reaction when fish are 
consumed.  Subjects should be well characterized fish-allergic children and 
adults in generally good health, between the ages of 3 and 70 years.  
Subjects with severe reactions to fish should be included so that this segment 
of the fish-allergic population is not overlooked. 
  
2. Positive skin prick test to one or more  species of fish (since fish contain a 
pan-allergen, parvalbumin, a positive skin test to any aqueous fish extract 
provides the needed demonstration of IgE reactivity to fish) with a commercial 
extract AND
 positive specific IgE to fish that meet the following criteria: 
 
 a).  If the most recent skin prick testing was perfo rmed more than 6  months 
 previously, a new skin prick test must  be done.  Skin prick test diameters 
 need to be reported in millimeters and be as  large, or larger than the positive 
 control histamine skin prick test. 
 b). Specific IgE score to fish (b y any specific IgE measurement approach 
 since IgE to one or more species of fish is assumed to support a diagnosis of 
 fish allergy and a need to avoid all s pecies of fish) must be greater than 0.35 
 kU
A/L and be performed no more than 6 months previously.  The actual 
 specific IgE score in kU A/L must be reported. 
 
  3. Subjects enrolled in this challen ge trial should cease taking all prescribed   
   medications related to their allergie s for suitable withdrawal periods before  
   commencement of the challe nge trial.  In particular, H1 anti-histamines with a  
   short duration of activity should be withheld for a minimum of 48 hours.    
   Hydroxyzine is to be withheld for a minimum of 72 hours, leukotriene receptor 
   antagonists should be withheld for up to 1 week, and second generation anti- 
   histamines (cetirizine) should be withheld for at least 1 week.  In the case of  
   patients with co-existin g or food-induced asthma, short-acting inhaled or oral  
   beta-agonists and inhaled anticholinergics could be continued up to 6 hours  
   before challenge.  Long-term beta-agonists should be stopped 12 hours   
   before challenge.  Chromones (cromo lyn and nedocromil) should be withheld  
   for 48 hours.  Inhaled ster oids or oral corticosteroids would be continued in  
   patients where prescri bed, although patients with serious asthma should not  
   be included in this challenge.  If pati ents are taken off of routine medications,  
   the challenge trials must be conducted in a manner that any reactions arising  
   from the withdrawal of medications can be distinguished from true reactions  
   to the food incorporated into the challenge trial.   
 
  4. Caffeine and alcohol should also be ex cluded for 24 hours prior to challenge.  
   Females of child-bearing age must hav e a negative pregnancy test each day  
   that oral challenges are given. 
 
 4Methods and Procedures: 
 
Skin Prick Test (SPT) 
  
Skin prick testing is done by placing a drop of commercially prepared fish extract (from 
any fish species or mixture of fish species as noted above) on the cleansed forearm or 
back of the individual, and lightly pricking the skin with a sterile needle or lancet.  
Negative and positive skin prick test controls are done in the same fashion with saline 
solution or the solution used to prepare the extract and histamine solution, respectively.  
All of the SPT materials are commercial products and are expressly prepared for 
diagnostic skin testing.  
 
Skin prick tests for fish extracts will be judged and recorded based on the size of the 
wheal (raised welt around prick site) and flare (reddened area around wheal) as 
compared to the positive and negative control skin tests after 15-30 minutes.   A SPT is 
deemed positive by comparison to the negative and positive control skin tests.  A small 
amount of reddening may occur with the negative control and this is taken into account 
when judging the other SPT results.  A positive SPT is characterized usually by the 
wheal at the site of the prick that is sometimes surrounded by the flare or reddening.  
The size of the reaction is individualistic and may range from 2 mm to 15 mm or larger 
wheal diameter, with a flare around the wheal that is hardly visible to one that may have 
a diameter of 50 mm or more.  This wheal and flare response to fish should be at least 
as large as the positive histamine control SPT.  Extremely large wheal and flare 
reactions are uncommon when using commercially prepared skin test reagents, but may 
occur on occasion.  The result is recorded by measuring the diameter of the wheal and 
the diameter of the wheal and flare.  Any unique or distinguishing characteristics should 
be noted (i.e. pseudopodia). 
 
The size of the wheal and flare is not necessarily indicative of the severity of the 
reaction that may be experienced when fish is ingested, or the amount of fish required 
to cause a reaction.    
 
Blood draw (venipuncture) 
 
A sample of blood will be taken from a vein in the arm for RAST testing.  The blood will 
be processed into serum by the clinical investigator as soon as possible so that the 
serum can be submitted for specific testing against fish proteins.  Testing for specific 
IgE to fish requires only a few milliliters of serum. 
 
Oral Challenge Description 
 
Oral challenges will occur in a clinical setting allowing prompt medical treatment if 
necessary during the challenge.  Subjects will be monitored by qualified medical 
personnel.  In the extremely unlikely event that the subject will have a severe reaction 
during skin prick testing or oral challenge, a code cart or special emergency supplies 
including intubation equipment and defibrillator will be available and epinephrine and 
 5other medications will be administered according to the level and severity of reaction.  
Clinical Investigators may deem it necessary for some subject to have an intravenous 
line placed for rapid medical treatment.   Standard biophysical measurements will be 
made before each dose: pulse, blood pressure.  If appropriate, some clinical 
investigators may wish to monitor peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR), but this is not 
required.   Subjective symptoms should be recorded on the FARRP Isinglass Study 
Challenge Data Sheet, but the challenge should continue until objective symptoms are 
observed, unless the subject cannot tolerate the subjective symptoms.  Investigators 
may wish to consider photographs or digital images to document visible reactions (i.e. 
skin reactions). 
 
Subjects will be challenged with four doses of isinglass in a rehydrated, seasoned 
mashed potato preparation.  The doses will be 0.5 mg, 5 mg, 15 mg and 30 mg 
isinglass in 20-40 grams mashed potato given in order of increasing amount.  Four 
portions of mashed potatoes containing no isinglass will be given on a different day and 
act as the placebo portion of the oral challenge.  The doses will be given at 30-minute 
intervals.  Duplicates of each dose and placebo will be provided (all in blinded fashion) 
in the event that a dose needs to be repeated.  Doses should be repeated if there is a 
question about the objectivity of the reaction.  If no objective reaction is observed after 
the duplicate dose, the next dose should be given.  
 
The isinglass challenge material will be a commercially available product supplied by 
The Allied Brewery Trading Association of the U.K which represents most of the 
isinglass manufacturers of the world.  Dehydrated potatoes and isinglass challenge 
material will be pre-weighed into challenge containers in a food grade facility at the 
University of Nebraska-Lincoln by the FARRP Clinical Study Coordinator. 
 
Preparation of the challenge material at the clinical investigation site will require the 
addition of nearly boiling water to the challenge containers, briefly stirring to moisten, 
allowing the mixture to stand for thirty seconds, mixing and then presenting to the 
subject.  Newly purchased Pyrex containers and graduated cylinders will be provided to 
heat and measure the water.  These containers will require cleaning by clinical 
investigator prior to each challenge prepared and used exclusively for this study.  The 
challenge may be served in the same container in which the material is rehydrated. The 
clinical investigator will need a method of heating the water.  A microwave oven works 
well for this as does an electric tea kettle. 
 
Challenge materials will be randomized, blinded and the challenge order randomized 
before shipping to the clinical investigation site. 
 
Benefits  
 
The direct benefit to the subject is to know whether or not isinglass is an allergy risk for 
him or her.  Results from all of the subjects will be used to determine labeling policies 
for isinglass-containing products. 
 6  
Risks 
 
Skin prick testing is considered a relatively safe procedure and is performed daily in 
allergy clinics (14). The risk of anaphylactic shock with skin testing is less that 1% (15-
20). The most common side effect is the development of an itchy spot (like a mosquito 
bite) in the area of skin where a positive reaction occurs.  The itchiness resolves after a 
few minutes and the skin lesion should resolve within an hour or two. 
 
The drawing of blood from subjects is also an everyday procedure but unforeseen risks 
can occur. The most common side effect is a small discoloration or bruise that may 
remain at the site for several days. There may be mild temporary pain occasionally 
associated with insertion of the needle.  In very rare cases, a local infection may occur 
at the site of the venipuncture.  
 
The subject will be informed that there may be some slight pain and discomfort with the 
skin prick test and blood draw.  Nursing and physician staff will be present during skin 
prick testing.  In the extremely unlikely event that the subject has a reaction during skin 
prick testing emergency supplies and medications will be available and be administered 
according to the level and severity of reaction.  
 
The precise risk of anaphylaxis from the food challenge is unknown.  In a recent study 
examining the risks of oral food challenges, 253 oral challenges resulted in reactions 
with foods to which the subject was allergic (21).  Most reactions to all foods in this 
study were classified as mild to moderate with 28% of the reactions categorized as 
severe.  The lowest median dose associated with a severe allergic reaction was 0.6 
grams of milk.  There was a similar risk of severe reactions regardless of the food in the 
challenge.  Overall, all reactions were reversible with short-acting histamine with or 
without epinephrine, β-agonists, and/or corticosteroids.  No subjects required 
hospitalization.  The authors note that there are risks associated with food challenges, 
but these risks are reasonable when challenges are performed under the guidance of 
and experienced practitioner in a properly equipped setting.  Nursing and physician staff 
will be present during the oral food challenge.  In the event that the subject has a 
reaction during the oral food challenge, emergency supplies and medications will be 
available and be administered according to the level and severity of reaction. 
   
Recruiting Procedures 
 
Each clinical investigator will determine the best recruitment procedure for their location.  
Suggested methods include newspaper ads, flyers and posters in the clinic, and 
recruitment databanks may be available at some study centers.  Letters may also be 
sent to known fish-allergic individuals.  The clinical investigator must include examples 
of letters, ads and posters when submitting their proposal to their human subjects use 
committee.  All recruiting techniques must be approved by the clinical investigator’s 
local human subjects use committee. 
 
 7Compensation 
A per subject fee will be negotiated with FARRP before the study starts.  Each site 
should propose a per subject fee that will defray the clinical investigator costs for staff, 
supplies, equipment and facility use, fees for services, human subjects use proposal 
preparation and submission fees, and compensation to the challenge subject.  
Compensation should be provided to each subject to defray any of their costs when 
allowed (i.e. travel, work time lost).  Clinical investigators may want to recompense the 
subject for completing specific parts of the study: for example, a set amount would be 
given for undergoing skin prick tests or blood draw; an additional amount would be 
given for completing the oral challenge. The compensation amount is to be determined 
by and paid by each clinical investigator.  The amount should be included in the per 
subject cost agreement that will be made with FARRP before the study starts.  
Instructions for invoicing FARRP will be included when challenge materials are 
distributed to the clinical investigator.  Payment of invoices will not be made without 
receipt of deliverables by FARRP. 
 
Informed Consent Forms 
Each clinical investigator will be required to produce the appropriate consent forms to 
conform to the criteria and formats required by their local human subjects use 
committee.   
 
Obtaining Informed Consent 
This procedure will vary from site to site so the procedure must be written by each 
clinical investigator. 
 
Maintaining Confidentiality 
Each clinical site has specific rules about maintaining confidentiality.   The “FARRP 
Isinglass Study Food Allergy Questionnaire” and the “FARRP Isinglass Study Challenge 
Data Sheet “will be completed for each subject.  These forms do not contain subject 
names, but subject number and subject initials.  Originals will be sent to FARRP.  At the 
University of Nebraska-Lincoln the “FARRP Isinglass Study Food Allergy Questionnaire” 
and the “Isinglass Study Challenge Data Sheet” will be stored in a locked file.  Only the 
Clinical Study Coordinator and the Co-Directors of FARRP will have access to this 
information.  In publications or reports using information collected from this work, the 
subjects will either be referred to as a collective or be identified by a subject number or 
other appropriate blinded designation. 
 
Copy of Questionnaire and Datasheets   
Copies of the “FARRP Isinglass Study Food Allergy Questionnaire” and the “FARRP 
Isinglass Study Challenge Data Sheet” are included for submittal with clinical 
investigators’ proposal to their institute’s human subjects use committee. 
 
Funding  
This project is being funded by the Food Allergy Research & Resource Program at the 
University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE USA.  If you require a letter indicating this, 
contact Julie A. Nordlee, FARRP Clinical Study Coordinator.   
 8 
Contract 
Each clinical investigator will be asked to sign a contract with FARRP and the University 
of Nebraska which will detail the deliverables to FARRP, the agreed upon per subject 
cost and details regarding the terms and conditions of the agreement between FARRP 
and the clinical investigator and their institution. 
 
Data Safety Monitoring Board (DSMB) 
A two-member board will be established consisting of two allergists with experience in 
double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenges.  Serious adverse events (SAEs) will 
be reported to the FARRP Clinical Study Coordinator by fax, phone and email within 24 
hours.  A standardized form to report these events will be provided to the clinical 
collaborators with the challenge material instructions. The FARRP Clinical Study 
Coordinator will immediately fax or email the SAE report form to the Board.  The Board 
will convene a teleconference within 48 hours to discuss what actions, if any, should be 
taken.  The Board will have 7 days to return its written recommendations and comments 
to the FARRP Clinical Study Coordinator and the Clinical Investigators.   The Board will 
also be charged with examining, discussing and producing a short report of its findings 
for all adverse event data to be supplied to the Board by the FARRP Clinical Study 
Coordinator.  The Board will convene a teleconference or electronic mail 
correspondence every three months until the completion of the study or when 50% of 
the subjects have completed the challenges, which ever occurs first.  The Board will 
have 7 days to return its written recommendations and comments to the FARRP Clinical 
Study Coordinator and the Clinical Investigators. 
 
1. Each member of the Board will be paid a stipend of $150 per meeting.  
 
2. In the event that the death of a subject occurs during the course of the study, 
the FARRP Clinical Study Coordinator will be contacted immediately and all 
procedures at all clinical study sites will cease until further notice.  Other SAEs 
will be evaluated as indicated above and according to the SAE Report form. 
 
Definition of a Serious Adverse Event (SAE) 
A serious adverse event or reaction is defined as any adverse event occurring at any 
dose that suggests a significant hazard, contraindication, side effect or precaution.  This 
includes, but may not be limited to any of the following events: 
 
• Death:  A death occurring during the study must be reported. 
• Life-threatening:  Any adverse therapy ex perience that places the subject, in the 
view of the Investigator, at immediate risk of death from the reaction as it occurred. 
• Hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization. 
• Persistent or significant disability/incapacity. 
• Congenital anomaly/birth defect. 
• Other conditions as specified in the protocol. 
• An event that requires intervention to pr event permanent impairment or damage.  An 
important medical event that may not result in death, be life threatening, or require 
 9hospitalization may be considered an SAE when, based upon appropriate medical 
judgment, it may jeopardize the participant and may require medical or surgical 
intervention to prevent one of the outcomes listed above. 
Definition of an Adverse Event (AE) 
• Any untoward medical occurrence in a subject temporally associated with the 
challenge material, whether or not considered related to the challenge material.   
• An AE can therefore be any  unfavorable or unintended sign or symptom temporally 
associated with the challenge material. 
• These occurrences should be reported on the Challenge Data Sheet. 
 
 
 
 10References 
 
1.   Taylor SL, Kabourek JL, and Hefle SL.  Fish allergy: fish and products thereof.  J  
 Food Sci.  2004; 69:175-180. 
 
2.  [BBPA] British Beer Pub Assn. and [BFBi] The Allied Brewery Trade Assn.  The case 
     of isinglass exemption by the BFBi isinglass committee and BBPA.  European 
     Directive 2000/13/EC, London:BBPA, 2004. 
 
3.  Bernhisel-Broadbent J, Scanlon SM, and Sampson HA.  Fish hypersensitivity.  I.  In 
     vitro and oral challenge results in fish-allergic patients.  J Allergy Clin Immunol 1992; 
     89:730-737. 
 
4.   Hansen TK, Bindslev-Jensen C, Skov PS, and Poulsen LK.  Codfish allergy in 
      adults: IgE cross-reactivity among fish species.  Ann Allergy Asthma Immunol 1997; 
      78:187-194. 
 
5.   Bugajska-Schretter A, Elfman L, Fuchs T, Kapiotis S, Rumpold H, Valenta R,  
      Spitzauer S.  Parvalbumin, a cross-reactive fish allergen, contains IgE-binding 
      epitopes sensitive to periodate treatment and Ca2+ depletion.  J Allergy Clin 
      Immunol 1998; 101:67-74. 
 
6.   Aas K.  Fish allergy and the codfish allergen model.  In:  Brostoff J and Challacombe 
      SJ, editors.  Food Allergy and Intolerance, London:Bailliere Tindall, 1987:356-366. 
 
7.   Shiomi K, Hamada Y, Sekiguchi K, Shimakura K, and Nagashima Y.  Two classes 
      of allergens, parvalbumins and high molecular weight substances, in Japanese eel 
      and bigeye tuna.  Fisheries Sci 1999; 65:948-948. 
 
8.   Van Do T, Hordvik I, Endresen C, and Elsayed S.  Expression and analysis of 
      recombinant salmon parvalbumin, the major allergen in Atlantic salmon (Salmo 
      salar).  Scand J Immunol 50:619-625. 
 
9.   Gerday C, Collin S, and Gerardin Otthiers N. The amino acid sequence of the 
      parvalbumin from the very fast swim bladder muscle of toadfish (Opsanus tau). 
      Comp Biochem Physiol 1989; 93B:49-55. 
 
10.  Hamada Y, Nagashima Y, and Shiomi K.  Identification of collagen as a new fish 
       allergen.  Biosci Biotech Biochem 2001; 65:285-291. 
 
11.  Hansen TK, Poulsen LK, Skov PS, Hefle SL, Hlywka JJ, Taylor SL, Bindslev- 
       Jensen U, Bindslev-Jensen C.  A randomized, double-blin ded, placebo-controlled 
       oral challenge study to evaluate the allergenicity of commercial, food-grade fish 
       gelatin.  F ood Chem Tox 2004;42:2037-44. 
 
 1112. Taylor SL, Hefle SL, Bindslev-Jensen C, Atkins FM, Andre C, Bruijnzeel-Koomen 
 C, Burks AW, Bush RK, Ebisawa M,  Eigenmann PA, Host A, Hourihane JO’B, 
 Isolauri E, Hill DJ, Knulst A, Lack G, Sa mpson HA, Moneret-Vautrin DA, Rance  F,  
 Vadas PA, Yunginger JW, Zeiger RS, Salminen JW, Madsen C, and Abbott P.  A 
 consensus protocol for the det ermination of the threshold doses for allergenic  foods: 
 how much is too much? Clin  Exp Allergy 2004; 34:689-695 
 
13.  Briggs D, Aspinall L, Dickens A, Bindslev-Jensen C. Statistical model for assessing   
       the proportion of subjects with subjective sensitisations in adverse reactions to 
       foods. Allergy 2001;56, Suppl. 67, 83-5.   
 
14. Norman PS, Peebles RS.  In vivo diagnostic allergy testing methods.  In NR Rose, 
      RG Hamilton, B Detrick (ed.), Manual of Clinical Laboratory Immunology,  6th       
 ed.2002, American Society for Microbiology, Washington, DC 
 
15. Reid M, Lockey R, Turkeltaub P, Platts-Mills T. Survey of fatalities from skin testing 
      and immunotherapy 1985-89. J Allergy Clin Immunol 1993:92:6-15. 
 
16.  Turkeltaub PC, Gergen PJ. The risk of adverse reactions from percutaneous prick- 
       puncture allergen skin testing, venipuncture, and body measurements:  data from 
       the Second National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey 1976-80 (NHANES 
       II). J Allergy Clin Immunol 1989:84:886-90. 
 
17.  Lockey RF, Benedict LM, Turkeltaub PC, Bukantz SC. Fatalities from 
      immunotherapy (IT) and skin testing (ST). J Allergy Clin Immunol 1987:79:660-77. 
 
18.  Novembre E, Bernardini R, Bertini G, Massai G, Vierucci A. Case report. 
      Skin-prick-test-induced anaphylaxis. Allergy 1995:50:511-3. 
 
19.  Bonnekoh B, Merk HF. Safety of latex prick skin testing in allergic patients 
       (Letter). JAMA 1992:267:2603-4. 
 
20.  Vanin E., et al. Case Report: Anaphylactic reaction after skin-prick testing in an 8- 
       year-old boy.  Ped Allergy Immunol 2002:13:227-8. 
 
21.  Perry TT, Matsui EC, Conover-Walker MK, Wood RA.  Risk of oral food challenges. 
      J Allergy Clin Immunol 2004;14:1164-8. 
 
 12

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Food Allergy Research and Resource Program (FARRP) 
Determination of Skin Reactivity to Unique Fish Species 
 
1.  DESCRIBE THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE PROJECT 
 
Objective:  By means of routine methods used by clinicians in allergy practice, 
determine the potential allergenicity of unique fish species by performing skin prick tests 
in fish allergic individuals. 
 
Background:  Though not specifically confirmed by clinical studies, fish allergic 
individuals are believed to be potentially reactive to all species of fish (1).  Hundreds of 
fish species exist worldwide that are used for human consumption or to make food 
ingredients including fermented fish sauces, isinglass, fish gelatin, fish oil, and collagen. 
Specifically, this research project is part of a larger effort aimed at assessing the 
potential allergenicity of isinglass.  Isinglass is a fish-derived ingredient used in the 
clarification of beers, wine, ales, and champagnes (1).  Isinglass is obtained from the 
swim bladders of certain species of fish, usually large tropical fish, including croaker, 
threadfin, corvina, and others (1).  Isinglass is composed primarily of collagen (2).  
Edible fish muscle contains an allergenic protein called parvalbumin, a calcium-binding 
protein involved in muscle contraction (3).  Parvalbumin is thought to exist in the muscle 
tissues of all fish species and has specifically been found in a large number of fish 
species including cod, salmon, carp, mackerel, tuna, and others (3-8).  Parvalbumin is 
theorized to be the pan-allergen that is responsible for fish allergies and its ubiquity in 
fish muscle is the reason why fish-allergic individuals are believed to react to all fish 
species.  Moreover, parvalbumin is known to exist in the swim bladders of at least one 
fish species [toadfish] (9).  However, the presence of parvalbumin in the unique fish 
species used to make isinglass or in the swim bladders from these fish has not been 
established.  The commercial process for making isinglass likely results in the removal 
of some of the water-soluble parvalbumin.  Skin testing with extracts prepared from the 
flesh and swim bladders of these unique fish will provide additional information to 
support or refute the premise that fish allergic individuals could be potentially reactive to 
all species of fish.  Skin testing would be useful in ascertaining whether parvalbumin is 
present in the swim bladders of these unique species.  
 
Overview:  Fifteen fish allergic individuals will be selected.  The subject selection will be 
based on a history of allergy to fish species commonly consumed such as cod, salmon 
and tuna, etc. and positive skin prick tests to commercial skin test extracts prepared 
from these same types of fish.  The selected subjects will be skin prick tested with 
materials prepared from the flesh and swim bladders of the unique species of fish used 
to make isinglass, that are not commonly ingested in the United States or European 
Union.   
 
Clinical collaborators will be required to submit protocols and receive approval for the 
use of human subjects at their specific institutions.   Copies of these approvals must be 
provided to FARRP before skin-test materials will be provided.  These approvals will be 
provided to the University of Nebraska-Lincoln IRB when received. 
 12.  METHODS AND PROCEDURES 
 
Procedure Overview:  Qualified subjects will be skin prick tested with 12 extracts 
derived from different unique species of fish flesh and swim bladders as well as a 
positive control solution (1% histamine), and negative control solution [extraction buffer 
containing sodium chloride and phosphates at or near neutral pH (7.0-7.5)].  Time 
required for the subject will be 1.5-3 hours.   
 
Clinical collaborators will be required to submit protocols to the ethics or human 
subjects use committee and receive approval for the use of human subjects at his or her 
specific institutions.  The following clinicians have expressed an interest in participating 
as our collaborators: 
 
Dr. Carsten Bindslev-Jensen 
Odense University Hospital 
Odense, DENMARK 
FWA00004088 
 
Dr. Richard Pumphrey 
Manchester Royal Infirmary 
Manchester, UNITED KINGDOM 
FWA00006996 
   
 
Specific Methods and Procedures: 
 
Skin prick testing and blood draws are needed to qualify subjects for the study. 
 
Skin Prick Test (SPTs) 
  
Skin prick testing is done by placing a drop of fish extract or control extracts on the 
cleansed volar surface of the forearm or the back of the individual, and lightly pricking 
the skin with a sterile needle or lancet.  Negative and positive skin prick test controls are 
done in the same fashion with saline solution or the solution used to prepare the extract 
and histamine solution (1%), respectively.  Skin prick test materials used to qualify 
subjects for this study should be commercial products and are expressly prepared for 
diagnostic skin testing.  The commercial extract will be used in accordance with the 
manufacturer’s instructions.   Other skin test materials will be provided and prepared in 
the laboratory by the procedures described below. 
 
Skin prick tests for fish extracts will be judged and recorded based on the size of the 
wheal (raised welt around prick site) and flare (reddened area around wheal) as 
compared to the positive and negative control skin prick tests after 15 minutes and re-
inspected at 30 minutes.   The diameters of wheal and flare reactions will be measured 
in millimeters and recorded for each time point.  A SPT is deemed positive by 
comparison to the negative and positive control skin prick tests.  A small amount of 
 2reddening may occur with the negative control and this is taken into account when 
judging the other SPT results.  A positive SPT is characterized usually by the wheal at 
the site of the prick that is sometimes surrounded by the flare or reddening (14).  The 
size of the reaction is individualistic and may range from 2 mm to 14 mm or larger wheal 
diameter (14), with a flare around the wheal that may range from hardly visible to one 
that may have a diameter of 50 mm or more.  The wheal and flare response to fish 
extracts should be at least as large as the positive histamine control SPT to be 
considered positive.  Any unique or distinguishing characteristics should be noted (i.e. 
pseudopodia). 
 
Blood draw (venipuncture) 
 
A sample of blood will be taken from a vein in the arm.  The blood will be processed into 
serum by the clinical investigator as soon as possible so that the serum can be 
submitted for specific testing against fish proteins.  Testing for specific IgE to fish 
requires only a few milliliters of serum. 
  
Preparation of Non-Commercial Skin Prick Test Materials 
 
Fish extracts of the flesh and swim bladders of six selected unique fish species (see 
following table) will be prepared by PodiCeps BV, Houten The Netherlands.  Extracts 
will be prepared using the most optimal extraction buffer.  At least 100 ml of extract will 
be prepared for each species by the following steps.  Sterility checks of the extracts will 
be performed at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Department of Food Science and 
Technology Microbiological Services Laboratory.  Histamine analysis will be performed 
using Neogen Corporation Veratox® Quantitative Histamine Test in the laboratory of Dr. 
Sue Hefle, Food Allergy Research and Resource Program, Department of Food 
Science and Technology, University of Nebraska-Lincoln. 
 
1.  Crude extracts of each unique species of fish flesh and swim bladders will be   
  prepared using extraction buffer containi ng sodium chloride and phosphates at or 
  near neutral pH (7.0-7.5).  One part fi nely chopped or ground fish flesh or swim  
  bladder will be mixed with 10 parts extrac tion buffer and mixed overnight at 4-  
  6°C.  Before the extraction procedur e the swim bladders will be milled to a   
  nominal size of 4 cm and washed in a 2% hydrogen peroxide solution for 30   
  minutes before rinsing and drying. 
2. The crude extract will be clar ified by centrifugation. 
3.  The supernatant material resulting from  the centrifugation will be sterilized by   
  filtration using 0.22 µm  sterile  memb ranes in a laminar flow chamber and    
  packaged aseptically in the chamber. 
4.  The protein content of  the sterilized extract will be determined using the Bradford  
  method (15).  If necessary the extracts  will be diluted using sterile extraction   
  buffer in a laminar flow chamber to a pr otein content within the range reported in  
  commercially available skin pr ick test extracts for fish. 
5.  The resulting material will be aseptically distributed into sterile vials and stored at 
  -80°C until distributed to the clinical test  sites.  One vial of each extract will be  
 3  prepared for each subject.  The materi als will be distributed frozen and     
  subsequently held frozen.  Once thaw ed for use, the material will be     
  used for only one subject on one day and then discarded.   
6.  Histamine content will be determined using immunoassay methods (Neogen   
  Corp, Lansing, MI).  To assure that the unique fish starting materials have not  
  been subjected to spoilage conditions the level of histamine in the non-    
  commercial fish skin prick test extracts must be less than 0.005% (16).  If the   
  level of histamine is greater than or equal to 0.005% new materials will be    
  obtained and the extractions remade. 
7.  Information/fact sheets of each unique fi sh flesh and swim bladder extract will be  
  prepared and shipped to the clinical co llaborators together with the extracts.   
  Facts sheets will contain information on: pr otein content, salt content, pH and   
  histamine content. 
 
Unique Fish Species to be Used for Fish Flesh and Swim Bladder Extracts 
 
NAME COMMON NAME ORIGIN SCIENTIFIC NAME 
Pakistan Singala Spotted Catfish Pakistan Arius maculates 
Indian Singala Blacktip Sea Catfish India Arius dussumieri 
African Purse African Sea Catfish Mauritania/The Gambia Arius africanus 
East African Semutundu  Bagrid Catfish Uganda, Lake Albert 
etc. 
Bagrus docmak 
South American Corvina Corvina del Lago Venezuela/Costa Rica Cynoscions 
acoupa 
South American Purse Bagre Blanco (White 
Catfish) 
Venezuela/Costa Rica Pseudopimelodus sp. 
 
3. SUBJECT CRITERIA 
 
Fifteen fish-allergic subjects will be challenged.  Potential subjects must have: 
 
1. Convincing clinical history of a Type I allergic reaction when fish are 
consumed.  Subjects should be well characterized fish-allergic children and 
adults in generally good health.  Potential subjects must be at least three 
years old and not older than 70 years.   
  
2. Positive skin prick test to one or more  species of fish (since fish contain a 
pan-allergen, parvalbumin, a positive skin test to any aqueous fish extract 
provides the needed demonstration of IgE reactivity to fish) with a commercial 
fish extract AND
 positive specific IgE to fish that meet the following criteria: 
 
 a).  If the most recent skin prick testing was perfo rmed more than 6  months 
 previously, a new skin prick test must  be done.  Skin prick test diameters 
 need to be reported in millimeters and be, as large or larger than the positive
 control histamine skin prick test. 
 b). Specific IgE score to fish (b y any specific IgE measurement approach 
 since IgE to one or more species of fish is assumed to support a diagnosis of 
 fish allergy and a need to avoid all s pecies of fish) must be greater than 0.35 
 4 kU A/L and be performed no more than 6 months previously.  The actual 
 specific IgE score in kU A/L and the method used must be reported. 
 
  3. Certain medications may interfere with the development and interpretation of  
   the skin test wheal and flare responses elicited by allergen extracts and   
   histamine positive control. Conv entional antihistamines should be     
   discontinued at least 3 days before skin testing. Long acting antihistamines  
   should be discontinued for at least 7 da ys prior to skin testing.  Topical    
   steroids should be discontinued at the skin test site for at least 2-3     
   weeks before skin testing (10,11).  Tr icyclic antidepressants such as Doxepin  
   should be withheld for at least 7 days before skin testing (12) Topical local  
   anesthetics may suppress the flare responses and should be avoided at skin  
   test sites (13). 
 
 
Statistical Design 
The working hypothesis for this project is that the unique fish species used in the 
production of isinglass will be allergenic as documented by positive skin prick tests in 
individuals with well documented allergies to more frequently consumed fish.  If this 
hypothesis is true, then all of the patients will display positive skin prick tests to the 
extracts of the various species of fish used in this study.  Since the subjects selected for 
this study will have allergies to fish and these fish are known to contain parvalbumin as 
their major allergen, this finding will also provide proof that these unique fish species 
contain parvalbumin that is cross-reactive with parvalbumin from the more commonly 
ingested species.  If one or more of the unique fish species in this study contain no 
parvalbumin or low levels of parvalbumin, then some or all subjects may have negative 
skin prick test reactions to those extracts.  Similar determinations will be made for the 
swim bladder extracts from the unique fish species except that it is much less certain 
that the swim bladders will contain sufficient allergen to provoke a positive skin prick 
test reaction.  Statistically, we expect significantly higher numbers of positive skin prick 
test reactions in the subjects to the various unique fish extracts than to the negative 
control skin prick tests.   
 
4.  BENEFITS AND RISKS  
 
Benefits  
 
The direct benefit to the subject is to know whether or not there is a potential for him or 
her to be allergic to these unique species of fish if ingested.  Results from all of the 
subjects will be used to determine if the swim bladders contain parvalbumin and thus 
whether isinglass used in processing of alcoholic beverages (beer, champagne, ale and 
wine) might be a risk for fish allergic individuals. 
 5  
 
 
Risks 
 
Skin prick testing is considered a relatively safe procedure and is performed daily in 
allergy clinics (14). The risk of anaphylactic shock with skin testing is less that 1% (17-
22. The most common side effect is the development of an itchy spot (like a mosquito 
bite) in the area of skin where a positive reaction occurs.  The itchiness resolves after a 
few minutes and the skin lesion should resolve within an hour or two. 
 
The drawing of blood from subjects is also an everyday procedure but unforeseen risks 
can occur. The most common side effect is a small discoloration or bruise that may 
remain at the site for several days. There may be mild temporary pain occasionally 
associated with insertion of the needle.  In very rare cases, a local infection may occur 
at the site of the venipuncture.   
 
The subject will be informed that there may be some slight pain and discomfort with the 
skin prick test and blood draw.  Nursing and physician staff will be present during skin 
prick testing.  In the extremely unlikely event that the subject has a reaction during skin 
prick testing emergency supplies and medications will be available and be administered 
according to the level and severity of reaction.  
 
5.  RECRUITING PROCEDURES 
 
Each clinical investigator will determine the best recruitment procedure for his or her 
location.  Suggested methods include newspaper ads, flyers and posters in the clinic, 
and recruitment databanks may be available at some study centers.  Letters may also 
be sent to known fish-allergic individuals.  The clinical investigator must include 
examples of letters, ads and posters when submitting their proposal to their human 
subjects use committee.  All recruiting techniques must be approved by the clinical 
investigator’s local human subjects use committee. 
 
6.  COMPENSATION 
 
A per subject fee will be negotiated with FARRP before the study starts.  Each site 
should propose a per subject fee that will defray the clinical investigator costs for staff, 
supplies, equipment and facility use, fees for services, human subjects use proposal 
preparation and submission fees, and compensation to the challenge subject.  
Compensation should be provided to each subject to defray any of their costs when 
allowed (i.e. travel, work time lost).  The compensation amount is to be determined by 
and paid by each clinical investigator.  The amount should be included in the per subject 
cost agreement that will be made with FARRP before the study starts.  Instructions for 
invoicing FARRP will be included when challenge materials are distributed to the clinical 
investigator.  Payment of invoices will not be made without receipt of deliverables by 
FARRP. 
 6 
7.  INFORMED CONSENT FORMS 
 
Each clinical investigator will be required to produce the appropriate consent forms to 
conform to the criteria and formats required by their local human subjects use 
committee.   
 
Obtaining Informed Consent 
This procedure will vary from site to site so the procedure must be written by each 
clinical investigator.   
 
8.  MAINTAINING CONFIDENTIALITY 
 
Each clinical site has specific rules about maintaining confidentiality.   The “FARRP Skin 
Reactivity to Fish Study-Food Allergy Questionnaire” and the “FARRP Skin Reactivity to 
Fish Study Data Sheet“ will be completed for each subject.  These forms do not contain 
subject names, but subject number and subject initials.  Originals will be sent to 
FARRP.  At the University of Nebraska-Lincoln the questionnaire and the data sheet will 
be stored in a locked file in the Clinical Study Coordinators office.  Only the Clinical 
Study Coordinator and the Co-Directors of FARRP will have access to this information.  
In publications or reports using information collected from this work, the subjects will 
either be referred to as a collective or be identified by a subject number or other 
appropriate blinded designation.  Materials will be kept for 5 years after the completion 
of the study.  
 
9.  COPY OF QUESTIONNAIRE AND DATASHEETS   
 
Copies of the ““FARRP Skin Reactivity to Fish Study-Food Allergy Questionnaire” and 
the “FARRP Skin Reactivity to Fish Study Data Sheet” are included for submittal with 
clinical investigators’ proposal to their institute’s human subjects use committee. 
 
Funding  
This project is being funded by the Food Allergy Research & Resource Program of the 
University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE USA.  If you require a letter indicating this, 
contact Julie A. Nordlee, FARRP Clinical Study Coordinator.   
 
Contract 
Each clinical investigator will be asked to sign a contract with FARRP and the University 
of Nebraska which will detail the deliverables to FARRP, the agreed upon per subject 
cost and details regarding the terms and conditions of the agreement between FARRP 
and the clinical investigator and their institution. 
 
REFERENCES 
 
1. Taylor SL, Kabourek JL, and Hefle SL.  Fi sh allergy: fish and products thereof.  J  
 Food Sci.  2004; 69:175-180. 
 7 
2.  Leather RV.  Analysis of the collagen and total soluble nitrogen content of isinglass 
 finings by polarimetry.  J Inst Brew 1994;100:331-34. 
 
3.  Aas K.  Fish allergy and the codfish allergen model.  In:  Brostoff J,  Challacombe 
 SJ, editors. 1987; Food Allergy and Intolerance.  London:  Bailliere Tindall. p 356-
 66. 
 
4.  Bugajska-Schretter A, Grote M, Vangelista L, Valent P, Sperr WR, Rumpold H,

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.

Investigation of the Potential Allergenicity of Isinglass

             Digestion

         Isinglass Committee

Study Directors: Steve L. Taylor, Ph.D.   
Sue L. Hefle, Ph.D. 
 
 
Study Start Date: January 01, 2005 
 
Study Completion Date: July 15, 2006 
 
Records Retention: All study specific raw data and a copy of the final report will be 
retained at the Food Allergy Research and Resource Program, 
University of Nebraska. 
 
Signatures of Final Report Approval:

I.  Pepsin Digesti on of Fish Gelatin........................................................................................... ........................ 5  
 A. Introduction............................................................................................................... ...................... 5  
 B. Materials and Methods...................................................................................................... .............. 5  
 C. Re sults.................................................................................................................... ......................... 7  
 D. Conclusion ................................................................................................................. ..................... 8

 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-06-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 4 of 14 
  
Figures 
  Page 
 
Figure 1.1. Protein profiles of samples before digestion ........................................................................ 9 
Figure 1.2. Time course of the pepsin digestion of isinglass at pH 1.2................................................ 10  
Figure 1.3. Time course of the pepsin digestion of isinglass at pH 2................................................... 11  
Figure 1.4. Pepsin auto-digestion samples .............................................................................12  
Figure 1.5. Time course of the pepsin digestion of crude peanut extract ......................................13  
  
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-06-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 5 of 14 
  
I.  Pepsin Digestion of Isinglass 
 
Lead Scientists:   Stef J. Koppelman, Ph.D., AllerTeQ, Netherlands 
 Sue L. Hefle, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
 Steve L. Taylor, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
 
A. Introduction: 
 
Isinglass is prepared from the swim bladders of various species of tropical fish.  Collagen is the 
primary component of isinglass.  Molecular weights of well over 200 kD are described for 
collagen preparations.  In the allergenicity assessment of novel proteins, pepsin digestion is one 
of the criteria used to evaluate their potential allergenicity (Taylor and Hefle, 2002).  Although 
isinglass is not a novel protein in human diets, its comparative resistance to pepsin digestion 
should be a useful measure of its potential allergenicity.  If rapidly hydrolyzed by pepsin, less 
likelihood exists that isinglass would sensitize susceptible individuals.  Sensitization to isinglass 
has not been reported, despite its widespread use as a clarifying agent for beers, ales, and wines 
for many years.    This report describes the digestive stability of isinglass samples to pepsin in an 
identical approach used for assessing the digestibility of several allergens and proteins 
considered to be non-allergenic (Thomas et al., 2004). 
 
B.  Materials and Methods: 
 
Test sample
 
Isinglass (lot number 1839) was provided obtained from A. B. Vickers, Burton-upon-Trent, U.K. 
by FARPP.  The isinglass sample (received in dry state) was dissolved in distilled water at a 
concentration of 5 mg/ml.  The isinglass solution remained slightly turbid.  Pre-incubation at 
lower pH (pH = 2) partially overcame this turbidity, but in order to make a fair comparison with 
other food proteins tested for digestibility, pre-incubation at low pH was not done.  Crude peanut 
extract (CPE) was prepared from ground peanut (Runner variety) as described previously 
(Koppelman et al., 2001).  
 
Pepsin
 
 
Pepsin was obtained from Sigma (St. Louis, MO, USA), catalogue number P-6887.  This product 
was chosen because it has the highest specific activity commercially available (3300 U/mg for 
the particular batch), and because other researchers investigating the digestibility behavior of 
potentially allergenic proteins used this product as well (Thomas et al, 2004).  Pepsin was stored 
as a lyophilized powder, as supplied by the manufacturer, at – 20 C.  The ratio of 10 U of pepsin 
per ug of test protein was used throughout the study, according to Thomas et al. (2004).  Pepsin 
was dissolved immediately before the digestion experiment and used within 15 minutes in order 
prevent possible loss of activity due to auto-digestion. 
 
Digestion assay conditions
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-06-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 6 of 14 
  
 
Tubes containing 1.52 ml of simulated gastric fluid (SGS) were prepared.  SGF was used at pH 
1.2 (0.063 N HCl, containing 35 mM NaCl and 4000 U pepsin) and pH 2.0 (0.01 N HCl, 
containing 35 mM NaCl and 4000 U pepsin).  In a control experiment the potential effect of 
adding protein (pepsin, test proteins) on the final pH was tested, and found to be negligible (less 
than 0.05 pH points).   SGF was pre-warmed to 37 C for 5 minutes and 80 ul of 5 mg/ml 
isinglass was added at time point t = 0. For CPE, due to a lower solubility, SGF was prepared at 
a higher concentration such that the addition of 400 ul of 1 mg/ml CPE resulted in the same final 
concentration of HCl, NaCl, pepsin, and isinglass.  Samples of 200 ul were collected at time 
points: 0.5 min, 2 min, 5 min, 10, min, 20 min, 30 min and 60 min.  Samples were immediately 
stopped by mixing with 70 ul of 200 mM NaHCO
3 (pH = 11.0) and 70 ul of 5 times concentrated 
Laemmli electrophoresis buffer (Laemmli et al, 1970) containing 40% glycerol, 20% SDS, 5% 
b-mercaptoethanol, 0.33 M TRIS (pH 6.8) and 0.05% bromophenol blue.  The samples of 0.5 
min, 1 min, 2 min and 5 min were heated for 5 minutes at > 75 C directly after taking the sample 
of time point 5 min.  Samples of other time points were heated immediately after sampling.  All 
samples were stored at – 20 C until analysis by SDS-PAGE.  
 
The sample of time point t = 0 min was prepared by stopping and heating SGF prior to the 
addition of test protein.  After adding the isinglass, the samples were heated again to ensure full 
denaturation.  Pepsin auto-digestion was tested by adding 80 ul of water to SGF and incubation 
of 60 minutes as described for test proteins.  Protein stability at low pH was tested by preparing 
SGF without pepsin, and incubating the test protein for 60 minutes. 
 
Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate-Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE)
 
 
SDS-PAGE was performed generally according to Laemmli (Laemmli, et al. 1970) with the 
MiniProtean system (BioRad, Richmond, CA, USA) using 10-20% precast gels or with manually 
prepared 15% homogenous gels.  The molecular weight markers were from Invitrogen 
(Carlsbad, CA. USA, Mark12 catalogue number LC5677, ranging from 2.5 to 200 kD) and were 
used according to the manufacturer’s instructions. 20 ul per sample was loaded and 
electrophoresis was stopped just before the bromophenol blue-containing front reached the end 
of the gel.  
 
Two methods for gel staining were used. First, the novel Page-Blue method from Fermentas was 
used (Hanover, MD).  This method is said to be more sensitive compared to classical Coomassie 
staining method.  Gels were destained overnight. For the analyses of the peanut protein digestion 
(performed earlier), the classical method was used: gels were stained in 1% Coomassie Brilliant 
Blue R-250 (Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) in 50% methanol/20% acetic acid over night. 
Subsequently, gels were washed with 50% methanol/20% acetic acid for 5 minutes and destained 
with 50% methanol/20% acetic acid for 30 minutes.  After that, gels were further destained with 
25% methanol/10% acetic acid for 2 hours.  
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-06-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 7 of 14 
  
All gels were scanned with a regular laboratory scanner, and scans were not optimized in any 
way in order to allow an objective comparison. 
 
C. Results: 
 
Characterization of isinglass 
 
Undigested isinglass showed bands in the molecular weight range of 100-200 kD, but also three 
more distinct bands at approximately 25 kD, 45 kD, and 100 kD, and one vague band between 6 
and 14 kD (Figure 1).    
 
Digestibility of isinglass at pH 1.2
 
Upon incubation with pepsin at pH = 1.2, isinglass is digested rapidly.  The high molecular 
weight protein fraction was only visible at time points t = 0, 0.5 and 2 minutes. (Figure 2).  At 
time point 0.5 minutes, a distinct band at approximately 100 kD remains visible.  After 2 
minutes, no high molecular weight protein is observed.  At time points 0.5, 2, and 5 minutes, 
some intermediate molecular weight protein/peptide smear (range: 30 to 60 kD) is observed, but 
only vaguely.  This protein/peptide digestion product is completely further digested at later time 
points.  
 
Digestibility of isinglass at pH 2
 
Upon incubation with pepsin at a somewhat higher pH of 2, isinglass is digested rapidly, but 
some proteins/peptides remained for a longer time as compared to digestion at pH 1.2.  At time 
points 0.5 and 2 minutes, a distinct band at approximately 100 kD remains visible (Figure 3).  
This band disappeared after 5 minutes, somewhat later compared to the incubation at pH = 1.2.  
In the time span from 0.5 to 30 minutes, some intermediate weight protein/peptides were visible, 
and these disappeared after 30 minutes.  
 
 
Isinglass at both pH 1.2 and 2.0 appears to be labile in the absence of pepsin (Figure 2, 3). 
Pepsin auto-digestion experiments at pH = 2.0 and pH = 1.2 show that the pepsin band in SDS-
PAGE analysis is unaffected during the time course of the experiment (Figure 4), demonstrating 
that observed bands in the intermediate and low molecular weight areas after incubation with 
pepsin do not originate from pepsin. 
 
Digestibility of crude peanut extract - reference
 
Crude peanut extract (CPE) (Figure 5) is characterized by a typical band pattern showing Ara h 1 
(at approximately 63 kD as an intense, uniform band), Ara h 2 (a doublet at approximately 20 
kD), Ara h 3 (a triplet at 42-45 kD, and bands at 25 kD, and 14 kD), and Ara h 6 (a single, less 
intense band at approximately 15 kD), shown in Figure 5, left lane, arrows indicate the identified 
allergens).  Incubation with pepsin at both  pH  = 2.0 and pH = 1.2 shows that the majority of 
Ara h 1 disappears within 0.5 min, as well as the 42-45 kD bands of Ara h 3 (note that the 
remaining thick band at this height is pepsin).  In contrast, Ara h 2, in particular the heavy 
isoform remains stable for the time course of the experiment.  Ara h 6 also shows a high stability 
during the experiment, probably even more stable than Ara h 2.  Other bands in CPE are difficult Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-06-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 8 of 14 
  
to assign, especially during the time course of the digestion experiment where a series of 
peptides are generated as a results of degradation of the higher molecular weight proteins (Ara h 
1 mainly).  
 
D. Conclusions: 
 
Isinglass was analyzed for digestibility by pepsin, in a similar approach as used for assessing the 
digestibility of several allergens and also proteins considered to be non-allergenic (Thomas et al., 
2004).  Digestibility of peanut allergens was used as a reference. Compared to certain peanut 
allergens, isinglass is digested quickly.   
  
Limitations/speculation 
 
The nature of the intermediate bands is not known.  They may represent isinglass-derived 
peptides, or other fish proteins. The vague band between 6 and 14 kD may possibly represent 
parvalbumin, with a molecular weight of 12.3 kD, but from this investigation, there are no 
experimental data to support this.  However, all of the protein bands in isinglass are quickly 
digested by pepsin. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-06-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 9 of 14 
  
 
Figures:   
 
 
Figure 1.1. Protein profiles of samples before digestion 
FG2: a 2 mg/ml fish gelatin solution was loaded on gel  
FG4: a 4 mg/ml fish gelatin solution was loaded on gel  
I2: a 2 mg/ml isinglass solution was loaded on gel 
I4: a 4 mg/ml isinglass solution was loaded on gel  
M: molecular marker proteins (indicated at the right margin)

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.

In general, the various samples react limitedly. Dilutions were not parallel with dilutions 
of cod parvalbumin, and true quantification therefore is not possible. The non-parallelism 
is illustrated by the high SD’s (same order of magnitude as response), and by the 
increasing calculated value for higher diluted extracts (data not shown here). The non-
parallelism may be caused by differences in affinity of cod parvalbumin and parvalbumin 
of other fishes. Differences between the various samples are clearly visible. These may be 
explained by differences in parvalbumin content, but due to the issues mentioned above, 
this is not conclusive.PodiCeps BV

Figure 1.3. Two dimensional electrophoresis maps of carp, catfish, cod, and tilapia

Figure 1.7. Inhibition curves generated by anti-carp, catfish, cod, tilapia, tuna fish protein

  as determined by immunoblotting........................................................................................ 9
