  parvalbumin Mab ELISA ................................................................................................... 18 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 5 of 21 
  
      I.  Evaluation of Commercial Anti-Frog and Anti-Carp Parvalbumin Monoclonal 
Antibodies for Use in ELISA for Detection of Parvalbumin in Isinglass  
 
Lead Scientists:   Lingyun Chen, Ph.D., University of Nebraska 
 Richard E. Goodman, Ph.D., University of Nebraska 
  
A. Introduction: 
 
Commercial monoclonal antibodies directed against frog and carp parvalbumin are available.  A 
commercial monoclonal antibody directed against frog parvalbumin has been used in one study 
as a screening tool in selecting a cDNA library for mackerel parvalbumin, and also was 
successfully used in the development of a mackerel parvalbumin ELISA (Hamada et al., 2003). 
Frog parvalbumin shares 43-88% sequence homology with parvalbumins from fish species 
(according to a search of a database of sequences of known allergens; www.allergenonline.com).  
Carp parvalbumin has a rather high degree of sequence homology with cod parvalbumin so the 
use of the anti-carp parvalbumin antibody might be even more promising for the detection of 
potentially allergenic fish parvalbumin.  Thus, an evaluation of the commercial anti-frog and 
anti-carp parvalbumin monoclonal antibodies was conducted for applicability/efficacy in 
designing an ELISA for the detection of residual parvalbumin in isinglass.  Simultaneously (and 
as described in FARRP-08-2006), polyclonal antisera were produced against purified codfish 
parvalbumin and used in the development of an ELISA for detection of residual parvalbumin in 
isinglass.  
 
Isinglass is a commonly used ingredient for the clarification of beers and ales.  Isinglass is 
prepared from the swim bladders of various species of tropical fish.  Collagen is the primary 
component of isinglass.  Molecular weights of well over 200 kD are described for collagen 
preparations.  Fish collagen is not a major fish allergen but parvalbumin is widely considered as 
the major pan-allergen from fish (Taylor et al., 2004).  Although swim bladders are composed 
primarily of collagen, swim bladders are also likely to contain parvalbumin (Gerday et al., 
1989).  However, the presence of parvalbumin in fish swim bladders has not been thoroughly 
investigated and certainly not from the species of fish used to produce isinglass.  Sensitization to 
isinglass has not been reported nor have allergic reactions been reported in fish-sensitized 
individuals, despite its widespread use as a clarifying agent for beers, ales, and wines.  This 
observation suggests that fish collagen is an unlikely allergen and that isinglass contains 
insufficient parvalbumin to elicit reactions in fish-allergic individuals. 
   
The anti-frog parvalbumin antibody was recently shown to detect parvalbumin found in the 
edible muscle tissues of cod, carp, catfish, and tilapia but not tuna (Chen et al., 2006).  The 
results demonstrating the ability of the anti-frog parvalbumin monoclonal antibody to detect fish 
parvalbumins will be shared herein because sufficient cross-reactivity may exist to allow 
detection of parvalbumin residues in commercial isinglass.  The anti-frog and anti-carp 
parvalbumin antibodies were evaluated for their ability to detect parvalbumin from various fish 
species in both ELISA and western blotting formats.   Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 6 of 21 
  
 
 B.  Materials: 
 
1. Antibodies: 
• Anti-frog parvalbumin Mab (PARV-19):  obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Co, St. Louis, 
MO.  
• Anti-carp parvalbumin Mab (Swant 235):  obtained from Swant (Bellinzona, 
Switzerland). 
• Monoclonal anti-mouse IgG1 as negative control: obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. 
• Anti-mouse IgG -alkaline phosphatase conjugate: obtained from Pierce 
Biotechnolgoy, Inc. Rockford, IL 
2. Frozen carp, catfish, cod, tuna and tilapia fillet were purchased from local market in Lincoln, 
NE and isinglass samples were provided by A. B. Vickers of the U.K. All fish and isinglass 
samples were stored at -20 °C prior to extraction.   
3. Recombinant carp parvalbumin (rCyp C1.01) was provided by Dr. Ines Swoboda, Medical 
University of Vienna, Austria.  
 
 C.  Methods: 
 
Protein extraction from fish tissue and isinglass 
 
Five grams of each fish sample were extracted with 50 mL of phosphate buffered saline (PBS, 
0.01M, pH 7.4), with 1% (v/v) Triton X-100 and 1 tablet of Complete® EDTA-free protease 
inhibitor cocktail (Roche Applied Science, Indianapolis, IN).  Samples were blended in 50 mL of 
extraction buffer for 1 min using a Waring blender.  The mixture was then centrifuged at 3000 x 
g for 30 min at 4°C. The supernatant solution was collected and stored at -20 °C until analysis.  
Isinglass samples were extracted by PBS at a ratio of 1:20 (w/v) with continuous shaking 
overnight at 4 °C.  The mixture was centrifuged at 3000 x g for 30 min at 4°C and the 
supernatant was used as protein extract. 
 
Protein assay
 
The protein concentration of each extract was determined using a Lowry protein assay (Bio-Rad 
Laboratories, Hercules, CA) according to the manufacturer’s instructions using bovine serum 
albumin (BSA) as a standard. 
 
SDS polyacrylamide gel elctrophoresis (SDS-PAGE)
 
Fish extracts were mixed with an equal volume of Laemmli sample buffer (Bio-Rad), containing 
2- mercaptoethanol as a reducing agent, and heated at 95 °C for five min. Ten µL of each fish 
extract (containing 10 µg protein) was loaded onto a Novex® tris-glycine 10-20% ready gel 
(Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA).  Five µL Precision Plus ProteinTM standards (Bio-Rad) were also 
used. Electrophoresis was carried out in a SureLockTM Mini-Cell system (Invitrogen).  
Following electrophoresis, proteins were transferred to Invitrolon PVDF membranes using an 
Xcell II™ Blot Module (Invitrogen) for immunoblotting.  Transfer of proteins from the gel to 
each of the PVDF membranes was verified by staining the membranes with Ponceau S stain Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 7 of 21 
  
(Sigma-Aldrich).  Additional gels were stained with Brilliant Blue G colloidal concentrate 
(Sigma-Aldrich) following the manufacturer’s instructions.  Images of freshly destained gels 
were captured and analyzed using a Kodak GL440 image station and 1D image analysis software 
(Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, NY).  
 
2D electrophoresis
  
Isoelectric focusing was performed on 7 cm nonlinear pH 3-10 Zoom® strips in a Zoom® 
IPGRunner™ system (Invitrogen).  The strips were rehydrated for 1 hr at room temperature in a 
solution consisting of 7 M urea, 0.5% CHAPS, 100 mM 1,4-dithiothreitol, 1% pH 3-10 
ampholytes (Invitrogen) and 35 µg (for protein stain) or 3.5 µg (for immunoblotting)  fish protein 
extract.  Focusing conditions were controlled with a multi-step program: 200 V for 20 min, 450 
V for 15 min, 750 V for 15 min and 2000 V for 30 min. After focusing and prior to the second 
dimension, strips were equilibrated in a mixture of one mL NuPage® reducing agent 
(Invitrogen) and 9 mL 1X NuPage® LDS sample buffer (Invitrogen) for 15 min, then alkylated 
by incubation with 125 mM iodoacetamide in 1X NuPage® LDS sample buffer (Invitrogen) for 
15 min.  The second dimension electrophoresis was conducted in a Novex® 4-20% Tris-Glycine 
Zoom® Gel (Invitrogen).  Completed gels were used for immunoblotting and protein stain.  The 
pI gradient of the Zoom® strips was calibrated by a low range pI isoelectric focusing calibration 
kit (Amersham Biosciences Corp, Piscataway, NJ). 
 
Immunoblotting
 
Proteins separated in gels were transferred to PVDF membranes using an XCell II™ Blot 
Module (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’s instruction.  Following transfer, 
membranes were blocked with 5% non-fat dry milk in PBS (PBS-NFDM) for two hours at room 
temperature and washed four times with PBS containing 0.5% v/v Tween 20 (PBS-T) with 
vigorous shaking.  The membranes were then incubated overnight at 4°C with anti-frog Mab 
(Parv-19) diluted 1:5,000 or anti-carp Mab (Swant 235) diluted 1:10,000 in 2.5% PBS-NFDM.  
After four washes in PBS-T, the membranes were incubated for one hour with goat anti-mouse 
IgG conjugated with horseradish peroxidase (Pierce Biotechnology, Rockford, IL), diluted 
1:5000 (v/v) in 2.5% PBS-NFDM.  Membranes were washed four times with PBS-T and wetted 
in SuperSignal west Dura extended duration substrates (Pierce Biotechnology) to visualize the 
immunocomplex. The chemiluminescent signal was captured by exposing Kodak® BioMax light 
films for various times (Eastman Kodak Company).   
 
Competitive ELISA
 
A 96-well microtiter plate (MaxiSorp, Nagle Nunc international, Rochester, NY) was coated 
with 20µg protein/ml carp extract (100µl/well) overnight at 4˚C.  After coating, the free binding 
sites of the plate were blocked by 350µl/well 0.1% porcine gelatin in PBS for 2 hr at room 
temperature.  Serially diluted fish extracts, isinglass extracts, recombinant carp parvalbumin, 
PBS solution, or isinglass extracts spiked with a known amount of  recombinant carp 
parvalbumin were added to the blocked plate (50µl/well) as inhibitors followed by adding an 
equal volume of anti-carp Mab, diluted 1:15,000(v/v) in blocking buffer.  After incubation at 
37˚C for 1 hr, the plate was washed 4 times with PBS-T. Following washing, anti-mouse IgG -Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 8 of 21 
  
alkaline phosphatase conjugate, diluted 1:5000(v/v) in blocking buffer, was added to plate and 
incubated for 1 hr at 37˚C.  After washing, p-nitrophenyl phosphate substrate was added and the 
color development was read at 410nm on a MRX microplate reader (Dynex technologies, 
Chantlly, VA). 
 
 D.  Results: 
 
Electrophoresis and immunoblots of fish protein extracts
 
 
1D electrophoresis and western blot
 
Initially, the protein profiles of cod, carp, catfish, tilapia, and tuna were assessed by SDS-PAGE, 
shown in Figure1.1A.  All five species showed similar protein banding patterns above a 
molecular weight of 25 kDa.  Differences in protein bands were observed at lower molecular 
weights among fish species.  Either one or two distinct bands of high concentration were 
observed in the molecular weight range of 10-12 kDa expected for parvalbumins in carp (2), 
catfish (2), cod (1), and tilapia (2).  No significant bands were noted in the tuna sample below 25 
kDa.   
 
Immunoblots obtained using the anti-frog parvalbumin Mab are shown in Figure 1.1B.  All 
visible fish protein bands in the molecular weight range of 10-13 kDa were recognized by anti-
frog parvalbumin Mab.  The antibody did not bind to any bands in tuna (Figure 1.1B, lane 5).  
The molecular weight and relative abundance (determined by densitometry using the Kodak 
image analysis software) of the antibody-binding fish proteins is summarized in Table 1.1.  Lane 
6 of Figure1.1B contains recombinant carp parvalbumin (rCyp C1.01) with a molecular weight 
of 11.4 kDa (Swoboda, 2002). 
 
Immunoblots using anti-carp parvalbumin Mab failed to provide clear profile of antibody 
binding bands, which were masked by strong background.  In an effort to improve the 
background, several blocking reagents were tested in the immunoblotting, including non-fat dry 
milk, bovine serum albumin and porcine gelatin.  However, no immunoblot of satisfactory 
quality was obtained that is comparable to those using anti-frog parvalbumin Mab.  More 
optimization work is needed to reveal the binding pattern of anti-carp parvalbumin Mab to fish 
proteins on immunoblots.  
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 9 of 21 
  
 
Figure 1.1. SDS-PAGE and western blots with anti-frog and anti-carp parvalbumin antibodies. 
A. Sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE); B. western blot 
using anti-frog parvalbumin Mab and C. western blot using mouse IgG1 isotype control (Sigma-
Aldrich) as negative control. Lane 1 = carp, 2 = catfish; 3 = cod; 4 = tilapia; 5 = tuna; 6 = carp 
recombinant parvalbumin (rCyp C1.01).   
 
 
Table 1.1. 
Esimate of Parvalbumin Content of Fish Muscle Tissue  
Using Anti-Frog Parvalbumin as Determined by Immunoblotting.  
*Densitometry analysis was conducted on SDS-PAGE using Kodak 1D image analysis software 
to calculate the abundance of the antibody-binding protein in the total fish extract. 
 
Subsequently, the protein profile of cod extract was compared to an additional six species of 
fish.  The protein and immunoblotting profiles of the seven fish species were revealed by SDS-
PAGE, shown in Figure1.2.  As with the previously evaluated 5 species and based on protein 
staining with Coomassie blue, these 6 species showed similar protein banding patterns above a 
molecular weight of 25 kDa.  Differences in protein bands were observed at lower molecular 
weights among fish species.  Either one or two distinct bands of high concentration were 
observed in the molecular weight range of 10-13 kDa expected for parvalbumins.

abundance

Cod 1 11.6 12.5 12.5 
1 12.1 5.0 Tilapia 2 11.1 9.6 14.7 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 10 of 21 
  
Immunoblots using anti-frog and anti-carp parvalbumin Mab show both antibodies can detect 
parvalbumins from most of the fish species tested.  Little non-specific binding of the two 
antibodies to other proteins was observed.  Anti-carp parvalbumin Mab exhibited higher 
sensitivity than anti-frog parvalbumin Mab since similar signal intensities were achieved within 
shorter exposure time when anti-carp Mab was used.  As noted with the earlier studies of 5 
species, it should be noted that anti-frog and anti-carp parvalbumin Mab bind to parvalbumin 
from various fish species with different specificities.  Interestingly, the strongest binding 
apparently obtained for anti-frog parvalbumin Mab was with the parvalbumins from redfish and 
flounder.  These same two parvalbumins showed very low apparent binding to anti-carp 
parvalbumin Mab.  Meanwhile, anti-carp parvalbumin Mab had high apparent specificity to 
parvalbumins from cod, cusk, hake and haddock, which exhibited weak apparent binding to anti-
frog parvalbumin Mab.  Both antibodies appear to bind well to pollock parvalbumin. 
 
 
Figure 1.2. SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting of seven additional fish protein extracts. 
 
These additional results further suggest that anti-frog and anti-carp parvalbumin antibodies have 
some value in the detection of parvalbumin from the muscle tissues of a wide range of species.   
 
2D electrophoresis and western blot
 
 
Figure 1.3 shows the 2D electrophoresis maps of carp, catfish, cod and tilapia extracts in 
conjunction with immunoblots using anti-carp parvalbumin Mab.  Tuna fish was not included 
because of negative results in 1D SDS-PAGE shown earlier.  And, 2D electrophoresis was not 
done with cusk, flounder, hake, haddock, redfish, and pollock  Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 11 of 21 
  
 
Carp contained five isoforms that bound to the anti-frog parvalbumin antibody. Three of the five 
polypeptides had a molecular weight of 10.6 kDa and the other two were of 11.6 kDa. Their pI 
values ranged from 3.5-4.25, based on protein markers in the low range pI (Amersham 
Biosciences), data not shown.  Catfish had two fairly strong antibody-binding proteins at pI 4.25 
and a barely visible spot at pI 3.5.  Only one antibody-binding protein was observed in cod fish, 
with a molecular weight of 11.6 kDa and pI 3.6.  Anti-frog parvalbumin antibody recognized two 
bands in tilapia.  Even though these two proteins showed similar intensity in SDS-PAGE (Figure 
1.3 D1), their antibody-binding capacities were markedly different (Figure 1.3 D2). The 11.1 
kDa protein with pI 3.6 exhibited much stronger binding than the 12.1 kDa subunit with pI 4.0.  
This suggested that the anti-frog pravlbumin Mab binds to different parvalbumin isoforms with 
different specificity. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 12 of 21 
  
 
Figure 1.3. Two dimensional electrophoresis maps of carp (A1), catfish (B1), cod (C1) and 
tilapia (D1) extracts and their corresponding immunoblotting profiles: carp (A2), catfish (B2), 
cod (C2) and tilapia (D2). 
 
 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 13 of 21 
  
Method development of competitive ELISA 
 
Figure 1.4 shows IgG binding inhibition curves of soluble carp and cod protein extracts that 
compete with bound carp protein on the ELISA plate using soluble anti-frog or anti-carp 
parvalbumin Mab.  The inhibition curves of both carp and cod shifted to the left (the lower 
concerntration end) when anti-carp parvalbumin Mab (solid lines in Figure 1.4) was used instead 
of anti-frog parvalbumin Mab (dot lines in Figure 1.4).  This suggested that less soluble fish 
protein was needed to inhibit binding of anti-carp parvalbumin Mab to solid-phased carp protein 
than when anti-frog parvalbumin Mab is used.  As a result, the competitive ELISA using anti-
carp parvalbumin Mab has higher sensitivity in detecting fish parvalbumins than when anti-frog 
parvalbumin Mab is used.  It should be noted that the competitive ELISA was not conducted by 
using more concentrated primary antibodies (1:5,000) than the optimized dilution (1:15,000) as 
described in methods section. 
 
 
 
 
Figure 1.4. Inhibition curves generated by soluble carp and cod protein extracts in competitive 
ELISA using anti-frog or anti-carp parvalbumin Mab (diluted 1:5,000) to bind to solid-phased 
carp protein. 
 
A competitive ELISA using anti-carp parvalbumin Mab was developed to detect parvalbumin in 
fish and fish derived products due to the superior sensitivity of the anti-carp Mab compared to 
that of the anti-frog parvalbumin Mab.  Using the amount of recombinant carp parvalbumin 
needed to obtain 20% inhibition as a detection limit, this ELISA method is capable of detecting 
0.05 µg/mL carp parvalbumin in a PBS extract (or 1 µg/g on a weight/weight basis). 
 
The competitive ELISA is developed to test fish parvalbumin in fish and fish derived products.  
Since the complex biochemical constituents in the extract of a matrix such as isinglass or fish 
gelatin might interfere with the assay, we wanted to evaluate the possibility that a high collagen Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 14 of 21 
  
content matrix might alter assay results.  Therefore, inhibition curves were obtained by serially 
diluting recombinant carp parvalbumin in PBS (no matrix effect) or in 10% (w/v) fish gelatin 
extract (Norland Products, Inc.), simulating fish protein matrix effects (Figure 1.5).  The fish 
collagen extract may contain an unknown amount of fish parvalbumin.  The results showed a 
dramatic difference in the slopes of the two inhibition curves, which suggested the standard 
curve generated in a PBS solution of recombinant carp parvalbumin was not suitable to evaluate 
parvalbumin content in the fish gelatin extract. 
 
 
 
Figure 1.5. Competitive ELISA detecting recombinant carp parvalbumin (rCyp c1.01) in PBS or 
fish collagen protein extract. 
 
It is possible to overcome the problem of matrix effect by spiking a known amount of 
recombinant carp parvalbumin into the sample protein extract and testing both spiked and 
unspiked samples in the same assay.  At least theoretically both spiked and non-spiked samples 
experience similar matrix effects and should exhibit parallel inhibition curves.  Figure 1.6 shows 
an example of competitive ELISA carried out on an isinglass sample.  In this case the sample 
was spiked with 20 µg recombinant carp parvalbumin per g sample and analyzed simulateously 
with an equivalent unspiked sample.  Based on the inhibition curves, a dilution representing 0.28 
mg dry weight of spiked sample and a dilution representing 1.57 mg of unspiked sample both 
exhibited 50% inhibition (contain equivalent amounts of parvalbumin).  Assuming the 
parvalbumin content in non-spiked sample is X µg/g, the amount of parvalbumin in both non-
spiked and spiked sample is 
1.57mg*X µg/g=0.28 mg *(X µg/g +20 µg/g) 
 
Solving the equation,  
X=4.3 µg/g Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 15 of 21 
  
Thus this specific sample of isinglass contains 4.3 ppm parvalbumin.  This example 
demonstrates that this assay can be used to measure the equivalent content of parvalbumin in 
isinglass samples or those of other similar matrices. 
 
 
 
 
Figure 1.6. Competitive ELISA detection of parvalbumin content in a fish collagen sample using 
recombinant carp parvalbumin as internal standard. 
 
Analysis of Parvalbumin Content of Fish Tissues by Competitive ELISA Using Anti-Carp 
Parvalbumin Mab 
 
Competitive ELISA using anti-carp parvalbumin Mab was performed under optimized 
conditions to detect parvalbumins in various fish protein extracts and the results were showed in 
Figure 1.7.  Protein concentration of fish extracts that achieved 50% inhibition are calculated as 
1.8, 0.4, 2.8, 0.7 and 10 µg/mL for carp, catfish, cod, tilapia and tuna respectively, which is 
equivalent to 0.1  µg/mL recombinant carp parvalbumin.  If recombinant carp parvalbumin 
needed for 20% inhibition is defined as detection limit, this ELISA method is capable of 
detecting parvalbumin content equivalent to as low as 0.05 µg/mL carp parvalbumin. 
 
The inhibition curves of most fish extracts except catfish and cod exhibited similar slopes to that 
of recombinant carp parvalbumin.   It is not known if the slopes of catfish and cod were 
significant different from the others.  The slope differences can be explained by the existence of 
differing specificities for the antibody binding to the epitopes of catfish or cod parvalbumin. 
Nevertheless, the matrix effect of fish extracts may also introduce slope variation.   
 
Carp extract containing 1.8 µg/mL total proteins exhibited inhibition equivalent to 0.1 µg/mL 
recombinant carp parvalbumin.  That is, the abundance of parvalbumin in carp extract is 
0.1/1.8=5.5%.  Similarly, parvalbumin abundances of catfish, cod, tilapia and tuna in protein Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 16 of 21 
  
extracts were estimated at 25, 3.6, 14.3 and 1% respectively.  These numbers are different from 
the abundance results calculated by SDS-PAGE densitometry shown in Table 1.1, which 
suggested the anti-carp parvalbumin Mab binds to fish parvalbumin from various fish species 
with different specificity.   It is interesting to observe detectable parvalbumin in tuna extract that 
is not visible in either SDS-PAGE or westernblot using anti-frog parvalbumin Mab.  Anti-carp 
parvalbumin Mab may have higher specificity for tuna parvalbumin than anti-frog antibody. 
 
 
 
Figure 1.7. Inhibition curves generated by carp, catfish, cod, tilapia, tuna fish protein extracts 
and recombinant carp parvalbumin (rCyp c1.01) in competitive ELISA using anti-carp 
parvalbumin Mab.
 
 
Analysis of Parvalbumin Content of Isinglass by Competitive ELISA Using Anti-Carp 
Parvalbumin Mab 
 
The competitive ELISA method described above using anti-carp parvalbumin monoclonal 
antibody was used to assess the levels of parvalbumin in isinglass.  Initially,  nine samples of 
isinglass produced from the maws of seven different species of fish were analyzed as shown in 
Table 1.2.  These isinglass samples were manufactured in typical fashion with milling but no 
further processing steps; thus these would be considered as unprocessed fish maws.  A low, but 
variable, level of residual parvalbumin was found in isinglass from all of the fish species.  Based 
on the comparatively higher level of residual parvalbumin found in the isinglass manufactured 
from the Nile perch maws, this species of fish was eliminated as a source of maws for the 
production of isinglass.   
 
Since parvalbumin is a water-soluble protein that binds calcium, washing was introduced as a 
commercial unit operation in an attempt to decrease residual parvalbumin levels.  Normally, 
unprocessed maws would be washed with water.  Thus, the “before treatment” column in Table

1.3 shows the usual water wash procedure.  Additional water washing was one of the attempted 
conditions.  Table 1.3 shows the results of additional washing with water, a calcium wash, and a Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 18 of 21 
  
phosphate buffer wash.  Based on limited experiments, the determination was made that the 
phosphate buffer wash was perhaps the most effective in reducing parvalbumin levels.  
Somewhat variable results were obtained for isinglass produced from maws of various fish 
species but the phosphate buffer wash appeared to be effective.  This experiment was not 
repeated.  The sources of the fish swim bladders used to produce these samples of isinglass are 
representative of the range of species used in the commercial production of isinglass. 
 
Table 1.4 shows the parvalbumin content of some commercial isinglass samples provided by the 
isinglass manufacturers.  These samples were selected after the elimination of Nile perch as a 
commercial source of maws and after development of the phosphate buffer washing operation.  
The sample codes can be matched to the descriptions provided in Table 1.3.  It should be noted 
that, for some unknown reason, the results of this batch of assay were apparently lower than 
what we tested previously.  The reference isinglass sample was tested on this occasion as usual 
and it yielded a result of 1.8 µg/g, much less than previous results (4.6-5.0 µg/g); the earlier, 
higher level was confirmed on numerous occasions.  Some potential assay problems, such as 
poor protein extraction, degradation of coating protein or anti-parvalbumin antibody, have been 
excluded as possible causes of the lower than expected results.   
 
Table 1.4

by the Anti-Carp Parvalbumin Mab ELISA

  * nd: not detectable, <0.2 µg/g 
   
Table 1.4 also provides the analysis of the residual parvalbumin level in the clinical challenge 
material that is currently being used to assess whether isinglass has the potential to elicit allergic 
reactions in fish-allergic individuals.  The clinical challenge material was a blend of the first six 
samples listed in Table 1.4 (all but the reference sample). 
 
 
 
E. Discussion:   
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 19 of 21 
  
Parvalbumins share considerable sequence homology among fishes.  Frog parvalbumin shares 
43-88% sequence homology with parvalbumins from fish species (according to a search of a 
database of sequences of known allergens; www.allergenonline.com).  Anti-frog and anti-carp 
parvalbumin monoclonal antibodies are capable of binding to the parvalbumins in fish muscle 
tissues from several divergent fish species (Chen et al., 2006).  We were unable to obtain fish 
muscle tissues from the species of fish used to manufacture isinglass but these results suggest 
that parvalbumin is present in the muscle tissues of most, if not all, fish species.  Of course, 
swim bladders rather than muscle tissues are used as the raw material for preparation of 
isinglass.  However, swim bladders are also likely to contain parvalbumin (Gerday et al., 1989).   
 
While anti-frog and anti-carp parvalbumin Mabs detect the presence of parvalbumin in muscle 
tissues from the muscle tissues of all fish species tested in this study, parvalbumin from various 
fish species show differences in specificity to each of these antibodies.  Anti-frog parvalbumin 
Mab appears to be most useful for detecting parvalbumin from flounder, pollock and redfish 
compared to the other species tested.  Anti-carp parvalbumin Mab exhibited higher specifity for 
carp, cod, cusk, hake, haddock and pollock parvalbumins than anti-frog parvalbumin Mab, 
however, it displayed much weaker binding to parvalbumins from flounder and redfish.  In 2-
dimensional electrophoresis with immunoblotting only, the anti-carp parvalbumin Mab was able 
to detect parvalbumin from tuna.   
 
These electrophoresis and immunoblotting results demonstrate convincingly that commercial 
anti-parvalbumin antibodies are able to detect the presence of parvalbumin in a range of fish 
species.  Certainly, the quantitative reliability of an ELISA based upon either of these antibodies 
may be dependent upon the species origin of the fish-based ingredient that is being evaluated.  
However, even though isinglass is made from species of fish that were not evaluated here, a 
sufficient number of species were evaluated to indicate that these antibodies should have some 
utility in the detection of parvalbumin residues in isinglass. 
 
The anti-carp parvalbumin Mab was employed for the development of a parvalbumin ELISA.  
Because sequence homology was greater between other fish parvalbumin and carp parvalbumin 
compared to frog parvalbumin, the choice of the anti-carp parvalbumin Mab was considered as 
advantageous.  The inhibition curves presented in Figure 1.4 also indicate that the anti-carp 
parvalbumin MAb was the superior choice.  While a successful ELISA method was developed, 
its quantitative accuracy for detecting residual parvalbumin from species other than carp is 
undoubtedly compromised to some degree by the variability in binding specificity discussed 
above.     
 
Residual parvalbumin was detected in samples of commercial isinglass using the competitive 
ELISA method with anti-carp parvalbumin Mab.  Obviously, some caution is warranted in the 
interpretation of these results because of the previously discussed differences in binding 
specificity of the anti-carp parvalbumin Mab with parvalbumins from the various fish species.  
The anti-carp parvalbumin Mab is reasonably good at detecting parvalbumins from cod, cusk, 
hake, pollock, haddock, carp, catfish, and tilapia based upon the binding specificity.  This Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 20 of 21 
  
demonstrates that this antibody has reasonably broad specificity.  The rather low level of 
sensitivity (1 µg/g or 1 ppm) of the ELISA also suggests that the method would detect 
parvalbumin residues in spite of the differences in binding specificities.  However, since this 
ELISA has not been applied to samples of the fish used in the manufacture of isinglass, we 
cannot categorically indicate that it would detect parvalbumin from those species.  Furthermore, 
the quantitative accuracy of this method cannot easily be substantiated.  However, its value in 
comparative analysis of the effectiveness of various approaches to the possible reduction of 
residual parvalbumin levels in commercial isinglass would seem to be quite excellent. 
 
Since the swim bladder of the oyster toadfish contains parvalbumin (Gerday et al., 1989), a 
reasonable assumption would be that the swim bladders of the fish used in the manufacture of 
isinglass would also contain parvalbumin.  The nature of the collagen matrix and the known 
effectiveness of isinglass in removal of protein haze components of beers and ales suggest that 
isinglass might well bind parvalbumin.  The discovery of residual parvalbumin in isinglass 
indicates that this is the case.  Since parvalbumin is water-soluble, the expectation would be that 
the parvalbumin could be removed from isinglass by incorporation of washing steps in the 
manufacturing process.  In fact, washing with phosphate buffer is apparently effective in 
reduction of residual parvalbumin levels.  However, parvalbumin cannot be entirely eliminated 
from isinglass by washing.  Although this ELISA seems to provide reasonable proof that residual 
parvalbumin is present at rather low levels in isinglass, development of an ELISA based upon 
anti-cod parvalbumin was also pursued. 
 
The levels of residual isinglass found in commercial isinglass using the anti-carp parvalbumin 
monoclonal Ab ELISA are very low (1-5 ppm).  Since isinglass is very insoluble and used as a 
clarifying agent for beers and ales, the majority of any isinglass added to these beverages would 
be removed by precipitation, filtration, centrifugation or other means.  In all likelihood, much of 
the residual isinglass would also likely be removed.  Clearly, addition of isinglass to these 
beverages could result in the incorporation of extremely low levels of parvalbumin into these 
beverages.  Clinical challenges trials on the allergenicity of isinglass are needed to determine if 
the low levels of parvalbumin present in isinglass represent any risk whatsoever to fish-allergic 
individuals. 
 
 
References: 
 
Chen L, Hefle S L, Taylor S L, Swoboda I, Goodman R E.  2006.  Detecting fish parvalbumin 
with commercial mouse monoclonal anti-frog parvalbumin IgG.  J. Agric. Food Chem. 54:5577-
5582. 
 
Gerday Ch, Collin S, Gerardin-Otthiers N.  1989.  The amino acid sequence of the parvalbumin 
from the very fast swimbladder muscle of the toadfish (Opsanus tau). Comp Biochem Physiol B   
93:49-55.  
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-07-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 21 of 21 
  
Hamada Y, Tanaka H, Ishizaki S, Ishida M, Nagashima Y, Shiomi K. 2003.  Purification, 
reactivity with IgE and cDNA cloning of parvalbumin as the major allergen of mackerels. 
Food Chem Toxicol.  41:1149-1156.   
 
Taylor S L, Kabourek J L, Hefle S L. 2004. Fish allergy: fish and products thereof.  J. Food Sci. 
69:175-80. 
 
 Detection of fish parvalbumin in beer tank sediment (containing 
isinglass) by inhibition ELISA 
Lingyun Chen, 07-26-05 
 
Materials  
Sediment of beer tank from AB Vickers, received on 7/21/2005. 
Monoclonal mouse anti-carp parvalbumin antibody: Swant 235 
Recombinant carp parvalbumin (rCyp C1.01): provided by Dr. Ines Swoboda. 
 
Methods: 
• Protein extraction:   
The beer tank sediment sample was centrifuged at 15,000 xg for 5 min and the 
supernatant was collected as crude extract.    
 
• Spiking rCyp C1.01 into protein extract:  
Add 5ul 220μg/ml rCyp C1.01 into 995 μL extract. 
 
• Inhibition ELISA:    
Inhibition ELISA was set up based on FARRP ELISA protocols with 
modification. The procedure is briefly outlined as following: 
1. The microplates were coated with 20 μg/mL carp protein extract (100 μL/well) 
overnight at 4ºC; 
2. Blocking the wells with 350 μL of blocking buffer (0.1% porcine gelatin PBS) at 
room temperature for 2 hours; 
3. Adding 50 μL inhibitors (spiked or non-spiked extract, 2 fold serial dilution in PBS) 
and then 50 μL anti-carp antibody (dilution 1:15,000 in blocking buffer) to each 
well, incubate at 37ºC  for 1 hour; 
4. ELISA washing; 
5. Adding 100 μL /well secondary antibody (goat anti-mouse IgG AP conjugated, 
Pierce 31323, diluted 1:5,000 in blocking buffer), incubate at 37ºC for 1 hour; 
6. ELISA washing; 
7. Adding ρ-NPP substrate 100 μL/well, incubate at room temperature for 30min; 
8. Stopping by adding 100 μL/well 1N NaOH and reading at 410nm. 
 
Results: 
 
• Inhibition ELISA 
Inhibition curves are shown in Fig 1 for unspiked and spiked beer sediment 
extracts. The level of rCyp C1.01 spiked in the extract was 1.1 μg/mL isinglass.  
Assuming the non-spiked extract contains X μg/mL parvalbumin, the spiked sample 
contains (X+1.1) μg/mL parvalbumin. Based on the inhibition curve, 0.025 mL unspiked 
extract (the second point from right end of the unspiked curve) and 0.0025 mL spiked 
extract exhibited similar inhibition.  Therefore, 0.025 mL unspiked extract and 0.0025 
mL spiked extract contained equal amount of parvalbumin.   
 
X*0.025=(X+1.1)*0.0025 X=0.12 ug (rCyp C1.01 equivalence)/mL (beer sediment extract)  
 
 
Inhibition ELISA detecting fish parvalubmin in sediment of
beer tank
-4.0 -3.5 -3.0 -2.5 -2.0 -1.5 -1.0
0.0
0.5
1.0
1.5
2.0
Unspiked
Spiked
Log Inhibitor (beer tank sediment  extract), mL/well
Optical density at 410nm
 
 
Figure 1. Inhibition ELISA of beer tank sediment extract, 1.1 ppm (w/v) rCyp C1.01 was 
spiked into the extract as internal standard 
 
 
Conclusion:   
The beer tank sediment sample contained 0.12 ppm (w/v) of parvalbumin (rCyp 
C1.01 equivalent), measured by inhibition ELISA.

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.

 I.  Sequence Homology of Fish Parvalbumins 
 
Lead Scientists: Richard E. Goodman, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
   John C. Wise, M.S., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
 
A. Introduction 
 
All codfish-allergic individuals are reported to have IgE antibodies specific to Gad c 1, a 
parvalbumin, the first purified and characterized fish allergen (Elsayed and Bennich, 1975; 
Taylor et al., 2004). Parvalbumins are a group of highly related calcium binding proteins that are 
apparently important in regulating calcium flux in vertebrates.  Parvalbumins have also been 
identified as the major allergens in other fish species including salmon (Sal s 1), horse mackerel 
(Tra j 1), bigeye tuna (Thu o 1), carp (Cyp c 1) and several species of mackerels (Sco j 1, Sco a 
1, and Sco s 1) (Bugajaska-Schretter et al., 2000; Van Do et al., 1999; Shiomi et al., 1998; 
Shiomi et al., 1999; Hamada et al., 2003).  Thus, parvalbumin is considered as a pan-allergen in 
fish (Bernhisel-Broadbent et al., 1992; Taylor et al., 2004; Hansen et al., 1997).  Parvalbumin is 
also the major allergen of frog and the sequence of frog parvalbumin has been determined 
(Hilger et al., 2002; cross-reactivity exists between fish and frog parvalbumins (Hilger et al., 
2004).  Based on these studies it is clear that most vertebrates have at least two genes that encode 
highly identical forms of parvalbumin, that are classified primarily by pI values as alpha-
parvalbumins (pI ~ 5.0 or greater) and beta-parvalbumins (pI ~ 4.5 or less), and with sequences 
that align more closely within the two lineages (Swoboda et al., 2002).  However, it is not clear 
that definition based on pI value alone is meaningful.  Although mammals also have 
parvalbumins, they have not been reported as allergens.  While many of the parvalbumin 
sequences that have been reported as allergens appear to be of the beta-lineage by sequence 
alignment it is important to recognize that various fish species have between two and five 
parvalbumin proteins (Pechere et al., 1971; Giriga and Rehbein, 1988; Chen et al., 2006).   
Because we were interested in detecting the major allergenic protein from a variety of fish 
species it is important to evaluate species and isoform differences of the parvalbumins.  
Therefore we performed bioinformatics analyses to compare available sequences from 
commonly consumed fish parvalbumins in order to understand the structural and sequential 
similarity of these proteins.  This analysis will assist in the evaluation of the use of various 
antibodies such as anti-frog parvalbumin, anti-carp parvalbumin, and anti-cod parvalbumin in 
the detection of parvalbumins from a range of fish species. 
 
 
B. Methods 
 
Parvalbumin sequences were obtained from the National Center for Biotechnology Information 
(www.ncbi.nih.gov).  A clustal W alignment was performed using DNASTAR with 
representative parvalbumins from a number of important species of fish: carp, cod, mackerel, 
perch, pike, pollack, salmon, silver hake, whiting and toadfish swimbladder.  If two or more Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-05-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 6 of 12 
  
sequences were available for a given species, the most divergent were compared.  Results are 
presented as multiple sequence alignment, a percent identity and sequence divergence table and a 
phylogenetic tree (Figures 2.1-2.3).  In addition, a multiple sequence alignment to carp 
parvalbumin sequence GI# 17977825 was performed (Fig. 2.4) with another carp, three cod, one 
catfish, two frog parvalbumins and those of rat and bovine using the Align program (Scientific 
and Educational Software, Cary, NC), which uses a PAM250 scoring matrix with a mismatch 
penalty of 2, gap penalty of 4 and gap extension penalty of 1 (Chen et al., 2006).  The pI value 
for each sequence was calculated using Protean protein structure prediction and annotation 
software (DNASTAR, Inc., Madison, WI).     
 
C. Results & Discussion 
 
The results are summarized graphically in Figures 2.1-2.4. 
 
Note that the sequences around the two calcium binding pockets are the most conserved, as 
expected (Fig. 2.1).  It is not clear whether IgE from most individuals with allergy to fish 
parvalbumin bind at the Ca+ binding region, though there are data that indicate the removal of 
calcium reduces IgE binding for at least some allergic subjects (Bugajska-Schretter et al., 1998; 
Swoboda et al., 2002).  As aligned here, parvalbumin from the other fish are between 56 and 
91% identical to those of the three cod fish parvalbumin species (Fig. 2.2), which are themselves 
only 63 to 74% identical.  These high levels of sequence identity indicate a high likelihood of 
IgE cross-reactivity for at least some allergic subjects (Aalberse, 2000).  The studies by 
Bugajska-Schretter et al. (1998) and Swoboda et al. (2002) have also provided evidence that 
many individuals bind to parvalbumin from a number of these species including: carp, cod, eel, 
perch, salmon and tuna.  Cross-species inhibition has also demonstrated that pre-incubating sera 
of a number of fish allergic individuals with an extract of codfish significantly diminished or 
abolished IgE binding to carp, eel, perch, salmon and tuna demonstrating shared IgE binding 
(Bugajska-Schretter et al., 1998).   
 
The parvalbumin family of calcium binding proteins has diverged through evolutionary history, 
but the overall structure and the sequences are remarkably conserved across broad taxonomic 
groups.  An interesting finding is that many fish species have two or more “types” of 
parvalbumins that either represent, alpha- and beta-parvalbumins or functionally different beta-
isoforms that appear to be more conserved across species than across types, within a given taxa 
(Fig. 2.3).  For instance, one parvalbumin from salmon aligns better with pike than it does to the 
other salmon parvalbumin, which is closer to a parvalbumin from pollack.  However, these fish 
proteins are all more similar to each other than to the mammalian and amphibian alpha-
parvalbumins that are known and appear to be less allergenic (or alternatively more tolerogenic 
than the fish parvalbumins.  The biological significance of the two types of parvalumins is not 
understood (Swoboda et al., 2002).    
 
Together this information demonstrating the close sequence similarity across species of fish 
suggests that one or two parvalbumins may function well as diagnostic reagents (skin test Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-05-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 7 of 12 
  
reagents or IgE binding targets) for most individuals with fish allergy.  Conversely, antibodies to 
one or two of these fish parvalbumins could serve as reagents for detection of muscle tissue from 
a wide range of fish species.

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.

  Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 5 of 28 
  
 I.  Purification of Codfish Parvalbumin 
 
 Lead Scientist:  Aard de Jong., Ph.D., TNO, The Netherlands 
 
A. Introduction: 
 
Since isinglass is primarily composed of fish collagen and collagen is not a major allergen from 
fish, the primary concern about the allergenicity of isinglass focuses around the possible 
presence of parvalbumin in isinglass.  Parvalbumin is the major allergen in several different 
species of fish including cod, salmon, carp, mackerels, and tuna (Elsayed and Aas, 1971; 
Bugajaska-Schretter et al., 1998; Van Do et al., 1999; Bugajska-Schretter et al., 2000; Hamada et 
al., 2003a; Hamada et al., 2004; Lindström et al., 1996; Van Do et al., 2005; Shiomi et al., 1998; 
Shiomi et al., 1999; Yamada et al., 1999 ) and is considered as a pan-allergen for individuals 
with fish allergy (Taylor et al., 2004).  The presence and levels of parvalbumin in the fish species 
used in the manufacturing of isinglass have not been examined.  However, because parvalbumin 
is present at some level in the majority of fish that have been investigated (Chen et al., 2006; 
Taylor et al., 2004), the assumption that parvalbumin is present in the fish species used to 
manufacture isinglass seems reasonable.  Furthermore, although parvalbumin is primarily found 
in fish muscle while isinglass is manufactured from swim bladders, parvalbumin has been 
identified in the swim bladder of the oyster toadfish (Gerday et al., 1989).  Again, it seems 
prudent to assume that the swim bladders of the fish species used to manufacture isinglass also 
contain parvalbumin.  Thus, the detection of residual parvalbumin levels in commercial isinglass 
seems to be a key factor in the assessment of the potential allergenicity of this material.  Because 
cod parvalbumin is the best characterized of the fish allergens, the development of an ELISA for 
parvalbumin was pursued with the hypothesis that this ELISA would also detect any residual 
parvalbumin in isinglass emanating from the swim bladders used in its manufacture. 
 
The development of a cod parvalbumin ELISA required several steps.  This first step was the 
purification of cod parvalbumin.  This portion of the research effort was sub-contracted to TNO 
in the Netherlands to a group headed by Aard de Jong., Ph.D.  This group succeeded in the 
purification of gram amounts of cod parvalbumin.  Their report can be found as Appendix A. 
 
II.  Production of Anti-Cod Parvalbumin Polyclonal Antibodies 
 
 Lead Scientist:  Sue L. Hefle, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
 
A. Introduction: 
 
Once purified cod parvalbumin was obtained (see Section IV), the production of antibodies was 
needed as the next step in the development of a cod parvalbumin ELISA.  The approach involved 
the production of polyclonal antibodies against cod parvalbumin in rabbits.  While the earlier 
ELISA efforts had involved use of commercial monoclonal antibodies against frog and carp 
parvalbumins (see FARRP-07-2006), the production of polyclonal antisera was selected in hopes 
that the specificity of the antibodies would be broader allowing more consistent detection of Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 6 of 28 
  
parvalbumins from various fish species and the swim bladders of the species used to produce 
isinglass. 
 
 
 B.  Materials & Methods: 
 
Purified cod parvalbumin was obtained from TNO Food Research Institute (Zeist, the 
Netherlands, see Section I and Appendix A).  Antibodies were produced at Covance 
Laboratories (Denver, PA, USA).  Three New Zealand female rabbits were injected with the 
purified cod parvalbumin using a standard immunization protocol (Harlow and Lane, 1988) and 
TiterMax adjuvant (Sigma-Aldrich Co., St. Louis, MO, USA).  Initial injections were 200 µg 
parvalbumin per rabbit intradermally, and booster injections were 100 µg subcutaneously every 
four weeks.  Blood serum was collected every three weeks and tested for response using a non-
competitive ELISA.  As of the second booster injection, titers (defined as the log reciprocal of 
the mid-linear portion of the titration curve) reached more than 10,000 in all rabbits.  A pool of 
two production bleeds from each rabbit (pool titer 100,000) was sent to Drs. Stef Koppelman 
(AllerTeQ) and Martin Hessing (Podiceps) for use in developing ELISAs for the detection of 
parvalbumin. 
 
 C.  Results & Discussion:  
 
High-titer polyclonal antisera against cod parvalbumin was obtained from the immunized 
rabbits.  This antisera was used to develop the cod parvalbumin ELISA (see Section III). 
 
 D.  References: 
 
Harlow E, Lane D. 1988. Antibodies: a laboratory manual.  Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory 
Press, Cold Springs Harbor, NY.  
 
 
III.  Extraction of Fish Muscle Tissue and Fish Maws 
 
 Lead Scientists:  Stef J. Koppelman, Ph.D., AllerTeQ, The Netherlands 
        Martin Hessing, Ph.D., Podiceps B.V., The Netherlands 
        Sue L. Hefle, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
 
A. Introduction: 
 
Although it is widely recognized that parvalbumin is a pan-allergen from fish muscle tissues and 
the major allergen for fish-allergic individuals, no documentation exists to demonstrate the 
presence of parvalbumin in either fish flesh or fish maws from the species of fish used to 
manufacture isinglass.  This report describes the procurement of fish and fish maws from these 
species of fish and the preparation of extracts from those samples.  In the following phase of the 
investigations, an ELISA for the detection of cod parvalbumin was developed and used to assess Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 7 of 28 
  
the parvalbumin content of these extracts.  In this section of the report, the extracts were 
analyzed for protein concentration and SDS-PAGE band pattern.  The extraction studies resulted 
in the selection of phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) for the preparation of the extracts on a larger 
scale.  
 
 
 B.  Materials & Methods: 
 
Fish samples
 
Whole fish and dried maws (swim bladder) were forwarded to Podiceps BV by various suppliers 
used by the isinglass manufacturers.  Table 1 gives a list of the samples obtained (6 maws, 6 
whole fish).  The fish samples were filleted, and clean fillets (essentially free of collagen-like 
tissue and fat) were used for preparation of extracts.  The remainder of the fish was discarded.  In 
this report, samples are referred to by species code (first column in Table 1) and the description 
maw or fish, the latter meaning fillet.

All maw samples arrived in dried condition.  The processing background of these samples was 
unknown. All fish samples arrived frozen, except for F 21/05, which arrived non-frozen and 
covered with mold.  Samples of maw and fish (after fillets were prepared) were stored until use 
at -20° C. 
 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 8 of 28 
  
Extraction buffers 
Water, PBS and 0.9% salt solution were used to prepare extracts.  Although water and 0.9% salt 
solution are not buffers, the set of these extraction fluids are referred to as extraction buffers 
(water, PBS, 0.9% NaCl).  All three extraction buffers were sterile and pyrogen free solutions. 
PBS was from Fresenius Kabi (Schelle, Belgium, catalogue number N400500) and contained per 
liter: 8.2 g NaCl, 1.9 g Na
2HPO4·2H2Oand , 0.3 g NaH2PO4·2H2O (pH = 7.4).  Water and 0.9% 
NaCl were from Fresenius Kabi as well (catalogue numbers B230667 and 2660091, 
respectively).  Containers with extraction buffer were only used once after opening.  
 
Protein concentration determination
 
Bradford analysis was used, applying Bradford reagent from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MI, 
catalogue number B6916) with bovine serum albumin (BSA) as a standard (Sigma: A7906, 
minimum BSA content: 98%) 
 
SDS-PAGE 
 
SDS-PAGE was performed with a ready-to-use electrophoresis system equipped with 4-20% 
gradient gels (precast, Mercury PerfectPAGE SDS, catalogue number 5300.41212, Continental 
Lab Products, San Diego, CA, USA) under standard conditions.  Markers were from BioRad 
(Hercules, CA, USA, product name: Precision Plus Protein Standards). Laemmli sample buffer 
was from Biorad (catalogue number 161.0737) and 1:20 (V:V) β-mercaptoethanol (MP 
Biomedicals Inc., Uden, the Netherlands, catalogue number 194834) was added prior to use.  
Gels were stained with Coomassie Briljant Blue (Acros Organics, Landsmeer, the Netherlands, 
catalogue number 191490250, 0.1% in 10% acetic acid and 40% methanol), and destained with 
10% acetic acid and 40% methanol.  Gels were scanned with a HP Photosmart 3110 scanner, 
using HP Solution Center software. 
  
A reference sample of purified parvalbumin obtained from FARRP and its preparation has been 
described in Section I of this report. 
 
General extraction procedure
 
Fish and maw samples were ground using a kitchen-scale blender and if necessary with a 
professional blender (Super Total Nutrition Center, stainless steel, Whole food machine®, Vita-
mix Corp., Cleveland, OH, USA).  Ground samples were stored frozen.  Extracts were prepared 
by stirring 1 part of ground fish or maw sample with 4 parts of extraction buffer for 2 hours at 
room temperature.  Suspensions were centrifuged (15 minutes at 4 °C, 4000 rpm in sterile 50 ml 
PP-test tubes, Greiner Bio-one, Longwood, FL, USA, catalogue reference Cellstar® 227261).  
For exploratory extracts, supernatants were taken and analyzed directely.  Production extracts 
were filtered over 0.22 µm bottle-top filters (500 ml filter system 0.22µm PES (polyethersulfone) 
sterilizing, low protein binding membrane, non pyrogenic (Corning Inc., Acton, MA, USA). 
After filtration, extracts were subdivided into 1 ml aliquots (2 ml polypropylene cryo vials, 
12,5/48 mm, sterile and pyrogen-free vials with screw cap, Greiner bio-one catalogue number 
121263).  Filtration and subdividing was done in a flow chamber.

flesh and maws respectively.

Figure 3.2. SDS-PAGE results of maw extracts 
Samples J52/04 and FL17/18/05 (Panel A, previous page), samples FA 1/2/05 and FA 13/05 (Panel B, previous 
page), and samples FA 1/2/05 and FA 13/05 (Panel C, this page) were extracted with different extraction fluids and 
analyzed on SDS-PAGE (4-20% gels stained with Coomassie Briliant Blue).  Molecular weights of markers are 
indicated next the marker lanes (kDa). 
 
 
All fish flesh samples (Figure 3.1), except F 21/05 show a band pattern very similar to each other 
and very similar to that of cod fish, (sample from a local supermarket).  A triplet between 
approximately 37 and 50 kDa is clearly visible, as well as bands at approximately 60 and 100 
kDa.  A faint triplet at approximately 30 kDa is visible in all samples (except for F 21/05) as 
well.  Also, a band at approximately 12 kDa is clearly visible in all fish samples, including F 
21/05.  This band is most likely parvalbumin (based on MW and band assignment described in 
the relevant literature.  The staining of the gel depicted in Figure 3.1A is less clear, for unknown 
reason, and the parvalbumin is therefore less clearly visible.  The control sample of cod fish on 
this gel shows the same phenomenon, indicating the that this is indeed a gel (staining) artifact, 
rather than a difference in band pattern as compared to the other fish samples investigated 
(Figures 1B and 1C).  It should be noted that the fish sample F 21/05 arrived in a non-frozen 
condition at PodiCeps premises, covered with mold.  Although the fish flesh was prepared as 
best as possible under these conditions, the different SDS-PAGE pattern may well be explained 
by this.  
 
Water, PBS, and 0.9% NaCl gave similar results for extracts of fish flesh (similar band pattern, 
similar band intensity).  Extracts prepared with SDS-PAGE sample buffer showed more intense 
bands.

For maws, quite another picture emerges.  As shown in Figure 2 (panels A, B, and C), all 
samples of maws have a band pattern different to that of cod flesh which was used as a control.  
A set of bands at approximately 150 kDa, and a (sometimes) vague band at around 50 kDa is 
present in all maw samples.  There are some individual differences as well.  For example, 
samples FA 1/2/05 and FA 13/05 show protein bands at approximately 20 kDa.  
 
A noteworthy difference occurred in maw extracts prepared with salt versus without salt.  The 
overall intensity of proteins bands was higher for all maw samples (except for FL 17/18/05) in 
extracts prepared with physiological salt concentration.  More specifically, the protein band at 
approximately 150 kDa was not present or was barely visible in extracts prepared without salt. 
There are some additional differences between extracts with or without salt, varying for each 
species.  When SDS-PAGE sample buffer was used for extraction, the overall intensity of 
staining was much higher.  Furthermore, an additional band at approximately 20 kDa was found 
in all samples.  Sample J52/04 had the lowest intensity of this band.  It is unlikely that this band 
is parvalbumin for two reasons.  First, the molecular weight is different.  Second, parvalbumin is 
water/salt extractable by definition.  It cannot be excluded, though, that parvalbumin is present in 
the maw extracts based on this SDS-PAGE analysis even though no noteworthy bands were 
visible in the 12kDa region. 
 
Qualitative analysis (Bradford)
 
The protein concentration of all fish flesh and fish maw extracts was determined using Bradford 
analysis (Table 3.2).

For fish flesh extracts, minor differences in protein concentration were found between the 
various extraction buffers.  Only sample F 21/05 shows a substantially lower protein 
concentration.  This is the sample that arrived at Podiceps in non-frozen, mold covered Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 14 of 28 
  
condition. For the other samples,  the protein concentration ranges from approximately 2.2 to 4.4 
mg/ml. More noteworthy differences in protein concentrations were found for extracts made 
from the flesh of the different fish species.  
 
For fish maw extracts, lower protein concentrations were found.  Differences in protein 
concentration were found in comparisons between the different extraction buffers.  Differences 
were also noted in the protein concentrations prepared from maws of different species.  In fact, 
extracts prepared in the absence of physiological concentrations of salt show a much lower 
protein concentration as compared to extracts prepared with salt.  These data are in line with the 
results of the SDS-PAGE analysis (Figure 2A, B, and C).  
 
Selection of extraction buffer
 
The choice of extraction buffer (water, 0.9% NaCl, and PBS) had little effect on the protein band 
pattern encountered with SDS-PAGE and the protein yield as determined by the Bradford assay 
for fish flesh.  However, for the maw extracts, a substantially higher yield and a richer band 
pattern was obtained when extracts were prepared in the presence of physiological 
concentrations of salt.  
 
SDS-PAGE sample buffer was used to prepare extracts as controls.  Due to the presence of the 
detergent SDS and the reducing agent DTT, protein extraction becomes more efficient, resulting 
in higher yields and additional proteins that get solubilized.  However, the nature of this buffer 
makes it not suitable for the skin testing aspects of this investigation (results not yet available). 
 
The decision was made to select PBS as the extraction buffer and to exclude fish sample F 21/05 
from production of skin test extracts.  The production of skin test extracts will be described later 
in conjuction with the results of the skin test trials. 
 
The extracts described in this section of the report were subsequently used with the cod 
parvalbumin ELISA to assess the parvalbumin content of the fish flesh and maw samples used in 
the manufacturing of isinglass (see Section V below). 
 
IV. Western Immunoblot of Rabbit Anti-Codfish Parvalbumin Antibody 
 
Lead Scientists:   Stef J. Koppelman, Ph.D., AllerTeQ, The Netherlands 
         Martin Hessing, Ph.D., Podiceps B.V., The Netherlands 
         Sue L. Hefle, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
 
A. Introduction: 
Western blotting of the rabbit anti-codfish parvalbumin antibody against fish flesh and maws 
was carried out in order to ascertain which band(s) in fish flesh and maws would be recognized 
by the antisera. 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 15 of 28 
  
B. Materials and Methods: 
 
SDS-PAGE-separated proteins were transferred to PVDF membrane by electroblotting according 
to the method of Towbin et al. (1979). After blocking, the membranes were incubated with 
affinity purified anti-cod parvalbumin antibodies. Bound anti-cod parvalbumin IgG was detected 
with peroxidase-labelled goat-anti-rabbit-IgG antibodies using the DAB staining method.  
  
 C.  Results & Discussion: 
The Westen blot indicates that all fish muscle extracts reacted with affinity-purified antibodies 
against cod parvalbumin, with some differences in reactivity (Figure 4, upper panel).  Maws 
were analyzed as well (Figure 4, lower panel).  In maws, the parvalbumin was only vaguely 
visible for F21/05 and other extracts did not show any reacting parvalbumin.  While parvalbumin 
seems present in fish muscle on the basis of Western blots, parvalbumin was not detected using 
the same antibodies in the ELISA (see following section).  This may be explained by the fact that 
epitopes are under native condition in the ELISA and not as readily accessible to the anti-
parvalbumin antibodies.

V. ELISA for Detecting Cod Parvalbumin  
 
 Lead Scientists:  Stef J. Koppelman, Ph.D., AllerTeQ, The Netherlands 
        Martin Hessing, Ph.D., Podiceps B.V., The Netherlands 
        Sue L. Hefle, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
 
A.  Introduction: 
 
With the production of purified cod parvalbumin (see Section I) and anti-cod parvalbumin 
antisera (see Section II), the development of an ELISA for cod parvalbumin was possible.  
Although the existing ELISAs using anti-frog and anti-carp parvalbumin monoclonal antibodies 
seemed reasonably good, the cod parvalbumin ELISA was developed because an ELISA based 
upon polyclonal antisera might have broader specificity to detect parvalbumins from a wider 
range of species. 
 
B. Methods & Materials 
 
Inhibition ELISA
 
An indirect ELISA utilizing the rabbit anti-cod parvalbumin antibodies was initially developed. 
The antibodies were purified using Protein G (Pierce Chemical Co., Rockford, IL, USA) before 
use. Using the indirect ELISA in a quantitative determination, a cod extract was analyzed for cod 
parvalbumin content. The extract contained 0.3 ± 0.2 mg/ml cod parvalbumin, in line with an 
average protein concentration of 2-3 mg/ml. However, further development and testing of the 
inhibition ELISA was abrogated because it was found that a sandwich-type format ELISA was 
more suitable for quantification of analyte concentrations close to the detection limit. 
 
Sandwich ELISA
 
All sandwich ELISA experiments were performed with a capture antibody of Protein G-purified 
rabbit anti-parvalbumin antibody (1 µg/ml) and peroxidase-conjugated, affinity-purified rabbit 
anti-parvalbumin antibody (500 fold diluted) as the detector antibody. Blocking of remaining 
sites on the microtiter plate was done with 0.01 M phosphate buffered saline, pH 7.4 (PBS) 
containing 3% BSA. The incubation buffer was PBS containing 0.5% BSA and 0.2% Tween 20 
and the washing buffer consisted of PBS containing 0.2% Tween 20. 
 
Fish and Fish Maws (Swim Bladders)
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006

The commercial manufacturers of isinglass (study sponsors) provided samples of fish muscle 
tissue and fish maws (common name for swim bladders). 
 
C. Results: 
 
Specificity of the Cod Parvalbumin ELISA
 
The substances shown in Table 5.1 were used for cross-reactivity testing. Samples were from a 
Dutch supermarket except for peanut, corn, soy flour and wheat flour which were obtained from 
food ingredient suppliers. Extracts were made by mixing 1 part of (ground, if necessary) sample 
plus 5 parts of extraction buffer (PBS) for two hours at room temperature, then clarified using 
centrifugation (15 minutes at 4 °C, 4000 rpm).

Figure 5.2 (continued). Spiking of matrices with purified cod parvalbumin. 
X-axis: purified cod parvalbumin (µg/ml, abbreviated PA). 
 
The data in Figure 5.2 show that isinglass does not inhibit the reactivity of parvalbumin in the 
sandwich ELISA substantially. Therefore, traces of potentially present parvalbumin should not 
be hindered from recognition by the matrix.  The matrix with most interference is isinglass.  At 
half-maximal reactivity (absorbance approximately 0.35), the difference in reactivity of 
parvalbumin in a 10-fold diluted isinglass extract is estimated to be 2 to 4-fold.  This should be 
considered when measuring the parvalbmin content in samples of isinglass that are diluted only 
10-fold. 
 
Reactivity of extracts of fish and maw in sandwich ELISA
 
Extracts of fish and maw samples were prepared and tested in several dilutions in duplicate.   
Figure 5.3 shows the results for fish and maw extracts.

is corrected for plateau height (absorbance at saturating parvalbumin concentrations). Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 24 of 28 
  
 
The majority of the samples did not react substantially.  In the fish extracts, parvalbumin was 
present based on SDS-PAGE patterns and immunoblotting with anti-cod parvalbumin antisera  .  
It was expected that the fish samples would be more reactive than the maw samples, but the 
contrary was observed.  Maw samples F21/05 and FL13/04 were most reactive. For F21/05 there 
was no usable fish extract (sample arrived moldy), and fish extract FL13/04 shows a lower 
response than maw sample FL13/04.  Of the fish samples, FA 13/05 is most reactive; again no 
dose dependence is observed and the maximum signal is far lower than that of purified 
parvalbumin. 
 
Even although the data show that the tested samples do not react substantially, data from Figure 
3.2 were calculated using the calibration curve of purified cod parvalbumin. Limit of 
quantification is 0.2 ug/g (ppm). Table 5.2 shows the results of the analysis of fish and fish maw 
samples for parvalbumin using the cod parvalbumin antiserum.  
 
Table 5.2. Fish and maw samples measured in cod parvalbumin sandwich ELISA 
Sample 
Mean ug/g (ppm) cod parvalbumin* 
FL 13/04 (Fish) <0.2 
FA 1/2/05 (fish) <0.2

* Results based on the assumption that all soluble parvalbumin is extracted and has comparable 
immunoreactivity as cod parvalbumin. 
 
All of the tested fish species extracts have parvalbumin, based on SDS-PAGE and 
immunoblotting.  However, with the exception of cod, these fish extracts do not react in the 
ELISA.  While some of the maw samples gave weak positive results in this parvalbumin ELISA, 
these preliminary results are of only limited value.  It may be that the extraction procedure does 
not recover 100% of the parvalbumin, but it was clearly shown that a 12 kDa band was present 
in the extracts, comparable to extraction in the presence of SDS in the SDS-PAGE studies.  
Thus, incomplete recovery cannot explain the lack of reactivity of the extracts in the sandwich 
ELISA for cod parvalbumin. 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 25 of 28 
  
Analysis of 11 samples of fish isinglass 
Eleven samples of isinglass were analyzed with the sandwich ELISA for cod parvalbumin.  
Table 5.3 shows the results.  
 
It is important to note that the fish species tested within the framework of this project (except 
cod) do not react substantially in the cod parvalbumin ELISA, even although there is evidence 
for the presence of parvalbumin, based on SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting results. 
 
Table 5.3. Isinglass samples measured in cod parvalbumin sandwich ELISA 
 
Sample Measured cod parvalbumin 
equivalents, ug/g (ppm)*

Isinglass paste (10%), frozen 
sample 1 
0.225 ± 0.105

Isinglass powder, blend 3 3.28 ± 3.27

50606229  
0.90 ± 0..575  
Caskleer paste 0.60 ± 0.42  
*Detection limit is 0.20 ug/g (ppm) 
 
Table 5.3 shows that low levels of parvalbumin are detectable in isinglass samples.  Dilutions of 
isinglass were not parallel with dilutions of cod parvalbumin, and true quantification therefore is 
not possible. The non-parallelism is illustrated by the high standard deviation (same order of 
magnitude as response), and by the increasing calculated value for higher diluted extracts (data 
not shown here).  The non-parallelism may be caused by differences in the affinity of cod 
parvalbumin and parvalbumin of other fishes to the anti-cod parvalbumin antibodies.  
Differences between isinglass samples are apparent.  These may be explained by differences in 
parvalbumin content, but due to the issues mentioned above, this is not conclusive.  It should 
furthermore be taken into consideration that isinglass matrix inhibits the signal of cod 
parvalbumin slightly (2 to 4 fold). Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-08-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 26 of 28 
  
 D.  Discussion: 
 
A sandwich ELISA was successfully developed for detection of cod parvalbumin using anti-cod 
parvalbumin polyclonal antisera.  The ELISA is specific for parvalbumin and does not 
substantially cross-react with common food ingredients. The ELISA could detect cod 
parvalbumin spiked into isinglass.  The sensitivity of the cod parvalbumin ELISA at 0.20 µg/g is 
excellent and equivalent or superior to commercial ELISAs for peanut, gluten, and β-
lactoglobulin.  These results suggested that the sandwich ELISA could be used for measuring 
residual parvalbumin in isinglass and in  other food matrices. Furthermore, purified parvalbumin 
spiked into beer and wine is not substantially inhibited.  However, some decrease of parvalbumin 
reactivity was observed when purified parvalbumin was spiked into isinglass.  
 
Although the tested fish flesh samples display a 12 kDa protein band on SDS-PAGE that is 
reactive with the anti-cod parvalbumin antiserum (see Figure 4.1), attempts to absolutely 
quantitate the level of parvalbumin in extracts of the muscle tissues and maws of fish species 
used to manufacture isinglass by ELISA were not successful.  Five of 6 maws did not react 
either; in one of the maws, some reactivity was found.  As noted above, several possible reasons 
exist for these unexpected results.  One possibility is the the specificity of the polyclonal anti-
cod parvalbumin antiserum is not suitable for the detection of parvalbumin in the muscles or 
maws of these particular species.  However, further research might well allow use of this 
antiserum or some combination of this antiserum with the anti-carp and anti-frog parvalbumin 
monoclonal antibodies described elsewhere (see FARRP-07-2006)  for the development of an 
ELISA that would be reliable for detection of parvalbumin in these muscle and maw extracts.  
This research group simply ran out of time to solve this technical problem in meeting the EFSA 
deadline for submission of data.  Certainly, it would be premature to conclude that these fish and 
maw samples have low or no parvalbumin. 
 
Curiously, parvalbumin could be detected at low levels in isinglass samples even though it could 
not be detected in extracts of muscle or maws of the species of fish used to prepare the isinglass.  
The reasons for this result are not clear.  The quantitative estimation of parvalbumin levels in 
isinglass is not reliable based upon the problems with the current anti-cod fish parvalbumin 
ELISA method.  However, the levels of residual parvalbumin in isinglass are definitely quite 
low, although it is impossible to indicate exactly how low.  As noted previously, because of the 
water solubility of parvalbumins, the expectation would be that the parvalbumin is removed from 
isinglass during the washing steps of the isinglass-manufacturing process.  However, fish 
collagen is used commercially for its ability to entrap and remove materials including proteins 
from alcoholic beverages.  Thus, it is not surprising that low levels of parvalbumin might remain 
despite extensive washing.  
 
 
 
 E. References:

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Appendix 3 
 
 
 
 
 
An investigation into typical residues of isinglass  
present in beers fined with isinglass.

    London SW8 5NQ
