    Lyttel Hall, Nutfield, Surrey, RH1 4HY 
    U K  
 
 
Date of report:  March 2006 
 
 
Study Director  Dr E Denise Baxter 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Appendix 3 
 
Study Number       BP 04-04 
 
 
Study Director       Dr E Denise Baxter 
 
 
C o - a u t h o r s         D r  R  E  M u l l e r  
         M r s  G  F i s h e r  
 
 
S t u d y  c o m p l e t e d         M a r c h  2 0 0 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Acceptance of final report 
 
 
 
    31.3.06 
……………………………………………………………………………………………….. 
 
 
Dr E Denise Baxter     Date 
Regulatory Affairs Director    
                                                            Page        of   17 2Appendix 3 
Index of contents 
 
           Page 
 
E x e c u t i v e  s u m m a r y          4  
 
Introduction and background       5 
 
Experimental approaches        5 
 
Materials and methods      7  
    
   Preparation and testing of the antibody      7 
 
   Separation of isinglass residues from beer      9 
 
   Hydrolysis of residues to constituent amino acids and derivatisation 9 
 
   Quantification of hydroxyproline      10 
 
   Correlation of hydroxyproline with isinglass      11 
 
   Survey of commercial small-pack beers      12 
 
   Cask-conditioned beers      12 
 
   Keg beer      12   
 
R e s u l t s           1 3  
 
    Brewery-conditioned small-pack beers     13 
 
    Brewery-conditioned keg beer       14 
 
    Cask-conditioned beer        14 
 
 
Discussion and Conclusions       15 
 
R e f e r e n c e s           1 6  
                                                            Page        of   17 3Appendix 3 
Executive Summary 
 
Traditionally, many types of beer are clarified (fined) by the addition of isinglass, which is a 
pure form of fish collagen. The isinglass combines with proteins and yeast in suspension in 
the beer, causing the formation of large flocs which sediment out of the beer. In some 
beers these flocs are removed in the brewery by filtration of centrifugation. Such beers are 
described as brewery-conditione d beers. However, in some beer styles (known as cask-
conditioned beers) the flocs ar e not removed but form a compact sediment at the bottom 
of the container (the cask). Only the beer above this sediment is marketable. 
 
A method has been developed wher eby residual isinglass presen t in fined beers can be 
concentrated by means of an antibody raised using isinglass as an antigen. The separated 
isinglass can then be hydrolysed to its consti tuent acids and quantifie d by measuring the 
content of hydroxyproli ne, which is an imino acid present in significant quantities only in 
animal collagens. The limit of quant ification of this method, t hat is the concentration of 
isinglass in beer which can be distinguished fr om background levels of hydroxyproline, is 
0.17 mg of isinglass / litre of beer (on an isinglass dry weight basis).  
 
This method has been used to quantify the concentration of isinglass residues which could 
be present in brewery- and cask-conditioned beers, and also to determine whether there is 
likely to be stratification of residues in casks, such that beer drawn from a position close to 
the bottom of the cask but still clear enough to be marketable, could nevertheless contain 
significantly higher concentrations of isinglass.  
 
The results indicate that residues in many bottled and canned beers fine d with isinglass in 
the brewery are below t he limit of quantificati on of the method. Wher e isinglass could be 
quantified, the highest concentrations found did not exceed 1mg/litre. 
 
For large containers (kegs and casks), isinglass concentrations were on ly slightly higher. 
Residues in kegs were also generally below 1 mg/litre, although occasional samples could 
contain up to 3 mg/litre. For cask-conditioned beer s, the highest concentration of isinglass 
found did not exceed 5 mg/litre. 
 
There was no evidence of stratification of residues within either casks or kegs. The 
concentration of isinglass in noticeably hazy beer (that is, beer drawn from just above the 
level of sedimented material) was marginally  higher than in the bulk, but still below 5 
mg/litre.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                            Page        of   17 4Appendix 3 
Introduction and Background 
 
Isinglass is used as a clarif ying (fining) agent in brewing. It is added at a low dosage 
(typically 15 mg/litre; total range 10 - 70 mg/ litre) to the beer after fermentation, where it 
reacts with yeast and proteins, forming large flo cs. These flocs are removed from the bulk 
of the liquid by filtration, centrifugation or sedimentation. Thus practically all the isinglass is 
removed and the product as presented to the c onsumer contains only small quantities of 
residues.  
 
Although isinglass has been widely used as a clarifying agent for centuries, extensive 
searches of the scientific and medical litera ture have not identified any documented cases 
of allergy due to the isinglass. This absence of documented evidence of allergic reactions 
to isinglass in beer suggests that such a response, if it exists at all, is extremely rare.  
 
New, comprehensive studies into the potential allergenicity of  isinglass have been carried 
out and are reported elsewhere in this dossier. The potential for allergenic reactions to 
occur is also influenced by the amount of residues consumed. Little robust data is 
available in the lit erature relating to the concentrations of isinglass which remain in fined 
beers.  This section of the dossier therefore reports on st udies carried out in order to 
quantify more precisely the amount of isinglass present in typical fined beers and also to 
define the maximum range of residue levels whic h could remain in t he beer in a worst 
case.  
 
 
Experimental approaches 
 
Analysis of residues 
The measurement of isinglas s residues in beer is complicated by three factors in 
particular; 
• The concentration of residues is expected to be low, so one or more concentration 
steps would be required 
• Isinglass is a protein; beer contains several other proteins  in addition to isinglass, 
and these are present in much larger quantities, making  identification and 
separation difficult 
• The isinglass residues may include fragments,  making it difficult to separate or 
identify them using methods based on molecular weight.  
 
In the current study, it was decided that th e best approach would be to use an antibody 
raised against isinglass. This would not only introduce specificity and provide a valuable 
concentration step, but should also allow for the detection of more of the smaller fragments 
of isinglass which might not be precipitated by ammonium sulphate alone.   
 
The antibody would be used to collect and c oncentrate the isinglass residues from a 
sample of beer.  In order to quantify these residues use was made of the unusual amino 
acid content of isinglass. Isinglass is a pu re form of collagen, which is characterised by 
presence of hydroxyproline. This  imino acid is rare in other  proteins but is key to the 
structure and functionality of isinglass. The hydroxyl group of hydroxyproline stabilises the 
helical structure of collagen thro ugh the formation of H bonds (Moir et al, 1984). As there 
is no other source of collagen in the bre wing process, and since hydroxyproline is not 
                                                            Page        of   17 5Appendix 3 
present in significant quantit ies in proteins other than collagen, measurement of 
hydroxyproline in the hydrolyse d residues provides a specific  means of quantification of 
isinglass. 
 
Cask-conditioned beers 
For the overwhelming majority (over 90%) of  fined beers, whether destined for canning, 
bottling or draught, isinglass residues are removed in the brewery by filtration or 
centrifugation. Cask-conditio ned beer, however, (often described as “real ale”) is a 
traditional style of be er and is unique to the UK. It r epresents an important traditional 
product, but is a niche market, and sales have continued to decline, from almost 17% of 
UK beer sales in 1980 to 6.6% in 2004 (British Beer and Pub Assoc. 2005).   
 
Figure 1.  Sales of UK cask-conditioned beer; 1990 – 2005 
        
2
3
4
5
6

1993

1995
1996

2005(p)
Million Hectolitres
  
Source: British Beer and Pub Association 
 
Nevertheless, consumers of cask ales tend to be loyal to this product type, and could 
drink, on average, around 12 pint s (6.8 litres) per week. T he typical cask ale consumer 
tends to be in the 35+ age gr oup (Table 1) with a high fr equency-low volume consumption 
pattern rather than the low frequency-high volume pattern which is more common amongst 
younger consumers.  
 
Table 1. Proportion of total UK beer volumes consumed by different age groups 
 
Beer Type 18 - 24 25 - 34 35 - 49 50+ 
All beer 16% 20% 29% 35% 
Cask ale 4% 8% 31% 57% 
 
(Source: AlcoVision 2004) 
                                                            Page        of   17 6Appendix 3 
 
In cask-conditioned beer, the yeast remains in the cask, and promotes flavour changes 
that contribute to the essential character of the final product. Is inglass is dosed either into 
the beer before filling or directly into the cask, at a rate of, typically, 50 mg/litre. The action 
of isinglass takes place gener ally within the first 3 to 4 hours after filling so that the 
flocculated solids (yeast plus isinglass plus protein) rapidly settle to the base of the cask, 
forming a compact sediment. The beer is drawn from the cask to a point above the 
sediment. For this style of beer, the beer serv ed must be bright (i.e. no cloudiness) and be 
free of suspended particles. Clo udy beer is not acceptable to  the consumer. In order to 
facilitate the dispense of clear beer, and to  avoid drawing on the sedimented material, 
there is a gap between the bottom of the cask and the position of the tap. This means that 
a certain volume of beer, generally around 2 litres, is not dispensed. This, which is known 
as the ullage, contains the sedimented material, together wit h the overwhelming majority 
of the isinglass. However, it is theoretically possible that t here could be some stratification 
of isinglass residues within the bulk of the ca sk, with lower layers of dispensable beer 
potentially containing more isinglass than t he higher levels. This possibility has been 
investigated in order to establish what the “worst case” expo sure might be for the 
consumer. 
 
Figure 2.  Diagrammatic representation of a cask when it is almost empty, showing 
the position of the contents and tap 
 
  
Lowest level of 
beer likely to be 
of marketable 
quality 
 
Ullage 
 
  
 
 
Materials and Methods 
 
Preparation and testing of the Antibody 
Polyclonal antibodies were raised in rabbits by the specialist company Biogenesis UK. The 
immunogens were commercial samples of pure isinglass (both powder and paste) 
                                                            Page        of   17 7Appendix 3 
provided by the major suppliers of commercial isinglass. Although processing details may 
vary between manufacturers, all commercial isinglass products are blends of material from 
the same limited range of tropical fish. Thus the isinglass samples used are expected to be 
representative of those marketed for fining beer. The antibodies pr ovided required some 
initial purification prior to use.  Serum was centrifuged at 12,000 rpm for 30 minutes at 4°C 
using a Beckman centrifuge.  The supernat ant was carefully poured off and the pellet 
discarded.  Ammonium sulphate was slowly added to the supernatant to achieve a final 
concentration of 30% (saturation), and then sti rred for 30 minutes at room temperature to 
encourage precipitation of IgG.  The mixture was centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 10 minutes 
at 4°C, then the supernatant was carefully re moved and the pellet re-suspended in 10 ml 
of 0.9% saline (w/v).  The ammonium sulphate precipitation procedure was repeated for a 
second time and the resulting pellet was re -suspended in 0.9% salin e.  The purified 
antibody solution was dialysed overnight in  phosphate buffered saline, using dialysis 
tubing with a 3.5 kDa molecular weight cut-off.   The antibody solution was stored in the 
fridge in the presence of 0.02% (w/v) sodium azide until required. 
 
The purified antibodies were tested against the immunogen usin g an ELISA protocol. The 
ELISA plates were coated with 1 µg of isinglass, using 200 μl of a solution of isinglass per 
well. Serial dilutions (10 fo ld) of the pre-immune and imm une sera were prepared at the 
same time. The antisera were in cubated in the treated wells at 37 oC for 30 minutes. The 
reaction was visualised with an alkaline ph osphatase-conjugated secondary antibody and 
para-nitrophenol phosphate at 405 nm. 
 
 
Figure 2.  ELISA testing of purified antibody 
0.00
0.50
1.00
1.50
2.00
2.50
3.00
1.E+00 1.E+01 1.E+02 1.E+03 1.E+04 1.E+05 1.E+06 1.E+07
 Dilution
OD 405nm
Pre-Immune
Terminal Bleed
 
Figure 2 shows the increase in absorbance associated with the immune serum when 
compared to the pre-immune serum. The great est difference in reaction was observed at 
1:500 dilution and therefore subs equent analysis was performed using this concentration 
of antibody.   
                                                            Page        of   17 8Appendix 3 
 
Separation of isinglass residues from beer 
The control beer used for method developm ent was a BRi standar d beer, prepared in the 
BRi pilot brewery without the use of isinglass.  
 
Beer was degassed overnight at room temperature. The pH of  the beer was adjusted to 
7.0, using a magnetic stirrer with drop-wise addition of 3M NaOH, allowing any precipitated 
materials to re-dissolve.  It was important that this was done slow ly and that the pH-
adjusted beer should still be bright. 
 
Antibody (200μl) was added to 100 ml of beer and the mixture was stirred gently at room 
temperature for 30 minutes. The antibody-ant igen complex was then precipitated using 
ammonium sulphate added to 30% saturation.   Again the ammonium sulphate was added 
slowly with constant gently stirring. (30% saturation required 17.6 g of ammonium sulphate 
per 100 ml of beer). The beer/ammonium sulphate mixture, wit h precipitated materials, 
was stirred for a further 30 minutes. 
 
The precipitate containing the antibody-isinglass complex was then collected by 
centrifugation (6500 rpm for 20 minutes) using round bottom centrifuge bottles.  The 
supernatant was discarded and the pellet was re -dissolved in 16 ml of 20 mM phosphate 
buffer pH 7, with vortexing. 
 
The re-dissolved antibody-isinglass complex was then dialysed against deionised water 
using Spectropore CE dialysis tubing. This dialysis tubing has a molecular weight cut off of 
3.5 kDa (equivalent to approxim ately 25-30 amino acid residu es).  Dialysis was for 20 
hours with three changes of water. The liquid wa s transferred from the dialysis tubing into 
round bottom flasks and frozen in solid carbon dioxide.  The samples were then reduced to 
dryness in a lyophiliser (usually 48 hours). Hydroxyproline content was then determined on 
these samples. 
 
Hydrolysis of residues to constituent amino acids and derivatisation.  
Test samples were reconstituted and hydrol ysed to their constituent amino acids using 
HCl. Two ml of 50% HCl was added to the r ound bottom flask to dissolve the sample 
which was then transferred to a 4 ml vial and the flask was rinsed with a further 2 ml of HCl 
which was also added to the vial. The seal ed vial was then heated for 4 hr at 100 °C then 
allowed to cool prior to derivatisation. 
 
Hydroxyproline and other amino acids in the hydrolysate we re derivatised and quantified 
were using a Phenomenex EZ:faast™ kit, accordi ng to the manufacturer’s instructions. In 
some cases the identity of the reagents was not  disclosed, the name used here is that 
provided by the kit manufacturers.   
Eluting Medium, Reagent 3, ( 200 µl) was added to 100 µl of hydrolysate, 95 µl KOH (400 
mg/ml) and 100 µl of Internal Standard (R eagent 1). After thorough mixing, 50 µl of 
Reagent 4 was added to the preparation vial. 
 
The mixture was emulsified by vortexing for 15 seconds and then allo wed to stand for at 
least 1 minute. During this period the amino acids were converted to derivatives which 
were more volatile than the original acids. 
 
                                                            Page        of   17 9Appendix 3 
The mixture was re-emulsified by vortexing for at least 15 seconds and again allowed to 
separate over a period of 1 minute.  Reagent 5 (50 µl) was then added to the mixture, 
which was vortexed for 15 seconds and allo wed to stand for 1 minute.  After phase 
separation, 400 µl of hexane was added to the vial. 
 
The upper, organic layer was removed to a cl ean vial and gently evaporated to near-
dryness under a stream of dry nitrogen gas. The residue was then re-dissolved in 100 µl of 
Tri-Sil TBT.  After 20 minutes , 500 µL of hexane was added to the vial followed by 500 µl 
of water.  The upper, organic layer was removed to a vial for GC-MS analysis. 
 
 
Quantification of Hydroxyproline 
Derivatised hydroxyproline was separated and quantified by gas chromatography with 
mass spectrophotometric detection. The GC -MS was fitted with a Phenomenex ZB-50 
column and operated in selected ion m onitoring mode. The quant ification ion for 
hydroxyproline was m/z 244,  with 158 and 142 as qualifier ions. Identification was 
confirmed from retention times and by matchi ng the qualifier ion rati os with those of the 
authentic compound.  Norvaline was used as the internal standard.  
 
Quantification was carried out using standard curves prepared by derivatisation of 
solutions of hydroxyproline over the range 0 - 200 nanomoles/ml. The limit of detection, 
defined as three times the signal  to noise ratio for a reagent blank, for hydroxyproline on 
the GC-MS was 40 picomoles/ml or 10 picogr ams injected. Allowing for the concentration 
of the beer during prepar ation of the samples, this corresp onds to a limit of detection of 
approximately 1 µg/litre of hydroxyproline in the beer. The limit of quantification for 
hydroxyproline in beer is approx imately three times the limit of detection, i.e. 3 µg/litre. 
Figures 3 and 4 show total ion and selected ion chromatograms respectively for a 50 
nmoles/ml hydroxyproline standard. 
 
 
Figure 3. Total ion chromatogram for 50 nmoles/ml  hydroxyproline standard 
   
 
               
  
 
 
                                                            Page        of   17 10Appendix 3 
Figure 4. Selection ion chromatogram for 50 nmoles/ml hydroxyproline standard  
 
 
 
 
Quantification 
ion 244 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Qualifier ion 158 
 
 
 
 
 
Qualifier ion 142 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Correlation of hydroxyproline with isinglass  
The values obtained from the GC-MS anal ysis were in terms of nanomoles of 
hydroxyproline. These had then to be converted to weights of isingl ass. A calibration was 
developed by hydrolyzing know n concentrations of isingl ass and analyzing them for 
hydroxyproline as described above (see Figure 5). 
 
 
 
Recovery 
The recovery of isinglass from beer was esti mated by adding a known weight of isinglass 
to beer produced in BRi’s pilot brewery without the use of isinglass, then analyzing aliquots 
using the antibody procedure as previously de scribed. At an addition rate of 2.26 mg 
isinglass (dry basis) / 100ml beer, the recovery ranged from 87 – 91.5%.   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                            Page        of   17 11Appendix 3 
Figure 5.  Correlation of hydroxyproline concentration to isinglass content 
 
R2 = 0.9905

mg isinglass
nmoles hydroxyproline 
derivative
 
 
  
Survey of commercial small pack beers 
Bottled and canned commercial beers were purchased in the UK in 2004/2005. Brands 
were chosen to include: 
• Different beer styles (lagers, ales, stouts) 
• Large national / international and small regional producers 
• Pack type (cans and bottles) 
• Beer known to be produced without isingl ass (produced in BRi’s pilot brewery) as 
well as brands known to be fined with isinglass  
 
Cask-conditioned beer 
A commercial brand of ale know n to use a high isinglass do se rate (72 mg/litre) was 
selected.  A cask was obtained  from commercial wholesal er, set up in the BRi beer 
dispense cellar at 12 °C, and allowed to settle for 3 days, as would be usual in commercial 
practice.  
The sampling protocol was designed to simulate a situation in a retail outlet in which beer 
is supplied to customers intermittently over several days. A 1 litre sample was taken via 
the tap and retained for analysis.  The next day several litres were drawn off and a further 
sample taken for analysis. This was repeated over the next week until the cask was almost 
empty and the beer sample was unaccept ably cloudy and would not have been 
marketable. This sample represents the beginnings of the ullage.  
 
In addition, single samples were taken of a number of other brands of  cask ale. In these 
cases the samples were taken when the casks were approximately half empty.  
 
Keg beer 
A keg containing an international brand of brewery-conditioned beer was set up in the BRi 
cellar and sampled as described for the ca sk-conditioned ale, except that, since 
sedimented material had been removed by filt ration in the brewery, the bottom samples 
remained clear and marketable.  
                                                            Page        of   17 12Appendix 3 
Results 
 
Background levels of hydroxyproline in beer 
In order to establish the backg round levels, if any, of hydr oxyproline in beer, control beers 
were prepared in the BRI pilo t brewery without using any is inglass. A total of eight 
samples, from 3 replicate all-malt brews, were taken and analysed for hydroxyproline 
using the antibody technique described. A mean concentration of 0.009 mg/litre of 
hydroxyproline was detected in the isingla ss free control beer. This background level, 
which corresponds to 0.17 mg/litre of isinglass,  was taken as the limit  of quantification of 
isinglass in beer. 
 
Brewery-conditioned small pack beers 
 
Table 2.  Isinglass residues in commercial bottled and canned beers 
 
 
Sample type mg hydroxyproline / 
litre beer

Table 2 lists the results for 13 commercial pa ckaged beers, including 8 ales which were 
known to be clarified in the brewery using is inglass. Hydroxyproline could be detected in 
all of the samples except for three ales. When this was converted to isinglass equivalents, 
                                                            Page        of   17 13Appendix 3 
it can be seen that all the la gers and one of the stout samples were below the limit of 
quantification for isinglass. Al though there was some variatio n between different samples, 
all contained less than 1 mg isinglass per litre of beer.  
 
Brewery-conditioned keg beer 
 
Table 3.  Isinglass residues in a brewery-conditioned keg beer 
 
Sample  mg hydroxyproline / litre

Table 3 shows the concentration  of isinglass residues found in  a brewery-conditioned keg 
beer dispensed over a period of time. Concent rations were slightly higher than in small-
pack beers, but the highest concentration found was below 3 mg/litre, with a mean of 1.0 
mg/litre. Although there was some variation in  isinglass concentrations, there was no 
evidence of any stratification of residues wit hin the keg and there was no accumulation of 
isinglass residues at the bottom of the keg.  
 
Cask-conditioned beer 
 
Table 4. Isinglass residues in a cask-conditioned ale 
 
Sample mg hydroxyproline / litre 
beer 
mg isinglass  / litre beer 
(dry weight basis) 
Day 1 0.101 1.9 
Day 2 0.140 2.7 
Day 3 0.087 1.7 
Day 4 0.104 2.0 
Day 7 0.044 0.9 
 
Day 7 - hazy 
 
0.187 
 
3.6 
 
Table 4 shows the concentration of isingl ass residues found in a cask-conditioned ale 
dispensed over a period of time. Within the bulk of the cask (t hat is, the beer which would 
be served to the customer) isinglass residues remained below 3 mg/ litre, with a mean of 
1.8 mg/litre and no evidence of stratification. The last sample which was drawn was 
noticeably hazy to the naked eye, and this cont ained a higher concentration of isinglass, 
                                                            Page        of   17 14Appendix 3 
3.6 mg/litre. Samples drawn fr om below this point represen ted the ullage, and contained 
visible yeast and protein clumps. The concentrati on of isinglass at this level was very high 
(> 100 mg/litre) but since it was associated with the solid material, the distribution was 
non-homogeneous and difficult to determine with any accuracy. 
 
Samples were also taken from a number of other brands of cask al e, including one micro-
brewery brand, and tested for isinglass residues. These were taken from casks 
approximately half empty. Results are shown in Table 5. 
 
Table 5. Isinglass residues in cask ales.  
 
Sample mg hydroxyproline / litre 
beer 
mg isinglass  / litre beer 
(dry weight basis) 
Brand 1 0.112 2.1 
Brand 2 0.029 0.6 
Brand 3 0.014 0.3 
Brand 4 0.117 2.2 
Brand 5 0.084 1.6 
Brand 6 0.219 4.2 
Brand 7 0.014 0.3 
 
Concentrations of isinglass in these 7 brands were similar to those found in the 
stratification study, with the highest concentr ation found being 4.2 mg/litre. This suggests 
that the cask chosen for the st ratification study was representative of other brands of cask 
ale.  
 
Discussion  
 
The studies reported here indicate that the overwhelming majority of the isinglass added to 
beer as a fining agent is either removed in the brewery (for brewer y-conditioned beers) or 
is contained in the sediments at the botto m of the cask (for cask-conditioned beers). In 
each case, the concentrations of isingla ss contained in the beer marketed and consumed 
by the drinker are extremely low. Precise quantif ication of the resi dues which could be 
consumed is complicated by the presence of a wide range of other proteins, by the likely 
heterogeneous nature of the isinglass residues themselves an d by the fact that the levels 
are close to the limits of quantification. These complications have undoubtedly reduced the 
precision of the determinations.  
 
Only a few other attempts to quantify isingla ss residues in beer hav e been reported. One 
method has been developed in New Zealand, (Hofman & MacDonald, 2002). The details 
of this method are not publicly available, bu t it is understood to be based on the classic 
biochemical principles of prec ipitation of the prot ein by ammonium su lphate, followed by 
separation of the protein molecu les on the basis of size and el ectrical charge. Using this 
method, levels of isinglass residues in a small number of commercial beers from Australia 
and New Zealand (all brewery- conditioned brands) were found to be in the range 0.02 - 
0.16 mg/litre (Hofman et al, 2002) . These values are similar to those found in the current 
study for small-pack brewery conditioned lagers. They ar e lower than some of the 
brewery-conditioned ales tested,  but this is not surprising given the different brewing 
styles. In addition, any method based on molecu lar size runs the risk of missing fragments 
                                                            Page        of   17 15Appendix 3 
which may (but also may not) have the same or  similar allergenic potential to the parent 
molecule.  One advantage of th e antibody method used in the pr esent study is that both 
parent molecule and larger fragments should be detected.  
 
Other groups have also used hydroxyproline measurement as a means of detecting or 
quantifying isinglass (Leach, 1969; Chlup et al, 2006). The first of these (Leach, 1969) 
was a colorimetric test, and was qualitative only, since the amount of hydroxyproline 
present was too small to quantify with the techniques available at that time. It was used for 
determining whether or not a beer had been fined with isinglass. More recently a group at 
the Heriot-Watt University in Scotland also  used determination of hydroxyproline as a 
method of quantifying isinglass residues in beer (Chlup et al, 2006). This group, who were 
not using any concentration techniques, found that although hydr oxyproline could be 
detected in cask beers immediately after the fi nings were added, the levels fell to below 
the limit of detection once the beer had settled (typically  2 -3 days).   
 
As previously noted, hydroxypro line is generally considered to occur at significant levels 
only in animal collagen. Howeve r, there are published reports in  the scientific literature of 
glycoproteins containing hydr oxyproline in higher plants (Cleland, 1968; Stuart and 
Varner, 1980).The current study did detec t low levels of hydroxyproline in beer which had 
not been treated with finings. This has not been previously reported, probably because 
methods have not been sufficiently sensitive. If barley contained similar proteins, any 
fragments remaining in the beer would hav e been concentrated by  the extraction 
procedure used in the study repor ted here. Thus the background levels of hydroxyproline 
detected in unfined beer are a likely consequence of the low limit of detection of the 
method used.  
 
In the current study, cask beer was sampled on a daily basis, over a total time period of 
one week, with the final samples being drawn from close to the sedimented material, 
where they appeared visibly cloudy. In fact, the flavour of a cask beer will begin to 
deteriorate if it is not cons umed within 3-4 days after tapping. Thus in commercial practice 
casks may be replaced before a ll the marketable beer has been consumed. Thus the 
maximum concentrations detected in this study are likely to represent a “worst case” as far 
as dietary exposure for the consumer is concerned.  
 
Conclusions 
 
The results of the study reported here confirm that the concentration of residues remaining 
in beers fined with isinglass is indeed very low. For many bottled and canned beers, levels 
of isinglass are below the lim it of quantification.  Slightly higher concentrations may be 
found in beers in large containers such as  kegs and casks, but even here the maximum 
concentrations would be likely to remain bel ow 5 mg/litre. There is no evidence of 
significant stratification of isinglass resi dues in the marketable beer in such bulk 
containers.  
 
 
                                                            Page        of   17 16Appendix 3 
 
References 
 
 
British Beer and Pub Association, Statistical Handbook 2005.  
 
Cleland, R., Plant Physiol. 1968 June; 43(6): 865–870. “Distribution and Metabolism of 
Protein-Bound Hydroxyproline in an Elongating Tissue, the Avena Coleoptile” 
 
Chlup, P.H., Leiper, K.A.  and Stewart, G.G., 2006, J. Instit. Brewing, 112 (1), 3-8, “A 
method of detection of residual isinglass in filtered and cask-conditioned beers.” 
 
Hofman, K., Bulling, K. and Chadderton, T.C., 2002, Crop and Food Research Confidential 
Reports Nos. 703,713 and 719. 
 
Leach, A.A., 1969, J. Instit. Brewing, 75, 443-445. “The detection of isinglass finings in 
beer.” 
 
Moir, A.J.G., Mathews, A.J. D., and Morson, B.T.,1984, Proc. Conv. Inst.  Brew. (Aust.NZ 
Section), Adelaide,18, 121-126. "Identification of Finings" 
 
Stuart, D.A. and Varner, J.E., Plant Physiol. 1980 November; 66(5): 787–792. “ Purification 
and Characterization of a Salt-extractable Hydroxyproline-rich Glycoprotein from Aerated 
Carrot Discs”.  
Westrupp, A.V., Hofman K.A. and MacDonald, G.A. 2002, Proc. Conv. Inst. Guild Brew . 
(Asia Pacific Sect.), Adelaide, 27, 1 p. "A Novel Highly Functi onal Fining Agent from New 
Zealand Hoki Collagen". 
 
 
 
                                                            Page        of   17 17

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.

Allergenicity

2.0 LITERATURE SEARCH METHODOLOGY ................................................................................................... 2

Table 2.2-1 Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria Used to Filter the Identified Literature .................................. 3 
Table 3-1 List of Studies Pertaining to the Allergenicity of Parvalbumin or Isinglass ............................... 5 
  CONFIDENTIAL 
  
 
 
Mascoma LLC 
18 July 2025 2 
Literature Search Report for Parvalbumin and Isinglass 
Allergenicity  
1.0 INTRODUCTION 
The objective of this report is to outline a search strategy and identify pertinent scientific literature related 
to the allergenicity of parvalbumin or isinglass used in beer production. Intertek Health Sciences Inc. 
therefore conducted a comprehensive literature search using the electronic search tool ProQuest Dialog™ 
(ProQuest) on 20 June 2025. Details of the search strategy, including the inclusion/exclusion criteria for 
literature filtration, are provided in Section 2.0. The results of the literature search are provided in Section 
3.0. 
2.0 LITERATURE SEARCH METHODOLOGY 
2.1 Search Strategy 
The following databases were searched using ProQuest: Adis Clinical Trials Insight, AGRICOLA, AGRIS, 
Allied & Complementary Medicine™, BIOSIS® Toxicology, BIOSIS Previews®, CAB ABSTRACTS, Embase®, 
Foodline®: SCIENCE, FSTA®, MEDLINE®, NTIS: National Technical Information Service, ToxFile®, and 
Toxicology Abstracts.  
Keywords related to the test article (i.e., parvalbumin or isinglass) were searched in combination with 
keywords related to its use in the brewing of alcoholic beverages (e.g., beer, wine, brew, alcohol). Results 
were further refined using keywords related to allergenicity including terms related to allergenicity, 
hypersensitivity, and anaphylaxis.  
For an article to be identified, at least 1 keyword from each of the relevant combined sets of keywords had 
to appear either in the title, abstract, or body of the text. The search terms and strategy are presented in 
Table 2.1-1 below. 
Table 2.1-1 Search Strategy Used to Retrieve Literaturea 
Set # Search Terms  Number of Titles 
S1 Parvalbumin or isinglass 36,147b 
S2 s1 and (beer or wine or brew* or alcohol*) 866 
S3 S2 and (allerg* or hypersensitiv* OR hypersensitiz* OR hypersensitis* or anaphyla*) 77 
a For an article to be identified, at least 1 keyword from each of the relevant combined sets of keywords had to appear either in 
the title, abstract, or body of the article. The asterisk indicates a truncation so as not to place a limitation on the word ending 
(e.g., “allerg*” would result in the identification of “allergen,” “allergies,” and “allergenicity”). 
b Duplicates are included in the results count.  CONFIDENTIAL 
  
 
 
Mascoma LLC 
18 July 2025 3 
2.2 Literature Filtration 
Once the search strategy was implemented and the publication titles were retrieved, the relevance of the 
publications was determined at 3 stages using the titles, abstracts, and full texts of the publications. At each 
stage, the exclusion criteria listed in Table 2.2-1 were applied to determine literature relevance. The 
3 stages of literature filtration are outlined below in greater detail. 
Stage 1: Titles of articles were reviewed, and abstracts of titles determined to be potentially relevant 
were retrieved. 
Stage 2:  Abstracts were reviewed, and full-length articles of abstracts determined to be potentially 
relevant were retrieved. 
Stage 3:  Full-length articles were reviewed, and those determined to meet any one of the exclusion 
criteria specified in Table 2.2-1 were excluded. 
Table 2.2-1 Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria Used to Filter the Identified Literature 
Inclusion Criteria 
• The substance studied was relevant to parvalbumin or isinglass and its use in the brewing of alcoholic beverages 
• The publication was a full-length article published in a peer-reviewed journal 
• The publication investigated allergenicity parameters 
Exclusion Criteria 
• The substance studied was not relevant to parvalbumin or isinglass and its use in the brewing of alcoholic beverages 
• The publication was a full-length article published in a non-peer-reviewed source (website, magazine, etc.) 
• The publication was published in abstract form only or as a short communication (conference abstract, letter to the editor, 
commentary, etc.) 
• The publication did not consider allergenicity parameters 
• The study was a duplicate record in the literature search 
• The full publication study report was not in English language 
3.0 LITERATURE SEARCH RESULTS 
As illustrated in Figure 3-1, the literature search resulted in the identification of 77 potentially relevant 
titles, and abstracts were retrieved for 17 of the records. Of the 17 abstracts, 12 were considered to be 
potentially relevant, and the full-length articles were retrieved. Of the full-length articles assessed, 2 met 
the exclusion criteria; therefore, 10 full-length studies were identified pertaining to the allergenicity of 
parvalbumin or isinglass used in beer production. A list of the 10 full-length studies identified as relevant to 
the allergenicity of isinglass or parvalbumin in the brewing of alcoholic beverages is presented in Table 3-1. 
The results of the title search are provided in Appendix A.  CONFIDENTIAL

Investigation of the allergenic potential of wines fined with various proteinogenic fining agents by ELISA  
 
Author: Weber, P; Steinhart, H; Paschke, A 
 
Publication details: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry 55.8 p.3127-3133 (Apr 18, 2007): p. 3127-3133. 
 
Abstract (English):  
Hidden allergens are a common problem in food safety that has been known for many years. This is why the European Parliament 
adopted Directive 2003/89/EC amending 2000/13/EC. In addition to specific ingredients, Directive 2003/89/EC also requests the 
declaration of specific products that were used in the production and could be a risk for allergic individuals. This also includes the 
declaration of fining agents and lysozyme used in wines. In fact, it could be assumed that fining agents would be almost 
completely removed during the manufacturing process; however, until now there has been no necessity to analyze wine for these 
fining agents. By applying enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), residuals of fining agent proteins and the stabilizer 
lysozyme were investigated in various German wines. The results showed no detectable amounts of fining agents in wines, except 
for dried egg white and lysozyme, both derived from hen's egg white. For those products, adverse reactions against treated wines 
could not be excluded. 
Potential food allergens in wine: double-blind, placebo-controlled trial and basophil activation analysis  
 
Author: Rolland, Jennifer M 1 ; Apostolou, Effie; Deckert, Kirsten; de Leon, Maria P; Douglass, Jo A; Glaspole, Ian N; Bailey, 
Michael; Stockley, Creina S; O'Hehir, Robyn E 1 Department of Immunology, Monash University, Melbourne, Australia, Australia 
 
Publication details: Nutrition (Burbank, Los Angeles County, Calif.) 22.9 (Sep 2006): 882-8. 
 
Abstract (English):  
OBJECTIVE 
Recent Australian and international legislation requires labeling of wines made by using the potentially allergenic food proteins 
casein, milk, egg white, or isinglass (fish-derived) where “there is a detectable residual processing aid.” We investigated whether 
wines fined using these proteins or non-grape-derived tannins (tree-nut derived) can provoke significant clinical allergic reactions 
(anaphylaxis) in patients with confirmed immunoglobulin E-mediated relevant food allergy. 
 
METHODS 
A double-blind, placebo-controlled trial was performed to determine whether allergic reactions followed consumption of 
Australian commercial wines fined using one or more of the legislation-targeted food proteins. In addition, allergenicity of a larger 
panel of these wines was evaluated by blood basophil activation. 
 
RESULTS 
No anaphylaxis was induced by wine consumption. Three mild clinical reactions to protein-fined wine and two mild reactions to 
unfined wine occurred, but there was no statistically significant difference in reaction parameters between subject groups or 
between processing aids. No pattern of basophil activation correlated with wine type, processing aid, or subject group. 
 
CONCLUSION 
Wines fined with egg white, isinglass, or non-grape-derived tannins present an extremely low risk of anaphylaxis to fish-, egg-, or 
peanut-allergic consumers. Although consumption of milk protein-fined wine did not induce anaphylaxis, there were insufficient 
subjects to determine statistically whether wines fined with milk proteins present a risk to the very rare milk-allergic consumers. 
In summary, the observed lack of anaphylaxis and basophil activation induced by wines made using the legislation-targeted food 
proteins according to good manufacturing practice suggests negligible residual food allergens in these wines.  CONFIDENTIAL

Development of animal models and sandwich-ELISA tests to detect the allergenicity and antigenicity of fining agent residues in 
wines  
 
Author: Lifrani, Awatif 1 ; Dos Santos, Jacinthe; Dubarry, Michel; Rautureau, Michelle; Blachier, Francois; Tome, Daniel 1 INRA, 
CRNH-IdF, UMR Nutrition Physiology and Ingestive Behavior, Paris, France, France 
 
Publication details: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry 57.2 (Jan 28, 2009): 525-34. 
 
Abstract (English):  
Food allergy can cause food-related anaphylaxis. Food allergen labeling is the principal means of protecting sensitized individuals. 
This motivated European Directive 2003/89 on the labeling of ingredients or additives that could trigger adverse reactions, which 
has been in effect since 2005. During this study, we developed animal models with allergy to ovalbumin, caseinate, and isinglass 
in order to be able to detect fining agent residues that could induce anaphylactic reactions in sensitized mice. The second aim of 
the study was to design sandwich ELISA tests specific to each fining agent in order to detect their residue antigenicity, both during 
wine processing and in commercially available bottled wines. Sensitized mice and sandwich ELISA methods were established to 
test a vast panel of wines. The results showed that although they were positive to our highly sensitive sandwich-ELISA tests, some 
commercially available wines are not allergenic in sensitized mice. Commercially available bottled wines made using standardized 
processes, fining, maturation, and filtration, do not therefore represent any risk of anaphylactic reactions in sensitized mice. 
Allergenicity of wine containing processing aids: a double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenge  
 
Author: Kirschner, S 1 ; Belloni, B; Kugler, C; Ring, J; Brockow, K 1 Department of Dermatology and Allergy Biederstein, Technische 
Universität München, Munich, Germany, Germany 
 
Publication details: Journal of Investigational Allergology & Clinical Immunology 19.3 (2009): 210-7. 
 
Abstract (English):  
BACKGROUND 
The European Union requires allergenic food ingredients to appear on labels in order to protect allergic consumers. 
 
OBJECTIVE 
To determine whether traces of egg-, milk-, and fish-derived processing aids used in winemaking might elicit clinical reactions in 
food-allergic patients. 
 
METHODS 
Five German wines were fined with a high dose of egg albumin, lysozyme, milk casein, fish gelatin, or isinglass, and filtered. 
Fourteen adults with allergy to egg (n = 5), milk (n = 5), or fish (n = 4) were included. Skin prick tests were performed with fining 
agents, and fined and unfined wines. All patients underwent double-blind placebo-controlled food challenges with fined and 
unfined wines. 
 
RESULTS 
Skin prick tests were positive to hen's egg (n = 5), ovalbumin (n = 5), lysozyme (n = 4), cow's milk (n = 5), casein (n = 4), and cod 
(n = 3), but not to isinglass or fish gelatin (n = 0). Positive skin prick test results were observed for wines fined with albumin 
(n = 3), lysozyme (n = 2), casein (n = 1), gelatin (n = 0), and isinglass (n = 3), and for unfined wines (n = 1-2 in each patient group), 
with no significant differences between groups. Seventy-five percent of skin test-positive patients had specific immunoglobulin E 
to other allergens present in wine (eg, carbohydrates). The provocation test revealed no reactions to fined or unfined wines. 
 
CONCLUSIONS 
Although concentrated fining agents containing ovalbumin, lysozyme, and casein were allergenic in the skin prick test, no patient 
reacted adversely in the provocation test to fined wine. Wines treated with fining agents at commercial concentrations appear 
not to present a risk to allergic individuals when filtered.  CONFIDENTIAL

Allergenic potential of fining agent residues in German wines related to their dosage and an ordinary bentonite treatment  
 
Author: Weber, P; Steinhart, H; Paschke, A 
 
Publication details: Agro Food Industry Hi-Tech 18.5 (2007): 22-24. 
 
Abstract (English):  
The effects of fining agent dosage (isinglass, potassium caseinate, dried egg white and gelatin derived from fish skin) and 
bentonite treatment on the amount of fining agent residues in German wines was studied. Fining agent proteins were measured 
by ELISA. Significant levels of fining agent residues were found neither in wines treated with an ordinary dosage nor in wines 
treated with an excess dosage of fining agents. Furthermore, significant levels of residues were found neither in wines with 
bentonite treatment nor in wines without bentonite treatment. 
Characterization, antigenicity and detection of fish gelatin and isinglass used as processing aid in wine 
 
Author: Weber, P; Steinhart, H; Paschke, A 
 
Publication details: Food Additives and Contaminants 27.3 (Mar 2010): 273-282. 
 
Abstract (English):  
Fish gelatin (FG) and isinglass (IG) are commonly used in the production of food and beverage products, as clarification aids or 
carriers for dyes, flavours and vitamins. There is a call for products processed with these fish-derived compounds to be labelled, 
for reasons of food safety (potential allergenicity), religious and ethical concerns and consumer protection. The aim of this study 
was to develop a reliable and sensitive method for the detection of FG and IG in foods. Polyclonal antibodies were raised against 
fish collagen and used to develop a sensitive indirect ELISA for the detection of FG and IG. Levels of less than 0.11 mcg/ml of FG 
and IG were detected and the method was successfully applied to the determination of FG and IG in wines. Wines, which had 
been processed with FG or IG and which had not been additionally treated with bentonite (for protein adsorption) and successive 
filtration, were found to have residues of up to 0.33 mcg/ml of FG and/of IG. 
Risk of allergic reactions to wine, in milk, egg and fish-allergic patients  
 
Author: Vassilopoulou, Emilia 1 ; Karathanos, Athanassios; Siragakis, George; Giavi, Stavroula; Sinaniotis, Athanassios; Douladiris, 
Nikolaos; Fernandez-Rivas, Montserrat; Clausen, Michael; Papadopoulos, Nikolaos G 1 Allergy Research Centre, 2nd Department 
of Pediatrics, University of Athens, Greece, Greece emivasil@hotmail.com 
 
Publication details: Clinical and Translational Allergy 1.1 (Oct 17, 2011): 10. 
 
Abstract (English):  
BACKGROUND 
European legislators and wine producers still debate on the requirement for labeling of wines fined with potentially allergenic 
food proteins (casein, egg white or fish-derived isinglass). We investigated whether wines fined with known concentrations of 
these proteins have the potential to provoke clinical allergic reactions in relevant patients. 
 
METHODS 
In-house wines were produced for the study, fined with different concentrations of casein (n = 7), egg albumin (n = 1) and 
isinglass (n = 3). ELISA and PCR kits specific for the respective proteins were used to identify the fining agents. Skin prick tests and 
basophil activation tests were performed in patients with confirmed IgE-mediated relevant food allergies (n = 24). A wine 
consumption questionnaire and detailed history on possible reactions to wine was obtained in a multinational cohort of milk, egg 
or fish allergic patients (n = 53) and patients allergic to irrelevant foods as controls (n = 13). 
 
RESULTS 
Fining agents were not detectable in wines with the available laboratory methods. Nevertheless, positive skin prick test reactions 
and basophil activation to the relevant wines were observed in the majority of patients with allergy to milk, egg or fish, 
correlating with the concentration of the fining agent. Among patients consuming wine, reported reactions were few and mild 
and similar with the ones reported from the control group.  CONFIDENTIAL

CONCLUSION 
Casein, isinglass or egg, remaining in traces in wine after fining, present a very low risk for the respective food allergic consumers. 
Physician and patient awareness campaigns may be more suitable than generalized labeling to address this issue, as the latter 
may have negative impact on both non-allergic and allergic consumers. 
Parvalbumin in fish skin-derived gelatin: is there a risk for fish allergic consumers?  
 
Author: Koppelman, S J; Nordlee, J A; Lee, P-W; Happe, R P; Hessing, M; Norland, R; Manning, T; Deschene, R; De Jong, G A H; 
Taylor, S L 
 
Publication details: Food Additives and Contaminants 29.9 (2012): 1347. 
 
Abstract (summary):  
The major allergen parvalbumin was purified from cod muscle tissues, and polyclonal antibodies were raised towards it. The 
antibodies were tested for specificity and an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was developed using these antibodies. 
The ELISA was applied to measure parvalbumin in cod skin, the starting material for fish gelatin made from deep sea, wild fish. 
The ELISA was sufficiently sensitive (LLOQ = 0.8 ng ml (-1) in extracts, corresponding to 0.02 µg of parvalbumin per g of tissue), 
and did not cross-react with common food constituents. Fish gelatin, wine and beer, matrices for the potential use of this ELISA, 
did not cause disturbance of the assay performance. The data show that the parvalbumin content in cod muscle tissue is 6.25 mg 
g (-1), while the skins contained considerably less, 0.4 mg g (-1) Washing of the skins, a common industrial procedure during the 
manufacturing of fish gelatin, reduced the level of parvalbumin about 1000-fold to 0.5 µg g (-1), or 0.5 ppm. From 95 commercial 
lots of fish gelatin it is shown that 73 are below 0.02 µg g (-1) parvalbumin. From the other 22 lots, the one with the highest 
concentration contained 0.15 µg g (-1) of parvalbumin. These levels are generally assumed to be safe for fish-allergic individuals. 
Allergenic proteins in enology: a review on technological applications and safety aspects  
 
Author: Peñas, Elena 1 ; di Lorenzo, Chiara 2 ; Uberti, Francesca 2 ; Restani, Patrizia 2 1 Institute of Food Science, Nutrition and 
Technology (ICTAN-CSIC), Juan de la Cierva 3, Madrid 28006, Spain, Spain elenape@ictan.csic.es 2 Dipartimento di Scienze 
Farmacologiche e Biomolecolari, Università degli Studi di Milano, via Balzzaretti 9, Milano 20133, Italy, Italy 
uberti_francesca@libero.it ; patrizia.restani@unimi.it 
 
Publication details: Molecules (Basel, Switzerland) 20.7 (Jul 21, 2015): 13144-64. 
 
Abstract (English):  
Proteinaceous products are widely used as fining agents during winemaking to remove unwanted insoluble particles and 
undissolved microscopic particles (colloidal material) from the must or wine to improve stability. Some of them (egg white, 
caseinates, and fish gelatine) have allergenic potential and the presence of their residues in the final product could represent a 
risk for allergic individuals. Moreover, lysozyme (an egg allergen) is included among wine additives to control the fermentation 
processes and avoid spoiling during winemaking. The aim of this paper is to review the experimental/clinical data on the use of 
allergenic products in enology and the measurement of relative risk for sensitized subjects. In addition, methods developed 
specifically for the quantification of allergenic residues in must and wine are described.  CONFIDENTIAL

Allergic and intolerance reactions to wine  
 
Author: Wüthrich, B 1 1 Specialist for Allergology and Clinical Immunology, Specialist for Dermatology, Zollikerberg, Switzerland, 
Switzerland 
 
Publication details: Allergologie select 2.1 (Sep 1, 2018): 80-88. 
 
Abstract (English):  
Hypersensitivity reactions to alcoholic beverages (particularly red wine) are relatively frequent, affecting 10% of the general 
population. Hypersensitivity reactions due to alcoholic drinks, mainly in the form of airway reactions (rhinitis and asthma), occur 
significantly more frequently in persons with pre-existing rhinitis and asthma. In terms of pathogenesis, it has to be differentiated 
between immunologic, mainly IgE-mediated, hypersensitivity reactions (wine allergies), and intolerance reactions in which no 
causative allergen-specific immune mechanisms can be detected. Allergens responsible for wine allergy could be: grape (Vitis 
vinifera) proteins (particularly the major allergen lipid transfer protein Vit v1), proteins and ingredients used for the fining of 
wines such as fish gelatin or isinglass (swim bladder of the fish huso, family of sturgeons), ovalbumin, dairy (casein) products, gum 
arabic, enzymes (lysozyme, pectinase, glucanase, cellulase, glucosidase, urease, aromatic enzymes), molds (particularly Botrytis 
cinerea) responsible for the noble rot in wines, yeasts and proteins from insects that contaminated the mash. Type 1 allergic 
reactions (positive prick tests) have been described for inorganic components like ethanol, acetaldehyde, acetic acid and sulfites, 
but no specific IgE could be detected in the serum. Ethanol, acetaldehyde and acetic acid, flavonoids (anthocyanins and 
chatechines), sulfites, histamine and other biogenic amines are the main causative agents of intolerance reactions (pseudoallergic 
reactions) to wine. After a short historic review of viticulture and the importance of wine in classical antiquity, we go into the 
chemical processes of alcoholic fermentation and the genetically inherited “flush syndrome” caused by an acetaldehyde 
dehydrogenase 2 polymorphism, subsequently we focus on the different etiologic factors of allergies and intolerance reactions to 
wine. The most frequent intolerance reactions to sulfites occur particularly after the ingestion of white wine and in asthma 
patients. Intolerance reactions to histamine and other biogenic amines occur mainly after ingestion of red wine and in persons 
with diamine oxidase (DAO) deficiency. 
  CONFIDENTIAL

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text:
Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act

This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production.

Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals.

Key findings include:

•Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption.
•Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products.
•Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits.
•International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence.
•Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine.

The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers 
Association (BFBi)  
 
 
Code of Good Manufacturing Practice  
for the Manufacture  
of Isinglass low in Parvalbumin 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Issue 1.   July 2006 
 
Page 1 of 12 Page 2 of 12 
Introduction  
Isinglass is a pure form of collagen derived from the dried swim bladders of specific tropical 
and subtropical fish, known in the industry as “maws”. Only certain species are selected for 
the isinglass used in brewing. These are certain catfish, croakers and threadfins.  
 
Swim bladders are part of the buoyancy mechanism of bony fish, and are distinct organs 
situated in the dorsal area of the body cavity, quite separate from the voluntary (skeletal) 
muscles which make up the fish "meat". There is little adherence between the bladder and the 
body cavity, thus when the fish are harvested, these swim bladders are readily detached and 
removed from the body of the fish without extr aneous tissue. Because of this, the levels of 
parvalbumin, which is the major allergen in fish and is found mainly in fish muscle, are low. 
Studies using an ELISA test for fish parvalbumin indicate that levels of parvalbumin in the 
swim bladders of those fish used for isinglass manufacture are in the range 7 – 30 mg/kg carp 
parvalbumin equivalents. These levels of parvalbumin are reduced to some extent during 
normal processing to prepare commercial isinglass products but can be further minimised by 
the use of buffer washes. Studies using the ELISA test referred to above indicate that normal 
processing reduces the range of parvalbumin concentrations slightly, but the introduction of an 
extra step of washing with phosphate buffer can achieve a significantly higher reduction. A 
Code of Good Manufacturing Practice, based on HACCP principles, has been developed by 
the BFBi in order to minimise levels of parvalbumin in their commercial isinglass-based 
products and to provide a common quality system for the industry. It is intended as a generic 
industry guide which has been adopted by the manufacturers concerned and has been 
incorporated into each company’s own HACCP system. 
 
Manufacture of isinglass  
 
1. Raw materials – pre-requisites 
 
1.1 Sourcing 
Analysis using the ELISA test has shown that levels of parvalbumin in swim bladders (maws) 
can vary between species. Consequently, only certain species are selected for the 
manufacture of isinglass. These are  
• Arius africanus  (sea catfish) 
• Arius dussumieri (blacktip catfish) 
• Arius maculatus (spotted catfish) 
• Bagrus docmak (bagrid catfish) 
• Bagrus Pseudopimelodus spp Bagre Blanco  (S.American White Catfish) 
• Cynoscions acoupa (Corvina del Lago) 
 
Maws for use by isinglass manufacturers are usually purchased from the same traders that 
supply the food market (the culinary market, for Chinese restaurants and delicatessen 
businesses, accounts for most of the volume of maws traded). These traders must be licensed 
to deal in foodstuffs by the Health Authorities in their respective countries. It is important for 
quality reasons that any maws destined for brewing and other beverage applications are 
cleaned and dried as soon as possible after being removed from the fish. Drying must be at 
ambient temperature in a good airflow without exposure to direct sunlight, which can cause 
damage through overheating (denaturation of the collagen). Great care must be taken during 
drying to avoid damaged by microbial growth.   
 
1.2 Packaging and Traceability Requirements 
The isinglass manufacturers specify that maws should be packed in new, food grade sacks 
and that shipping marks etc should not be sprayed/stenciled on the bags in such a way as to Page 3 of 12 
contaminate the maws inside with paint/ink. Maws should not be contaminated with pesticide 
residues. 
 
To ensure traceability each sack must be marked with  
• Supplier’s identification and lot number 
• maw type (species) 
• net weight 
 
Analytical specifications and visual checks at intake are used by the isinglass manufacturers 
to ensure the quality of their raw materials and that these pre-requisites have been met. 
Samples for pesticide residue analysis are taken after the milling stage of processing. 
 
1.3 Analytical specifications 
The following analytical specifications are set  
• Moisture                   16-22% ideally 17-19% 
• Protein                    >93% 
• Acid Soluble Protein           >90% 
• Collagen                   >88% 
 
 
2. Manufacturing process 
 
Good Manufacturing Practices for the production of Food Grade products are applied 
throughout the entire process. Isinglass products are very heat sensitive. Temperatures in 
excess of 18°C are therefore avoided during the manufacturing process to prevent damage to 
collagen (the active ingredient in isinglass). 
 
A flow diagram for the manufacturing process showing the HACCP Critical Control Points is 
given in Figure 1.  
 
2.1 Visual assessment (Critical Control Point No. 1) 
The outer packaging is removed and the fish maws are placed on a moving conveyor screen 
to remove fine dust particle and other loose material. The conveyor also allows the maws to 
be examined visually and any of doubtful quality to be removed. 
 
Maws are assessed visually to ensure that they are; 
• visually clean and free from infestation 
• free from tissue and fat residues  
• true in shape for the fish species specified 
• whole  
• not discloured (ideally of a pale yellow/straw colour) 
 
Supplier details and fish maw variety are recorded so the source and quality can be traced 
throughout the processing.  
 
2.1 Cleaning (Critical Control Point No. 2) 
The maws are then passed over a screen to remove foreign material such as metal fish hooks 
etc.  
 
2.2 Milling (Critical Control Points No. 3 and 4) 
The maws are first chopped so that they will pass through a 25mm screen. This finer particle 
size has two effects: 
 Page 4 of 12 
• it increases the surface area thus improving the extent of extraction of parvalbumin in 
the subsequent buffer wash 
• it ensures adequate sterilising during the peroxide wash  
 
The chopped product is then sieved to remove fines. The dry isinglass is then stored until 
required for processing. Details of the supplier and fish species are recorded for traceability. 
Metal fragments are removed by magnets, generally positioned between the mill and the 
screens.  
A representative sample of the fine milled material is taken for pesticide residue analysis. 
 
2.3 Sterilising (Critical Control Point No. 5).  
When required for processing, the dry chopped maws are transferred to the wet processing 
area. Here they are first sterilised by soaking in a solution of hydrogen peroxide and soaked 
for a minimum of 16 hours with intermittent stirring at approximately 4 hour intervals. The 
maws are then passed over a fine screen to remove the soluble impurities and fine insoluble 
material with the spent peroxide solution. The isinglass retained on the screen is rinsed with 
water. 
 
2.4  Buffer wash (Critical Control Point No. 6) 
The insoluble isinglass is then soaked in phosphate buffered saline (0.15M NaCl, 0.01M 
Na
2HPO4,pH7) for a minimum of 1 hour, drained, rinsed, then washed twice more with fresh 
water and finally drained. 
 
 This washing cycle removes the parvalbumin (whi ch is readily soluble at pH 7) from the 
isinglass, which is insoluble. The resultant wet isinglass is then further processed to a form 
suitable for the end user.  
 
2.5 Further processing 
Isinglass is sold in 3 different forms. 
1. Powder 
2. Aqueous Paste 
3. Aqueous Liquid. 
As mentioned earlier, for quality reasons it is critical to keep temperature <18 oC to prevent 
isinglass denaturing for both liquids and pastes. 
 
 
Powder: 
After washing, the wet isinglass is dried, either by freeze drying or using a low temperature air 
drier. The dried isinglass is then milled to a powder. It can be sold in this form to the user who 
dissolves it in dilute food grade acid prior to use. Alternatively, it may be blended with a 
powdered food grade organic acid by the isinglass manufacturer and sold to the end user as a 
ready-to-use powder. 
 
Aqueous Paste:   
After washing, the wet isinglass is added to water or to a buffer solution containing approved 
preservatives. This mix is then homogenised to give a fine paste for sale to the end user, who 
dissolves the paste in dilute food grade acid prior to use. 
 
 
Aqueous Liquid: 
After washing, the wet Isinglass is dissolved in dilute food grade acid solution containing 
approved preservatives. The resultant solution is then sold to the end user who further dilutes 
it with water prior to use. Page 5 of 12
