Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau
1310 G Street NW, Box l2
Washington, DC 20005
RE Notice No.os 237 & 238 - Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages; and Major Food
Allergen Labeling for Wineso Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
Comments of the Kentuckv Distillers' Association
Dear Director,
We are outside counsel for the Kentucky Distillers' Association, located in
Frankfort, Kentucky ("KDA"). The KDA is comprised of seventy-two distilled spirits
producers licensed and permitted in the Commonwealth of Kentucky, and the KDA and
its membership is thankful for the opportunity to provide high-level comments on
potential labelling changes for nutritional and allergen information on spirits packaging.
While the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau ("TTB") has issued two
notices of proposed rulemaking on complex labeling changes, we are choosing to submit
comments to both under a unified response as these issues are directly linked and raise
similar concerns for Kentucky's spirits industry. Please accept the following as the
KDA's comments relative to both Docket TTB-2025-002 (Notice No. 237) and Docket
TTB-2025-003 (Notice No. 238), relating to proposed changes to TTB regulations to
require the inclusion of alcohol fact and major food allergen statements on labels of
distilled spirits.
Since the KDA's founding in 1880, our mission has been to passionately and
responsibly promote, protect and elevate Kentucky's signature Bourbon and Distilled
Spirits Industry. We produce an estimated ninety-five percent (95%) of the world's
supply of Bourbon and our members have operations across the spirits categories. As
such, significant changes to current regulations would have an outsized financial and
administrative impact on our members.
Law Offices: Lexington I Louisville I Frankfort
Govennment Affains: Frankfont
mcbnayenf inm.comMtrBRAYER
Regulations and Rulings Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau
August 8,2025
Page 2
1. Increased Cost Burden to Producers
The KDA requests that TTB recognize that, first and foremost, the costs
associated with the proposed label changes would be significant for large and craft
producers alike. Nutritional sampling and testing would add substantial expense to
distilling operations and be unduly burdensome for smaller distillers who lack the staff
and capital to add this process. Additionally, reformatting and reprinting labels would be
an expensive undertaking. With our members producing so many different stock keeping
units ("SKUs"), these costs would be astronomical right out of the gate and the continued
testing would be cost prohibitive.
It is also important to note that so much information is already federally mandated
to be on spirits labels. Significant and meaningful data is already provided on spirits
labels, and any additions must balance consumer demand for information with economic
and logistical considerations, such as testing costs, limited labeling space, and expensive
packaging changes. Consumers trust what is labeled now and additional labeling real
estate devoted to unnecessary information might confuse the public, or worse, have them
ignore key labeling information altogether.
2. Alcohol Fact Statement Creating Confusion
The proposed requirements for the Alcohol Facts statement also introduces
redundancy to existing labeling requirements by requiring the percentage of alcohol by
volume ("ABV") be restated on the Alcohol Facts statement, in addition to the
requirement that ABV be presented on the front label. However, the proposal goes further
by requiring that the total quantity of pure ethyl alcohol be stated in fluid ounces as well,
which will result in customer confusion.
Customers are not used to seeing the quantity of alcohol in a beverage being
quantified in fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol. By redundantly including the ABV on
the Alcohol Facts statement in combination with a new measurement of quantity of
alcohol in a product, customers will be confused if those measurements are in conflict or
misinterpret the label entirely.
Further, as identified by TTB in Notice No. 238, the distillation process removes
proteins and the resulting spirits are therefore devoid of proteins. Yet, the proposed
Alcohol Facts statement would require distilled spirits to state the amount of protein in
the product, which will be zero. This would create customer confusion as a customer
would reasonably assume that seeing protein on a bottle of distilled spirits means that
there are some distilled spirits that do contain proteins.
tMtrBRAYER
Regulations and Rulings Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau
August 8,2025
Page 3
The KDA does not support the proposed Alcohol Facts statement as proposed due
to the inclusion of the fluid ounces of pure alcohol and proteins.
3. Digital Labeling Options
Spirits labels currently carry an abundance of consumer information. As
discussed, to keep consumers' attention and give them the ability to learn more about
certain products, a digital label or QR code would be a widely-accepted solution. Such
an approach would boost consumer confidence in the product and give buyers an easy
'click through' for the latest and more in-depth product information.
Moreover, digital labeling supports sustainability by reducing the need for
printing new labels every time regulations change, which can have significant
environmental impacts. The widespread use of smartphones in the U.S. (with almost
ninety-seven percent (97%) ownership) makes digital labeling a practical solution for
helping consumers make informed choices about dietary information while having less
environmental effects.
4. Major Allergens and the Distillation Process
As TTB properly observed, the distillation process removes all proteins -
including gluten - and major allergens from the resulting spirits. The end result of a
proper distillation produces an entirely gluten and allergen free spirit. Because distilled
spirits do not contain allergens or gluten post-distillation, the KDA supports the
exception provided for in proposed 27 CFR $ 5.75(bX2) specifically exempting distilled
spirits from disclosing allergens or proteins, unless allergens or proteins are introduced
post-distillation.
The KDA would suggest that the inclusion of language in the exemption
regarding TTB's testing of distilled spirits clarify that such testing will be on a case-by-
case basis, and not create a regulatory burden for distilled spirit plants and the TTB itself
by requiring lab analysis of every product.
If the proposed exception for distilled spirits is not included in the final
rulemaking, then the KDA opposes the requirement to disclose allergens and proteins due
to the scientific fact that protein and allergens are removed from the final distillation
product. Adding protein, not to mention other ingredients, to spirits labels would cause
tremendous consumer confusion-particularly those consumers who are trying to be
'gluten-free' due to diet or health concems. These consumers might not be aware about
gluten being removed from distillation and may misread bottles containing mash bill
information or just protein on the nutrition label and assume it is not safe to consume.
Including more language on already crowded distilled spirit labels will only amplifu theMEElRAYERI
Regulations and Rulings Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau
August 8,2025
Page 4
potential to confuse customers while creating misunderstanding among potential
customers.
5. Conclusion
As TTB considers additional labeling and allergen information, it is important to
consider how highly regulated the spirits industry already is. From traditional regulations
that consumers know and trust like the standards of identity that codifu Bourbon and
other spirits, to proof, age-requirements, and government warning labels, consumers are
already well-educated about distilled spirits products. Adding more could create nothing
more than confusion and indifference, all while adding burdensome costs and testing
inefficiencies.
Sincerely,
RRIS
TNM
4904-9883-6316, v. 1

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
spiritsEUROPE 
rue Belliard, 12 – Bte 5  |  1040 Brussels, Belgium 
Tel: + 32 (2) 7792423  |  info@spirits.eu  |  www.spirits.eu 
 
 
spiritsEUROPE Comments  
Notification G/TBT/N/USA/2183 
Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
Introduction 
spiritsEUROPE represents the interests of the European distilled spirits industry. Our members include 
31 national associations of spirits producers and 11 leading international companies with a strong base 
in Europe. The United States is EU spirits’ first export market in value, with exports worth €2.89 billion 
in 2024. Many of our larger members also have a presence and production facilities in the United 
States. 
 
We would like to thank the United States for notifying the TTB notice “Major Food Allergen Labeling 
for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages ” to the WTO TBT Committee . We welcome the 
opportunity to comment on these proposals and stand ready to expand on our written comments if 
needed.  
 
I. Comments on “Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages” 
 
spiritsEUROPE very much welcomes the approach taken by TTB on allergens labelling for distilled 
spirits. As the Notice rightly points out, the production of spirits involves the distillation of raw 
materials in such a way that no protein, allergenic or otherwise, remains in the distilled product or 
distilled ingredient. It is therefore appropriate that the mandatory labelling requirements do not apply 
to major food allergens used before the distillation process. 
 
We also support the method of verifying compliance when ingredients containing protein are added 
to the distilled spirits product after distillation, and no major food allergens are listed on the label. 
 
For those products where the presence of allergens would have to be disclosed , spiritsEUROPE  
welcomes the proposed transition period of 5 years. In addition, we  would like to request the 
possibility for our operators to exhaust all their stock which was put on the market before the proposed 
rule comes into effect. 
 
Finally, we would also like to request that if the proposed rulemaking  Notice No. 237 Alcohol Facts 
Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages is adopted, that its entry into 
force is aligned with that of  Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, 
and Malt Beverages.

comment_text:
Comments from Instituto Nacional de Vitivinicultura-INV (Arg) – Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
In line with international standards, fish gelatin or isinglass used as a clarifying agent in wine should be excluded.
Regarding the labeling format, the proposed text is “Contains Major Food Allergen: milk” or, when more than one allergen is present, “Contains Major Food Allergens: wheat and milk.” However, the possibility of using "Contains..." is also being considered. From INV perspective, we believe it is more appropriate and convenient to use the word "Contains..." as a specific indication.
Nevertheless, considering that there is a parallel project underway to require ingredient labeling, it could also be considered valid as an option for the bottler to include the mention of allergens in the ingredient list.
Regarding the labeling characteristics, the font size should follow the general labeling specifications and be placed on the supplementary label (back label).
The 5-year adaptation period is sufficiently long in the case of allergen labeling. A shorter period for example, 2 years would be acceptable as long as the implementation of allergen labeling remains independent from the implementation of nutritional labeling, which does require a longer adaptation period.
Allergen information should always be indicated on the physical label and, at the bottler’s discretion, may also be provided through electronic means, such as a QR code.

(TTB) Notice of Proposed Rulemaking Titled “Major Food Allergen
Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages,” Docket No.
TTB-2025-0003, 90 Fed. Reg. 5763 (January 17, 2025), 90 Fed. Reg.
14932 (April 7, 2025) (extending comment period) ("Biden-proposed
Allergen Labeling Rule”)

(2) TTB Notice of Proposed Rulemaking Titled “Alcohol Facts Statements in
the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages,” Docket No.
TTB-2025-0002, 90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 2025) 90 Fed. Reg.
14932 (April 7, 2025) (extending comment period) (“Biden-proposed
Alcohol Facts Rule’)

This letter presents comments of the National Federation of Independent Business
(NFIB)' on the Department of the Treasury Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
(TTB) Allergen Labeling and Alcohol Facts proposed rules cited above. NFIB finds it
hard to understand why the Department of the Treasury and the Office of Management
and Budget continue to pursue these Biden Administration proposals that would place
heavy and unwarranted burdens on the small businesses of America in the beer, wine,
and spirits industry. NFIB recommends and requests that the Treasury Department
withdraw both Biden proposals.

small businesses (here those with fewer than 20 employees) constitute most of the

Government's own data makes clear that, when the Treasury Department aims new
labeling requirements at the beer, wine, and spirits industry, it hits primarily small
businesses.5 The two Biden-proposed rules fail to recognize the practicalities of
running small businesses and fail to make the adjustments for small businesses that the
congressional policy stated in the Regulatory Flexibility Act contemplates.®

Small businesses, unlike the corporate behemoths in the beer, wine, and spirits industry
whose names and fortunes most everyone knows, cannot afford the bevy of lawyers
and experts necessary to decipher the rules and physically implement them, let alone
afford the cost of changes in processing and machinery to accommodate them.
Regulatory compliance costs small business owners time and money, both of which are
generally in short supply as they strive to keep their small businesses going, meet their
customers’ needs, and create jobs. The Biden-proposed rules would impose
unaffordable, unwarranted costs on small businesses and constitute an anti-competitive
barrier for small businesses that cannot afford such costs in comparison to the giants in
the industry who can.

The Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule and the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule
fail to take appropriate account of the needs of small businesses as called for in the
Regulatory Flexibility Act (RFA).” In paragraph 2(a)(4) of the RFA, Congress declared
that “the failure to recognize differences in the scale and resources of regulated entities
has in numerous instances adversely affected competition in the marketplace,

My Administration is unleashing a new era of opportunity for small businesses built

2. TTB Did Not Get the President's Deregula’ Message

President Trump could not have been clearer to the federal bureaucracies that they
should seek to deregulate, rather than further regulate, the American economy.

On January 31, 2025 -- eleven days after President Trump took office and fourteen days
after TTB published in the Federal Register the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule
and the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule, President Trump issued Executive Order
14192 on “Unleashing Prosperity Through Deregulation.” The President said: “The
ever-expanding morass of complicated Federal regulation imposes massive costs on
the lives of millions of Americans, creates a substantial restraint on our economic
growth and ability to build and innovate, and hampers our global competitiveness.” He
also said: “It is the policy of my Administration to significantly reduce the private

8 90 Fed. Reg. at 5775, col. 3 (in reference to the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling rule: “TTB
considered other options to reduce the regulatory burden and cost for small businesses, but ultimately is
not proposing them. One option considered was to exempt small businesses from the requirements of
the proposed rule. The primary purpose of this proposed rule is to provide information to consumers who
are allergic to one or more of the nine major food allergens. This purpose would be weakened by a
permanent exemption for small businesses. Consumers would not be able to rely on alcohol beverage
labels to disclose the presence of major food allergens if the requirements did not apply to all such
products.”). Thus, the Treasury Department did precisely the kind of dismissive, one-size-must-fit-all
pseudo-consideration of a small business alternative that the Regulatory Flexibility Act was designed to
combat.

® Proclamation 10932 of May 5, 2025, 90 Fed. Reg. 19609 (May 8, 2025).
expenditures required to comply with Federal regulations to secure America’s economic
prosperity and national security and the highest possible quality of life for each citizen.”
He emphasized that “[i]t is the policy of the executive branch . . . to alleviate
unnecessary regulatory burdens placed on the American people.” *°

On February 19, 2025, the President issued Executive Order 14219 on “Ensuring
Lawful Governance and Implementing the President's ‘Department of Government
Efficiency’ Deregulatory Initiative.” The President made clear that agency heads should
identify regulations that undermine the national interest, including “regulations that
impose significant costs upon private parties that are not outweighed by public benefits”
and “regulations that impose undue burdens on small businesses and impede private
enterprise and entrepreneurship.”*'

On April 9, 2025, the President issued Executive Order 14267 on “Reducing Anti-
Competitive Regulatory Barriers.” The order stated: “Federal regulations should not
predetermine economic winners and losers.” The order further stated: “Regulations that
reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innovation -- as well as the benefits they
create for American consumers -- should be eliminated.” The President directed
agency heads to identify anti-competitive regulations that “impose anti-competitive ...
distortions on the operation of a free market.”!2

These are not old orders by other Presidents that the bureaucracies can safely (though
improperly) ignore. These are not Executive Musings, Executive Wishes, or Executive
Suggestions to the bureaucracies. These are Executive Orders to the bureaucracies,
issued by the President the American people elected to direct those bureaucracies.

To comply with the clear anti-regulation, pro-competition policies the President set in the
quoted Executive Orders, the Treasury Department needs to withdraw the Biden-
proposed Allergen Labeling Rule and the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule. And the
Department of the Treasury should draw Executive Orders 14192, 14219, and 14267 to
the specific attention of the head of TTB and the departmental supervisors of the head
of TTB, to help the Department avoid issuance in the future of regulatory proposals that
unreasonably burden small and other businesses.

3. These Biden-proposed Rules Originated from a Flimsy Record

TTB says'® it pursued the Biden-proposed rules based on two things: (1) a finding and a
recommendation in the Treasury Department February 2022 report titled Competition in
the Markets for Beer, Wine, and Spirits '4 (“Treasury Competition Report”), and (2) a
February 24, 2021, letter from the Center for Science in the Public Interest (CSPI)'®
joined by six other organizations. Those documents, whether considered individually or
together, do not provide a reasonable and practical basis for pursuing the Biden-
proposed rules.

Regarding the Treasury Competition Report, TTB quotes'® the Executive Summary at
the front of the Report finding it a matter of concern that “[rjegulatory proposals that
could serve public health and foster competition by providing information to consumers,
such as mandatory allergen, nutrition, and ingredient labeling proposals, have not been
implemented”? and a recommendation at the other end of the report stating that “TTB
should revive or initiate rulemaking proposing ingredient labeling and mandatory
information on alcohol content, nutritional content, and appropriate serving sizes.”!® In
between the finding at the front of the report and the recommendation at the back of the
report, a scant five paragraphs’? addressed the matters that ended up in the
recommendation, and none of it was science as opposed to expressions of views by
commenters or views of the TTB itself. So, the Treasury Competition Report
recommendation provides no real justification for proceeding with the Biden-proposed
Allergen Labeling Rule. Moreover, although the finding mentioned allergen labeling, the
recommendation does not mention allergen labeling -- it mentions only ingredient
labeling, alcohol content, nutritional content, and appropriate serving sizes. It was
therefore misleading for TTB to state in the preamble to the Biden-proposed Allergen

The CSPI letter of February 24, 2021, represented the view of seven organizations that
exist to advocate particular views, in this case not favorable to the beer, wine, and
spirits industry: CSPI, Alcohol Justice, American Institute for Cancer Research,
Consumer Federation of America, Breast Cancer Prevention Partners, National
Consumers League, and U.S. Aicohol Policy Alliance. Advocacy to the federal and
state governments on regulatory subjects is a perfectly permissible activity protected by
the First Amendment right to petition for redress of grievances, and corresponding state
constitutional provisions, but no federal agency should view such advocacy as a
complete and unbiased basis for initiating a rulemaking process.

4. The Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule Fails
Legal, Truth, and Analytical Requirements

In addition to the heavy and unwarranted compliance burden the Biden-proposed
Allergen Labeling Rule imposes on small businesses, TTB has no lawful basis to issue
the rule, the rule compels untruthful speech, and TTB failed to conduct and provide the
benefit-cost analyses required by law and Executive Order.

First, no federal agency has any power whatsoever unless Congress has by law
conferred that power on the agency,’ and the law does not provide the Treasury
Department allergen labeling authority. The Treasury Department claims authority to
impose the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule under section 105(e) of the Federal
Alcohol Administration Act.22 The current absence of labeling about major allergens by
the beer, wine, and distilled spirit industry does not involve actual or alleged deception,
misleading of consumers, inaccurate statements, disparaging, false, misleading,
obscene, or indecent statements, or misleading brand or trade names, so the only

Section 105(e)(2) authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to issue labeling reguiations
for bottled distilled spirits, wine, or malt beverages “(2) as will provide the consumer with
adequate information as to the identity and quality of the products, the alcoholic content
thereof (except that statements of, or statements likely to be considered as statements
of, alcoholic content of malt beverages are prohibited unless required by State law and
except that, in case of wines, statements of alcoholic content shall be required only for
wines containing more than 14 per centum of alcohol by volume), the net contents of
the package, and the manufacturer or bottler or importer of the product[.]’ Applying the
canon of statutory interpretation that words are known by the company they keep
(noscitur a sociis in Latin), the requirement for adequacy of information applies to things
that are like identity, quality, alcohol content, net content, and manufacturer, bottler, or
importer -- but not what substances were used in the production of the beverage. Also,
applying the major questions canon of statutory interpretation, which presumes that
Congress has not delegated authority to issue rules of great economic significance”
unless Congress clearly says as much, section 105(e)(2) does not grant allergen
labeling authority. Accordingly, the Treasury Department lacks fegal authority to issue
the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule.

Second, the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule requires a label to state "Contains
Major Food Allergen(s)” even if the beer, wine, or distilled spirits in the bottle do not, in
fact, actually contain one or more of the major food allergens.”* It is bad enough that
TTB forces compelled speech upon the manufacturers of beer, wine, and distilled spirits
with its labeling requirement, but it is truly beyond the pale for TTB to compel speech
that is untrue. Proposed 27 CFR 4.32, 5.63, and 7.63 require, respectively, a wine,
distilled spirits, or malt beverage label, to list a major allergen if that allergen “is used in
the production of” the item.25 But it may be possible in some cases to use a major
allergen in the production of malt beverages, wine, or distilled spirits without any of the
allergen ending up in the beer, wine, or distilled spirits. TTB recognizes this possibility
in exempting from labeling a major allergen used in the production of distilled spirits if
the allergen was completely distilled so that no protein remains in the distilled spirits.7°
If an allergen is used in the production of wine, distilled spirits, or malt beverages, but

Third, TTB failed to calculate the costs of compliance of the Biden-proposed Allergen

Alcohol Facts rule, and industry members that were additionally affected by any new

The TTB then blithely asserted that it had no duty to conduct an initial regulatory
flexibility analysis because the proposed rule, if promulgated, will not have a significant
economic impact on a substantial number of smail entities.22 TTB has no business
assuming in the Biden-proposed Allergen Rule preamble that the Biden-proposed
Alcohol Facts Rule will be adopted, thereby making the cost of the Allergen Labeling
Rule marginal because it can piggyback on the Alcohol Facts label. TTB has a legal
duty to keep an open mind on whether to adopt the Alcohol Facts proposed rule and
must consider with an open mind the comments it will receive on that proposed rule.°°
TTB had a duty to undertake a proper cost-benefit analysis for three possible outcomes
of the rulemaking process: (1) TTB ends up adopting a final Alcohol Facts rule and a
final Allergen Labeling Rule; (2) TTB ends up adopting a final Alcohol! Facts rule, but not
an Allergen Labeling Rule; and (3) TTB ends up adopting a final Allergen Labeling Rule,
but not a final Alcohol Facts rule. The Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule fails to
comply with the requirement for an initial regulatory flexibility analysis under section 603

5. The Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule Fails
Legal, Benefit-Cost, and Analytical Requirements

In addition to the heavy and unwarranted compliance burden the Biden-proposed
Alcohol Facts Rule imposes on small businesses, TTB has no lawful basis to issue the
rule, failed to conduct and provide the benefit-cost analyses required by law and
Executive Order, and failed to provide the initial regulatory flexibility analysis required by
law.

First, no federal agency has any power whatsoever unless Congress has by law
conferred that power on the agency,°2 and the law does not provide the Treasury
Department authority to impose the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts rule. The Treasury
Department claims authority to impose alcohol facts labeling from two sources: (1)
chapter 51 and sections 5301, 5368, and 5412 of the Internal Revenue Code, and (2)
section 105(e) of the Federal Alcohol Administration Act.*? None of those statutes grant
the authority to impose the Alcohol Facts labeling that the Biden Administration
proposed.

Of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) provisions the Treasury Department cites, only
three provisions approach the subject of labeling. Section 5301(a)(1) provides: “(a)
REQUIREMENTS.--Whenever in his judgment such action is necessary to protect the
revenue, the Secretary is authorized, by the regulations prescribed by him and permits
issued thereunder if required by him--(1) to regulate the kind, size, branding, marking,
sale, resale, possession, use, and reuse of containers (of a capacity of not more than 5
wine gallons) designed or intended for use for the sale of distilled spirits[.]’ Section
5368 provides:

(a) GAUGING AND MARKING.--All wine or wine spirits shall be locked, sealed, and
gauged, and shall be marked, branded, labeled, or otherwise identified, in such
manner as the Secretary may by regulations prescribe.

(b) MARKING.--Wines shall be removed in such containers (including vessels,
vehicles, and pipelines) bearing such marks and labels, evidencing compliance with
this chapter, as the Secretary may by regulations prescribe.

Section 5412 provides: “Beer may be removed from the brewery for consumption or
sale only in hogsheads, packages, and similar containers, marked, branded, or labeled
in such manner as the Secretary may by regulation require, except that beer may be
removed from the brewery pursuant to section 5414 or by pipeline to contiguous distilled
spirits plants under section 5222.”

The three IRC provisions grant different authorities for distilled spirits, wine, and beer.
Section 5301(a)(1) grants branding and marking authority, but not labeling authority, for
distilled spirits. Section 5368 grants marking, branding, and labeling authority for wine.
Section 5412 grants marking, branding, and labeling authority for beer. From the
comparison of the language in the three provisions, it is clear that labeling is different
from marking and branding. So the first thing to note is that TTB has no authority to
impose the Alcohol Facts label on distilled spirits, especially given the inclusion of
labeling authority for wine and beer, but exclusion of it for distilled spirits.°* Note also
that the wine labeling authority is very limited under section 5368; it extends only to
labeling necessary for identification or to evidence “compliance with’ chapter 51 of the
Internal Revenue Code, neither of which reaches the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts
Rule’s requirement for a label to show serving size, servings per container, alcohol by
volume, calories, carbohydrate, fat, or protein. With respect to beer, section 5412
grants a labeling authority as long as the beer leaves the brewery in a container.
Accordingly, the Treasury Department has no authority under the Internal Revenue
Code to impose the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule on distilled spirits, wine, or
beer, except possibly for beer that leaves a brewery in a container.

The Treasury Department claim of labeling authority under section 105(e) of the Federal
Alcohol Administration Act fares no better. The current absence of labeling on serving
size, servings per container, alcohol by volume, calories, carbohydrate, fat, or protein by
the beer, wine, and distilled spirit industry does not involve actual or alleged deception,
misleading of consumers, inaccurate statements, disparaging, false, misleading,
obscene, or indecent statements, or misleading brand or trade names, so the only
provision of section 105 under which the Treasury Department could claim Alcohol
Facts labeling authority is section 105(e)(2).

Section 105(e)(2) authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to issue labeling regulations
for bottled distilled spirits, wine, or malt beverages “(2) as will provide the consumer with
adequate information as to the identity and quality of the products, the alcoholic content
thereof (except that statements of, or statements likely to be considered as statements

Also, applying the major questions canon of statutory interpretation, which presumes

The Treasury Department's triai balloon in the preamble, claiming that Center for

Congress’ intent as to whether the FAA Act either requires or prohibits ingredient
disclosure regulations. ... BATF’s conclusion that the Act vests it with a zone of
discretion within which it can choose to require or not to require ingredient disclosure,
as necessary to provide consumers with adequate information, is thus consistent with
that congressional intent which can be discerned. We accordingly acquiesce in the
agency’s interpretation of the general scope of its authority under § 205(e). See
Chevron U.S.A. Inc. v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., 467 U.S. 837, 842-45,
104 S. Ct. 2778, 2781-83, 81 L. Ed. 2d 694 (1984)."5° But in Loper Bright, the Supreme
Court rejected the Chevron reasoning the D.C. Circuit used in the 1986 case, by which
the Circuit found a statutory phrase ambiguous and deferred to the agency about its

3% if the regulatory term “alcohol by volume” as used in the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule were
defined to be identical to the statutory term “alcoholic content,” then section 105(e)(2) would appear to
authorize that single aspect of the proposed labeling.

36 The U.S. beer market is $117 billion (source: https:/Avww.brewersassociation.org/statistics-and-
data/national-beer-stats/), wine market is $107 billion (source:
https://commercial.bmo.com/media/filer_public/03/89/03891 f2e-3507-487f-a900-192dc5c9aefe/23-
2509_wine_market_report_hz_v57_final-ua.pdf}, and spirits market is $38 billion (source:
https:/Avww.distilledspirits.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2023-AEB-Slide-Deck-2.6.24-517PM.pdf), for
a combined total of a $262 billion beer, wine, and spirits market.

37 90 Fed. Reg. at 6655, col. 3.

38 Center for Science in the Public interest v. Department of the Treasury, 797 F. 2d 995, 999 n. 2 (D.C.
Cir. 1986).
13

meaning. The Supreme Court said: “Chevron is overruled. Courts must exercise their
independent judgment in deciding whether an agency has acted within its statutory
authority, as the APA [Administrative Procedure Act] requires.”9

So, at the end of the day, TTB has no statutory authority require the Biden-proposed
Alcohol Facts label for distilled spirits, for wine, or for beer, except possibly for beer that
leaves the brewery in containers. That conclusion should not be particularly surprising.
Congress knows precisely how to authorize calorie and nutritional content labeling when
it wants to do so, as it has done with respect to food in enacting section 403(q) of the
Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.”

Second, the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule imposes much cost to achieve little
benefit. TTB estimates that the proposed rule, if made applicable in five years, will cost
the industry $201.2 million over five years, or $40.2 million per year to implement
(figures expressed in 2023 dollars).** Also, recurring costs will occur in subsequent
years for as long as the rule remained in force. TTB’s negative statement that “TTB has
no reason to believe that the proposed rule would require industry members to
purchase new labeling equipment”? is a clever way of addressing the subject without
admitting that TTB cannot say affirmatively that the proposed rule will not require them
to purchase such new equipment. And, of course, with more costly regulatory labeling
requirements, new entrants to the industry will face higher entry costs than they
otherwise would have faced.

As for benefits, TTB admits that, even though it has been considering the subject of
alcohol facts labeling at least since December 2003, “TTB does not have data to
quantify the monetary benefits of the proposed rule[.]’“4 Again, TTB cleverly refers in
the absence of data to “the monetary benefits’ as opposed to “any monetary benefits,”
assuming, without having any supporting data, that there are some monetary benefits.
In the end, TTB cites only two purported benefits for the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts
Rule:

TTB does not have data to quantify the monetary benefits of the proposed rule, but
as stated previously, the overall purpose of the proposed rule is to provide
consumers with more information about the identity, quality, and alcohol content of
alcohol beverages. This information will in turn enable consumers to follow advice

38 Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo, 603 U.S. 369, 412 (2024).
4 24 U.S.C. 343(q).

41 90 Fed. Reg. at 6676, col. 1 and note 34.

42 90 Fed. Reg. at 6677, col. 1.

43 90 Fed. Reg. at 6656, col. 2.

44 90 Fed. Reg. at 6684, col 2.
14

about moderate alcohol consumption and will provide them with additional
information about the calorie and macronutrient content of alcohol beverages.

The first claimed benefit of the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts labeling, that it will
“enable consumers to follow advice about moderate alcohol consumption,” hangs by a
thread. For the many consumers who do not read package labeling, the Alcohol Facts
labeling will have zero effect. And perhaps alcohol content and calorie counts would
mean something to some consumers who read an Alcohol Facts label, but
carbohydrate, fat, and protein numbers will mean little if anything to most consumers.
Also, only consumers who serve themselves (for example, bought beer at the grocery
store), and not those served in establishments (for example, served a drink at a table in
a bar), will have the chance to see any labeling at all. And, for those who see a label, it
might be useful to consider whether the alleged drinking deterrence of an Aicoho! Facts
label diminishes after one moderate drink (woman) or two moderate drinks (man) with
respect to whether another drink might occur.* And lastly, for some consumers, the
Alcohol Facts labeling may have an anti-moderation effect, as it enables a consumer to
compare alcoholic content of different beer, wines and spirits and select a drink with a
higher alcohol content than the consumer might otherwise have chosen. TTB should
take human behavior into account to a greater degree before it makes and relies on
assumptions about the effects of the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule.

The second claimed benefit of the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts labeling, that it will
provide consumers “with additional information about the calorie and macronutrient
content of alcohol beverages,” is not a benefit -- it is merely a statement of what the
proposed rule allegedly does. It says nothing about what the impact will be of providing
the additional information. And, as mentioned above, many consumers will not see the
labeling, will ignore the labeling, will not understand the labeling, or, if they see the
labeling, will make decisions other than the TTB-desired moderation decision.

For the reasons set forth above, the costs of the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule
greatly outweigh the purported benefits of the proposed rule.

Thirdly, TTB’s failure to provide an initial regulatory flexibility analysis for the Biden-
proposed Alcohol! Facts rule plainly violates section 603 of title 5 of the U.S. Code.4”

4 90 Fed. Reg. at 6684, col. 2. TTB skips over the fact that the proposed rule’s mandated information
requirement goes far beyond “the identity, quality, and alcohol content” to reach serving size, servings per
container, alcohol by volume, calories, carbohydrate, fat, and protein.

48 The Dietary Guidelines for Americans published by the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the U.S.
Department of Health and Human Services, p. 18 (Key recommendation: “Alcoholic beverages—Adults of
legal drinking age can choose not to drink or to drink in moderation by limiting intake to 2 drinks or less in
a day for men and 1 drink or less in a day for women, when alcohol is consumed. Drinking less is better
for health than drinking more. There are some adults who should not drink alcohol, such as women who
are pregnant.”).

47 Section 603(a) of title 5 states in part: “Whenever an agency is required by section 553 of this title, or
any other law, to publish general notice of proposed rulemaking for any proposed rule, or publishes a
notice of proposed rulemaking for an interpretative rule involving the internal revenue laws of the United
15

TTB claims that it has no duty to provide such an analysis because section 605 of title 5
“allows the head of an agency to certify that a rule will not, if promulgated, have a
significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities." And
immediately thereafter TTB states: “TTB certifies that this proposed rule, if adopted,
would not have a significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities.
But that certification is plainly incorrect, by TTB’s own admissions in the preambles to
the proposed rules.

n

The data TTB provides in the preambles show more than 80% of the 7,550 enterprises
(a substantial number) in the beer, wine, and spirits industry are small businesses (in
this case, with fewer than 20 employees each) and that the implementation costs of the
proposed rule exceed $40 million per year over five years (without even taking account
of recurring costs).42 The TTB’s implementation cost estimate per enterprise, then, is
$5,298 per year. So, TTB estimates, each of the small businesses would spend $5,298
per year in the first five years, plus recurring costs on into the future, to carry out the
Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule. With the average small business owner making
about $69,000 per year,®° it is plain that a new $5,298 per year government-imposed
charge on small businesses with the proposed rule is significant.

Particularly galling is the statement TTB made in attempting (but failing) to justify its
decision to certify that the proposed rule has no significant economic impact on a
substantial number of small entities:

The production, bottling, importation, and distribution of alcohol beverages is an
industry subject to extensive Federal, State, and local regulation. The labeling and
advertising regulations under the FAA Act have been in place since 1936. Adding
more elements of mandatory information to the label will not have a significant
impact on the regulated industry.°!

The TTB attitude that the industry is already so highly regulated on labeling that adding
more labeling requirements really does not matter is appalling, contrary to presidential
policy, and contrary to law. TTB had a duty to publish an initial regulatory flexibility
analysis under section 603 of title 5 and failed to comply with that law.

kkKEK

States, the agency shall prepare and make available for public comment an initial regulatory flexibility
analysis.”

48 90 Fed. Reg. at 6685, col. 3.

48 90 Fed. Reg. at 5775, col. 1 (percentage of small businesses) and 90 Fed. Reg. at 6676, col. 1 (dollar
costs).

5° “Top Small Business Statistics,” Forbes Advisor (as of January 31, 2024), Item 16, available at
https:/Awww. forbes. com/advisor/business/small-business-
statistics/#small_business_ownership_statistics_section (visited July 25, 2025).

51 90 Fed. Reg. at 6687, col. 1.
16

NFIB recommends and requests that the Department of the Treasury withdraw the rules
on Allergen Labeling and Alcohol Facts proposed by the Biden Administration three
days before he left office. The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau of the
Department of the Treasury has no legal authority to promulgate the Biden-proposed
rules and failed to provide the regulatory analyses required in proposing the rules. And
the proposed rules run flatly contrary to the deregulatory policies President Trump has
established by executive order. Withdrawal of the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling
and Alcohol Facts rules will prevent imposition of unwarranted, burdensome, and costly
rules on small businesses in the beer, wine, and spirits industry.

Tell,

David S. Addington
Executive Vice President and General Counsel

comment_text:
I have been a volunteer in the field of substance abuse prevention for over 25 years. I have a Masters degree in Dietetics. I think it is extremely important to label all foods and beverages to prevent allergic reactions and drug interactions.
Roughly 11% of U.S. adults have food allergies.Many alcoholic beverages contain major allergens, such as wheat in many beers, milk and nuts in liqueurs, and even fish and eggs used as processing aids in wine. Consumers with food allergies have no way of knowing if they can safely consume alcoholic beverages because neither ingredient lists, nor major allergen labeling is required.
Nearly all foods and beverages we consume are required to have basic labeling of ingredients and allergens. Alcohol shouldn’t be exempt!I commend TTB for issuing a proposed rule that would greatly improve transparency and protect consumers with food allergies by requiring labeling of the top 9 major food allergens that does not exempt processing aids. The rule could be strengthened by specifying where the allergen disclosure should appear, outlining specific formatting requirements, and requiring species specific disclosure for the labeling of fin fish.
TTB should make clear in the final rule that this information should never be provided solely via QR code, as this would specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology
Consumers need this information as soon as possible! In the final rule, TTB should shorten the compliance period from 5 years to 3.5 years to prevent further delay of consumer access to this basic safety information.
In summary. please label alcoholic products with information about possible food allergens to protect public health.
Thank you for your consideration to this important topic.

comment_text:
I’m writing to oppose the proposed allergen labeling requirement for wine, spirits, and malt beverages. While I understand the intent — keeping consumers safe — this isn’t the way to do it, and I believe it will cause more confusion than clarity.

In winemaking, some substances that are technically considered allergens (egg whites, casein, isinglass, etc.) can be used during production, most often for fining. But here’s the thing — they’re removed before bottling. They don’t end up in the finished wine in any meaningful or measurable way. If I had to put “egg” or “milk” on a label when neither is actually in the bottle, a lot of people would assume they’re drinking something they’re not. That’s misleading, not helpful.

On top of that, the average consumer isn’t familiar with winemaking terminology. Words like “bentonite,” “potassium caseinate,” or “isinglass” can sound scary on a label with no explanation. I can already picture the reaction from someone who thinks potassium bicarbonate is “bad for you.” Listing these things out of context will only fuel unnecessary worry.

From a practical standpoint, wine labels are already packed with required information — varietal, vintage, appellation, health warnings, alcohol content, government statements — and there’s only so much space to work with. Every time you add something new, something else has to give. And for small producers, redesigning labels is expensive and time-consuming.

If the TTB truly wants to make this information available, there are better ways. A QR code or a note directing people to a website would allow producers to share details for specific vintages without constantly redesigning labels. That keeps the information accurate and avoids scaring off customers with technical terms they may not understand.

At the end of the day, this proposal feels like a solution in search of a problem. It won’t make consumers safer, but it will cost producers money, create confusion, and set a precedent for more unnecessary regulation. I urge you to reconsider and work with the industry on alternatives that actually make sense.

comment_title: Comment 184:  William Cox (Cox Vineyards, Adairsville Georgia)
comment_text:
Cox Vineyards in Adairsville Georgia would like to express opposition to Proposal 238. This proposal for adding additional allergen information to wine labels is not only unnecessary but very costly. Wine labels already are required to state major food allergens ( sulfites ). The addition of allergens listed in the proposal are unnecessary information as they are not common in the winemaking process, and even if they were present in the crafting of a wine the sanitary environment of wine ( commonly 12-14% abv and 3-4pH ) along with the even standard levels of filtering needed top make a commercial wine would completely remove any even minor allergy potential. This proposal would only create an completely false sense of potential danger and harm sales, small businesses and rural communities.
Many of our wineries in the not only the state but the region are small family owned farm businesses. Businesses that are already running on very tight budgets. These businesses bring in vital revenue, jobs, and tourism to often very economically stressed rural communities. Many other small businesses in those communities are dependent on the winery's presence, restaurants, hotels, bed and breakfast, events centers, and other agritourism based businesses are some examples. Placing these extra stresses on the wineries, but also endangers many supporting businesses dependent on the winery to bring customers to their rural communities.

comment_text: While I believe the consumer should be able to access allergen and nutritional information of a wine or spirit brand, I believe this information can be delivered via a common application or website, or at the very least required to be on the brand's website. There simply is not enough room on a brand's packaging to include the information required in a legible format.

comment_text:
A compliance date of 5 years from when a final rule is published in the Federal Register is proposed. Since it is necessary to ensure that companies have enough time to prepare for changes, we suggest that the proposed 5-year period not be shortened.
We, however, invite you to consider allowing declaration within voluntary ingredient listing as an alternative to a separate 'contains' statement; accepting exemptions already assessed by EFSA and FSANZ, like f.i. use of isinglass as a clarifying agent; and agreeing to grouping other required disclosures related to certain ingredients, such as 'contains sulphites', with the allergen information so all pertinent information is together in one place.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
A compliance date of 5 years from when a final rule is published in the Federal Register is proposed. Since it is necessary to ensure that companies have enough time to prepare for changes, we suggest that the proposed 5-year period not be shortened.
We, however, invite you to consider allowing declaration within voluntary ingredient listing as an alternative to a separate 'contains' statement; accepting exemptions already assessed by EFSA and FSANZ, like f.i. use of isinglass as a clarifying agent; and agreeing to grouping other required disclosures related to certain ingredients, such as 'contains sulphites', with the allergen information so all pertinent information is together in one place.

comment_text:
Dear Administrator,

On behalf of the Georgia Wine Producers, representing 110 member wineries across Georgia, we appreciate the opportunity to submit comments regarding TTB Notice No. 238. We respect TTB’s mission to ensure consumer safety and transparency, but must respectfully oppose the proposed mandatory allergen labeling regulations for alcoholic beverages.

Our position is supported by substantial scientific evidence and international standards demonstrating the following:

1. Standard Winemaking Practices Effectively Remove Allergenic Proteins
• Multiple scientific studies confirm that when wines are produced using good manufacturing practices, including fining followed by bentonite or sheet filtration and sterile filtration, allergenic proteins (e.g., from egg, milk, fish) are removed to undetectable levels (typically <0.1mg/L by ELISA assays).
• Wines tested after such treatments routinely show no detectable allergenic residues, and provocation tests on sensitive individuals consistently show no clinical reactions.
• The Organization International de la Vigne et du Vin (OIV) recommends a detection threshold below which labeling is unnecessary, in line with outcomes showing no risk in finished wine.

2. Risks to Allergic Individuals Are Negligible with Commercial Practices
• Clinical challenge studies (double-blind, placebo-controlled trials) on wines produced with egg white, casein, or fish gelatine failed to elicit reactions in highly sensitive individuals, validating that finished wine poses extremely low risk of anaphylaxis related to such allergens.
• In rare cases where trace residue was measurable, oral challenge studies involving up to 200mL wine showed no reaction in sensitized subjects.

3. Mandatory Labeling Is Disproportionate and Might Mislead Consumers
• Required labeling of allergens that do not exist in meaningful quantities in the finished product could cause unnecessary alarm and reduce consumer confidence in otherwise safe products.
• European and Australian regulators have adopted risk-proportionate approaches, requiring labeling only if residues exceed specific scientific thresholds.

4. Disproportionate Cost to Small Producers and Rural Communities
• The costs of compliance—label redesign, legal consultation, and ongoing analytical testing of finished wine—present a severe financial burden to small rural wineries, threatening not only their viability but also significant rural economic benefits.
• These costs are unjustified given the lack of evidence for public health benefit in properly produced commercial wine.

Conclusion
Scientific research and international regulatory experience demonstrate that potential allergenic proteins are reliably removed through standard winemaking techniques, resulting in products that do not pose a significant risk to sensitive individuals. We therefore urge TTB to align with global best practices and scientific evidence, limiting mandatory allergen disclosure to cases where validated laboratory methods can detect residues above internationally accepted thresholds.

Thank you for considering our data-driven opposition. We are committed to safe, high-quality wine production and continuing dialogue on proportionate regulatory measures.

Respectfully,
Steve Schmidt
Executive Director
Georgia Wine Producers

References to scientific evidence (for context, not for inclusion as an endnotes section):
• Proteinogenic wine fining agents risk assessment and OIV standards (PubMed).
• International studies on allergenic protein removal, oral challenge results, and ELISA testing (PMC review).
• Double-blind clinical study on allergen risk in wine (ScienceDirect).
• AWRI summary of allergen labeling and scientific studies.

comment_text: On behalf of Alcohol Justice Executive Director Cruz Avila, our comment is attached as a PDF.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: On behalf of Alcohol Justice Executive Director Cruz Avila, our comment is attached as a PDF.

comment_text: On behalf of Alcohol Justice Executive Director Cruz Avila, our comment is attached as a PDF.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 8, 2025    Mary G. Ryan Administrator Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau Regulations and Rulings Division 1310 G Street, NW, Box 12 Washington, DC 20005    Dear Ms. Ryan,   Alcohol Justice is a nonprofit based in San Rafael, CA. We are dedicated to advancing evidence-based policies that promote public health and safety. We are writing in response to the Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB)’s request for comment on rulemaking around allergen labeling for alcoholic beverages (27 CFR Parts 4, 5, and 7; Docket No. TTB-2025-0003; Notice No. 238).  We applaud TTB’s intention to improve the transparency and safety around alcoholic beverages. As a consumable product, alcohol is often unaccountably exempt from the consumer information requirements of other foods and beverages. This proposed rulemaking will close the gap.  Food allergies are not a rare condition. Approximately 11% of U.S. adults are estimated to have a food allergy (around 26 million), and 38.3% of those individuals have had an allergy-related emergency department visit.1 Of those with a food allergy, 90% are allergic to one of 9 major food types.2 Alcohol use is common in the United States, with 177.3 million residents ages 12 and up consuming alcohol in the past year. Depending on the nature of the alcohol product, many will very often contain one or more of the 9 major allergens (e.g., the grains used to make beer almost inevitably introduce wheat gluten to the finished product), while for others the presence of an allergen can be difficult to know for certain (e.g., distilled spirits) and in some cases un-anticipatable (e.g. the use of fish-derived products in wine production). Allergic events create a steady financial drain. In a systematic review of allergen economic impact studies, individual medical costs from allergen-related causes amount to an average of $2,081 per event, while household costs exceed an average of $8000 per event from out-of-pocket expenses and opportunity costs.3 As such, avoiding unexpected exposures to allergens in alcohol consumption could have a significant health and economic benefit to U.S. households.  To be most effective in addressing these concerns, the TTB rulemaking should err on the side of consistency across labels. That means minimizing the alternatives to the “Contains major food 
allergens” wording, even if said alternative wording is considered by the producer to be more emphatic. Consumers become accustomed to looking for allergen information in particular places with particular words. Along these same lines, the “minor” allergens should be consistently identified in the same place and same formatting as major ones. The warning should be high-visibility, including a minimum font size, restrictions on kerning and compressing, a mandated box, and contrasting background within that box.  We would advise against allowing allergen labeling exemptions for distilled products, because cross-contamination is a known and described phenomenon across food production. TTB could consider a warning akin to the “made in a facility that also processes” language commonly used in food product warnings, however it’s not clear that this complexity actually does producers a favor. It is less impactful to err towards an unnecessary label than to induce a medical event.  On-label warnings are an absolute requirement. QR codes are not universally sought out or employed, and the required access to the internet is not always available.4 Moreover, not all packaged alcohol will be consumed in circumstances where the consumer will be expected to have mobile device with them. Allergen information should be as available beachside as it is in the grocery store, and the only way to ensure this is to include the information directly on the packaging.   As a final note—we join with the Center for Science in the Public Interest (CSPI) and other groups in urging TTB to require full ingredient labeling for all products. While the allergen warnings are important to prevent acute medical events, there are many other reasons to avoid or seek out certain ingredients, including ethical and religious grounds. We also support CSPI’s request for an accelerated, 3.5–year timeline—the concerns from industry in ramping up the testing for products should be offset by the acclimation time required by the public to begin reflexively seeking allergen information on the labels.   We thank TTB for their long-term effort in developing and promulgating these new guidelines. Alcohol Justice is available at the Bureau’s request for any further information or context to help bring this rulemaking to fruition.     Respectfully,  
   Cruz Avila Executive Director Alcohol Justice 24 Belvedere St. San Rafael, CA 94901 cruza@alcoholjustice.org 
 References  1. Gupta RS, Warren CM, Smith BM, et al. Prevalence and severity of food allergies among US adults. JAMA Netw Open. 2019;2(1):e185630. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2018.5630. Accessed 8/7/2025. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2018.5630. 2. Boyce JA, Assa'ad A, Burks AW, et al. Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of food allergy in the United States: Summary of the NIAID-sponsored expert panel report. J Allergy Clin Immunol. 2010;126(6):1105–1118. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jaci.2010.10.008. doi: 10.1016/j.jaci.2010.10.008. 3. Bilaver LA, Chadha AS, Doshi P, O'Dwyer L, Gupta RS. Economic burden of food allergy: A systematic review. Annal Aller Asth Immunol. 2019;122(4):373–380.e1. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1081120619300511. doi: 10.1016/j.anai.2019.01.014. 4. Sidoti O, Dawson W. Pew Research Group. Mobile Fact Sheet. 2024. https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/mobile/. Accessed Aug 6, 2025.

comment_text: GS1 US Comments on TTB Proposed Rule - Major Allergen Labeling
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
GS1 US Corporate Headquarters 
Princeton South Corporate Center 
300 Charles Ewing Boulevard 
Ewing, NJ 08628 USA 
T: +1 937.435.3870 
E: info@gs1us.org 
 
www.gs1us.org  © 2025 GS1 US All Rights Reserved 
 
Maggie Lyons 
Vice President, Government and 
Regulatory Affairs 
GS1 US 
300 Charles Ewing Boulevard 
Ewing, NJ 08628 USA 
 
August 13, 2025 
 
 
 
To Whom It May Concern, 
 
GS1 US appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and 
Trade Bureau's (TTB) proposal to require disclosure of major food allergens used in the production 
of alcohol beverages. As an organization dedicated to developing global standards, GS1 US 
understands the importance of leveraging data and technology to improve transparency and 
enhance consumer access to detailed product information that supports informed decision making. 
We commend TTB’s commitment to these goals and are grateful for the opportunity to contribute 
our insights. 
 
For over 50 years, GS1 Standards have helped companies power their supply chains to deliver 
safe, consistent, authentic, and trusted experiences. Best known as the recognized source for UPC 
barcodes, GS1 creates the common language that helps companies and their trading partners 
identify, capture, and share trusted data that links their physical and digital supply chains. Millions 
of businesses around the world power commerce with GS1 Standards, and more than 300,000 
members across 25 industries turn to GS1 US for help. This includes the food and beverage 
production, foodservice, and retail grocery sectors in the United States. 
 
As a member-governed organization, GS1 US actively brings businesses together to identify 
industry challenges and to build consensus on best practices for solving them using global 
standards. These practices can meet an existing need and guide the development of new global 
standards when necessary. Beyond operational efficiencies for trading partners, GS1 Standards 
help empower consumers to make informed choices and trust their purchases by facilitating access 
to the information they want and need about those products. 
 
2D Barcodes: Enhancing Transparency in Allergen Labeling 
GS1 US acknowledges the importance of enhancing transparency and providing consumers with 
essential information about the alcohol beverages they consume. Implementing GS1 Standards, 
particularly the use of 2D barcodes, like QR codes or GS1 DataMatrix barcodes, can significantly aid 
in achieving these goals. Linear 1D barcodes, such as UPC barcodes, can only hold a limited 
amount of information, typically just a product identifier. In contrast, 2D barcodes are capable of 
storing much more data, including detailed product information, batch numbers, expiration dates,  
 
www.gs1us.org  2 
and more. This increased capacity makes 2D barcodes ideal for providing comprehensive 
information in a compact format. 
 
The food and beverage industry has already demonstrated the viability and consumer value of 
digital transparency tools through the adoption of SmartLabel, a platform launched in 2015 to 
provide detailed product information via QR codes. Incorporating 2D barcodes linked to the Global 
Trade Item Number (GTIN) can effectively support consumer access to allergen information. This 
approach promotes consumer engagement, transparency, and informed decision making. 
Additionally, 2D barcodes can serve as a valuable complement to the information required to 
appear on the physical label.  Besides the required on-pack disclosures, 2D barcodes provide a 
pathway to more detailed information, such as ingredient lists, sustainability practices, and 
responsible consumption messaging, enhancing transparency for consumers. 
 
A GS1 Digital Link-enabled QR code can provide consumers with access to detailed product and 
allergen information, including dynamic data including recalls or safety alerts, through a simple 
smartphone scan. The GS1 Digital Link standard enhances the power and flexibility of GS1 
identifiers by integrating them into the web. This transforms GS1 identifiers, such as the GTIN, into 
gateways to consumer information, aiding effective decision making and strengthening brand 
loyalty while improving supply chain traceability. 
 
Moreover, the 2D barcode approach is attractive to brand owners because it frees up label space. 
QR codes are typically smaller than traditional UPC barcodes, yet they have a greater capacity for 
information. This makes them ideal for compact labels while still providing comprehensive data. 
Furthermore, QR codes are consumer-friendly, as most consumers are already familiar with 
scanning them to access key product information. An estimated 90% of American adults use 
smartphones; in our own research, 66% of respondents said they would scan a QR code to access 
product information. The growing move to 2D barcodes and QR codes empowers consumers to 
easily learn more. For further details, you can access the full press release here. 
 
In addition to enhancing consumer access to product and allergen information, 2D barcodes 
encoded with a product’s GTIN offer a standardized and interoperable format, ensuring accuracy 
and consistency across retail and digital platforms. Including the GTIN in a QR code encoded with 
GS1 Digital Link enables direct access to online product information.  
 
Application of GS1 Standards for Enhanced Consumer Information 
GS1 Standards offer a consistent, standardized framework for globally unique product identification 
and efficient data sharing across various platforms. Utilizing these open, global standards can 
significantly enhance consumer access to detailed product information. These principles can be 
applied to support industry compliance with allergen labeling requirements: 
 
1. Identification: GS1 Standards enable the unique identification of products, logistics units, 
parties, locations, assets, documents, and relationships across the supply chain—from the 
manufacturer to the consumer. These identifiers provide a standardized method to 
recognize and track items, ensuring consistency and accuracy in product information.  
 
www.gs1us.org  3 
2. Capture: GS1 Standards offer means to capture data about products through technologies 
such as barcodes and radio frequency identification (RFID) tags. This data includes critical 
information like expiry dates, batch/lot numbers, and other key attributes. Accurate 
capture of product information ensures that consumers receive up-to-date, relevant details. 
3. Share: Transmitting the captured data between trading partners using standardized data 
formats allows for seamless information exchange across the supply chain. This 
transparency helps provide clear and consistent information to consumers, enhancing their 
confidence in the products they purchase. Additionally, it promotes consumer safety by 
facilitating efficient recalls and providing timely alerts about product issues. 
 
Conclusion 
Incorporating standards-based solutions such as GTIN for product identification, 2D barcodes, and 
GS1 Digital Link into the TTB’s allergen labeling framework offers a powerful path to enhance 
consumer access to accurate, comprehensive information. These tools not only enable industry 
stakeholders to efficiently meet disclosure requirements but also position them to adapt to future 
advancements in the digital marketplace. GS1 US remains committed to working collaboratively 
with TTB, industry partners, and other stakeholders to support the successful implementation of 
this important initiative. Thank you for considering our comments. We look forward to the 
opportunity to contribute to a more transparent, informed, and trusted marketplace for alcohol 
beverage products. 
 
 
Sincerely,    
   
Maggie Lyons  
Vice President, Government and Regulatory Affairs
