comment_title: Comment 210:  Government of the United Kingdom (Comment Letter)
comment_text: See Attached
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Draft Comments to United States Enquiry Point to comment on Docket No. TTB-
2025-0002; Notices No. 238 – Major Food Allergen Labelling for Wines, Distilled 
Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
Dear colleagues in the Unites States Enquiry Point,  
The United Kingdom appreciates the opportunity to provide comments to The Alcohol and 
Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) regarding Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 238 
on Major Food Allergen Labelling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages notified to 
the WTO TBT Committee under G/TBT/N/USA/2183, G/TBT/N/USA/2183/Add.1.  
The United Kingdom fully supports TTB's efforts to ensure that consumers have the relevant 
product information to make informed decisions.  
Notice No. 238 on Major Food Allergen Labelling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages 
 
• In the UK, food businesses must inform consumers under food law if they use any of 
the 14 Allergens as ingredients in the food and drink they provide and this applies to 
alcoholic drinks for both prepacked (bottled or canned) or those served in a glass. This 
includes sulphites and sulphur dioxide, which are among the 14 allergens and are 
commonly found in alcoholic drinks. 
• Alcoholic drinks with more than 1.2% by volume of alcohol do not require an 
ingredients list. In this case, the presence of any of the 14 allergens which are present 
and not clear from the name of the food needs to be indicated. For example, a bottle 
of wine must have a statement such as: ‘Contains: sulphites, milk and egg. 
• The United Kingdom appreciates TTB’s approach regarding allergens labelling for 
distilled spirits. As stated in the Notice, the production of spirits involves the distillation 
of raw materials in such a way that no protein, allergenic or otherwise, remains in the 
distilled product or distilled ingredient. I n the UK view it is therefore appropriate that 
the mandatory labelling requirements do not apply to major food allergens used before 
the distillation process.  
• We also support the method of verifying compliance when ingredients containing 
protein are added to the distilled spirits product after distillation, and no major food 
allergens are listed on the label. 
• In addition, we would request that the US consider allowing operators to exhaust all 
their stock which was put on the market before the proposed rule comes into effect. 
The United Kingdom remains firmly committed to ensuring consumers have access to clear 
and relevant product information and appreciate the US consideration of the above comments.

Comité Européen des Entreprises Vins (CEEV) represents the wine companies in the industry and trade in the
European Union. Its members produce and market the vast majority of quality European wines, with and without

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
15/08/2025 
 
 
A. INTRODUCTION 
Comité Européen des Entreprises Vins ( CEEV) represents the wine companies in the industry and trade in the 
European Union. Its members produce and market the vast majority of quality European wines, with and without 
a geographical indication, and account for over 90% of European wine exports. Micr o and small and medium -
sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the EU wine sector, representing more than 9 9% of wine 
companies. 
In 2024, European wines accounted for approximately 64% of the volume and 78% of the value of total U.S. wine 
imports. That year, the European Union exported an estimated €4.9 billion worth of wine to the United States . 
This robust transatlantic trade reflects the enduring demand for European wines by US consumers.  
CEEV thanks the U.S. authorities for the opportunity to comment on Notice No. 238 (Docket No. TTB-2025-0003), 
which proposes mandatory labelling of major food allergens in wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. 
B. CEEV COMMENTS 
CEEV shares TTB’s commitment to improving consumer access to product information and supporting informed 
decision-making. In this spirit, we offer constructive input to help ensure that any future allergen labelling 
requirements appropriately reflect the specific characteristics of wine. 
CEEV believes that the proposed approach to allergen disclosure should be adapted to account for the particular 
role of processing aids in winemaking, the limited space available on wine labels, and the need for consistency 
with international standards. Wi thout such adjustments, the TTB’s proposal risks placing disproportionate 
burdens on EU wine producers, especially small and medium -sized enterprises , who rely on established 
international practices that ensure consumer safety without requiring mandatory labelling of allergens that are 
no longer present in the final product. 
In this context, CEEV respectfully submits the following key comments and requests for the TTB’s consideration: 
 
1. Allergen disclosure for processing aids – presence approach and threshold 
CEEV raises concerns over the TTB’s intention to introduce compulsory disclosure of processing aids derived 
from major food allergens, determined by their “use” rather than by their “presence” in the final product.  
This measure would disproportionately affect wine products, particularly those utili sing albumen, isinglass, or 
casein as fining or clarifying agents, substances commonly used in winemaking, when they have been removed 
prior to bottling. 
CEEV contribution to TTB consultation on  
Notice No. 238 - Major Food Allergen Labeling for 
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages    
 
 
 
The principle of “presence” is the basis hosen at international and at EU levels: 
- Under the Codex General Standard for the Labelling of Prepackaged Foods (CXS 1-1985), major allergens 
“shall always be declared as allergenic food using the specified name in addition to or as part of the 
ingredient name when intentionally present in the food”.  The same Codex Standard defines processing 
aids as “a substance or material, not including apparatus or utensils, and not consumed as a food 
ingredient by itself, intentionally used in the processing of raw materials, foods or its ingredients, to fulfil 
a certain technological purpose during treatment or pr ocessing and which may result in the non -
intentional but unavoidable presence of residues or derivatives in the final product”. 
- EU legislation  provides for Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011  on of food information to consumers, that 
requires the declaration of any ingredient or processing aid used in the manufacture or preparation of 
a food and still present in the finished product.  
In line with these principles, EU wine producers follow rigorous filtration techniques and good manufacturing 
practices, especially during fining and clarification, to minimise or eliminate allergenic residues before the wine 
reaches consumers. These practices are guided by resolutions from the International Organisation of Vine and 
Wine (OIV), such as: 
− OIV/OENO 427 -2010, which established the framework for identifying allergenic residues in wine, 
particularly those originating from protein-based fining agents. 
− OIV/OENO 520-2014, the Code of Good Fining Practices for Wine, which recommends best practices to 
avoid residual allergens. 
− OIV/SECSAN 709-2022, which updated analytical criteria to ensure precise detection and quantification 
of allergens, reinforcing food safety and consumer protection. 
 
Therefore, CEEV requests the TTB not to require allergen labelling for processing aids  for wine based on their 
use, instead of their presence . The “presence” approach for allergen declaration, ensures high levels of 
consumer protection.  
Additionally, CEEV request TTB to propose  a presence threshold that would trigger disclosure of major food 
allergens.  
 
2. Allergen labelling terminology 
CEEV requests the TTB to adopt the term “Contains:” followed by the name of the food source from which each 
major allergen is derived, in place of the more generic phrase “Contains Major Food Allergens.” 
CEEV considers that this terminology would offer greater clarity and legibility for U.S. consumers, consistent 
with existing labelling practices for health -sensitive ingredients such sulphites. The term “Contains” is already 
widely used and understood in the U.S. market . In addition, the use of this wording would align U.S. allergen 
labelling requirements for wine with internationally recognised standards, notably the Codex General Standard 
for the Labelling of Prepackaged Foods (CXS 1-1985).  
Under the European Union legislative framework, Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011  on food information to 
consumers, it is stipulated that if a food product does not include an ingredient list, any allergen present must 
be indicated using the word "contains" followed by the name of the allergen. 
These established international frameworks ensure strong consumer protection and promote regulatory 
consistency across markets. Aligning with them facilitates clear communication to consumers and helps avoid 
unnecessary barriers to market access for EU wine exporters, while also preventing complications for reciprocal 
trade by U.S. producers abroad. 
  
 
 
3. Certificate of Label Approval applications 
Considering the variability of wine, CEEV is in favor of the TTB’s proposed exemption from requiring new COLA 
when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion or alteration of the required statement of major 
food allergens. 
 
4. Implementation period 
CEEV supports the TTB’s proposed five-year phase-in period as a reasonable timeframe for wine companies to 
adapt to the new requirements. 
In addition, CEEV requests the TTB that, should the rulemaking under Notice No. 237 – Alcohol Facts Statements 
in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages be adopted, its effective date be aligned with that 
of Notice No. 238 – Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Dist illed Spirits, and Malt Beverages, to ensure 
coordinated implementation and minimise disruption for producers.

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August  15,  2025   Ms.  Amy  Greenberg  Director,  Regulations  and  Rulings  Division  Alcohol  and  Tobacco  Tax  and  Trade  Bureau  1310  G  Street,  NW  Box  12  Washington,  DC  20005   RE:  Docket  No.  TTB  2025-0004;  Notice  238:  Major  Food  Allergen  Labeling  for  Wines,  
Distilled
 
Spirits,
 
and
 
Malt
 
Beverages
   WineAmerica  is  the  National  Association  of  American  Wineries.  We  represent  wineries,  winery  
associations,
 
and
 
wine
 
industry
 
supply
 
companies
 
across
 
the
 
country.
 
Our
 
mission
 
is
 
to
 
encourage
 
the
 
dynamic
 
growth
 
and
 
development
 
of
 
American
 
wineries
 
and
 
winegrowing
 
through
 
the
 
advancement
 
and
 
advocacy
 
of
 
sound
 
public
 
policy.
 
We
 
respectfully
 
submit
 
the
 
following
 
comments
 
on
 
TTB
 
Notice
 
238:
 
Major
 
Food
 
Allergen
 
Labeling
 
for
 
Wines,
 
Distilled
 
Spirits
 
and
 
Malt
 
Beverages
  Background   In  February  2022,  the  Department  of  the  Treasury,  in  consultation  with  the  Department  of  Justice  
and
 
the
 
Federal
 
Trade
 
Commission,
 
released
 
a
 
report
 
on
 
competition
 
in
 
the
 
markets
 
for
 
alcoholic
 
beverages.
 
One
 
of
 
the
 
Competition
 
Report's
 
findings
 
was
 
that
 
“[r]egulatory
 
proposals
 
that
 
could
 
serve
 
public
 
health
 
and
 
foster
 
competition
 
by
 
providing
 
information
 
to
 
consumers,
 
such
 
as
 
mandatory
 
allergen,
 
nutrition,
 
and
 
ingredient
 
labeling
 
proposals,
 
have
 
not
 
been
 
implemented.” 
[
The
 
Competition
 
Report
 
made
 
some
 
labeling
 
recommendations,
 
including
 
a
 
recommendation
 
that
 
TTB
 
“should
 
revive
 
or
 
initiate
 
rulemaking
 
proposing
 
ingredient
 
labeling
 
and
 
mandatory
 
information
 
on
 
alcohol
 
content,
 
nutritional
 
content,
 
and
 
appropriate
 
serving
 
sizes.”
  On  January  31,  2024,  TTB  issued  Notice  No.  232,  which  announced  two  virtual  listening  
sessions
 
and
 
the
 
opening
 
of
 
a
 
public
 
docket
 
to
 
receive
 
written
 
comments
 
on
 
the
 
labeling
 
of
 
alcohol
 
beverages
 
with
 
per-serving
 
alcohol
 
and
 
nutritional
 
information,
 
major
 
food
 
allergens,
 
and/or
 
ingredients.
 
WineAmerica
 
participated
 
in
 
the
 
listening
 
sessions
 
and
 
made
 
it
 
clear
 
that
 
the
 
preferred
 
disclosure
 
for
 
all
 
of
 
these
 
new
 
labeling
 
proposals
 
would
 
be
 
off
 
label.
 
  TTB  is  proposing  rules  for  the  mandatory  labeling  of  major  food  allergens  used  in  the  production  
of
 
alcohol
 
beverages.
 
Consistent
 
with
 
the
 
FALCPA
 
House
 
committee
 
report
 
and
 
TTB's
 
statutory
 
mandate
 
under
 
the
 
FAA
 
Act
 
to
 
promulgate
 
regulations
 
ensuring
 
that
 
consumers
 
receive
 
adequate
 
information
 
about
 
the
 
identity
 
and
 
quality
 
of
 
alcohol
 
beverages,
 
TTB
 
believes
 
that
 
alcohol
 
beverage  labels  should  provide  consumers  with  sufficient  information  about  the  use  of  major  
food
 
allergens
 
in
 
the
 
production
 
of
 
alcohol
 
beverages
 
so
 
that
 
consumers
 
with
 
food
 
allergies
 
may
 
make
 
an
 
informed
 
decision
 
as
 
to
 
whether
 
consumption
 
of
 
a
 
particular
 
beverage
 
may
 
pose
 
a
 
risk
 
of
 
an
 
allergic
 
reaction.
  Specific  Comments   Should  TTB  adopt  the  proposed  wording  of  the  major  food  allergen  statement  (“Contains  major  
food
 
allergen(s)”
 
followed
 
by
 
a
 
colon
 
and
 
the
 
name
 
of
 
the
 
food
 
source
 
from
 
which
 
each
 
major
 
food
 
allergen
 
is
 
derived)?
  WineAmerica  would  be  in  favor  of  such  a  disclosure  only  if  there  is  a  detectable  trace  of  the  
potential
 
allergen
 
in
 
the
 
finished
 
product.
 
Quite
 
often
 
wineries
 
will
 
use
 
certain
 
fining
 
and
 
filtering
 
agents
 
that
 
will
 
have
 
no
 
detectable
 
trace
 
in
 
the
 
finished
 
product.
 
  Should  TTB  allow  the  inclusion  of  major  food  allergens  within  a  voluntary  ingredient  statement  
on
 
labels
 
as
 
an
 
alternative
 
to
 
a
 
separate
 
major
 
food
 
allergen
 
statement?
  Producers  that  wish  to  disclose  that  information  should  have  this  option.   If  mandatory  ingredient  labeling  is  ultimately  adopted,  should  TTB  allow  the  inclusion  of  major  
food
 
allergens
 
in
 
the
 
list
 
of
 
ingredients
 
as
 
an
 
alternative
 
to
 
a
 
separate
 
major
 
food
 
allergen
 
statement?
 
If
 
mandatory
 
ingredient
 
labeling
 
is
 
ultimately
 
adopted,
 
should
 
TTB
 
use
 
the
 
“Contains”
 
statement
 
for
 
major
 
food
 
allergens,
 
consistent
 
with
 
FDA's
 
approach?
 
Should
 
TTB
 
limit
 
the
 
use
 
of
 
the
 
“Contains”
 
statement
 
only
 
for
 
major
 
food
 
allergens?
  If  ingredient  labeling  is  eventually  adopted,  WineAmerica  supports  the  use  of  one  statement  in  
an
 
off
 
label
 
disclosure
 
as
 
one
 
option.
  Should  other  ingredients  that  are  required  to  be  disclosed  under  current  TTB  regulations  (FD&C  
Yellow
 
No.
 
5,
 
cochineal
 
extract
 
or
 
carmine,
 
sulfites,
 
and
 
aspartame)
 
be
 
required
 
to
 
be
 
listed
 
in
 
one
 
statement
 
on
 
the
 
label?
 
If
 
so,
 
should
 
the
 
other
 
ingredients
 
be
 
included
 
in
 
a
 
“Contains”
 
statement
 
that
 
includes
 
the
 
major
 
food
 
allergens?
 
(For
 
example,
 
“Contains
 
egg
 
and
 
sulfites”).
 
Or
 
should
 
the
 
major
 
food
 
allergens
 
be
 
identified
 
as
 
such,
 
and
 
the
 
other
 
ingredients
 
listed
 
separately
 
(for
 
example,
 
“Contains
 
Major
 
Food
 
Allergen:
 
egg.
 
Contains
 
sulfites”)?
 
Should
 
another
 
statement
 
be
 
used
 
for
 
ingredients
 
that
 
are
 
required
 
to
 
be
 
disclosed
 
under
 
current
 
TTB
 
regulations
 
(FD&C
 
Yellow
 
No.
 
5,
 
cochineal
 
extract
 
or
 
carmine,
 
sulfites,
 
and
 
aspartame)
 
to
 
differentiate
 
from
 
the
 
“Contains”
 
statement
 
for
 
major
 
food
 
allergens?
  WineAmerica  would  be  in  favor  of  one  disclosure  statement,  if  there  are  any  detectable  allergens  
in
 
the
 
finished
 
product.
 
  Would  requiring  all  mandatory  disclosures  to  be  in  one  place  on  the  label,  including  the  
proposed
 
major
 
food
 
allergen
 
statement,
 
make
 
it
 
easier
 
for
 
consumers
 
to
 
find
 
this
 
information?
 
Would
 
such
 
a
 
requirement
 
impose
 
additional
 
costs
 
or
 
regulatory
 
burdens
 
on
 
industry
 
members
 
as
 
compared
 
to
 
allowing
 
the
 
mandatory
 
disclosures
 
to
 
appear
 
separately?
  WineAmerica  would  be  in  favor  of  all  mandatory  disclosures  in  one  place  on  the  label,  but  this  
premise
 
is
 
exactly
 
why
 
the
 
off
 
label
 
disclosure
 
of
 
mandatory
 
information
 
is
 
the
 
best
 
solution.
 
This
 
will
 
avoid
 
clutter
 
on
 
the
 
label,
 
which
 
could
 
lead
 
to
 
consumer
 
confusion.
 
There
 
would
 
be
 
additional
 
costs
 
in
 
changing
 
any
 
labeling
 
of
 
a
 
product.
 
It
 
is
 
estimated
 
that
 
changing
 
each
 
individual
 
label
 
could
 
cost
 
up
 
to
 
$1600.
 
An
 
off
 
label
 
solution
 
would
 
be
 
most
 
cost
 
effective
 
for
 
wineries,
 
particularly
 
if
 
a
 
new
 
COLA
 
is
 
not
 
required.
  Should  TTB  mandate  specific  placement,  type  size,  and  presentation  requirements  for  major  
allergen
 
labeling
 
statements
 
in
 
addition
 
to
 
the
 
requirements
 
already
 
applicable
 
to
 
all
 
mandatory
 
information
 
on
 
alcohol
 
beverage
 
labels?
 
For
 
example,
 
should
 
the
 
required
 
allergen
 
disclosure
 
statement
 
be
 
set
 
off
 
by
 
a
 
box?
 
Or,
 
to
 
the
 
extent
 
practicable,
 
should
 
TTB
 
mandate
 
formatting
 
consistent
 
with
 
FDA
 
requirements
 
for
 
major
 
allergen
 
labeling?
  WineAmerica  would  be  in  favor  of  a  type  size  that  would  match  the  requirements  for  other  
statements
 
required
 
on
 
a
 
wine
 
label,
 
such
 
as
 
the
 
alcohol
 
content
 
and
 
the
 
sulfite
 
statement.
 
The
 
TTB
 
should
 
require
 
disclosure
 
in
 
a
 
linear
 
format
 
or
 
off
 
label
 
through
 
a
 
QR
 
code
 
or
 
other
 
web
 
based
 
disclosure.
  Other  Comments   Wine  is  a  unique,  value  added  agricultural  product.  It  is  made  in  all  fifty  states  by  nearly  11,000  
wine
 
producers.
 
The
 
wine
 
industry
 
provides
 
$323
 
billion
 
in
 
economic
 
impact
 
on
 
the
 
United
 
States
 
economy.
 
Wine
 
can
 
only
 
be
 
produced
 
once
 
a
 
year
 
and
 
is
 
dependent
 
on
 
the
 
climate
 
and
 
other
 
environmental
 
factors.
 
Wine
 
is
 
also
 
unique
 
because
 
it
 
does
 
not
 
follow
 
a
 
recipe
 
or
 
formula.
 
There
 
will
 
be
 
times
 
where
 
wine
 
will
 
need
 
to
 
use
 
additives
 
and
 
other
 
agents
 
to
 
filter
 
and
 
finish
 
the
 
wine.
 
These
 
are
 
almost
 
never
 
detectable
  
in
 
the
 
finished
 
product.
 
  WineAmerica  is  in  favor  of  both  allergen  and  ingredient  disclosures,  as  long  as  it  is  done  in  a  
way
 
that
 
is
 
not
 
a
 
detriment
 
to
 
the
 
American
 
wine
 
industry.
 
Only
 
agents
 
that
 
are
 
detectable
 
in
 
the
 
finished
 
product
 
should
 
need
 
to
 
be
 
disclosed
 
by
 
a
 
producer.
 
Additionally,
 
as
 
we
 
stated
 
in
 
our
 
comments
 
for
 
Notice
 
237,
 
an
 
off
 
label,
 
web
 
based
 
disclosure
 
is
 
the
 
best
 
option
 
for
 
the
 
wine
 
industry.
 
This
 
is
 
already
 
occurring
 
in
 
the
 
European
 
Union
 
and
 
should
 
naturally
 
be
 
an
 
option
 
for
 
our
 
producers.
  The  American  wine  industry  is  unique  in  that  it  is  truly  nationwide  in  both  production  and  
consumption,
 
and
 
the
 
vast
 
majority
 
of
 
wine
 
producers
 
are
 
small
 
family
 
farms
 
with
 
limited
 
resources.
 
As
 
a
 
result,
 
WineAmerica
 
proposes
 
that
 
any
 
potential
 
changes
 
take
 
that
 
into
 
account,
 
such
 
as
 
allowing
 
off-label
 
options
 
to
 
fulfill
 
any
 
requirements.
  WineAmerica  would  like  to  thank  TTB  for  the  opportunity  to  comment  on  the  proposed  
rulemaking.
 
 Respectfully  submitted.    Michael  Kaiser  Executive  Vice  President  and  Director  of  Government  Affairs   WineAmerica

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 15, 2025 
Regulations and Ruling Division  
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
1310 G Street NW, Box 12  
Washington, DC 20005 
Comment on Proposed Rule: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages (Docket No. TTB-2025-0003) 
 
The undersigned organizations call on the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) to finalize 
the proposed rule mandating on-package labeling major food allergens and to propose a rule requiring full 
labeling of all ingredients. These rules will be a step forward, as current alcohol labels do not provide the 
information that consumers with food allergies need to make informed purchasing and consumption 
decisions. 
 
We commend TTB for issuing a proposed rule that would greatly improve transparency and protect 
consumers with food allergies by requiring labeling of the Top 9 major food allergens without exemption 
for processing aids. The rule could be strengthened by specifying where the allergen disclosure should 
appear, outlining specific formatting requirements, and requiring species specific disclosure for the 
labeling of finfish.  
Major allergen labeling on alcohol is important because roughly 11% of U.S. adults have food allergies1 
and many alcoholic beverages contain major allergens, such as wheat in many beers, milk and nuts in 
liqueurs, and even fish and eggs used as processing aids in wine.2 Currently, consumers with food 
allergies have no way of knowing if they can safely consume alcoholic beverages because neither 
ingredient lists, nor major allergen labeling are required.  
Consumers desire this information and would use it when making purchasing decisions. In a March 2024 
poll of 1,509 adults who drink alcohol (commissioned by CSPI and conducted by Big Village), strong 
majorities of consumers said that allergen information (79%) and ingredients (88%) would be at least 
somewhat important for deciding whether to purchase a particular alcoholic beverage.3  
 
TTB should make clear in the final rule that this vital safety information should never be provided solely 
via QR code, as this would specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones 
or similar technology (including those who are older or living rurally).  
Separately, TTB should publish a rule mandating full ingredients labeling on-package for all alcoholic 
beverages. This would further improve transparency on alcoholic products and provide additional 
protection for consumers with allergies to foods outside the Top 9 major food allergens. 
Alcohol should no longer be exempt from the basic labeling of allergens that consumers with allergies can 
rely upon for nearly all other foods and beverages. To ensure timely consumer access to this important 
information, the final rule should adopt a shorter compliance period of 3.5 years instead of the 5-year 
period proposed. 
 
We urge TTB to prioritize transparency by not only finalizing the proposed Major Food Allergen 
Labeling rule, but also by proposing a rule to mandate ingredients labeling on alcohol to ensure that 
Americans with food allergies can identify other ingredients that trigger allergy beyond the major food 
allergens.  
 
  Sincerely, 
 
Alcohol Justice 
Allergy and Asthma Network 
Alpha-gal Alliance Action Fund 
American Society for Nutrition 
Association of State Public Health Nutritionists 
Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America 
Celiac Disease Foundation  
Center for Science in the Public Interest 
Consumer Federation of America 
Consumer Reports 
CURED Nfp 
Elija-Alavi Foundation 
FARE (Food Allergy Research & Education) 
Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis Connection Team (FAACT) 
Food Equality Initiative 
Interfaith Public Health Network 
National Consumers League 
Project Extra Mile 
The FPIES Foundation 
U.S. Alcohol Policy Alliance 
 
Individuals: 
 
Thomas K. Greenfield 
Senior Scientist 
Alcohol Research Group 
 
Kaela Plank 
Health Program Planner 
San Francisco Department of Public Health 
 
  References 
 
1 Gupta RS, Warren CM, Smith BM, et al. Prevalence and Severity of Food Allergies Among US Adults. 
JAMA Netw Open. 2019;2(1):e185630. doi:10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2018.5630 
2 Allergy and Anaphylaxis Australia. Food Allergy and Alcohol. August 13, 2024. Accessed March 12, 
2025. https://allergyfacts.org.au/food-allergy-and-alcohol/  
3 Big Village’s CARAVAN U.S. Online Omnibus Survey, administered March 15-20, 2024.

comment_text: Please see attached comment from Wine Institute.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Page 1 of 6  
 
 
August 15, 2025 
 
Ms. Amy Greenberg 
Director, Regulations and Rulings Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
RE: Docket No. TTB-2025-0003; Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg, 
 
Wine Institute is the public policy advocacy association representing over 1,000 California 
wineries and affiliated businesses.  Our membership consists of wineries of all sizes including 
many small and family-owned wineries.  California is responsible for more than 81 percent of 
the nation’s wine production and more than 95 percent of US wine exports.   Wine Institute is 
committed to sound public policy at every level .  To that end, we provide the following 
comments in response to Notice of Proposed Rulemaking No. 23 8: Major Food Allergen 
Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (“NPRM 238”). 
 
Science-based major food allergen labeling that properly identifies products containing 
allergenic protein capable of causing an adverse reaction can be beneficial for consumers 
with allergies.  Accordingly, we support the current interim rule which provides for voluntary 
labeling of major food allergens in wine.  That said, we are concerned that what TTB proposes 
in NPRM 238—which does not base mandatory labeling on the presence of allergenic protein 
at certain levels or at all—will depart from international standards, cause consumer 
confusion and other  unintended consequences, and will present enforcement issues and 
potential trade distortions that negatively impact US wineries.   
 
The wine marketplace is distinct in terms of both the number of producers and unique wines 
available.  A ccording to TTB, there are currently more than 17,500 bonded wine producers 
across the US and approximately 6,300 of them are in California.  Like our membership, the 
overwhelming majority of these are small, family -owned wineries that operate in a heavily  
regulated industry with correspondingly high costs  in establishing and maintaining their 
businesses.  Therefore, it is critical that any new regulations be fiscally responsible, 
reasonable, minimally intrusive to winery operations, and adopted only if leg itimate public 
Page 2 of 6  
goals and established benefits to consumers justify them.  We respectfully request that TTB 
consider our comments fully given that NPRM 238 constitutes a “significant regulatory action” 
that will impose new financial and operational burdens on California’s many great wineries. 
 
1. Allergen Labeling and Unique Aspects of Wine 
 
Pursuant to the Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act of 2004 (“FALCPA”), food 
products that contain an ingredient that bears or contains a major food allergen (i.e., milk, egg, 
fish, Crustacean shellfish, tree nuts, wheat, peanuts, soybeans, and sesame ) must include 
this information on their labels unless the food ingredient does not cause an allergic response 
that poses a risk to human health or does not contain allergenic protein.   FALCPA does not 
apply to alcohol beverages that TTB regulate s under the F ederal Alcohol Administration  Act 
(“FAA Act”).  Instead, consistent with a 1987 Memorand um of  Understanding (“MOU”) , TTB 
worked with FDA in promulgation NPRM 238.  As TTB notes, however, the proposed regulations 
do not necessarily represent the views of FDA regarding allergen labeling or the requirements 
of FALCPA. 
 
Federal winemaking regulations authorize and limit the use of certain materials and processes 
for the treatment of wine.
1  These treatments include filtering, clarifying, or purifying the wine 
to remove  cloudiness, precipitation, or undesirable odors and flavors .  As TTB recognizes, 
some of these materials are processing aids derived from major food allergens.  For example, 
albumen (egg white) is approved as a fining agent for wine, and isinglass (a gelatin derived from 
fish) and casein (derived from milk) are approved to clarify wine  
 
Processing aids perform a function during production and are either removed entirely from the 
final product by filtration or remain in only trace amounts that are not always detectible.  Fining 
agents such as eggs and milk have been used in wine production for millennia with few, if any, 
substantiated adverse reactions from allergy sufferers.  And not all wines use these approved 
materials.  A winemaker will make a conscious decision to use a particular fining agent for the 
effect that it will have on the wine ; in most cases there are no suitable alternatives to these 
agents, as each agent has a very specific impact on the resultant wine.   It is also worth noting 
that due to legal drinking age regulations, the at-risk population under consideration should be 
only those members of the population over the age of 21 years.   Studies have shown that the 
vast majority of milk and egg allergy sufferers have outgrown their allergies by the age of 21. 
 
In sum, while TTB may work with FDA to inform a proposed rule for allergen labeling, TTB may 
also take into consideration aspects that are unique to wine and other alcohol beverage 
products over which it has jurisdiction under the FAA Act  and adopt appropriate measures 
such as establishing threshold levels for any allergens (i.e., a value below which it is unlikely 
that a food allergic individual would experience an adverse effect).   
 
 
 
 
1 27 CFR 24.246. Page 3 of 6  
 
 
2. TTB Should Establish and Adopt Thresholds Before Imposing Mandatory Allergen 
Labeling 
 
TTB is not proposing any thresholds that would trigger disclosure of major food allergens.  
Instead, the proposed rule provides that all major food allergens and proteins derived from the 
major food allergens used in production  must be declared on the beverage label, unless an 
approved petition for exemption covers the product or class of products or they otherwise fall 
under an applicable exception.  TTB states that if FDA establishes thresholds in the future, TTB 
will reconsider its policy on this issue.   In short, TTB ’s approach is based on use —regardless 
of whether any proteins derived from a major food allergen remain in the final product—rather 
than their presence in the product.   As described below, we  have concerns about this “use” 
rather than “presence” approach, and the absence of any thresholds. 
 
A Vast Majority of Countries Adopt “Presence” Rather Than “Use” for Allergen Labeling 
Contrary to what TTB proposes, Codex Alimentarius  and the OIV recommend “presence” and 
not “use ” as the trigger for allergen labeling.
2  Indeed, “presence” is almost universally the 
adopted standard.  We found almost 60 countries, including the 27 EU member states , that 
adopt “presence” as the standard. 3   We found only two counties that may take the “use” 
approach that TTB proposes.4   
 
Notably, the 27 EU member states  and at least six other countries  exempt isinglass from 
mandatory allergen labeling on alcohol beverages  after the European Foo d Safety Authority 
issued an opinion finding it was  not very likely that isinglass  used as clarifying agent in beer 
would trigger a severe allergic reaction in susceptible individuals  under the conditions of 
production and use specified in the application for exemption.   Moreover, Health Canada—a 
federal department responsible for public health—issued the following  position on fining 
agents in 2012:   
 
Although wines may be manufactured using allergen- or gluten-derived fining 
agents, mainly ovalbumin (protein from egg), casein (protein from milk) and, 
to a lesser extent, isinglass (protein from fish), the enhanced labelling 
 
2 Codex is a set of  internationally recognized standards for food and  labeling that two U N agencies (Food and 
Agricultural Organization and World Health Organization)  publish. International Organization of Vine and Wine  
(OIV) is an intergovernmental organization that addresses technical and scientific aspects of viticulture and wine. 
3 Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, Columbia, Costa Rica, Croatia, Cypr us, 
Czechia, Denmark, Dominican Republic, East African Community, Ecuador, El Salvador, Estonia, Finland, 
France, Georgia, Germany, Greece, Guatemala, Honduras, Hungary, India, Ireland, Italy, Jamaica, Kenya, Latvia, 
Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Mexico, New Zealand, Netherlands, Nicaragua, Nigeria, Norway, Panama, Papua 
New Guinea, Peru, Philippines , Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, South Africa, Spain, Sweden 
Switzerland, Chinese Taipei, Tanzania, Turkey, Ukraine, and Vietnam.  Note that our review of international 
regulations was neither comprehensive nor exhaustive.  W e relied on the subscriber- based online database 
Abridge (https://www.abridgebev.com/) for our review.   
4 Korea and Singapore.  Again, we note that our review was neither comprehensive nor exhaustive.  W e relied on 
the subscriber-based online database Abridge (https://www.abridgebev.com/). Page 4 of 6  
requirements are only triggered under the Regulations if the protein, or a 
modified protein, including any protein fraction, from an allergen source is 
present in the finished product. 
After conducting a thorough review of the current available scientific 
information, Health Canada scientists have concluded that the use of 
allergen-derived fining agents does not normally result in any appreciable 
amount of protein from food allergens remaining in the wine, particularly when 
usual manufacturing practices such as filtration steps are employed.  As such, 
the use of food allergen -derived fining agents in wine production, following 
good manufacturing practices, is not expected to produce wine that would 
pose a risk to egg, milk, or fish allergic consumers.  Therefore, in most cases 
of allergen-derived fining agent use, the new labelling regulations for priority 
allergens would not be triggered.
5 
 
What TTB proposes—i.e., labeling allergens based on use rather than presence—runs counter 
to the approach that an overwhelming majority of countries adopt for allergen labeling. 
 
On a similar note , and here in the US,  the Food Allergy Research and Resource Program 
(FARRP) at the University of Nebraska asserts that “it is now well -documented that food -
allergic individuals have threshold doses below which they will not experience adverse 
reactions.”6  That is one reason why FARRP concludes: “Regulatory guidance on thresholds for 
allergenic foods is sorely needed to improve the quality of life for food-allergic consumers and 
to focus limited regulatory resources on the genuine risks that exist to these consumers.”7  We 
agree.  We also agree with FARRP’s positions that thresholds must be scientifically based, and 
sufficient evidence exists to allow the development of regulatory thresholds for some of the 
most hazardous allergenic foods.
8 
 
Without Thresholds, Consumers Could be Misled 
TTB proposes labeling a wine with “ Contains Major Food Allergen ” any time major food 
allergens or proteins derived from major food allergens are used in production, even if they are 
used only as  processing aid s and do not remain in the final product  at all or only in trace 
amounts.  This proposed rule could mislead consumers and present wineries with conflicting 
regulations. 
 
Federal and state laws prohibit false and misleading statements including on wine labels.
9   In 
many instances, analysis of fined wines will not detect residues of processing aids  derived 
 
5 Health Canada, Bureau of Chemical Safety, Food Directorate, Health Products and Food Branch, Vintage Wine 
and Application of Enhanced Allergen Regulation, April 2012, available at  https://www.canada.ca/ 
content/dam/hc-sc/migration/hc-sc/fn-an/alt_formats/pdf/label-etiquet/allergen/vintage-wine-vin-millesimes-
eng.pdf.  
6 https://farrp.unl.edu/farrp-resources/thresholds-allergenic-foods/.  
7 Id. 
8 Id. 
9 See e.g., 27 CFR 4.39(a)(1) (prohibiting on wine labels “[a]ny statement that is false or untrue in any particular, 
 Page 5 of 6  
from food allergens  and that get filtered out.  For example, if casein ( milk) is used to  treat a 
wine it will trigger the proposed mandatory labeling  “Contains Major Food Allergen: m ilk.”  If 
an analysis is done on this wine and milk protein residues are not found—which is entirely 
plausible—the labeling  declaration potentially constitutes a false or  misleading statement  
because it does not “contain”  milk or milk proteins .  In fact, TTB expresses a similar concern 
when it explains why it is not proposing  advisory labeling such as  “May Contain” statements: 
“TTB is concerned that allergen advisory labeling could be used as substitute for adherence to 
current good manufacturing practices and could be misleading.” 
 
Instead, T TB proposes that an industry member may  include the added parenthetical 
“(processing aid),” if applicable, so the full declaration in that scenario could be: “Contains 
Major Food Allergen: milk (processing aid).”  It seems unlikely, however, that many if not most 
consumers understand what the term “processing aid”  means.  In addition, since including 
“(processing aid) ” is optional, it may not always appear , even when applicable.  The better 
solution would be for TTB to reconsider the proposed rule and establish and adopt thresholds 
so that actual presence of allergenic proteins at quantifiable and problematic amounts trigger 
mandatory labeling. An alternative approach is to use the phrase “Processed with [food 
allergen]” if TTB determines that a warning is required.  This does not claim the presence of the 
allergen, but simply notes the allergenic material was used in processing the wine. 
 
There is also a related concern that a zero-tolerance environment will only become 
increasingly challenging as analytical technology becomes more sensitive, permitting 
vanishingly low and inconsequential levels of processing aids and other components to be 
detected.  Science-based thresholds will help to improve the information provided to 
consumers so that they can make clear decisions about what foods or beverages they should 
avoid, and to which risks they are exposed .  Science-based thresholds will also allow 
producers to more accurately meet the public policy goals of allergen labeling. 
 
Last, there may be unintended consequences  from adopting a “use” standard for labeling 
wines.  For example, a consumer who is allergic to milk may have consumed a given wine over 
many years and suddenly finds it now states “Contains Major Food Allergen: milk.”  That 
individual may decide since they have consumed  the wine for years without  issue, they will 
continue to consume it.  Current scientific and observational data suggests that if the wine has 
been fined according to good practices , that person will not suffer an allergic reaction after 
drinking the wine.  This may embolden them to consume other foods that contain milk allergen 
labeling and do pose a risk to that consumer.  This is another way in which a “use” approach 
may not serve consumers well. 
 
A “Use” Standard Will Present Enforcement Challenges and Potential Trade Distortions 
Since a “non-detect” result by analysis does  not mean that potential allergens have  not been 
used in making any given wine, access to production records would be necessary to confirm 
what was used in production.  This would require additional TTB resources and time to 
 
or that, irrespective of falsity, directly, or by ambiguity, omission, or inference, or by the addition of irrelevant, 
scientific or technical matter, tends to create a misleading impression”).  Page 6 of 6  
investigate and it can only be done for domestically produced wine s and not for imported 
products.   If they have used potential allergens in production, winemakers exporting to the US 
will likely know that any remaining proteins are below the limit of analytical detection and may 
therefore choose to not declare something that lab analysis cannot detect.  US producers will 
then be placed at a disadvantage in the US market compared with imported products. 
 
3. A Five-Year Implementation Period is Reasonable and Necessary  if a Final Rule 
Issues 
 
TTB proposes a compliance date of five years from when a final rule is published in the Federal 
Register.  While we suggest that TTB first undertake work and review research to establish and 
adopt reasonable thresholds that would trigger allergen labeling, we agree with the proposed 
five-year compliance period for any final rule and with TTB’s sound reasons for proposing it.  
Five years would allow businesses to exhaust existing label stocks and prepare for new 
labeling processes which will help minimize —but not eliminate —financial and operational  
burdens.  It would allow ample time for public and stakeholder education and regulatory 
guidance.  It would also allow time to align other resources like product fact sheets, websites, 
and advertising material and ensure compliance.  Finally, as TTB noted in another rulemaking, 
five years is within the typical cycle for food and beverage products to relabel according to an 
FDA regulatory impact analysis for a food labeling rule.
10   
 
We also agree with TTB ’s proposal that industry members should not be required to submit 
new COLA applications when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion of a 
statement of major food allergens.   That too will help alleviate some of the ongoing financial 
and operational burdens  which is important given the proposed rule is considered a 
“significant regulatory action.” 
 
*** 
 
In closing, Wine Institute thanks TTB for the opportunity to comment on the issues raised in 
NPRM 238.  We would be pleased to respond to any follow-up questions that TTB might have 
concerning our comments. 
Thank you for your consideration. 
 
 
 
Robert P. Koch 
President & CEO 
Wine Institute 
 
10 U.S. Food and Drug Administration, Regulatory Impact Analysis for Final Rules On: “Food Labeling: Revision of 
the Nutrition and Supplement Facts Labels” and “Food Labeling: Serving Sizes of Foods That Can Reasonably Be 
Consumed at One Eating Occasion; Dua l-Column Labeling; Updating, Modifying, and Establishing Certain 
Reference Amounts Customarily Consumed; Serving Size for Breath Mints; and Technical Amendments,” 2016, 
available at https://www.fda.gov/media/98712/download.

comment_text: Please see our comments attached.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 15, 2025 
 
Director, Regulations and Ruling Division 
Alcohol, and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
1310 G Street NW, 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
Submitted electronically via Regulations.gov  
RE: Docket No. TTB-2025-0003; Notice No. 238; Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
To whom it may concern: 
 
As the association for the consumer-packaged goods (CPG) industry, including makers of food, 
beverage, personal care, and household products, the Consumer Brands Association champions 
the industry that makes the products you choose and the brands you trust. From household and 
personal care to food and beverage products, the consumer  packaged goods (CPG) industry 
plays a vital role in powering the U.S. economy, contributing $2.5 trillion to U.S. GDP and 
supporting 22.3 million American jobs. Consumer Brands advocates for uniform, workable, and 
durable regulatory frameworks that are informed by risk -based science, promote consumer 
choice, and build consumer trust across the sectors we represent. As such, we appreciate the 
opportunity to provide comments on the Alcohol, and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB or the 
Agency) proposed rule titled, “Alcohol Facts Statement in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, 
and Malt Beverages.” (Proposed Rule).  
 
As TTB develops labelling standards for most wine, spirits and malt beverages, we encourage it 
to allow  for the use of digital technologies to share labelling information with consumers. 
Succinctly, we urge the agency to be flexible in how labeling information is provided, 
including recognizing the valuable role that digital disclosure tools like SmartLabel can 
provide in facilitating accurate and up -to-date information ultimately leading to greater 
transparency for consumers.   
 
Introduction 
 
SmartLabel® by Consumer Brands Association is a nimble, adaptable digital platform launched 
in 2015 by brand owners and grocery retailers to give consumers access to more detailed product 
information than could ever fit on a package. SmartLabel serves as the defacto standard for  
consumer transparency and allows brands to display state and federally mandated and voluntary 
label information . Currently 80 parent companies participate in the SmartLabel program, 
representing more than 1,000 brands and over 100,000 products across all CPG categories, the 
largest being food and beverage. SmartLabel data is maintained by the participating brands who 
can provide  up-to-date product information with the click of a button. SmartLabel can easily 
accommodate the addition of data for wine, spirits and malt beverages.  
 
Further, SmartLabel can augment  federally required nutritional, ingredient , and allergen 
information with voluntary details that go beyond the package label such as ingredient definitions 
and sourcing  information, links to allergy prevention and management resources , as well as  SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 2 of 10 
 
sustainability attributes and practices.  Much of the voluntary information in SmartLabel spans 
nutrition, product claims,  certifications, and disclosures that consumers really care about.  
Consumers interacted with the SmartLabel platform over 22 million times in calendar year 2024. 
A national consumer survey with 1,000 respondents conducted in 2023 by the Consumer Brands 
Association found that consumers most often view the nutrition, ingredient , and allergen 
information on the SmartLabel pages. The survey also found that one-third of consumers have 
used SmartLabel and/or scanned a QR code to access product information  and 97% of those  
have used SmartLabel more than once. Almost six in ten (59%) American adults are likely to trust 
brands that feature SmartLabel, and more than half (55%) of consumers believe that integrating 
product information with SmartLabel will improve their impression of the brand. Consequently, 
SmartLabel food labeling provides the product information consumers seek to make informed 
decisions about the CPG products they purchase. 
 
SmartLabel Standardizes the Product Data Display 
 
SmartLabel complies with GS1 data standards (sourced via the Global Data Synchronisation 
Network or GDSN) for all attributes displayed on the platform and is a single source of up-to-date 
and accurate CPG product details because the data is directly owned, managed, updated, and 
hosted by the brand owner or the brand owner’s solution provider. Further, SmartLabel utilizes a 
uniform display and structure, which facilitates the ability of consumers to quickly and easily find 
the information they are seeking.  
 
SmartLabel can play an important role in providing accurate and up-to-date product information 
about alcoholic beverages to consumers.  SmartLabel data is displayed in a consistent 5 -tab 
template for all product categories  (Food and Beverage, Household Cleaning, Personal Care, 
Over-the-Counter Medications, Dietary Supplements and Pet Food)  and includes 
all federally mandated information that would be required to appear on the label  
(except for date code labeling for infant formula, which must be provided for the 
specific packaged product). For food and beverage products, the tabs are Nutrition, 
Ingredients, Allergens, About this Product (most of the voluntary information, 
including claims, resides on this tab) and Company, Brand & Sustainability.  
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 3 of 10 
 
The product image in the header of all SmartLabel pages can be clicked to display an enlarged 
image to aid consumers in determining if the product they have in hand matches the SmartLabel 
information. 
 
SmartLabel nutrition, ingredient, and allergen details are displayed in a consistent, readable 
template that mirrors the information on the packaging  and allows for variations in product 
formulations. The product image in the SmartLabel template header can be clicked to display an 
enlarged image of the package, which can be helpful for people with vision impairment. 
 
SmartLabel presents FDA mandatory information (nutrition information, ingredients, allergens, 
statement of identity, net quantity of contents, name and place of business, percent juice 
declaration and flavor labeling where applicable) in a consistent, easy to access and easy to read 
format. The SmartLabel program uses implementation manuals working with brands to provide 
information in accordance with applicable regulations for a consistent, reliable experience for 
consumers. For instances, the implementation manual for food and beverage prescribes that “the 
Nutrition Panel must exactly mirror what appears on the physical package for single column 
displays. ‘Exactly’ refers to all elements of the FDA’s Nutrition Facts label design including relative 
font sizes, indentations, alignment, and separation bar width. The Nutrition tab is not constrained 
by package size so the Nutrition Facts Panel should follow the FDA guidelines without truncation.” 
SmartLabel could implement a template that meets Alcohol/Serving Facts labelling requirements 
if any.  
 
The SmartLabel Trademark Licensing Agreement signed by all SmartLabel participants requires 
them to adhere to the specifications in the SmartLabel Food and Beverage Implementation 
Manual for the design and content in their SmartLabel pages. The program con ducts annual 
reviews of SmartLabel pages to make certain the data is consistent between the product 
packaging and the corresponding SmartLabel page. Elements that do not comply with 
programmatic and / or regulatory requirements are identified, and brands are given a reasonable 
time frame to bring their pages into compliance.   
 
SmartLabel is Accessible 
 
SmartLabel product pages can be accessed easily in several different ways including 
smartphones, tablets, and computers – and allow users to view the information in an easily legible 
format regardless of device . SmartLabel pages appear in the browser and do not require any 
software to download or install to view SmartLabel.   
 
Consumers commonly use the native camera app on a smartphone or tablet to scan the 
SmartLabel branded QR code to reach the digital product information.  SmartLabel also offers a 
free application that can be downloaded for both iPhone and android smartphones. The app 
allows users to scan UPC barcodes for products that participate in SmartLabel. SmartLabel pages 
can also be searched and accessed using the Sm artLabel product database 
(https://SmartLabel.org/product-search) without access to the actual package. 
 
Given the ubiquity of smartphones and wide availability of broadband, consumers can readily 
access SmartLabel information by scanning the SmartLabel branded QR code. USDA’s 
Agricultural Marketing Service ( AMS) has found that as of 2021, most Americans (97 percent) SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 4 of 10 
 
owned a smartphone of some kind.1 In particular, the Pew Research Center found that 89 percent 
of urban adults, 84 percent of suburban adults, and 80 percent of rural adults in America own a 
smartphone2. The Pew Research Center also found that 61 percent of individuals 65 and older  
own a smartphone.  
 
Similarly, QR code interactions increased by an estimated 6,200% between 2017 and 2021, with 
91% of consumers now having used a QR code at least once, and 87.1% of survey participants 
stating that QR codes are easy to use. 3 Moreover, internet access today is not the issue it once 
was. Today, 95% of American adults have reported that they use the internet.4  
 
Further, SmartLabel pages comply with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines developed by 
the World Wide Web Consortium’s (W3C’s) Web Accessibility Initiative, which partners with 
organizations around the world to provide a high degree of internet usability for people with 
disabilities by: 
• ensuring that W3C standards support accessibility 
• developing accessibility guidelines for web content and applications, browsers, and 
authoring tools 
• developing resources to improve web accessibility evaluation processes and tools 
• supporting education and outreach on web accessibility 
• coordinating with research and development that may impact future accessibility of the 
web 
• promoting harmonized international uptake of web accessibility standards 
 
The SmartLabel Template 
 
The SmartLabel landing page for food and beverage products is the Nutrition Tab, which 
replicates the Nutrition Facts Panel (NFP) on pack, including the FDA required formatting. In-
depth interviews from the 2021 national survey conducted by the Consumer Brands Association 
and FMI, revealed consumers found the product information in SmartLabel to be very clear, easy 
to navigate and easy to read. Consumers explained the digital rendering of the NFP in SmartLabel 
is easier to read than the NFP on-pack. 
 
 
1 DELOITTE, Study of Electronic or Digital Link Disclosure: A Third-Party Evaluation of Challenges Impacting Access 
to Bioengineered Food Disclosure, U.S. DEP’T OF AG. (July 2017), https://www.ams.usda.gov/sites/default/files  
/media/USDADeloitteStudyofElectronicorDigitalDisclosure20170801.pdf  (hereinafter, “Deloitte Study”). 
 
2 See PEW RESEARCH CENTER, Mobile Fact Sheet (Jan. 31, 2024), https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-
sheet/mobile/. 
3 See Alexander Eser, Essential QR Code Statistics in 2024, ZIPDO (July 4, 2023), https://zipdo.co/statistics/qr-
code/; see also Laura Ceci, U.S. smartphone users scanning QR codes 2020-2025, STATISTICS (Feb, 28, 2023), 
https://www.statista.com/statistics/1297768/us-smartphone-users-qr-scanner/(noting that in 2022, 
approximately 89 million smartphone users in the United States scanned a QR code on their mobile devices, up by 
26% compared to 2020. Usage of mobile QR code scanners is projected to experience constant growth, reaching 
over 100 million users in the U.S. by 2025). 
4 See PEW RESEARCH CENTER, Internet/Broadband Fact Sheet (Jan. 31, 2024), 
https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/internet-broadband/. SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 5 of 10 
 
 
 
Ingredients are displayed on the second tab in descending order of predominance in a stacked, 
legible format. Many of the food and beverage implementors in SmartLabel also include voluntary 
information on ingredient definitions and functions , which can be accessed by clicking on the 
arrow next to the listed ingredient . The ingredients tab also supports information on ingredient 
sourcing and growing methods, providing consumers with valuable information about the products 
they consume. 
 
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 6 of 10 
 
 
The third tab, Allergens, displays a statement identifying the nine major food allergens under the 
Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. Allergens contained in the product are listed in a stacked 
format, with the option for brands to also provide additional information on the composition of the 
allergen – for example, the allergen “milk” in a product might be composed of pasteurized milk 
and cream, dried milk , and cream cheese  – and links to allergy prevention and management 
resources. 
The fourth tab – About this Product  – displays voluntary information like claims, certifications, 
health and safety  warnings and product instructions. The fifth tab – Company, Brand & 
Sustainability – displays hyperlinks to the brand’s customer suppor t and website, company 
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 7 of 10 
 
website, Dietary Guidelines for Americans and USDA My Plate. The fifth tab is also used to display 
product sustainability attributes like How2Recycle , Recycle Check, CIRT  and hyperlinks to 
corporate sustainability practices. 
SmartLabel is a viable option for manufacturers to provide product information, both mandatory 
and voluntary, that may not be as readily available or in -depth on the product packaging. Other 
types of detailed product information that are available to consumers through SmartLabel that go 
beyond what is commonly available on the product packaging  include information about, 
bioengineered food declarations, product certifications, sustainability attributes, and company or 
brand information.  
 
Additionally, SmartLabel informs consumers that a product contains a known allergen and, if 
provided by the manufacturer, can go further and advise if the product was made in a shared 
facility or even on shared equipment for hyper-sensitive consumers. 
 
SmartLabel Facilitates Data Management  
 
For CPG manufacturers, the processes for managing digital product content generally run in 
parallel with the changes made to the physical label. Manufacturers need to determine when the 
updated product and its label will be in market to identify when it would be appropriate to circulate 
the updated online retail information. This determination does not follow a specific timeline  
because it is based on the estimated turnover rate of the product that is in commerce.  
 
Manufacturers can update SmartLabel to accommodate reformulations in near real time . 
Furthermore, SmartLabel displays the  date of the  information up date in the footer of each 
SmartLabel page: 
 
 
 
 
Consumer Research Validates SmartLabel as a Digital Transparency Tool 
 
Through consumer research , SmartLabel has confirmed that consumers expect the labeling 
information in SmartLabel to be consistent with the information on the label. As noted, the program 
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 8 of 10 
 
conducts annual reviews of SmartLabel pages to ensure the data is consistent between the 
product packaging and the corresponding SmartLabel page.  
 
Consumer research conducted in 2023 by SmartLabel nationally with 1,000 respondents across 
all demographic groups found that 43% of consumers are very likely to access more product 
information online (compared to what is provided on the label).  
 
For reasons related to their family’s well-being, 80% of respondents said they would like to know 
more about products than what is usually  on the package label . When asked about shopping 
online, 80% of survey respondents said they seek more information about a product when 
shopping online than when shopping in-store. 
 
The same survey found that 84% of consumers said they believe product information directly from 
the manufacturer is most accurate. SmartLabel pages are populated directly by the brand owners. 
 
Consumers also sa id access to product information in SmartLabel is faster and easier  to read 
than the same information on the package label . The 5 -tab SmartLabel template serves as a 
standard and ensures consistency in the way product information is displayed  
 
Digital Disclosure Provides Benefits to Manufacturers and Consumers 
 
The benefits of digital labeling accrue to both consumers and manufacturers. Consumers demand 
transparency and value the detailed ingredient, nutrition and health information  in SmartLabel. 
They appreciate the consistency of the SmartLabel design, its organized layout and the ease of 
access. Moreover, providing information via off -label, electronic means benefit s consumers by 
ensuring they receive the most up -to-date, accurate, and more comprehensive information  
directly from the product manufacturers.  A national consumer survey with 1,000 respondents 
conducted in 2023 by the Consumer Brands Association and FMI found that: 
• 58% of consumers look for SmartLabel on products  and 51% are likely to buy products 
featuring SmartLabel. 
• 60% of consumers are likely to trust brands that feature SmartLabel. 
• Accurate and up -to-date product information and detailed product information a re key 
purchase drivers. 26% of consumers are willing to pay more for products that offer 
additional information through SmartLabel.  
 
For brand owners, the primary benefit of using the electronic or digital link disclosure option is the 
ability for the industry to rapidly and efficiently update product information, therefore minimizing 
packaging costs and packaging obsolescence. Updates are influenced by numerous factors 
including reformulations, supplier driven changes, supply chain pressures, packaging inventory 
turnover as well as limited vendor resources. Electronic or digital disclosure provides flexibility for 
manufacturers to quickly address product changes as ingredient supplies are updated and 
modified. A nimble and adaptable tool allows for efficient communication and transparency, 
ultimately benefiting consumers. with minimal disruptions to both the manufacturer and 
consumers.  
With SmartLabel, brands don’t need to touch their packaging as often, since changes can be 
made to the SmartLabel page on the fly. When a change is made on the SmartLabel page, it will SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 9 of 10 
 
appear everywhere the page is hosted in real time – on the brand ecommerce pages and retail 
ecommerce sites. In other words, with SmartLabel, manufacturers only have to make a change 
once, instead of on multiple platforms. As important, the ability to make real-time corrections and 
provide real-time information can streamline and aid regulatory enforcement efforts associated 
with any new and mandatory labeling rules. 
 
GS1 Sunrise 2027 is Just Around the Corner 
 
SmartLabel is collaborating with GS1 US in prepara tion for Sunrise 2027 – the transition from 
UPC barcodes to 2D barcodes (Digital Links). With a single scan on a smartphone, a GS1 digital 
link-enabled SmartLabel QR code will allow consumers to access nutritional information, 
allergens, sustainability and sourcing data on the SmartLabel product page. That same QR code 
can be scanned at the point-of-sale (POS) checkout counter for price lookup and a variety of other 
supply chain processes related to inventory management and recall readiness. More information 
on GS1 Sunrise 2027 and 2D barcodes can be found here. A June 13, 2025 article in Packaging 
World described how brands are piloting 2D barcodes today in anticipation of Sunrise 2027. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
******************************************************************** 
 
 
Thank you again for the opportunity to provide comment on the TTB’s proposal for mandatory 
labeling for wine, distilled spirits and malt beverages . SmartLabel and its  implementers are 
committed to consumer transparency, enhancing trust in the CPG industry, and ensuring that 
consumers can make informed product purchasing decisions. The TTB has an important role to 
play in supporting the standardization of labeling information and supporting innovation  and 
flexibility by permitting the use of digital technology to provide  core regulatory information to 
consumers. Further, SmartLabel is a solution to the transition to 2D barcodes.  
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 10 of 10 
 
We urge the agency to be flexible  in how labeling information is provided, including 
recognizing the valuable role that digital disclosure tools like  SmartLabel can provide in 
facilitating accurate and up-to-date information ultimately leading to greater transparency 
for consumers.   
 
 
Respectfully submitted, 
 
 
 
Rishi Banerjee 
Senior Director, SmartLabel 
Consumer Brands Association

comment_text:
On behalf of the Government of Mexico, I hereby attach the comments of the Mexican alcoholic beverages industry regarding the U.S. TTB’s draft regulation "Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages," with the attentive request that they are taken into account in the elaboration of the final standard. The Mexican industry appreciates the notification (G/TBT/N/USA/2183) made to the WTO TBT Committee in accordance with Article 2.9.2 of the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, which allows comments to be considered at a stage where modifications to the proposal are still possible.

We note that the proposed regulation requires mandatory labeling of major food allergens in alcoholic beverages with the phrase "Contains Major Food Allergen(s)" followed by the specific allergens. While recognizing the importance of allergen disclosure for consumer safety, the Mexican alcoholic beverages industry considers that adding a separate declaration in addition to the ingredient list may increase costs and constitute a potential technical barrier to trade, contrary to Article 2.2 of the TBT Agreement.

We encourage the TTB to consider integrating allergen information into the ingredient list as the primary method, consistent with existing voluntary declarations (T.D. TTB-53) and in line with the CODEX Alimentarius recommendations. We also suggest that the use of electronic labeling tools, such as QR codes or digital platforms, be considered to provide additional information in a clear, accessible, and consumer-friendly manner.

Finally, we highlight that compliance timelines and exemptions for distilled products should continue to be considered to avoid undue trade impacts. The Mexican industry appreciates the consideration of these comments to ensure that the regulation promotes consumer safety without imposing unnecessary barriers to trade. We thank you in advance for your kind attention and remain attentive to your response.
gov_agency: Government of Mexico (Director General of International Trade Disciplines, Secretary of Economy of Mexico, Undersecretary of Foreign Trade)
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
On behalf of the Government of Mexico, I hereby attach the comments of the Mexican alcoholic beverages industry regarding the U.S. TTB’s draft regulation "Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages," with the attentive request that they are taken into account in the elaboration of the final standard. The Mexican industry appreciates the notification (G/TBT/N/USA/2183) made to the WTO TBT Committee in accordance with Article 2.9.2 of the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, which allows comments to be considered at a stage where modifications to the proposal are still possible.

We note that the proposed regulation requires mandatory labeling of major food allergens in alcoholic beverages with the phrase "Contains Major Food Allergen(s)" followed by the specific allergens. While recognizing the importance of allergen disclosure for consumer safety, the Mexican alcoholic beverages industry considers that adding a separate declaration in addition to the ingredient list may increase costs and constitute a potential technical barrier to trade, contrary to Article 2.2 of the TBT Agreement.

We encourage the TTB to consider integrating allergen information into the ingredient list as the primary method, consistent with existing voluntary declarations (T.D. TTB-53) and in line with the CODEX Alimentarius recommendations. We also suggest that the use of electronic labeling tools, such as QR codes or digital platforms, be considered to provide additional information in a clear, accessible, and consumer-friendly manner.

Finally, we highlight that compliance timelines and exemptions for distilled products should continue to be considered to avoid undue trade impacts. The Mexican industry appreciates the consideration of these comments to ensure that the regulation promotes consumer safety without imposing unnecessary barriers to trade. We thank you in advance for your kind attention and remain attentive to your response.
