document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
From: 
Cámara Nacional 
de la Industria 
Tequilera  
To: Alcohol and Tobacco Tax 
and Trade Bureau (TTB) Subject: 
Comments on: Major Food Allergen Labeling 
for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 238 
Notification : G/TBT/N/USA/2183 
 
Agency responsible: 
 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
About the Cámara Nacional de la Industria Tequilera: The Chamber of the Tequila Industry (CNIT – 
for its acronym in Spanish) is the leading voice of the Tequila industry worldwide, championing the 
interests of its members and promoting the responsible production and consumption of Tequila. As 
a globally recognized symbol of Mexico, Tequila has a rich history dating back to the 16th century 
and boasts a Designation of Origin Tequila (DOT) acknowledged by 57 countries. The Tequila 
industry plays a vital role in Mexico's economy, supporting approximately 41,840 agave farmers, 
100,000 distillery employees, and 209 authorized distilleries. 
 
Appreciation Statement: The Chamber of the Tequila Industry extends its sincere gratitude to the 
TTB for the opportunity to submit our comments on this significant matter. We trust that the TTB 
will give due consideration to our perspective and to the potential impact of t his proposed 
rulemaking on the Tequila industry and its supply chain within the United States market. 
TTB Proposal on Allergen Declaration in Alcoholic Beverage Labeling 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. published the 
proposal (Notice No. 238) "Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, 
and Malt Beverages ", which seeks to implement mandatory labeling of major food allergens in 
alcoholic beverages. 
Comparison of the TTB proposal vs. the Official Mexican Standard NOM-142-SSA1/SCFI-2014, 
Alcoholic Beverages. Sanitary Specifications. Sanitary and Commercial Labeling: 
Pursuant to  Notice No. 238: Major Food 
Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, 
and Malt Beverages. 
Pursuant to NOM-142-SSA1/SCFI-2014, Alcoholic 
Beverages. Sanitary Specifications. Sanitary and 
Commercial Labeling. 
Proposal to add the following legend to 
alcoholic beverage labeling: 
“Contains Major Food Allergen(s)" 
followed by a colon and the name of the food 
source(s) from which each major food allergen is 
derived, for example, 
9. Labeling 
 
The labeling of the products covered by this 
Standard, in addition to complying with the 
provisions of the Regulations and other applicable 
legal provisions, shall be subject to the following: 
(…) 
“Contains Major Food Allergen: milk" 
This wording differs from the current voluntary 
allergen declaration (interim rule,  T.D. TTB -53 
(71 FR 42260) which states that in alcoholic 
beverages such as wines and distilled spirits, 
primary allergens may be voluntarily declared 
on labels affix ed to the container. The 
declaration must consist of the word 
"Contains", followed by a colon and the name of 
the food source of each allergen (e.g., 
"Contains: egg"). 
9.3 Mandatory Requirements. The following are 
mandatory sanitary and commercial information 
requirements: 
(…) 
9.3.7 Sanitary Information. 
 
9.3.7.7 List of ingredients. 
9.3.7.1.1 The list of ingredients must appear on the 
label of prepared alcoholic beverages, liqueurs or 
creams and all these alcoholic beverages, which 
after distillation and/or before bottling use 
optional ingredient s and/or additives that cause 
hypersensitivity, intolerance or allergy and are 
present in the final product. 
Definition of Major Food Allergen: 
 
"The proposed regulations define the term 
"major food allergen" as any of the following: 
 
 Milk 
 Egg 
 Fish (e.g.,  bass, flounder, or cod) 
Crustacean shellfish (e.g., crab, lobster, 
or shrimp) 
 Tree nuts (e.g., almonds, pecans, or 
walnuts) 
 Wheat 
 Peanuts 
 Soybeans 
 Sesame 
 
The defined term also includes any food 
ingredient that contains protein derived from 
one of these nine foods or food groups, subject 
to certain exceptions. 
The following foods and ingredients have been 
shown to cause hypersensitivity and must always 
be declared: 
 
9.3.7.1.1.1 Cereals containing gluten, e.g.: wheat, 
rye, barley, oats, spelt or their hybr idized strains, 
and products thereof; 
 
9.3.7.1.1.2 Egg and its products; 
 
9.3.7.1.1.3 Peanut and its products; 
 
9.3.7.1.1.4 Soy and its products, with the 
exception of soybean oil; 
 
9.3.7.1.1.5 Milk and dairy products, including 
lactose; 
 
9.3.7.1.1.6 Tree nuts and their derivatives, and 
 
9.3.7.1.1.7 Sulfite in concentrations of 10 mg/kg or 
more. 
Compliance Period: The TTB proposes a compliance date of 5 years from the date a final rule 
resulting from this proposal is published in the Federal Register. 
In Mexico, NOM -142-SSA1/SCFI-2014 establishes that food allergens must be declared in the 
ingredient list only if they are present in the final product, without the need for a specific warning, 
and only in liqueurs or creams, cocktails, and prepared beverages. 
On the other hand, the TTB proposal requires that alcoholic beverage labels include a legend with 
the phrase "Contains Major Food Allergen(s)", followed by the specific allergens, as in the example 
"Contains Major Food Allergen: milk". Furthermore, the current voluntary major allergen declaration standard (interim rule, T.D. TTB-53 
(71 FR 42260)) establishes that in alcoholic beverages such as wines and distilled spirits, p rimary 
allergens may be voluntarily declared on labels.  The declaration must consist of the word 
"Contains", followed by a colon and the name of the food source of each allergen (e.g., "Contains: 
egg"). However, the TTB proposal seeks to make allergen declaration mandatory. It should be noted 
that the TTB proposes an exemption for allergen declaration in distilled alcoholic beverages, 
provided that an allergen or ingredient containing it undergoes a distillation process that completely 
removes any protein, allergenic or not, in the distilled product or ingredient. 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB adopt the proposed wording of the major food allergen statement (“Contains major 
food allergen(s)” followed by a colon and the name of the food source from which each major 
food allergen is derived)? Alternately, should TTB require or allow alternative formats, including 
the following: 
 “Contains” followed by a colon and the name of the food source from which each major 
food allergen is derived; or 
 A heading such as “Major Food Allergen Information” followed by “Contains:” or other 
language and the name of the food source from which each major food allergen is derived. 
While we understand the importance of informing about allergens on labels, we believe that adding 
an additional legend or declaration to the ingredient list does not provide any real benefit to the 
consumer. On the contrary, this would increase costs for manufacturers, importers, and 
distributors. This practice could be considered a technical barrier to trade, which would go against 
Article 2.2 of the World Trade Organization's Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, which seeks 
to avoid the creation of unnecessary trade barriers. The CODEX Alimentarius, in its revision of the 
General Standard for the Labeling of Prepackaged Foods (CXS 1-1985), recommends that allergen 
declaration be preferably done within the ingredient list.  In cases where a separate declaration is 
required, it should be limited to the term "Contains" (or its equivalent) followed by the name of the 
allergen and, when applicable, should be located directly below or near the ingredient list.  The 
interim rule T.D. TTB-53 (71 FR 42260) allows producers of wines and distilled spirits to voluntarily 
declare major allergens on their product labels. This declaration must include the word "Contains", 
followed by a colon and the name of the allergenic ingredient, such as "Contains: egg". It is proposed 
that the TTB consider the possibility of declaring major allergens as part of the ingredient list, which 
is only mandatory for prepared alcoholic beverages, liqueurs or creams that contain ingredients that 
cause hypersensitivity and are present in the final product. Another option is to simply use the word 
"Contains" followed by the allergen, without the need for a longer phrase. This would be easy for 
the consumer to understand and would be in line with the current regulation for voluntary allergen 
declaration in alcoholic beverages. 
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Developme nt (OECD) recommends that 
information on alcoholic beverage labels be clear, concise, and relevant to be effective, and that 
excessive information can confuse the consumer. If it is decided to move forward with this proposal that would modify alcoholic beverage labeling, it 
is essential to allow the use of technological tools on the label to provide additional information.  
This can be achieved through electronic labeling, using a QR code, a digital medium, or a website. 
This tool offers the advantage of providing unlimited space for consumer information, presenting it 
in a friendly and easy-to-understand format. In addition, it allows for easy adaptation to changes in 
regulatory provisions, and facilitates information reaching young people, a vulnerable g roup, to 
prevent harmful alcohol consumption.  It also allows for the development of educational and 
interactive content for the consumer.  Thus, consumers would be effectively informed without 
overloading alcoholic beverage labels with excessive information. 
2. Should TTB allow the inclusion of major food allergens within a voluntary ingredient statement 
on labels as an alternative to a separate major food allergen statement? 
Voluntary allergen declaration is not recommended due to the health risk to consumers. To clearly 
and accurately inform about major allergens, it is proposed that it be sufficient to include them in 
the product's ingredient list or to use the legend "Contains" followed by the allergen's name.  It is 
also proposed to consider the use of e lectronic labeling (QR codes, digital media, or websites) to 
display this information and avoid saturating the physical label.  
3. If mandatory ingredient labeling is ultimately adopted, should TTB allow the inclusion of major 
food allergens in the list of  ingredients as an alternative to a separate major food allergen 
statement? If mandatory ingredient labeling is ultimately adopted, should TTB use the “Contains” 
statement for major food allergens, consistent with FDA's approach? Should TTB limit the use of 
the “Contains” statement only for major food allergens? 
It is recommended that the declaration of major allergens be integrated into the ingredient list, 
including the proteins they contain, instead of creating a separate section.  It is also suggested to 
evaluate the use of electronic labeling (QR codes, digital platforms, or websites) to display detailed 
allergen information, thus avoiding overloading the physical product label. 
4. Should other ingredients that are required to be disclosed under current TTB regulations (FD&C 
Yellow No. 5, cochineal extract or carmine, sulfites, and aspartame) be required to be listed in one 
statement on the label? If so, should the other ingredients be included in a “Contains” statement 
that includes the major food allergens? (For example, “Contains egg and sulfites”). Or should the 
major food allergens be identified as such, and the other ingredients listed separately (for 
example, “Contains Major Food Allergen: egg. Contains sulfites”)? Should another statement be 
used for ingredients that are required to be disclosed under current TTB regulations (FD&C Yellow 
No. 5, cochineal extract or carmine, sulfites, and aspartame) to differentiate from the “Contains” 
statement for major food allergens? 
It is considered that mentioning the ingredients in the list is sufficient to inform consumers, as they 
can easily identify them on the label.  Alternatively, it is proposed to use electronic labeling (QR 
codes, digital media, or websites) to display allergen information, thus avoiding  overloading the 
physical product label. 
 5. Would requiring all mandatory disclosures to be in one place on the label, including the 
proposed major food allergen statement, make it easier for consumers to find this information? 
Would such a requirement impose additional costs or regulatory burdens on industry members 
as compared to allowing the mandatory disclosures to appear separately? 
Requiring specific wording and location for allergen information on the label can create trade 
barriers and increase costs, negatively affecting the trade of alcoholic beverages.  Therefore, it is 
proposed that this information can be placed anywhere on the label.  According to studies by the 
Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), presenting too much information 
together can make it difficult for consumers to identify important data. To avoid this, it is suggested 
to consider the use of electronic labeling (QR codes, digital platforms, or websites) to display 
additional allergen information, thus avoiding overloading the physical label. 
6. Should TTB mandate specific placement, type size, and presentation requirements for major 
allergen labeling statements in addition to the requirements already applicable to all mandatory 
information on alcohol beverage l abels? For example, should the required allergen disclosure 
statement be set off by a box? Or, to the extent practicable, should TTB mandate formatting 
consistent with FDA requirements for major allergen labeling? 
It is not advisable to establish specific location, size, and presentation requirements for allergen 
declarations, as this offers no benefits to the consumer and generates additional costs for 
manufacturers, importers, and distributors. This imposition of additional costs could be considered 
a tec hnical barrier to trade, which contravenes Article 2.2 of the World Trade Organization's 
Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, which seeks to avoid the creation of unnecessary trade 
barriers. This agreement establishes that technical regulations should  not be implemented that 
hinder international trade without valid justification in the legitimate objectives of member states. 
In the recent revision of the General Standard for the Labeling of Prepackaged Foods (CXS 1-1985): 
Provisions for Allergen Labeli ng of the CODEX Alimentarius, it has been established that the 
presentation of allergens should preferably be done through the ingredient list. Should a separate 
declaration be necessary, it should begin with the term "Contains ________" (or an equivalent term) 
and be placed directly below or very near the ingredient list, when present.  This provision avoids 
the use of a more extensive legend, which could confuse the consumer. 
Conclusion: 
Based on the arguments presented, it is suggested that allergen information in alcoholic beverages 
be presented clearly and concisely to the consumer, avoiding additional costs and barriers to 
international trade.  Likewise, it is proposed that the declaration of major allergens in alcoholic 
beverages be limited to thei r inclusion in the ingredient list.  Should an additional declaration be 
required, it is suggested that it be concise, as proposed by the CODEX Alimentarius and the 
Voluntary Major Allergen Declaration Standard (T.D. TTB-53 (71 FR 42260)), using only the legend 
"Contains" followed by the allergen, without the need for a more extensive text. It is essential that 
the possibility of using electronic labeling (through QR codes, digital platforms, or websites) to 
provide additional information or legends about ma jor allergens be considered.  This method 
facilitates access to relevant information for the consumer and avoids the imposition of unnecessary 
regulatory and commercial burdens. 
End of the document

comment_text:
On behalf of the Government of Mexico, I hereby attach the comments of the Mexican alcoholic beverages industry regarding the U.S. TTB’s draft regulation "Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages," with the attentive request that they are taken into account in the elaboration of the final standard. The Mexican industry appreciates the notification (G/TBT/N/USA/2183) made to the WTO TBT Committee in accordance with Article 2.9.2 of the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, which allows comments to be considered at a stage where modifications to the proposal are still possible.

We note that the proposed regulation requires mandatory labeling of major food allergens in alcoholic beverages with the phrase "Contains Major Food Allergen(s)" followed by the specific allergens. While recognizing the importance of allergen disclosure for consumer safety, the Mexican alcoholic beverages industry considers that adding a separate declaration in addition to the ingredient list may increase costs and constitute a potential technical barrier to trade, contrary to Article 2.2 of the TBT Agreement.

We encourage the TTB to consider integrating allergen information into the ingredient list as the primary method, consistent with existing voluntary declarations (T.D. TTB-53) and in line with the CODEX Alimentarius recommendations. We also suggest that the use of electronic labeling tools, such as QR codes or digital platforms, be considered to provide additional information in a clear, accessible, and consumer-friendly manner.

Finally, we highlight that compliance timelines and exemptions for distilled products should continue to be considered to avoid undue trade impacts. The Mexican industry appreciates the consideration of these comments to ensure that the regulation promotes consumer safety without imposing unnecessary barriers to trade. We thank you in advance for your kind attention and remain attentive to your response.
gov_agency: Government of Mexico (Director General of International Trade Disciplines, Secretary of Economy of Mexico, Undersecretary of Foreign Trade)
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 14, 2025.  
 
 
Agency responsible: 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
 
Subject: Comments on: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages 
 
 
To whom it may concern, 
 
I write to you today on behalf of the Mezcal Sustainability Alliance, a strategic collaboration 
among companies and with  institutions in the sector, committed to the sustainable 
development of Mezcal. Its purpose is to  strengthen the identity of the spirit by 
disseminating good practices, promoting joint projects and generating a positive impact on 
producing communities. With a focus on innovative  solutions, the Alliance seeks to 
accelerate change and preserve the artisanal tradition that defines Mezcal.  
 
The Mezcal Sustainability Alliance thanks the TTB for notifying its proposed regulation to the 
TBT Committee, in compliance with its commitments as a member of the World Trade 
Organization, in accordance with article 2.9.2 of the Agreement, which establishes that 
notifications of technical regulations sh ould occur at a stage where comments can be 
considered and modifications to the initial proposal can be made. 
 
Background 
 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. 
published the proposal  "Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled 
Spirits, and Malt Beverages ", which seeks to implement mandatory labeling of major food 
allergens in alcoholic beverages.  The TTB has proposed a five -year compliance period, 
starting from the date the final standard is published in the Federal Register. 
Under the current interim standard (T.D. TTB-53), major allergens in alcoholic beverages like 
wine and spirits may be voluntarily declared using the phrase “Contains: [allergen]”. 
However, the TTB now proposes making allergen labeling mandatory, with an exemption for 
distilled products whe re the distillation process fully removes all proteins, including 
allergens. It should be noted that the TTB proposes an exemption for allergen declaration in  
distilled alcoholic beverages, provided that an allergen or ingredient containing it undergoes 
a distillation process that completely removes any protein, allergenic or not, in the distilled 
product or ingredient. 
Furthermore, the TTB proposal requires that alcoholic beverage labels include a legend with 
the phrase "Contains Major Food Allergen(s)", followed by the specific allergens, as in the 
example "Contains Major Food Allergen: milk". 
In Mexico, NOM -142-SSA1/SCFI-2014 stipulates that food allergens must be listed in the 
ingredient declaration only when they are present in the final product, and this requirement 
applies exclusively to liqueurs, creams, cocktails, and prepared alcoholic b everages. No 
specific allergen warning is mandated. 
 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB adopt the proposed wording of the major food allergen statement 
(“Contains major food allergen(s)” followed by a colon and the name of the food source 
from which each major food allergen is derived)? Alternately, should TTB require or 
allow alternative formats, including the following: 
• “Contains” followed by a colon and the name of the food source from which 
each major food allergen is derived; or 
• A heading such as “Major Food Allergen Information” followed by “Contains:” or 
other language and the name of the food source from which each major food 
allergen is derived. 
While we understand the importance of informing about allergens on labels, we believe that 
adding an additional legend or declaration to the ingredient list does not provide any real 
benefit to the consumer. On the contrary, this would increase costs for m anufacturers, 
importers, and distributors. This practice could be considered a technical barrier to trade, 
which would go against Article 2.2 of the World Trade Organization's Agreement on 
Technical Barriers to Trade, which seeks to avoid the creation of unnecessary trade barriers.  
Moreover, the CODEX Alimentarius, in its revision of the General Standard for the Labeling 
of Prepackaged Foods (CXS 1 -1985), recommends that allergen declaration be preferably 
done within the ingredient list. In cases where a separate declaration is required, it sho uld 
be limited to the term "Contains" (or its equivalent) followed by the name of the allergen and, 
when applicable, should be located directly below or near the ingredient list.   
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) recommends that 
information on alcoholic beverage labels be clear, concise, and relevant to be effective, and 
that excessive information can confuse the consumer. 
The interim rule T.D. TTB-53 (71 FR 42260) allows producers of wines and distilled spirits to 
voluntarily declare major allergens on their product labels. This declaration must include 
the word "Contains", followed by a colon and the name of the allergenic ingredient, such as 
"Contains: egg". It is proposed that the TTB consider s the possibility of declaring major 
allergens as part of the ingredient list, which is only mandatory for prepared alcoholic 
beverages, liqueurs or creams that contain ingredients t hat cause hypersensitivity and are 
present in the final product. Another option is to simply use the word "Contains" followed by 
the allergen, without the need for a longer phrase. This would be easy for the consumer to 
understand and would be in line with  the current regulation for voluntary allergen 
declaration in alcoholic beverages. 
However, i f it is decided to move forward with this proposal that would modify alcoholic 
beverage labelling, it is essential to allow the use of technological tools on the label to 
provide additional information. This can be achieved through electronic labelling, using a 
QR code, a digital medium, or a website. This tool offers the advantage of providing unlimited 
space for consumer information, presenting it in a friendly and easy -to-understand format. 
In addition, it allows for easy adaptation to changes in regulatory provisions, and facilitates 
information reaching young people, a vulnerable group, to prevent harmful alcohol 
consumption. It also allows for the development of educational and interactive content for 
the consumer. Thus, consumers would be ef fectively informed without overloading 
alcoholic beverage labels with excessive information. 
 
2. Should TTB allow the inclusion of major food allergens within a voluntary ingredient 
statement on labels as an alternative to a separate major food allergen statement? 
Voluntary allergen declaration is not recommended due to the health risk to consumers. To 
clearly and accurately inform about major allergens, it is proposed to include them in the 
product's ingredient list or to use the legend "Contains" followed by the allergen's name. It 
is also proposed to consider the use of electronic labeling (QR codes, digital media, or 
websites) to display this information and avoid saturating the physical label.  
3. If mandatory ingredient labeling is ultimately adopted, should TTB allow the inclusion 
of major food allergens in the list of ingredients as an alternative to a separate major 
food allergen statement? If mandatory ingredient labeling is ultimately adopt ed, 
should TTB use the “Contains” statement for major food allergens, consistent with  
FDA's approach? Should TTB limit the use of the “Contains” statement only for major 
food allergens? 
It is recommended that the declaration of major allergens be integrated into the ingredient 
list, including the proteins they contain, instead of creating a separate section. It is also 
suggested to evaluate the use of electronic labeling (QR codes, digita l platforms, or 
websites) to display detailed allergen information, thus avoiding overloading the physical 
product label. 
4. Should other ingredients that are required to be disclosed under current TTB 
regulations (FD&C Yellow No. 5, cochineal extract or carmine, sulfites, and aspartame) 
be required to be listed in one statement on the label? If so, should the other 
ingredients be included in a “Contains” statement that includes the major food 
allergens? (For example, “Contains egg and sulfites”). Or should the major food 
allergens be identified as such, and the other ingredients listed separately (for 
example, “Contains Major  Food Allergen: egg. Contains sulfites”)? Should another 
statement be used for ingredients that are required to be disclosed under current TTB 
regulations (FD&C Yellow No. 5, cochineal extract or carmine, sulfites, and aspartame) 
to differentiate from the “Contains” statement for major food allergens? 
It is considered that mentioning the ingredients in the list is sufficient to inform consumers, 
as they can easily identify them on the label. Alternatively, it is proposed to use electronic 
labeling (QR codes, digital media, or websites) to display allergen information, thus avoiding 
overloading the physical product label. 
5. Would requiring all mandatory disclosures to be in one place on the label, including 
the proposed major food allergen statement, make it easier for consumers to find this 
information? Would such a requirement impose additional costs or regulatory burdens 
on industry members as compared to allowing the mandatory disclosures to appear 
separately? 
Mandating specific wording and placement for allergen information may raise trade barriers 
and increase costs. 
According to studies by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development 
(OECD), presenting too much information together can make it difficult for consumers to 
identify important data.  To avoid this, it is suggested to consider the use of electronic 
labeling (QR codes, digital platforms, or websites) to display additional allergen information, 
thus avoiding overloading the physical label. 
  
6. Should TTB mandate specific placement, type size, and presentation requirements 
for major allergen labeling statements in addition to the requirements already 
applicable to all mandatory information on alcohol beverage labels? For example, 
should the required allergen disclosure statement be set off by a box? Or, to the extent 
practicable, should TTB mandate formatting consistent with FDA requirements for 
major allergen labeling? 
It is not advisable to establish specific location, size, and presentation requirements for 
allergen declarations, as this offers no benefits to the consumer and generates additional 
costs for manufacturers, importers, and distributors. This imposition of additional costs 
could be considered a technical barrier to trade, which contravenes Article 2.2 of the World 
Trade Organization's Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, which seeks to avoid the 
creation of unnecessary trade barriers. This agreement est ablishes that technical 
regulations should not be implemented that hinder international trade without valid 
justification in the legitimate objectives of member states.  
In the recent revision of the General Standard for the Labeling of Prepackaged Foods (CXS 
1-1985): Provisions for Allergen Labeling of the CODEX Alimentarius, it has been established 
that the presentation of allergens should preferably be done through the ingredient list. 
Should a separate declaration be necessary, it should begin with the term "Contains 
________" (or an equivalent term) and be placed directly below or very near the ingredient 
list, when present. This provision avoids the use of a more exte nsive legend, which could 
confuse the consumer. 
 
 
   
 
 
Conclusion: 
 
Based on the arguments presented, it is suggested that allergen information in alcoholic 
beverages be presented clearly and concisely to the consumer, avoiding additional costs 
and barriers to international trade. Likewise, it is proposed that the declarat ion of major 
allergens in alcoholic beverages be limited to their inclusion in the ingredient list. Should an 
additional declaration be required, it is suggested that it be concise, as proposed by the 
CODEX Alimentarius and the Voluntary Major Allergen Declaration Standard (T.D. TTB-53 (71 
FR 42260), using only the legend "Contains" followed by the allergen, without the need for a 
more extensive text. It is essential that the possibility of using electronic labeling (through 
QR codes, digital platforms, or websites) to provide additional information or legends about 
major allergens be considered. This method facilitates access to relevant information for 
the consumer and avoids the imposition of unnecessary regulatory and commercial 
burdens. 
 
Best regards, 
 
 
 
 
 
Rocio Melendrez Ramirez 
Representative 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Members of the “Alianza para la Sustentabilidad”: Casa Xipe; Del Maguey Single Village Mezcal; Mezcal Los Danzantes; Mezcal Amarás; Mezcal El 
Tinieblo; Mezcal Júrame; Marqués del Jaral de Berrio; Casa Mezcal Huitzila; Mezcal Amaxak; Promotora y Comercializadora de De stilados SA de

comment_text: Comment from FARE (Food Allergy Research & Education)
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
7901 Jones Branch Drive, Suite 240 
 McLean, VA  22102 
 
 
1 
August 15, 2025 
 
TO: Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau, US Treasury Department 
 
RE: Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 238, Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled 
Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
Submitted electronically via www.regulations.gov 
 
On behalf of the over 33 million Americans who suﬀer directly from life-threatening food allergies, and 
the more than 85 million that are directly and indirectly aﬀected by food allergies and/or intolerances to 
one of the top 9 food allergens, FARE (Food Allergy Research and Education) appreciates the opportunity 
to submit the following comments to the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the US 
Treasury Department on the TTB’s Proposed Rule, Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled 
Spirits, and Malt Beverages. 
 
FARE is the nation’s leading non-proﬁt engaged in food allergy advocacy as well as the largest private 
funder of food allergy research. FARE’s innovative education, advocacy, and research initiatives transform 
the future of food allergy through the advancement of new and improved treatments and prevention 
strategies, eﬀective policies and legislation, and novel approaches to managing the disease. Food allergy 
is a disease, not a diet. 
 
FARE estimates that over 75% of Americans with food allergy, over 25 million individuals, are of legal 
drinking age and can be harmed without food allergen labeling of alcoholic beverages, if they choose to 
consume. Our food allergy community needs full disclosure and transparency about food allergens that 
remain in beverage alcohol products—wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages—after manufacture 
and processing. This labeling need also extends to individuals with celiac disease as well. 
 
There has been a long history of discussion related to beverage alcohol labeling with alcohol content, 
nutrition information, major food allergens, and ingredients – in the US and globally. FARE urges that the 
top 9 major food allergens requiring labeling in the US must be disclosed – egg, milk, peanut, tree nuts, 
wheat, soy, sesame, ﬁsh, and crustacean shellﬁsh – as well as gluten, on beverage alcohol products 
regulated by TTB. 
 
When the Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act of 2004 (FALCPA) was passed, the House 
report noted that consistent with a 1987 Memorandum of Understanding between TTB and the Food & 
Drug Administration (FDA), the House Committee expected that the agencies work together to 
promulgate food allergen labeling regulations with respect to applicable TTB products. 
 
The World Health Organization’s Global Alcohol Action Plan, 2022-2030, notes that “… appropriate 
consumer protection measures through the development and implementation of labelling requirements 
for alcoholic beverages that display essential information for health protection on alcohol content in a 
way that is understood by consumers….” 
 
In recent years, FARE notes that many “hard seltzer” and other similar products produced and sold by 
many beverage alcohol companies with 7% or less alcohol currently follow FDA labeling regulations for 2 
nutrition, ingredients, and food allergens without objection. Additionally, sectors of the beverage alcohol 
industry have been labeling “Contains sulﬁtes” for over 35 years. Thus, FARE urges TTB to work diligently 
and expeditiously to ﬁnalize and implement this proposed rule as quickly as possible. 
 
A ﬁnal introductory note. Our food allergy consumer is highly brand loyal. For foods, data from our FARE 
Food Allergy Consumer Journey research showed that with clear and consistent labeling, food 
manufacturers could unlock over 19 billion dollars per year. A similar scenario could apply to alcoholic 
beverage purchasing. This can be a win-win for those with food allergies and beverage alcohol 
companies by adopting clear food allergen labeling. 
 
Speciﬁc Comments on the Proposed Rule 
 
Allergen disclosure terminology and naming conventions 
 
FARE supports including mandating disclosure and the language of “Contains Major Food Allergen (s)” 
and strongly recommends that TTB consider moving forward on requirements for full ingredient labeling 
to align with FDA food labeling regulations and guidance. 
 
FARE supports TTB’s proposal to require disclosure of the top 9 food allergens, when present in ﬁnished 
alcoholic beverage products as noted in Section V. A. 1. of the proposed rule, using a statement on the 
product label that states, “Contains Major Food Allergen(s): [name of food allergen].” At this time, this 
deviation from FALCPA and FDA guidance is critical as TTB has not issued a proposal for ingredient 
labeling of alcoholic beverages. This statement should follow the same format and type size, and 
placement requirements for sulﬁte labeling on alcoholic beverages. It must be placed either above or 
below sulﬁte labeling disclosure, when applicable. 
 
At present, FARE only can support the above statement to clearly articulate the presence of one or more 
of the top 9 food allergens when present in ﬁnished alcoholic beverage products. However, FARE strongly 
encourages TTB to propose and ﬁnalize labeling requirements for ingredients on alcoholic beverage 
products. Food-allergic consumers are accustomed to looking for allergen information in both the 
ingredient statement and speciﬁcally in the “Contains” statement on FDA-regulated foods and 
beverages. We believe that TTB should make every eﬀort to align with FDA regulations by requiring 
ingredient labeling and disclosure alongside mandatory allergen disclosure. This would facilitate the 
consistent use of the verbiage “Contains: [food allergen]” for disclosure of the major food allergens. FDA 
also permits other allergen information outside of the top nine allergens to be included voluntarily under 
“Other allergen information” separate from the “Contains” statement. TTB could take a similar approach 
to ensure appropriation separation. Once ingredient labeling is established, it would then be appropriate 
for TTB-regulated products to use “Contains: [food allergen],” along with similar plain English naming of 
food allergen ingredients in the full ingredient declaration. 
 
Regarding the question of combining food allergen and existing requirement for disclosure of the 
presence of sulﬁtes as “Contains sulﬁtes.” FARE believes that separation is preferred as both consumers 
with food allergy and those with sulﬁte sensitivity are accustomed to separate information and 
combining could lead to confusion or misreading label information. 
 
Related to naming conventions, FARE urges TTB to adopt the same category and species naming 
conventions used for FDA food allergen labeling within the proposed “Contains…” statement above (e.g., 3 
tree nuts [almond, hazelnut], or ﬁsh [cod]). This has been clear to consumers since the implementation 
of FALCPA requirements since 2004. 
 
Labeling disclosure location and type size requirements 
 
Further, FARE supports the proposed provision of disclosing food allergen information only directly on 
the label of alcoholic beverages. Such information must follow the requirements of FALCPA and FDA’s 
labeling guidance with, at minimum, use of TTB’s proposed “Contains Major Food Allergen(s): [name of 
food allergen]” statement in plain English to alert consumers of the presence of the top 9 food allergens 
requiring labeling. FARE opposes the provision of food allergen information solely oﬀ-label via electronic 
or digital means (e.g., websites, QR codes). This is supported by consumer feedback received on 
development of the US Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) ﬁnal rule on its National Bioengineered Food 
Disclosure (83 Fed Reg 65814). The ﬁnal rule states, “The majority of commenters did not support the 
use of electronic or digital link disclosure in lieu of on-package labeling.” 
 
Food allergen thresholds 
 
The proposed rule in Section V. A.  5. discusses the issue of food allergen thresholds. To date, FDA has not 
yet proposed use of food allergen thresholds on food labeling, exemptions, and enforcement. FARE is 
supportive of the use of food allergen thresholds for the prior reasons and to control and limit the use of 
“May contain” precautionary labeling. In relation to advisory or precaution allergen labeling (PAL), FARE 
appreciates TTB’s recognition of the challenges that come with the use of precautionary or advisory 
allergen (PAL) statements and the recognition that such approaches should not substitute for good 
manufacturing practices. FARE’s comments on this proposal consistently note “when present in ﬁnished 
alcoholic beverage products” [Emphasis added]. FARE believes there are opportunities for TTB to learn 
from the challenges and future being navigated by FDA about employing food allergen thresholds in food 
regulations. Providing clear parameters around the use of PAL, and the potential use of utilizing allergen 
thresholds, oﬀers such an opportunity, and FARE urges TTB to maintain a strong, ongoing dialogue with 
FDA about food allergen thresholds. 
 
The issue of food allergen thresholds has been thoroughly addressed in recent reports from an expert 
consultation led by the Food & Agriculture Organization and World Health Organization of the United 
Nations (FAO/WHO) to inform work of the Codex Alimentarius’s Committee on Food Labeling related to 
priority labeling of food allergens, guidelines for the use of precautionary allergen labeling (PAL) 
statements, and ingredient exemptions. The science is very strong on the applicability of food allergen 
thresholds to not over-label the presence of food allergens and provide clearer information for 
consumers. This may apply to labeling of alcoholic beverages as well. FDA scientists were integral 
members of the FAO/WHO expert consultations, and the agency is exploring the use of food allergen 
thresholds in the US. Food allergen thresholds may be a very useful tool for TTB to employ to determine 
the absence of food allergens in alcoholic beverages, and when the risk of presence of a food allergen 
used as a beverage alcohol processing aid (e.g., ﬁsh ingredients for ﬁning) is determined by risk 
assessment via quantitative data. Until such time that absence of food allergen protein in processing aids 
used in manufacture of alcoholic beverages can be consistently determined, FARE does not oppose TTB’s 
proposed requirement for processing aids to be labeled as, for example, “Contains Major Food Allergen: 
egg (processing aid).’’ 
 
 
 4 
Exemptions 
 
In Section V. B. 1. & 2. of the proposed rule, TTB addresses and requests feedback on exemptions and 
distillation. These issues are complementary and supported by FARE’s discussion of the use of food 
allergen thresholds and our view that labeling is required only when food allergens are present in a 
ﬁnished alcoholic beverage product. FARE supports the use of petitions for exemption when no food 
allergen protein is present along with consultation with FDA. FARE agrees with TTB’s discussion on 
distillation and absence of food allergen protein when manufacturing alcoholic beverages, and supports 
the complementary rational of FDA actions and for TTB to ﬁnalize the distilled spirits regulations in 
proposed 27 CFR 5.75(b)(2) “to speciﬁcally provide that the mandatory labeling requirements do not 
apply to major food allergens used in the production of a distilled spirits product if they have been 
completely distilled in such a manner that no protein remains in the distilled spirits.” 
 
Compliance date 
 
Regarding compliance date for this proposed rule, FARE urges TTB to adopt a compliance date of no 
more than 3 years. Our community has needed and wanted this information for over 20 years and 
deserves it as soon as possible. 
 
Comments on Related Proposals on Labeling of Alcoholic Beverages 
 
In addition to this proposed rule on food allergen labeling of alcoholic beverages, TTB issued a proposed 
rule on “Alcohol Facts” provision of nutrition and alcohol content information, and a pre-proposal (since 
withdrawn) on ingredient labeling of alcoholic beverages. FARE wholly supports the comments from the 
Center for Science in the Public Interest (CSPI) on the proposed rule for “Alcohol Facts” submitted to this 
docket. FARE urges TTB to publish a proposed rule on ingredient labeling of alcoholic beverages for 
public comment as soon as possible. 
 
FARE looks forward to continuing dialogue with TTB and the Treasury Department on all food allergy and 
labeling issues. If you have questions, please contact Robert Earl, Vice President, Regulatory Aﬀairs, at 
rearl@foodallergy.org or 571-771-8582. 
 
Respectfully submitted, 
 
 
Sung Poblete, PhD, RN 
FARE CEO

comment_text: See attached file(s)
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
1 
 
 
 
Comments of the Beer Institute Regarding NPRM 238 
 
This submission represents comments of the Beer Institute (BI) regarding NPRM 238, by which the 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) proposes to require disclosure of specific allergens on 
all alcohol beverage labels subject to TTB's regulatory authority under the Federal Alcohol 
Administration Act (FAA Act). 
 
BI is a national trade association for the American brewing industry, representing brewers, beer 
importers, and industry suppliers. This industry supports more than 2.4 million jobs and provides more 
than $471 billion to the American economy. First founded in 1862 as the U.S. Brewers Association, BI is 
committed today to developing sound public policy and to the values of civic duty and personal 
responsibility. 
 
BI believes TTB should closely follow FDA regulations in addressing allergen disclosures for TTB-
regulated products. With that background, BI responds in this comment to the questions raised in 
NPRM 238. For any question not expressly addressed, BI currently takes no position. 
 
TTB Request for Comment: TTB solicits comments on the wording of the proposed mandatory 
major food allergen statement and the possible inclusion of other mandatory ingredient 
disclosures. Speciﬁcally, TTB solicits comments on the following:  
 
Should TTB adopt the proposed wording of the major food allergen 
statement (“Contains major 
food allergen(s)” followed by a colon and the name of the food source from which each major 
food allergen is derived)? Alternately, should TTB require or allow alternative formats, including the 
following:  
 
• “Contains” followed by a colon and the name of the food source from which each major food 
allergen is derived; or  
 
• A heading such as “Major Food Allergen Information” followed by “Contains:” or other 
language and the name of the food source from which each major food allergen is 
derived.  
 
BI Response: TTB should adopt the statement “CONTAINS” followed by a colon and the 
name of the allergen as the simplest and already recognized manner of disclosing 
allergens.    
2 
 
 
TTB Request for Comment :  
1. Should TTB allow the inclusion of major food allergens within a voluntary ingredient 
statement on labels as an alternative to a separate major food allergen statement?  
2. If mandatory ingredient labeling is ultimately adopted, should TTB allow the inclusion of major 
food allergens in the list of ingredients as an alternative to a separate major food allergen 
statement? If mandatory ingredient labeling is ultimately adopted, should TTB use the 
“Contains” statement for major food allergens, consistent with FDA’s approach? Should TTB 
limit the use of the “Contains” statement only for major food allergens?  
 
3. Should other ingredients that are required to be disclosed under current TTB regulations 
(FD&C Yellow No. 5, cochineal extract or carmine, sulﬁtes, and aspartame) be required to 
be listed in one statement on the label? If so, should the other ingredients be included in a  
“Contains” statement that includes the major food allergens? (For example,  “Contains egg 
and sulﬁtes”). Or should the major food allergens be identiﬁed as such, and the other 
ingredients listed separately (for example,  “Contains Major Food Allergen: egg. Contains 
sulﬁtes”)? Should another statement be used for i ngredients that are required to be 
disclosed under current TTB regulations (FD&C Yellow No. 5, cochineal extract or carmine, 
sulﬁtes, and aspartame) to differentiate from the “Contains” statement for major food 
allergens? 
 
BI Response to TTB Requests 1-3 above: TTB should align with FDA rules on mandatory 
allergen disclosures. For example, TTB should provide flexibility for producers to use either 
a) a list of ingredients (voluntarily disclosed) or b) a “CONTAINS” statement. And if a 
voluntary ingredient statement lists an allergen, there should be no additional disclosure 
requirement. TTB should not allow flexibility in listing other ingredients that a producer 
must disclose under current TTB regulations, such as major food allergens. 
(For example, 
“Contains egg and sulﬁtes”). The major allergen declaration should be separate from other 
ingredient claims. 
 
TTB Request for Comment : Would requiring all mandatory disclosures to be in one place on the 
label, including the proposed major food allergen statement, make it easier for consumers to ﬁnd 
this information? Would such a requirement impose additional costs or regulatory burdens on 
industry members as compared to allowing the mandatory disclosures to appear separately?  
 
BI Response: Provided all mandatory disclosures are conspicuous, producers should have 
the flexibility to separate required disclosures. Major allergen declarations should be 
separated from other compulsory disclosures. 
  
3 
 
 
TTB Request for Comment : Should TTB mandate speciﬁc placement, type size, and 
presentation requirements for major allergen labeling statements in addition to the requirements 
already applicable to all mandatory information on alcohol beverage labels? For example, 
should the required allergen disclosure statement be set off by a box? Or, to the extent 
practicable, should TTB mandate formatting consistent with FDA requirements for major 
allergen labeling?  
 
BI Response: TTB should align its requirements with FDA’s allergen disclosure 
requirements. 
 
TTB Request for Comment : TTB solicits comments on whether labeling alcohol beverages 
produced using ﬁnﬁsh protein merely as containing “ﬁsh,” rather than with the name of the ﬁsh 
species, provides adequate information to consumers. TTB also seeks comments on whether 
there are alternative approaches to this issue that would provide consumers with adequate 
information regarding the use of ﬁnﬁsh protein in the production of alcohol beverages.  
 
BI Response: We support using “fish” rather than the species' name. However, consistent with 
FDA guidance, TTB should not require an allergen disclosure if finfish protein used in alcohol 
beverage production does not appear  in the finished product or cannot cause an allergic 
reaction. 
 
TTB Request for Comment : TTB is proposing to require the disclosure of ﬁning or processing 
agents that are or contain major food allergens, with the option of including the added 
parenthetical “(processing aid)” and is soliciting comments on this proposal. For example, if egg 
whites are used as a processing aid for wine, the industry member has the  option of disclosing 
this on the label as follows: “Contains Major Food Allergen: egg (processing aid).” This is an option 
that industry members may choose to use, but they also may choose to list these agents without 
parentheticals. TTB is not proposing parenthetical statements for other incidental additives 
besides processing aids. TTB seeks comments on whether this proposal, which is generally 
consistent with FALCPA, will provide adequate information to consumers.  
 
 
BI Response: TTB should not require disclosure of fining or processing agents that do not 
appear in the finished product or that  cannot cause an allergic reaction.  
 
TTB Request for Comment : TTB’s proposal does not speciﬁcally address allergen advisory labeling, 
such as statements that a product may contain a major food allergen, e.g., “May Contain (major 
food allergen).” TTB is concerned that allergen advisory labeling could be used as a substitute for 
adherence to current good manufacturing practices and could be misleading. TTB is soliciting 
comments on the use of allergen advisory la
beling.   
4 
 
 
 
BI Response: TTB should align its requirements with FDA’s allergen disclosure requirements. 
  
TTB Request for Comment : TTB is proposing in 27 CFR 5.75(b)(2) that major food allergens, or 
ingredients containing major food allergens, need not be declared on a label when such allergens 
or ingredients have been subject to distillation in such a manner that no protein, allergenic or 
otherwise, remains in the distilled product or distilled ingredient. As explained below, this is 
consistent with the position FDA has taken regarding the removal of proteins using the distillation 
process within the context of major food allergen labeling and gluten- free labeling of distilled 
foods. TTB is soliciting comments on this proposal.  
 
BI Response: Consistent with FDA guidance, TTB should not mandate allergen disclosures for 
ingredients that do not appear in the finished product or that can no longer cause an allergic 
reaction. 
 
TTB Request for Comment : TTB solicits comments on whether the proposed compliance date 
would suffice to limit the impact on small businesses and to reduce overall costs of compliance 
while ensuring that consumers are adequately informed. TTB also seeks comments on whether 
the use of a single compliance date for any new regulations on allergen, ingredient, or “Alcohol 
Facts” labeling would provide consumers with adequate information in a coherent and timely 
manner while also reducing costs and other regulatory burdens on industry.  
 
BI Response: TTB should align compliance dates for any rulemaking resulting from NPRM 237 and 
238. This will aid producers in developing a single label redesign, as multiple compliance dates will 
require multiple label redesigns and unnecessary costs.  
 
TTB Request for Comment : TTB is seeking comments on whether the compliance date for this 
proposed rule should be coordinated with the compliance dates of other labeling changes that 
have been proposed by TTB, including Notice No. 237, Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of 
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, which proposed the inclusion of Alcohol Facts 
statements on alcohol beverage labels, as well as any proposals that may be aired as a result of 
the ANPRM on ingredient labeling. See  Notice No. 237. Promulgating the requirements for the 
ﬁnal label changes together would allow bottlers and importers to undertake all the label 
revisions necessary to implement these changes in one label change. For example,  it is TTB’s 
preliminary conclusion that for industry members that would be required to  make label changes 
under any new requirements resulting from the Alcohol Facts and the Allergen rulemakings, it 
would be more efficient and less costly to make changes to the label to accommodate both 
requirements at the same time. If the rules were instead promulgated and took effect at different 
points in time, TTB assumes th at the multiple distinct label changes would result in  greater costs.  
5 
 
 
TTB invites comments on this preliminary conclusion.  
 
BI Response: TTB should align compliance dates for any rulemaking resulting from NPRM 237 and 
238. This will aid producers in developing a single label redesign, as multiple compliance dates will 
require multiple label redesigns and unnecessary costs.  
 
TTB Request for Comment : Are there alternative ways of providing a major food allergen disclosure, 
for example, by allowing information to be provided through a website using a quick response code 
(QR code) or website address on the label? Will such an alternative method still provide adequate 
information to the consumer?  
 
BI Response: QR codes should only be an option for voluntarily disclosed information. QR 
codes or website addresses are not the best way to disclose mandatory allergen 
information to consumers. 
 
TTB Request for Comment : Does the proposed compliance date suffice to reduce overall costs 
of compliance, and speciﬁcally the costs to small businesses, while ensuring that consumers are 
protected?  
 
BI Response: Unless the rule changes are extensive and require more time for full 
compliance, five years should be sufficient for a full compliance date. As noted, TTB should 
align compliance dates for any rulemaking resulting from NPRM 237 and 238. This will aid 
producers in developing a single label redesign, as multiple compliance dates will require multiple 
label redesigns and unnecessary costs.  
  
TTB Request for Comment : Is there a shorter compliance period that would provide more beneﬁts to 
consumers while still limiting costs and potential impacts on small businesses? Speciﬁcally, 
would a 2-, 3- or 3.5-year compliance period suffice?  
 
BI Response: Unless the rule changes are extensive and require more time for full 
compliance, five years should be sufficient for a full compliance date. As noted, TTB 
should align compliance dates for any rulemaking resulting from NPRM 237 and 238. This 
will aid producers in developing a single label redesign, as multiple compliance dates will 
require multiple label redesigns and unnecessary costs.  
 
TTB Request for Comment : If a ﬁnal rule is issued, will industry members begin implementation 
of the labeling changes in advance of the compliance date?  
 
BI Response: Many industry members will begin phasing in compliant labels earlier than the 
compliance date as brands undergo label changes in the normal course of business. However, new  
6 
 
 
label lead times, even for existing products (not including new-to-market products), may take 6 
months or more. Industry members must update hundreds of distinct brands, labels, and package 
types. The rule changes proposed here and in NPRM 237 are significant regarding time 
requirements and cost.  
 
TTB Request for Comment : How might consumers beneﬁt from early compliance by industry? Are 
there any ongoing costs of compliance with the proposed rule that TTB has not addressed in this 
document?  
 
BI Response: Most compliance costs will be associated with the initial label changeover. Ongoing 
expenses might include additional analysis and ingredient evaluation, formula creation, and product 
testing.  
 
TTB Request for Comment : TTB believes that a labeling statement with information about the 
presence of major food allergens in the production of an alcohol beverage will provide signiﬁcant 
beneﬁts. Consumers with these food allergies will be able to make an informed decision as to 
whether consumption of a particular alcohol beverage may pose  a risk of an allergic reaction. This 
proposal will also promote consistency in major food allergen disclosure across all types of food 
product labels, removing ambiguity about whether a product contains a major food allergen or 
not. TTB invites comments on its conclusion that consumers would beneﬁt from having this 
information available on product labels. 
 
 
BI Response: BI believes consumers would benefit from information on labels about major 
food allergens present in finished alcohol beverages, which  can cause an allergic reaction . 
 
Conclusion 
 
BI strongly encourages TTB to align with the FDA on reasonable allergen disclosures. Again, BI currently 
takes no position on any question not expressly addressed in this comment. Additionally, BI reserves 
the right to amend these responses or to comment further as appropriate.

comment_text: It is unacceptable that alcohol is currently exempt from major food allergen labelling. People with food allergies deserve to know what they are consuming so they can protect their health without fear of having an allergic reaction. As a physician, I urge you to mandate major food allergen labelling for alcoholic beverage products.

comment_text:
RE: Docket No. TTB 2025-0004; Notice 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

The American Cider Association (ACA) appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) proposed rulemaking regarding mandatory allergen labeling for alcohol beverages (Notice No. 238). The ACA represents more than 1,200 cider and perry producers nationwide, from small orchard-based family operations to regional brands distributing across multiple states. While our members vary in scale and business model, they share a commitment to transparency, quality, and agricultural tradition.

We support the TTB’s goal of ensuring consumers have accurate and consistent access to information about the presence of major food allergens in beverage alcohol products. We agree that clear labeling can help protect public health and build consumer confidence. However, we respectfully urge the Bureau to consider the operational realities of small, agricultural-based producers and to structure the rule in a way that delivers transparency without creating unintended burdens or confusion.

Distinguishing Ingredients from Processing Aids
We urge TTB to clearly differentiate between ingredients that remain present in the finished product and processing aids that are fully removed prior to packaging. For example, certain fining agents or fermentation aids—some of which may be derived from major allergen sources—are used temporarily during production but are filtered or racked out before bottling. In such cases, no detectable protein from the allergen source remains in the finished beverage.

Mandating allergen declarations for such non-residual processing aids could cause unnecessary consumer alarm and potentially misrepresent the safety of the product. This approach would also be inconsistent with allergen-labeling practices in other food and beverage sectors, which typically focus on the presence of allergens in the final, consumable product.

Guidance for Fermented Beverage Producers
The ACA recommends that TTB develop a clear, practical allergen reference guide tailored to fermented products such as cider, wine, and mead. This guide should:

Clearly define “used in production” versus “present in the finished product.”

Provide examples of common cider- and wine-making inputs and whether they require allergen declaration.

Include testing thresholds or detection methods that can be used to verify the absence of allergens in finished products.

Such a guide would help ensure accuracy and consistency in labeling, reduce the risk of over- or under-disclosure, and help small producers navigate compliance without costly guesswork or unnecessary relabeling.

Implementation Considerations
Should the allergen labeling requirement be adopted, it is important that producers—especially small operations with limited staff and resources—be given sufficient lead time to update their labels and production protocols. We recommend a phased implementation period of at least three years, along with technical assistance in the form of sample label formats, FAQs, and virtual office hours with TTB specialists.

Conclusion
The American Cider Association supports the TTB’s intent to modernize labeling in a way that benefits consumers and promotes transparency. By focusing on allergens present in the finished product, providing clear industry-specific guidance, and allowing reasonable implementation timelines, the Bureau can achieve these goals while preserving the diversity and vitality of small-scale and agricultural-based beverage alcohol producers.

We appreciate the opportunity to provide input on this important rulemaking and look forward to continued engagement with the TTB as the process moves forward.

Sincerely,
Monica Cohen
CEO
American Cider Association

text:
RE: Docket No. TTB 2025-0004; Notice 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

The American Cider Association (ACA) appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) proposed rulemaking regarding mandatory allergen labeling for alcohol beverages (Notice No. 238). The ACA represents more than 1,200 cider and perry producers nationwide, from small orchard-based family operations to regional brands distributing across multiple states. While our members vary in scale and business model, they share a commitment to transparency, quality, and agricultural tradition.

We support the TTB’s goal of ensuring consumers have accurate and consistent access to information about the presence of major food allergens in beverage alcohol products. We agree that clear labeling can help protect public health and build consumer confidence. However, we respectfully urge the Bureau to consider the operational realities of small, agricultural-based producers and to structure the rule in a way that delivers transparency without creating unintended burdens or confusion.

Distinguishing Ingredients from Processing Aids
We urge TTB to clearly differentiate between ingredients that remain present in the finished product and processing aids that are fully removed prior to packaging. For example, certain fining agents or fermentation aids—some of which may be derived from major allergen sources—are used temporarily during production but are filtered or racked out before bottling. In such cases, no detectable protein from the allergen source remains in the finished beverage.

Mandating allergen declarations for such non-residual processing aids could cause unnecessary consumer alarm and potentially misrepresent the safety of the product. This approach would also be inconsistent with allergen-labeling practices in other food and beverage sectors, which typically focus on the presence of allergens in the final, consumable product.

Guidance for Fermented Beverage Producers
The ACA recommends that TTB develop a clear, practical allergen reference guide tailored to fermented products such as cider, wine, and mead. This guide should:

Clearly define “used in production” versus “present in the finished product.”

Provide examples of common cider- and wine-making inputs and whether they require allergen declaration.

Include testing thresholds or detection methods that can be used to verify the absence of allergens in finished products.

Such a guide would help ensure accuracy and consistency in labeling, reduce the risk of over- or under-disclosure, and help small producers navigate compliance without costly guesswork or unnecessary relabeling.

Implementation Considerations
Should the allergen labeling requirement be adopted, it is important that producers—especially small operations with limited staff and resources—be given sufficient lead time to update their labels and production protocols. We recommend a phased implementation period of at least three years, along with technical assistance in the form of sample label formats, FAQs, and virtual office hours with TTB specialists.

Conclusion
The American Cider Association supports the TTB’s intent to modernize labeling in a way that benefits consumers and promotes transparency. By focusing on allergens present in the finished product, providing clear industry-specific guidance, and allowing reasonable implementation timelines, the Bureau can achieve these goals while preserving the diversity and vitality of small-scale and agricultural-based beverage alcohol producers.

We appreciate the opportunity to provide input on this important rulemaking and look forward to continued engagement with the TTB as the process moves forward.

Sincerely,
Monica Cohen
CEO
American Cider Association

comment_title: Comment 207:  National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI)
comment_text:
NOTE - The Attach Files would function would not let me upload the comment letter. Below is a portion of the letter and I will email the full letter to Mr. Eilers.

National Press Building
Suite 1300-NPC
Washington, DC 20045
August 15, 2025

Submitted by regulations.gov

Director, Regulations and Ruling Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
1310 G Street NW, Box 12
Washington, DC 20005
ATTN: Curt Eilers, Regulations and Rulings Division

Re: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wine, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, Notice No. 238, Docket No. TTB-2025-0002, 90 Fed. Reg. 5763 (January 17, 2025)

Dear Ms. Greenberg and Mr. Eilers:

The National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI) greatly appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) on Major Food Allergen Labeling. For the reasons stated below, NABI believes that the Major Food Allergen should remain voluntary. First, the regulatory environment today poses a higher bar for agencies in issuing regulations because of various executive orders. Second, there remains a core question on the structure of the proposed regulations: should the threshold for label disclosure be whether the major food allergen was “used in” in the production of the wine, spirits, or beer or whether the major food allergen is present in the final product. The proposed regulations adopt the “used in” standard whereas NABI argues that the “presence” standard would provide the consumer with more accurate information and is what the vast majority of consumer rely on.

Regulatory Environment

Notice 238 cites the Treasury Report on Competition as an impetus for revisiting this proposal. On February 9, 2022, the Department of the Treasury, in consultation with the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission, released a report entitled “Competition in the Markets for Beer, Wine, and Spirits” (Competition Report). The Competition Report was required by Executive Order 14036, “Promoting Competition in the American Economy”. One of the Competition Report's findings directed agencies to review “[r]egulatory proposals that could serve public health and foster competition by providing information to consumers, such as mandatory allergen, nutrition, and ingredient labeling proposals, have not been implemented.”  The Competition Report contained several recommendations, including that “TTB should revive or initiate rulemaking proposing ingredient labeling and mandatory information on alcohol content, nutritional content, and appropriate serving sizes.”  Consistent with the Competition Report's recommendations, TTB revisited the issue of mandatory allergen labeling for alcohol beverages. However, by Executive Order, dated August 13, 2025 the President revoked Executive Order 14036.
* * * * * * *

NABI appreciates the opportunity to present these comments. Please reach out if you have any questions.

Sincerely,

Robert M. Tobiassen

Robert M. Tobiassen
President
