document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
1 
 
 
National Press Building  
Suite 1300-NPC  
Washington, DC  20045   
August 15, 2025  
  
Submitted by regulations.gov    
  
Director, Regulations and Ruling Division  
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
 1310 G Street NW, Box 12   
Washington, DC 20005    
ATTN: Curt Eilers, Regulations and Rulings Division  
  
Re: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wine, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, 
Notice No. 238, Docket No. TTB-2025-0002, 90 Fed. Reg. 5763 (January 17, 2025)  
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg and Mr. Eilers:   
  
The National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI) greatly appreciates the opportunity to 
provide comments on the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) on Major Food Allergen 
Labeling.1  For the reasons stated below, NABI believes that the Major Food Allergen should 
remain voluntary.  First, the regulatory environment today poses a higher bar for agencies in 
issuing regulations because of various executive orders.  Second, there remains a core question 
on the structure of the proposed regulations: should the threshold for label disclosure be whether 
the major food allergen was “used in” in the production of the wine, spirits, or beer or whether 
the major food allergen is present in the final product.  The proposed regulations adopt the “used 
in” standard whereas NABI argues that the “presence” standard would provide the consumer 
with more accurate information and is what the vast majority of consumer rely on. 
 
 
Regulatory Environment 
 
Notice 238 cites the Treasury Report on Competition as an impetus for revisiting this proposal.  
On February 9, 2022, the Department of the Treasury, in consultation with the Department of 
Justice and the Federal Trade Commission, released a report entitled “Competition in the 
Markets for Beer, Wine, and Spirits” (Competition Report). The Competition Report was 
 
1 Prior to the publication of these notices, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) held two virtual 
“Listening Sessions” on these topics in February 2024, and NABI presented a statement and submitted a written  
comment at https://www.regulations.gov/comment/TTB-2024-0002-0416  
  
   
  
   
  2 
 
required by Executive Order 14036,2 “Promoting Competition in the American Economy”. One 
of the Competition Report's findings directed agencies to review “[r]egulatory proposals that 
could serve public health and foster competition by providing information to consumers, such as 
mandatory allergen, nutrition, and ingredient labeling proposals, have not been implemented.”  
The Competition Report contained several recommendations, including that “TTB should revive 
or initiate rulemaking proposing ingredient labeling and mandatory information on alcohol 
content, nutritional content, and appropriate serving sizes.”  Consistent with the Competition 
Report's recommendations, TTB revisited the issue of mandatory allergen labeling for alcohol 
beverages.  However, by Executive Order, dated August 13, 20253 the President revoked 
Executive Order 14036.   
 
Notice 238 was published before the current Administration took office.  The current 
Administration has issued several executive orders on the promulgation of new regulations and 
review of existing regulations to ensure “regulations [are] squarely authorized by constitutional 
Federal statutes, and to commence the deconstruction of the overbearing and burdensome 
administrative state.”4   Any new regulations, especially mandatory ones, will be held to a higher 
scrutiny. A voluntary standard as opposed to a mandatory requirement is more likely to clear a 
review under the executive orders because it is less burdensome.  It is maintaining an option for 
the industry and not imposing a new requirement on it.    
 
Accordingly, NABI’s comments recognize the regulatory climate of the current Administration 
that was not present in February 2024, at the time of the listening sessions.       
 
Consistent with the above, NABI respectfully recommends that the major food allergens label 
disclosure continue as a voluntary label provision in the regulations and not a mandatory one and 
should be assessable through a Quick Response (QR) code.    
       
  
 
 
2 https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2021/07/14/2021-15069/promoting-competition-in-the-american-
economy  
3 https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/08/revocation-of-executive-order-on-competition/  The 
Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission applauded this action as “protecting everyday Americans from 
anticompetitive practices through tailored action, promoting economic growth, and ensuring that American workers 
benefit from competition for their labor.” at https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-releases/2025/08/ftc-
chairman-applauds-revocation-biden-harris-executive-order-competition?utm_source=govdelivery   
4 Executive Order, dated February 19, 2025, titled “Ensuring Lawful Governance and Implementing the 
President’s ‘Department of Government Efficiency’ Deregulatory” Initiative.”  
https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/ensuring-lawful-governance-and-implementing-the-
presidents-department-of-government-efficiency-regulatory-initiative/  
Executive Order, dated January 31, 2025, titled “Unleashing Prosperity through Deregulation.”     
https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/unleashing-prosperity-through-deregulation/  
Presidential Memorandum, dated April 9, 2025,“Memorandum for the Head of Departments and Agencies, 
Directing the Repeal of Unlawful Regulations”    https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-
actions/2025/04/directing-the-repeal-of-unlawful-regulations/   
Executive Order, dated May 9, 2025, titled “Fighting Over Criminalization in Federal Regulations” at 
https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/05/fighting-overcriminalization-in-federal-regulations/  and 
White House Fact Sheet at https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/05/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-
fights-overcriminalization-in-federal-regulations/    3 
 
Major Food Allergen Labeling (Notice No. 238) 
 
Under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act (FAA Act), 27 USC Chapter 8, TTB is responsible 
for ensuring that the consumer has “adequate information as to identify and quality” of the wine, 
distilled spirits, or malt beverages from the label.  27 USC 205(e)(2).  Enacted in 2004, the Food 
Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act (FALCPA) required food labels to declare the 
presence of each major food allergen using the name of the food source from which the major 
food allergen is derived.  The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) administers FALCPA.  
However, the report of the House of Representatives Committee on Energy and Commerce 
recognized that TTB has primary jurisdiction under the FAA Act for the labeling of wines, 
distilled spirits, and malt beverages.  The Committee directed TTB to work with FDA on 
developing its own regulations on major food allergens for beverage alcohol products under the 
FAA Act.5   
 
Initially in 2006, TTB promulgated a voluntary interim rule on the disclosure of the major food 
allergens and published a notice of proposed rulemaking to make the major food allergen label 
requirement mandatory.  TTB did not finalized the mandatory proposal; rather, the interim 
regulations remain in effect. The regulations in Notice No. 238, now propose to make the major 
food allergen labeling mandatory.   
 
Voluntary Disclosure of Major Food Allergens 
 
NABI urges TTB to maintain the voluntary nature of the major food allergen disclosure because 
of the testing costs that would be necessary for imported products.  This cost could arise with 
every import shipment of wine, spirits, or beer in order to confirm or guarantee that no major 
food allergen is present in the imported product.  The Supplementary Information states “TTB 
notes that this proposal does not require additional analytical testing, as it generally requires 
labeling of major food allergens used as an ingredient, and ingredients are expected to be known 
by the producer.”6   In the majority of these shipments, the importer is not the producer or may 
be purchasing the products from an exporter in the other country who also is not the producer.  
Shipment-by-shipment testing is the only way for the importer to confirm the absence of a major 
food allergen.  The five-year implementation period does not address or mitigate this concern.  
 
Moreover, the pivotal question is determining the standard that triggers the label disclosure of 
this information to the consumer.  In order not to mislead the consumer, the disclosure, if any, 
must be scientifically accurate regarding the end product for consumers.  The proposed 
regulations adopt a threshold of whether the major food allergen was “used in” the production of 
the wine, spirits, or beer is not as accurate for the consumer as is whether it is “present” in the 
final product.  For example, under the “used in” production standard “Fish” would have to be 
disclosed in all cases whereas under the “presence” standard this would have to be disclosed 
only where the fish protein remains in the final wine or beer.  For this reason, NABI supports the 
“presence” standard.    
 
 
5 H.R. Rep. No. 608, 108th Cong., 2d Sess., at 3 (2004).   
6 90 Federal Register 5774 (January 17, 2025). 4 
 
This distinction is important for importers.  Importers of bottled, canned, or other consumer 
ready containers would need to obtain the allergen content information from the exporter who 
may or may not be the producer of the product.  The proposed rule explains that no additional 
testing needs to be untaken because the producer is generally assumed to know whether major 
allergens were “used” in the production process.  For some imported products, this information 
may be difficult to obtain from the foreign producer or exporter so additional testing would be 
required.  The “presence” standard would facilitate this additional testing more than would the 
“used in” standard.   
 
Finally, one of the questions for comment is whether the caption on the label should be 
“Contains:” or “Contains Major Food Allergens:”.  The use of the “presence” standard is more 
consistent with the term “Contains.”   
 
Disclosure of Other Additives 
 
Adoption of the proposed regulations would result in two categories of public health information 
on additives, fermenting material, and fining agents in the regulations.  Current TTB regulations7 
require the disclosure of FD&C Yellow #5, cochineal extract or carmine, sulfites, and aspartame 
(in the case of distilled spirits and malt beverages8). These are not major food allergens.  The 
major food allergens are the second category and are Milk, Egg, Fish (for example, bass, 
flounder, or cod), Crustacean shellfish (for example crab, lobster, or shrimp, tree nuts (for 
example, almonds, pecans, or walnuts), wheat, peanuts, soybeans, and sesame.  
 
Accordingly, NABI believes that these two elements of information may appear adjacent on the 
label as long as the consumer readily understands that the additives are not major food allergens.      
 
Major Food Allergens – FDA and TTB Regulations 
 
In preparing the proposed regulations, TTB has relied heavily on and deferred to the FDA 
regulatory framework on major food allergens while also noting in the NPRM where it proposes 
a variation.  The Supplementary Information explains “it is TTB's responsibility to implement 
allergen labeling regulations that are appropriate for alcohol beverages, as noted in the FALCPA 
House committee report.”9 
 
For example, fish is a major food allergen and the species of fish is required to be disclosed 
under the FALCPA.  Wineries and brewers use isinglass and fish gelatin as a fining agent but are 
generally unable to obtain the species of the fish used. TTB’s proposal will allow the disclosure 
term of “Fish” in this circumstance and not the species.  NABI fully concurs with this approach 
because it lessens the burden on the industry member and still protects the consumer who is 
allergic to a species of fish.   
 
 
 
 
7 27 CFR 4.32(c), (d), and (e)’ 27 CFR 5.63(c)(5)-(8); and 27 CFR 7.63(b)(1)-(4). 
8 27 CFR 5.63(c)(8) and 27 CFR 7.63(b)(4) 
9 90 Federal Register 5770 (January 17, 2025)  5 
 
Quick Response (QR) Codes   
 
NABI supports the use of a QR code to convey major food allergen details to consumers.  The 
quality and quantity of additional information that may be given to a consumer via the QR code 
is enormous and, moreover, the QR code allows this additional information to be updated 
constantly at a cost to the industry that is far less than a paper label.   
 
Additionally, the QR code gives the industry member the opportunity to include some 
explanation about the major food allergen that would not otherwise be available on the limited 
"real estate" of labels on the bottle or consumer container.  Moreover, broad generational 
acceptance of e-devices and I-phones necessitate their use today. Consumers today look for the 
QR code on a label as an information resource.     
 
* * * * * * * 
 
NABI appreciates the opportunity to present these comments.  Please reach out if you have any 
questions. 
 
Sincerely, 
 
Robert M. Tobiassen   
 
Robert M. Tobiassen 
President

comment_title: Comment 189:  Brent Hancock (Cairn View Winery, Jasper, Georgia)
comment_text:
To whom it may concern,

I’m writing as the owner of Cairn View Winery to share my concerns about the proposed TTB’s rule, Notice No. 237 and No. 238, which would require new “Alcohol Facts” labels on wine bottles.

While I support educating consumers, this rule would create serious financial challenges for myself and all the other small boutique wineries in Georgia. Redesigning labels and testing for nutritional content is costly and time-consuming—especially for small producers like us, where our margins are already slim.

There are better ways to promote health awareness without hurting local businesses. Public campaigns or online education tools could inform consumers without forcing costly label changes.

Please consider the impact of this rule on Georgia’s wine industry and the small businesses, like ours, that support our state’s economy and agriculture.

Thank you for your time and attention.

Sincerely,

Cairn View Winery
Jasper, GA

comment_text: I write as President and CEO of the American Distilled Spirits Alliance (“ADSA”) to provide the collective comments of ADSA members on TTB’s Notice No. 238, Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. ADSA is a trade association of twenty member companies with shared interests in the manufacturing, importation, and marketing of distilled spirits in the United States, whose members produce over sixty percent of all distilled spirits sold domestically. Formerly known as the Presidents’ Forum of the Distilled Spirits Industry, ADSA has represented the industry for more than forty years. Consistent with our 2024 position, ADSA supports transparent labeling that protects consumers while avoiding unnecessary confusion or undue costs for producers. We believe any allergen labeling requirements should be narrowly tailored, grounded in sound science, and implemented through modern, flexible disclosure methods. The following comments address each key area of the proposed rule.

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 15, 2025 
 
Amy Greenberg 
Director, Regulations and Ruling Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
Re: Comments on TTB  Notice No. 238, Docket No. TTB -2024-0003: Major 
Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages 
 
Dear Director Greenberg: 
 
I write as President and CEO of the American Distilled Spirts Alliance (“ADSA”) to provide 
the collective comments of ADSA members to TTB’s Notice No. 238 entitled Major Food 
Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (the “Notice”).1  ADSA 
is a trade association of twenty member companies with common interests in the 
manufacturing, importation, and marketing of distilled spirits products in the United States.  
ADSA members produce over sixty percent of all the distilled spirits sold in the U.S.  
Previously known as the Presidents’ Forum of the Distilled Spirits Industry, ADSA traces 
its history back over 40 years.   
 
As in 2024, we support transparent labeling that protects consumers while avoiding 
unnecessary confusion or costs. We believe the proposed allergen labeling requirements 
should be carefully scoped, science -based, and technologically modern. Below, ADSA 
provides its comments on each key area raised in this rulemaking. 
 
Support for Allergen Disclosure Based on Finished Product Composition 
 
ADSA supports mandatory disclosure of allergens only where the allergenic substance is 
present in the finished product and poses a realistic risk to consumers. Many distilled 
spirits begin with raw materials such as grains or nuts that are entirely transformed during 
distillation. In such cases, no allergenic protein remains. Requiring these inputs to be 
listed would mislead consumers by implying a risk that does not exist. 
 
This approach aligns with long -standing U.S. Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer 
Protection Act principles and international standards. For example, EU regulations do not 
require listing allergens that have been fully transformed in production or when the 
product name clearly identifies an allergenic ingredient (such as hazelnut liqueur). The 
U.S. should avoid unnecessary, misleading, or redundant allergen disclosures that 
provide no additional safety benefit. 
 
1 90 FR 5763 (Jan. 17, 2025).   
 
TTB-2025-0002 
Page 2 of 4 
 
We support TTB’s proposal that the mandatory food allergen statement consist of the 
words “Contains Major Food Allergen(s)” followed by a colon and the name of the food 
source(s) from which each major food allergen is derived. For example: “Contains Major 
Food Allergen: milk” or “Contains Major Food Allergens: wheat and milk.” TTB should also 
allow inclusion of major food allergens within a voluntary ingredient statement (or a 
mandatory ingredient statement, should such a requirement be adopted) rather than  
mandating a separate allergen statement. 
Further, the presence of a major food allergen statement should not affect the location of 
other mandatory ingredient disclosures, including FD&C Yellow No. 5, cochineal extract 
or carmine, sulfites, and aspartame. We also recommend that TTB not mandate specific 
placement, type size, or presentation requirements for major allergen labeling statements. 
It is possible to provide full transparency to consumers while preserving flexibili ty for 
suppliers in how allergen information is presented. 
We appreciate TTB’s intention to clarify that mandatory labeling requirements do not 
apply to major food allergens used in the production of a distilled spirits product if they 
have been completely distilled in such a manner that no protein remains in the final 
product. We further support TTB’s plan to evaluate compliance through scientifically valid 
analytical methods capable of reliably detecting the presence or absence of protein or 
protein fragments in the finished product. We encourage TTB to broaden t his approach 
by stipulating that, for flavors or other ingredients included in a distilled spirits product, 
proteins from major allergens that have been removed by methods other than distillation 
should likewise not require disclosure. Once the protein has been removed, the allergen 
is no longer present and should not be treated as such for labeling purposes. 
Recommended Label Declaration Format and Placement 
 
Where allergens are truly present in the final product, ADSA recommends a clear and 
concise statement, such as "Contains milk," displayed near required product information. 
We do not support long -form ingredient lists, which are both scientifically inaccur ate for 
distilled products and unnecessarily complicated for consumers. 
 
TTB should also explicitly allow allergen information to be provided digitally through QR 
codes or a designated website. This would enable producers to maintain concise on-label 
information while making detailed allergen statements readily available online . Digital 
disclosures are increasingly familiar to consumers and avoid the label clutter that can 
make key safety information harder to read. 
 
The food and beverage industry has already established a proven model for this type of 
disclosure through SmartLabel. SmartLabel allows participating brands to present both 
mandatory and voluntary label information —including allergens—in a consistent, easy -
to-navigate format. More than 80 parent companies, representing over 1,000 brands and 
100,000 products across consumer-packaged goods categories, use SmartLabel to 
share detailed product data, much of which could not fit on traditional packaging. 
  
 
TTB-2025-0002 
Page 3 of 4 
 
A key advantage of SmartLabel is its flexibility and timeliness. Brand owners control the 
content and can update it instantly, ensuring that allergen information is accurate and 
reflects any product reformulations. This eliminates the lag time and costs associated with 
reprinting labels, while maintaining compliance and consumer safety. 
 
Consumers value and trust this type of disclosure. A 2021 national survey conducted by 
the Consumer Brands Association and the Food Marketing Institute found that consumers 
viewed SmartLabel’s product information as very clear, easy to navigate, and easy t o 
read. This positive reception shows that a digital format can successfully communicate 
important safety data while remaining user-friendly. 
 
TTB can follow this tested path by allowing QR code or web -based disclosures for 
allergens. Doing so would align alcohol beverage labeling with best practices in other 
regulated sectors, increase the accuracy and accessibility of allergen information, and 
help ensure that consumers have the tools they need to make safe, informed choices 
without sacrificing on-label clarity. 
 
Costs to Producers and Practical Alternatives 
 
Mandatory static allergen statements on every label would create significant costs. 
Producers would need to redesign labels, reapply for approvals, and potentially retest 
formulations. Each of these steps carries expenses that are particularly difficult fo r small 
producers to absorb, potentially reducing innovation and limiting consumer choice. 
 
Allowing QR codes as a recognized form of disclosure dramatically lowers these costs. It 
permits updates without redesigning labels or resubmitting for approval, accommodates 
seasonal or batch -specific products, and allows producers to tailor information f or 
different export markets while maintaining accuracy and compliance. 
 
Impact on Small and New Businesses 
 
Small and emerging businesses often lack the internal infrastructure that larger 
companies have to manage frequent label changes or absorb the high costs of allergen 
testing. Imposing static allergen labeling requirements without flexibility would 
disproportionately burden these companies and could deter new market entrants. We 
appreciate TTB’s careful consideration of stakeholder comments on mandatory ingredient 
labeling for distilled spirits, wine, and malt beverages, and applaud its decision to 
withdraw the rulemaking on this topic. 
 
To address these challenges going forward, ADSA urges TTB to take a digital -first 
approach. Allowing QR codes would enable small producers to meet disclosure 
requirements without incurring excessive design, printing, or regulatory costs. Coupled 
with this approach, we strongly recommend a phased implementation period of at least 
five years and a single effective date for all labeling changes. Avoiding piecemeal 
rulemaking will prevent multiple rounds of costly modifications, giving businesses the 
ability to plan and budget effectively. Aligning this five -year compliance period with the  
 
TTB-2025-0002 
Page 4 of 4 
 
new “Alcohol Facts” requirement  and confirming that new COLA applications are not 
needed when the only change is the inclusion of a major food allergen statement  will 
further ease the transition for industry members. 
 
Need for Ongoing Collaboration with TTB 
 
ADSA strongly supports continued collaboration between TTB, public health experts, 
consumer representatives, and industry stakeholders before finalizing any new rule. We 
recommend forming a technical working group to evaluate allergen risk, test QR code 
solutions, and develop uniform guidance on definitions, testing thresholds, and best 
practices. 
 
This cooperative process will ensure rules are science-based, feasible to implement, and 
provide meaningful information to consumers. We also encourage TTB to coordinate 
future rulemakings to avoid staggered or piecemeal changes that would compound costs 
and confusion. 
 
Maintaining U.S. Leadership in Modern, Flexible Labeling Standards 
 
The U.S. has an opportunity to lead in modernizing alcohol labeling through flexible, 
digital-forward solutions. The EU’s approach to allergen labeling has added significant 
on-pack complexity without proven benefit to consumers, often requiring labels to list 
ingredients that have no presence in the final product. U.S. policy should avoid this path 
by focusing on material risks and embracing technological tools like QR codes to give 
consumers more, not less, clarity. 
 
*     *     * 
 
ADSA appreciates the opportunity to provide input on Notice No. 238. We support clear 
allergen disclosures based on finished product composition and recommend digital 
disclosure methods to improve accuracy, lower costs, and avoid cluttering labels. We 
believe a hybrid approach that combines concise on-label statements with QR code 
access to more detailed information best serves consumers, promotes innovation, and 
keeps regulatory burdens reasonable. 
 
We look forward to continuing to work with TTB to ensure any final rule is science-based, 
practical to implement, and responsive to consumer needs. 
Respectfully submitted, 
 
Amanda Nguyen 
President & CEO 
American Distilled Spirits Alliance

comment_title: Comment 198:  Alliance for Sustainability in Mezcal (Alianza por la Sustentabilidad en el Mezcal)
comment_text: The attached comments are submitted on behalf of the comments from the Alliance for Sustainability in Mezcal (Alianza por la Sustentabilidad en el Mezcal).
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 14, 2025.  
 
 
Agency responsible: 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
 
Subject: Comments on: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages 
 
 
To whom it may concern, 
 
I write to you today on behalf of the Mezcal Sustainability Alliance, a strategic collaboration 
among companies and with  institutions in the sector, committed to the sustainable 
development of Mezcal. Its purpose is to  strengthen the identity of the spirit by 
disseminating good practices, promoting joint projects and generating a positive impact on 
producing communities. With a focus on innovative  solutions, the Alliance seeks to 
accelerate change and preserve the artisanal tradition that defines Mezcal.  
 
The Mezcal Sustainability Alliance thanks the TTB for notifying its proposed regulation to the 
TBT Committee, in compliance with its commitments as a member of the World Trade 
Organization, in accordance with article 2.9.2 of the Agreement, which establishes that 
notifications of technical regulations sh ould occur at a stage where comments can be 
considered and modifications to the initial proposal can be made. 
 
Background 
 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. 
published the proposal  "Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled 
Spirits, and Malt Beverages ", which seeks to implement mandatory labeling of major food 
allergens in alcoholic beverages.  The TTB has proposed a five -year compliance period, 
starting from the date the final standard is published in the Federal Register. 
Under the current interim standard (T.D. TTB-53), major allergens in alcoholic beverages like 
wine and spirits may be voluntarily declared using the phrase “Contains: [allergen]”. 
However, the TTB now proposes making allergen labeling mandatory, with an exemption for 
distilled products whe re the distillation process fully removes all proteins, including 
allergens. It should be noted that the TTB proposes an exemption for allergen declaration in  
distilled alcoholic beverages, provided that an allergen or ingredient containing it undergoes 
a distillation process that completely removes any protein, allergenic or not, in the distilled 
product or ingredient. 
Furthermore, the TTB proposal requires that alcoholic beverage labels include a legend with 
the phrase "Contains Major Food Allergen(s)", followed by the specific allergens, as in the 
example "Contains Major Food Allergen: milk". 
In Mexico, NOM -142-SSA1/SCFI-2014 stipulates that food allergens must be listed in the 
ingredient declaration only when they are present in the final product, and this requirement 
applies exclusively to liqueurs, creams, cocktails, and prepared alcoholic b everages. No 
specific allergen warning is mandated. 
 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB adopt the proposed wording of the major food allergen statement 
(“Contains major food allergen(s)” followed by a colon and the name of the food source 
from which each major food allergen is derived)? Alternately, should TTB require or 
allow alternative formats, including the following: 
• “Contains” followed by a colon and the name of the food source from which 
each major food allergen is derived; or 
• A heading such as “Major Food Allergen Information” followed by “Contains:” or 
other language and the name of the food source from which each major food 
allergen is derived. 
While we understand the importance of informing about allergens on labels, we believe that 
adding an additional legend or declaration to the ingredient list does not provide any real 
benefit to the consumer. On the contrary, this would increase costs for m anufacturers, 
importers, and distributors. This practice could be considered a technical barrier to trade, 
which would go against Article 2.2 of the World Trade Organization's Agreement on 
Technical Barriers to Trade, which seeks to avoid the creation of unnecessary trade barriers.  
Moreover, the CODEX Alimentarius, in its revision of the General Standard for the Labeling 
of Prepackaged Foods (CXS 1 -1985), recommends that allergen declaration be preferably 
done within the ingredient list. In cases where a separate declaration is required, it sho uld 
be limited to the term "Contains" (or its equivalent) followed by the name of the allergen and, 
when applicable, should be located directly below or near the ingredient list.   
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) recommends that 
information on alcoholic beverage labels be clear, concise, and relevant to be effective, and 
that excessive information can confuse the consumer. 
The interim rule T.D. TTB-53 (71 FR 42260) allows producers of wines and distilled spirits to 
voluntarily declare major allergens on their product labels. This declaration must include 
the word "Contains", followed by a colon and the name of the allergenic ingredient, such as 
"Contains: egg". It is proposed that the TTB consider s the possibility of declaring major 
allergens as part of the ingredient list, which is only mandatory for prepared alcoholic 
beverages, liqueurs or creams that contain ingredients t hat cause hypersensitivity and are 
present in the final product. Another option is to simply use the word "Contains" followed by 
the allergen, without the need for a longer phrase. This would be easy for the consumer to 
understand and would be in line with  the current regulation for voluntary allergen 
declaration in alcoholic beverages. 
However, i f it is decided to move forward with this proposal that would modify alcoholic 
beverage labelling, it is essential to allow the use of technological tools on the label to 
provide additional information. This can be achieved through electronic labelling, using a 
QR code, a digital medium, or a website. This tool offers the advantage of providing unlimited 
space for consumer information, presenting it in a friendly and easy -to-understand format. 
In addition, it allows for easy adaptation to changes in regulatory provisions, and facilitates 
information reaching young people, a vulnerable group, to prevent harmful alcohol 
consumption. It also allows for the development of educational and interactive content for 
the consumer. Thus, consumers would be ef fectively informed without overloading 
alcoholic beverage labels with excessive information. 
 
2. Should TTB allow the inclusion of major food allergens within a voluntary ingredient 
statement on labels as an alternative to a separate major food allergen statement? 
Voluntary allergen declaration is not recommended due to the health risk to consumers. To 
clearly and accurately inform about major allergens, it is proposed to include them in the 
product's ingredient list or to use the legend "Contains" followed by the allergen's name. It 
is also proposed to consider the use of electronic labeling (QR codes, digital media, or 
websites) to display this information and avoid saturating the physical label.  
3. If mandatory ingredient labeling is ultimately adopted, should TTB allow the inclusion 
of major food allergens in the list of ingredients as an alternative to a separate major 
food allergen statement? If mandatory ingredient labeling is ultimately adopt ed, 
should TTB use the “Contains” statement for major food allergens, consistent with  
FDA's approach? Should TTB limit the use of the “Contains” statement only for major 
food allergens? 
It is recommended that the declaration of major allergens be integrated into the ingredient 
list, including the proteins they contain, instead of creating a separate section. It is also 
suggested to evaluate the use of electronic labeling (QR codes, digita l platforms, or 
websites) to display detailed allergen information, thus avoiding overloading the physical 
product label. 
4. Should other ingredients that are required to be disclosed under current TTB 
regulations (FD&C Yellow No. 5, cochineal extract or carmine, sulfites, and aspartame) 
be required to be listed in one statement on the label? If so, should the other 
ingredients be included in a “Contains” statement that includes the major food 
allergens? (For example, “Contains egg and sulfites”). Or should the major food 
allergens be identified as such, and the other ingredients listed separately (for 
example, “Contains Major  Food Allergen: egg. Contains sulfites”)? Should another 
statement be used for ingredients that are required to be disclosed under current TTB 
regulations (FD&C Yellow No. 5, cochineal extract or carmine, sulfites, and aspartame) 
to differentiate from the “Contains” statement for major food allergens? 
It is considered that mentioning the ingredients in the list is sufficient to inform consumers, 
as they can easily identify them on the label. Alternatively, it is proposed to use electronic 
labeling (QR codes, digital media, or websites) to display allergen information, thus avoiding 
overloading the physical product label. 
5. Would requiring all mandatory disclosures to be in one place on the label, including 
the proposed major food allergen statement, make it easier for consumers to find this 
information? Would such a requirement impose additional costs or regulatory burdens 
on industry members as compared to allowing the mandatory disclosures to appear 
separately? 
Mandating specific wording and placement for allergen information may raise trade barriers 
and increase costs. 
According to studies by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development 
(OECD), presenting too much information together can make it difficult for consumers to 
identify important data.  To avoid this, it is suggested to consider the use of electronic 
labeling (QR codes, digital platforms, or websites) to display additional allergen information, 
thus avoiding overloading the physical label. 
  
6. Should TTB mandate specific placement, type size, and presentation requirements 
for major allergen labeling statements in addition to the requirements already 
applicable to all mandatory information on alcohol beverage labels? For example, 
should the required allergen disclosure statement be set off by a box? Or, to the extent 
practicable, should TTB mandate formatting consistent with FDA requirements for 
major allergen labeling? 
It is not advisable to establish specific location, size, and presentation requirements for 
allergen declarations, as this offers no benefits to the consumer and generates additional 
costs for manufacturers, importers, and distributors. This imposition of additional costs 
could be considered a technical barrier to trade, which contravenes Article 2.2 of the World 
Trade Organization's Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, which seeks to avoid the 
creation of unnecessary trade barriers. This agreement est ablishes that technical 
regulations should not be implemented that hinder international trade without valid 
justification in the legitimate objectives of member states.  
In the recent revision of the General Standard for the Labeling of Prepackaged Foods (CXS 
1-1985): Provisions for Allergen Labeling of the CODEX Alimentarius, it has been established 
that the presentation of allergens should preferably be done through the ingredient list. 
Should a separate declaration be necessary, it should begin with the term "Contains 
________" (or an equivalent term) and be placed directly below or very near the ingredient 
list, when present. This provision avoids the use of a more exte nsive legend, which could 
confuse the consumer. 
 
 
   
 
 
Conclusion: 
 
Based on the arguments presented, it is suggested that allergen information in alcoholic 
beverages be presented clearly and concisely to the consumer, avoiding additional costs 
and barriers to international trade. Likewise, it is proposed that the declarat ion of major 
allergens in alcoholic beverages be limited to their inclusion in the ingredient list. Should an 
additional declaration be required, it is suggested that it be concise, as proposed by the 
CODEX Alimentarius and the Voluntary Major Allergen Declaration Standard (T.D. TTB-53 (71 
FR 42260), using only the legend "Contains" followed by the allergen, without the need for a 
more extensive text. It is essential that the possibility of using electronic labeling (through 
QR codes, digital platforms, or websites) to provide additional information or legends about 
major allergens be considered. This method facilitates access to relevant information for 
the consumer and avoids the imposition of unnecessary regulatory and commercial 
burdens. 
 
Best regards, 
 
 
 
 
 
Rocio Melendrez Ramirez 
Representative 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Members of the “Alianza para la Sustentabilidad”: Casa Xipe; Del Maguey Single Village Mezcal; Mezcal Los Danzantes; Mezcal Amarás; Mezcal El 
Tinieblo; Mezcal Júrame; Marqués del Jaral de Berrio; Casa Mezcal Huitzila; Mezcal Amaxak; Promotora y Comercializadora de De stilados SA de 
CV; Casa Parada Mezcal; Santa Fátima; WYN Spirits S. de R.L de C.V./Dos Hombres.

comment_text: The Scotch Whisky Association (SWA) is grateful for the opportunity to provide comments to The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) regarding Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 238 on Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. The SWA is the Scotch Whisky industry’s trade association. We have over 90 member companies, from multinational spirits producers through to small family-run distillers, bottlers, blenders, and brand owners. Membership accounts for around 97% of the Scotch Whisky industry by production. Any rulemaking in this area is important for the SWA as the United States has long been the Scotch Whisky’s biggest market by value, with exports worth £971 million in 2024. In addition, many of our larger members are also investors in the United States. You will find our detailed comments in the attached file.

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice 238 
 
1 
 
 
15 August 2025 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Director 
Regulations and Ruling Division , 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade 
Bureau 
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
 Washington, DC 20005 
 
Re: Docket No. TTB -2025-0002; Notices No. 237 and 238 – Alcohol 
Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages; and Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
Dear Director, 
 
The Scotch Whisky Association (SWA) is grateful for the opportunity to provide comments to The 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) regarding  Docket No. TTB -2025-0002; Notice 
No. 238 on Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. 
 
The SWA is the Scotch Whisky industry ’s trade association . We have over 90 member 
companies, from multinational spirits producers through to small family -run distillers, bottlers, 
blenders, and brand owners. Membership accounts for around 97% of the Scotch Whisky 
industry by production.  
 
Any rulemaking in this area is important for the SWA as the United States has long been the 
Scotch Whisky’s biggest market by value, with exports worth £971 million in 2024. In addition, 
many of our larger members are also investors in the United States. 
 
The SWA appreciates TTB’s approach regarding allergens labelling for distilled spirits. As stated 
in the Notice, the production of spirits involves the distillation of raw materials in such a way that 
no protein, allergenic or otherwise, remains in the distilled product or distilled ingredient. It is 
therefore appropriate that the mandatory labelling requirements do not apply to major food 
allergens used before the distillation process.  Due to the same reasoning, the SWA does not 
recommend the adoption of allergen advisory labelling for distilled spirits . Proper distillation 
practices ensures that no protein is contained in the distilled product or distilled ingredient . 
Furthermore, allergen advisory labelling such as “May contain: [ ]” has the potential to create 
more confusion for consumers and does not provide clear actionable messaging regarding the 
presence of a major food allergen in the final product. 
 
We also support the method of verifying compliance when ingredients containing protein are 
added to the distilled spirits product after distillation, and no major food allergens are listed on 
the label.  
 
SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice 238 
 
2 
 
For those products where the presence of allergens would have to be disclosed, the SWA 
welcomes the proposed transition period of 5 years. In addition, we would like to request the 
possibility for our operators to exhaust all their stock which was put on t he market before the 
proposed rule comes into effect. 
 
We would also like to request that if the proposed rulemaking Notice No. 237 Alcohol Facts 
Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages is adopted, that its 
implementation is aligned with that of Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, along with any other ingredient labeling proposal TTB might 
be considering. 
 
 
Yours sincerely, 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
María José Kong  
Head of Trade Americas  
Scotch Whisky Association

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
**TTB received this email on Friday, August 15, 2025, at 1:12 pm (copied from the original received in Outlook).**

**CAUTION:**This email has originated from an external entity. **PLEASE CONSIDER** **THE SOURCE** before responding, clicking on links, or opening attachments.

|  |
| --- |
| This email is from a US Government agency. |

Dear TTB Colleagues,

Earlier today (8/15/25), our office received (per the below) a request from the United Kingdon’s TBT Enquiry Point for an extension of the comment period on a notice of proposed rulemaking published in the Federal Register and entitled “Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages”, identified by Docket Number TTB-2025-0003; Notice No. 238:

**Date Published:** January 17, 2025

**URLs:** [https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2025-01-17/html/2025-00955.htm](https://urldefense.com/v3/__https%3A/www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2025-01-17/html/2025-00955.htm__;!!OsxilXc!suGCXLNAwJxZ0zE45aS0LIEZJkXb3xOdtv8nEAhscu_hPdWyfKyqogJyyXEMxhYy0op5RJM9IgYERrYEGcGdQnNgr8k_NSE$) and [https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2025-01-17/pdf/2025-00955.pdf](https://urldefense.com/v3/__https%3A/www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2025-01-17/pdf/2025-00955.pdf__;!!OsxilXc!suGCXLNAwJxZ0zE45aS0LIEZJkXb3xOdtv8nEAhscu_hPdWyfKyqogJyyXEMxhYy0op5RJM9IgYERrYEGcGdQnNgmUD9EuI$)

**DATES:** Comments must be received on or before April 17, 2025.

**Docket Folder on Regulations.gov:** [https://www.regulations.gov/docket/TTB-2025-0003/document](https://urldefense.com/v3/__https%3A/www.regulations.gov/docket/TTB-2025-0003/document__;!!OsxilXc!suGCXLNAwJxZ0zE45aS0LIEZJkXb3xOdtv8nEAhscu_hPdWyfKyqogJyyXEMxhYy0op5RJM9IgYERrYEGcGdQnNgg3vGqno$)

*Notified to the WTO TBT Committee and distributed on January 22, 2025 under the symbol* [*G/TBT/N/USA/2183*](https://urldefense.com/v3/__https%3A/eping.wto.org/en/Search?domainIds=1&documentSymbol=USA*2F2183__;JQ!!OsxilXc!suGCXLNAwJxZ0zE45aS0LIEZJkXb3xOdtv8nEAhscu_hPdWyfKyqogJyyXEMxhYy0op5RJM9IgYERrYEGcGdQnNg2xlakjo$)*.*

comment_text: Please consider requiring allergy listing on alcohol products!
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: Please consider requiring allergy listing on alcohol products!

comment_text:
To whom,

Please make it mandatory to declare certain allergens on labels of all products that are sold for the purpose of human ingestion. We, the consumers, want to know what it is that we put in our bodies. Alcohol producers have long gotten a pass in the USA market, but that needs to change in the name of public health. Do not be swayed by arguments that alcohol beverage is non-essential and thus excused from disclosures: these products are presented in media as being the essential elements of cultured dining and enjoyment, the singular beverage for celebration and other occasions. Do not let them sweep more dirty alcohol business under the rug for the next generation.

Act now to protect the American Consumer

comment_text: The minimum information that should be required is a list of all ingredients, including all additives.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: The minimum information that should be required is a list of all ingredients, including all additives.

comment_text: Please sign this bill into law. It could save lives. Allergies are a life threatening food disability, many of those suffering with food allergies are  unaware of what their beverages may contain. Some may come to find out by having a beverage with friends and instead of enjoying their day end up enduring an allergic reaction. Alcoholic beverages should be held to the same standards as food and drink and required to proclaim what allergens are in these consumed products. I have personally suffered allergic reactions, which required hospitalization,  due to drinking wine, not knowing the drink had egg in it. Allergen information is not easily located on beverage websites or even known by company representatives, when I've reached out for ingredient lists. Ingredient lists and allergen warnings can save lives and keep the public save.

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
1 
Comment on Major Food Allergen Labeling  Docket No. TTB-2025-0003, Notice No. 238, RIN 1513-AC94  I support the proposed rule requiring labeling disclosure of all major food allergens used in the production of alcoholic beverages, but I would like to emphasize the critical need for a requirement specifying a minimum font size for allergen notifications on labels. Many individuals, including those with visual impairments, older consumers, and those with limited literacy skills, struggle to read small print on product labels. Clear and legible allergen notifications are essential for ensuring that all consumers can easily identify potential allergens and make informed decisions about the products they consume. For individuals with food allergies, the ability to quickly and accurately read allergen information can be a matter of life and death. Ingesting an allergen due to unreadable labeling can lead to severe allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis. Therefore, it is imperative that allergen notifications be presented in a font size that is easily readable by all consumers. To respond to a specific question posed by the TTB regarding the format of allergen notifications, I propose that the phrase “Contains:” followed by the potential allergen(s) is sufficient to convey the needed information. This succinct approach avoids unnecessary elaboration or wordiness, ensuring the label remains clear and easy to understand. There is no need to prominently state "Major Food Allergen" or similar terms on the label. Consumers concerned about particular allergens only need to see the specific allergen identified, and this will adequately serve the cautionary purpose. To enhance the readability of allergen notifications, I recommend that the TTB establish a minimum font size of at least 10 points for allergen declarations. (This is equivalent to a size of approximately 3.53 millimeters.) This recommendation aligns with best practices in labeling and ensures that the critical information is accessible to a broad audience. Other regulatory agencies, such as the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), have established minimum font size requirements for  2 
important label information to ensure readability. Adopting a similar approach for allergen notifications on alcoholic beverage labels would be consistent with these established practices and promote consumer safety. Studies have shown that larger font sizes significantly improve readability and comprehension of label information. According to research published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA), increasing font size on medication labels improved patient understanding and compliance. Additionally, organizations advocating for individuals with food allergies and visual impairments have consistently highlighted the importance of readable labeling. Groups including the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America (AAFA) and the American Council of the Blind (ACB) have called for larger font sizes to ensure that critical health information is accessible to all consumers. Establishing a minimum font size for allergen notifications on alcoholic beverage labels is a necessary and logical step to enhance consumer safety and accessibility. I strongly urge the TTB to incorporate this requirement into the final rule to ensure that all consumers, regardless of visual ability, can easily access and understand allergen information.   Thank you for considering this important issue.   Michael Ravnitzky Silver Spring, Maryland

comment_text:
Docket ID: TTB-2025-0003
Subject: Support for Mandatory Major Food Allergen Labeling

I strongly support TTB's proposal to mandate the disclosure of major food allergens on labels for wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. As someone with severe food sensitivities, clear and accurate labeling is essential for protecting my health and ensuring I can confidently make safe consumption decisions.​

Requiring labels to clearly identify allergens such as milk, eggs, fish, Crustacean shellfish, tree nuts, wheat, peanuts, soybeans, and sesame will significantly reduce the risk of accidental exposure and potentially life-threatening reactions. This proposal aligns alcohol beverage labeling standards with those already established for food products, promoting consistency, transparency, and consumer safety.​

Additionally, the proposed five-year compliance period provides producers sufficient time to update labeling processes without excessive burden. This thoughtful approach demonstrates a balanced consideration of both consumer protection and industry practicality.​

Implementing mandatory allergen labeling will foster greater consumer confidence and demonstrate a strong commitment to public health and transparency within the alcohol industry. I strongly encourage the TTB to promptly adopt this important regulatory proposal.​

comment_text:
Overall, following FDA’s current requirements for allergen labeling on food products would be most beneficial for consumers. Consumers are already accustomed to seeing “Contains:___” on food labels. TTB’s proposed wording, “Contains Major Food Allergen:____” may be confusing to consumers. While food industry professionals know that “major food allergens” are those that are regulated by FDA and require labeling, the word “major” could lead some consumers to believe that it is somehow more allergenic or more hazardous than the same allergens found in food.

TTB should also mandate the size and placement of the allergen statement. FDA requires a minimum font size for the allergen statement on food labels; this should be done on alcohol labels as well, to prevent manufacturers from minimizing it in order to fit other information or graphics on the label. Font size is important because the statement should be prominent and easily legible. Following FDA’s current formatting requirements for placement will also minimize the amount of consumer adjustment or education needed. If it is located where it is on most foods – the information panel, immediately following the nutrition panel and ingredient statement (if present)- consumers who have an allergy and already look for this information on foods will intuitively look for it in the same place on alcohol beverage labels.

comment_text:
To whom,

I urge the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) to require alcohol labels to disclose all common allergens found in their product and/or manufacturing process. The alcohol industry has long existed in the United States with little checks, but that must change. Consumers have a right to understand exactly what they are ingesting, especially if it could cause them adverse health effects, including death. The lack of information currently provided by alcohol companies is cause for regulatory agencies to intervene on behalf of the consumer. Implementing this rule can improve safety for the hundreds of thousands of Americans suffering from allergens and give them a better piece of mind.

Act now in the interest of American consumers

comment_text: The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau proposes new regulation on allergen labeling for alcoholic beverages. This is an important change, but it is long overdue, and the five-year deadline for compliance only adds to the already long history of allergen research and legislation. Major food allergens were not fully defined until 2004, and since then requests for major food allergens used in production to be labeled on alcoholic beverages have gone largely unheard. This new regulation is important to protecting the health and safety of citizens with major, potentially life-threatening allergies, and there is no reason it should take any corporation five years to comply with the new changes. I suggest a revised one-year compliance date from the publishing of a final rule.

This is an important change, but it is long overdue, and the five-year deadline for compliance only adds to the already long history of allergen research and legislation. Major food allergens were not fully defined until 2004, and since then requests for major food allergens used in production to be labeled on alcoholic beverages have gone largely unheard. This new regulation is important to protecting the health and safety of citizens with major, potentially life-threatening allergies, and there is no reason it should take any corporation five years to comply with the new changes. I suggest a revised one-year compliance date from the publishing of a final rule.

comment_text:
To Whom It May Concern:

I write in strong support of the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) proposed rule to require the labeling of major food allergens on alcoholic beverages subject to TTB’s regulatory authority.

The inclusion of clear and consistent allergen labeling is long overdue. Consumers with food allergies must be able to make informed decisions about the products they consume, including alcoholic beverages. While food labeling laws under the Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act (FALCPA) have significantly improved transparency for packaged foods, alcoholic beverages have largely remained an exception—despite the fact that they may contain common allergens such as wheat, eggs, or tree nuts.

This proposal aligns TTB policy with well-established public health principles and reflects a necessary step toward protecting individuals with food allergies. Labeling allergens such as milk, eggs, fish, shellfish, tree nuts, wheat, peanuts, soybeans, and sesame—as well as any ingredient containing protein derived from these foods—is critical for safeguarding health and ensuring equity for consumers with dietary restrictions or medical vulnerabilities.

The proposed five-year compliance period is reasonable, as it allows industry members sufficient time to adapt their labeling processes and reformulate products if necessary. However, I encourage TTB to explore ways to support small producers during the transition period to ensure equitable implementation.

Overall, this rule enhances consumer safety, aligns alcohol labeling with broader food labeling standards, and promotes transparency in a sector where such disclosures are urgently needed.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment, and for your commitment to public health and consumer protection.

comment_text: Please see attached letter from the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
1400 Crystal Drive • Suite 660 • Arlington, VA 22202 • 202-466-7643 • 800-7-ASTHMA • aafa.org 
April 16, 2025 
Regulations and Rulings Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
U.S. Department of the Treasury 
1310 G Street NW, Box 12  
Washington, DC 20005 
Submitted via regulations.gov 
Re:  
Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (Docket 
No. TTB-2025-0003) 
To Whom It May Concern: 
On behalf of AAFA, the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, thank you for the 
opportunity to offer comments on proposed mandatory major food allergen labeling 
for wine, distilled spirits, and malt beverages with alcohol content.  AAFA is the leading 
patient organization for people with asthma and allergies, and the oldest asthma 
and allergy patient group in the world.  We are dedicated to improving the quality of 
life for people with allergic diseases and asthma through education, advocacy and 
research.   
AAFA strongly supports the proposal to mandate major allergen labeling on the 
alcoholic beverages under the Bureau’s jurisdiction.  Our position, and responses to 
some of the specific questions posed by the Bureau, are detailed below. 
The importance of mandatory major allergen labeling for alcoholic beverages 
Many consumers of alcoholic beverages have food allergies.  Over 10 percent of 
adults in the United States have food allergies, and 38% of these adults have 
experienced at least one food-allergy-related emergency department visit.1  
Exposure to an allergen can trigger reactions ranging from mild symptoms like 
isolated hives to a more severe, multi-system reaction called anaphylaxis, which is 
potentially life-threatening. 
 
1 Gupta R, Warren C, Smith B, Jiang J, Blumenstock J, Davis M, Schleimer R, Nadeau K.  Prevalence 
and Severity of Food Allergies Among US Adults.  JAMA Open Network. 2019; 2: e185630  
1400 Crystal Drive • Suite 660 • Arlington, VA 22202 • 202-466-7643 • 800-7-ASTHMA • aafa.org 
 
2 
Concerns about allergens in alcoholic beverages are not theoretical.  Wines, distilled 
spirits and beers can contain undisclosed allergens, either used as processing agents 
or as ingredients.2  For example, wine may contain residue from egg albumen, casein 
(milk protein), chitin (fiber from crustacean shells), fish oil, gelatin (protein from 
boiling animal parts) and isinglass (gelatin from fish bladder membranes).
3 
Consuming these particles in wine can trigger reactions for people allergic to these 
foods.4  Craft beers and liqueurs can also contain allergenic ingredients.   
To prevent a reaction, people with allergies must avoid foods and beverages 
containing their allergen.  For over two decades, the Food Allergen Labeling and 
Consumer Protection Act of 2004 (FALCPA) has required major allergen labeling for 
FDA-regulated foods and beverages, making it far easier for people navigating food 
allergies to stay healthy.  FALCPA applies to the “top nine” allergens – milk, egg, fish, 
crustacean shellfish, tree nuts, wheat, peanuts, soybeans, and sesame.   
Alcoholic beverages do not fall under the FDA’s jurisdiction.  However, when FALCPA 
was enacted, a House committee report noted that the committee expected the Tax 
and Trade Bureau to develop allergen labeling for alcoholic beverages.
5  As the 
preamble details, TTB has taken a long route to reaching the current proposal, and 
we strongly support its finally being enacted.  Mandatory labeling is crucial to provide 
consistent, reliable information to consumers. 
 
2 Deckwart M, Carstens C, Webber‐Witt M, Schäfer V, Eichhorn L, Schröter F, Fischer M, Brockow K, 
Christmann M, Paschke‐Kratzin A. 2014b. Impact of wine manufacturing practice on the occurrence 
of fining agents with allergenic potential. Food Addit Contam A 31(11):1805–17.  
3 Uberti F, Danzi R, Stockley CS, Peñas E, Ballabio C, Di Lorenzo C, Tarantino C, Restani P. 2014. 
Immunochemical investigation of allergenic residues in experimental and commercially‐available 
wines fined with egg white proteins. Food Chem 159(0):343–52.  
4 Stockley CS, Johnson DL. 2015. Adverse food reactions from consuming wine. Aust J Grape Wine 
Res 21:568–81. 
5 H.R. Rep. No. 608, 108th Cong., 2d Sess., at 3 (2004).  Available at 
https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/108th-congress/house-report/608.  “The 
Committee expects, consistent with the November 30, 1987 Memorandum of Understanding, that 
the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the Department of Treasury will pursuant 
to the Federal Alcohol Administration Act determine how, as appropriate, to apply allergen labeling 
of beverage alcohol products and the labeling requirements for those products. The Committee 
expects that the TTB and the FDA will work together in promulgation of allergen regulations, with 
respect to those products.”  
1400 Crystal Drive • Suite 660 • Arlington, VA 22202 • 202-466-7643 • 800-7-ASTHMA • aafa.org 
 
3 
While not directly addressed by this proposed rule, AAFA also strongly supports the 
mandatory inclusion of an ingredient list for alcoholic beverages.  Many people have 
allergies to foods that are not in the “top nine,” and need to know when their allergens 
are present in a food or drink.  In addition, this basic requirement would simply bring 
alcoholic beverages in line with what consumers are entitled to know about the 
ingredients of their FDA-regulated foods.  Similarly, to ensure the health and nutrition 
of all consumers, AAFA believes information on nutrition and serving sizes should be 
required on labels.  This would allow consumers to assess both their intake of alcohol, 
to stay within recommended safety guidelines,6 and their overall consumption of 
calories from alcoholic beverages,7,8 helping address obesity and related disease.  
 
Wording and Placement of the Labeling Statement 
As noted in the preamble to the proposed rule, in our 2024 comments AAFA 
encouraged TTB to hew as closely as possible to allergen labeling on FDA-regulated 
foods.9  Consumers with food allergies are familiar with FDA labeling, and would be 
able to most easily transition to a model that looks similar. 
We understand that this proposed rule does not address full ingredient listing 
requirements, and that the presence or absence of such a requirement could 
influence the allergen labeling.  Therefore: 
- If there is no full ingredient labeling requirement, AAFA supports TTB’s proposal 
to require “Contains Major Food Allergens:” followed by the relevant food 
 
6 U.S. Department of Agriculture and U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Dietary 
Guidelines for Americans, 2020-2025. 2020. 
https://www.dietaryguidelines.gov/sites/default/files/2020- 
12/Dietary_Guidelines_for_Americans_2020-2025.pdf 
7 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee. Scientific Report of the 2020 Dietary Guidelines Advisory 
Committee: Advisory Report to the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of Health and Human 
Services. July 2020. https://www.dietaryguidelines.gov/2020-advisory-committee-report 
8 Nielsen S J, et al. Calories consumed from alcoholic beverages by U.S. adults, 2007-2010. U.S. 
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. November 2012. 
https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/products/databriefs/db110.htm
 
9 Letter from Kenny Mendez, President and CEO, AAFA, to TTB (March 29, 2024).  Available at 
https://aafa.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/aafa-letter-supporting-allergen-labeling-
alcoholic-beverages-29-march-2024.pdf 
  
1400 Crystal Drive • Suite 660 • Arlington, VA 22202 • 202-466-7643 • 800-7-ASTHMA • aafa.org 
 
4 
sources.  We agree that using the modifier “Major” can help reduce confusion 
regarding whether other, non-“top” allergens are addressed.  We do not 
support the inclusion of allergens in a voluntary ingredients statement 
because this would create inconsistency across products for consumers.  
Other ingredients (such as sulfites) should be listed in a statement that is 
separate from the “Contains Major Allergens” statement. 
 
- In the context of full ingredients listing, we would support TTB echoing the FDA’s 
requirements for major allergen labeling (permitting inclusion of allergens in 
the ingredients list or in a Contains statement). 
 
In either scenario, AAFA encourages TTB to require that all disclosures appear in one 
place on the label, with standard placement, type, size and presentation 
requirements to ensure consumer ease.  We note that a 2022 meta-analysis of 
studies that assessed health warning labels on alcohol bottles found that placement 
of the label, as well as size, were associated with attention paid to them by 
consumers.10  While allergen labels are somewhat different from other alcohol 
warnings because consumers with allergens will likely specifically seek them out, TTB 
should still consider minimum size requirements and consistent placement to ensure 
that this information is easy for consumers to find and read. 
AAFA strongly urges TTB to ensure that, as for FDA-regulated foods, major allergen 
information is included on the label itself, and not provided separately via QR code or 
any other electronic link.  On-package labeling is the standard for FDA-regulated 
products and ensures that all consumers, regardless of technology access or skills, 
can understand the information and make decisions to protect their health. 
Compliance Date 
AAFA encourages TTB to establish a compliance date of 3.5 years or less from the 
date of publication of a final rule.  This policy has been under discussion for decades, 
and producers of alcoholic beverages should be able to accomplish this on that 
 
10 Citation: Giesbrecht, N.; Reisdorfer, E.; Rios, I. Alcohol Health Warning Labels: A Rapid Review 
with Action Recommendations. Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health 2022, 19, 11676. 
https://doi.org/10.3390/ijerph191811676  
1400 Crystal Drive • Suite 660 • Arlington, VA 22202 • 202-466-7643 • 800-7-ASTHMA • aafa.org 
 
5 
timeframe.  TTB should work to assist any small producers who present with questions 
or need technical support to comply. 
Conclusion  
AAFA strongly supports common-sense regulation to mandate major allergen 
labeling for wine, distilled spirits and malt beverages, to align with FDA’s requirements 
and consistently protect consumer health.  If you would like any further information 
on food allergies or the consumer perspective on labeling, please do not hesitate to 
contact Jenna Riemenschneider, AAFA’s Vice President of Advocacy and Policy, at 
jennar@aafa.org.  
Sincerely, 
 
 
Kenneth Mendez 
President and Chief Executive Officer 
Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America

Dear Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau,

My name is Finn, and I am a junior in college currently studying public policy. I fully support this proposal, as it increases transparency about the ingredients popular beverage products and ensures that consumers can make informed choices about what allergens they might be exposed to. This change would also help consumers who might want to avoid certain ingredients due to religious beliefs. Sincerely,

Finn

comment_text:
opposes the proposed Food Allergen labelling rule because it sends mixed signals about TTB commitment to voluntary compliance, relies on anecdotal incidents rather than hard data, ignores the prevalence of information cues, and the fact that allergic consumers maintain protective behaviors in the absence of label warnings.

RATIONALE IN SUPPORT OF REJECTING THE RULE:

1. Under the voluntary disclosure system, there is a lack of cited scientific evidence of allergic reactions caused by undeclared allergens in wines, spirits, or malt beverages. A claim of regulatory necessity requires a good-faith effort to compile supportive scientific data (APA §706(2)(A)). Further, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has published that finings are unlikely to pose an allergen risk because they are removed through production methods.

2. Voluntary compliance is justified due to a) rare usage, b) rare reactions, c) the prevalence of alternative cues, d) awareness and heightened self-protective behaviors of at-risk persons. The history of TTB Ruling 2006-1 supports the argument that reasonable nondisclosure results from non-use, adequate removal of residues, and alternative information sources, and not neglect. Inconsistent labelling is the result of variability in production methods and scientifically assessed risk.

3. Listing allergens that are not present creates signal noise that consumers have trouble processing accurately, resulting in loss of brand trust and label fatigue. The proposed rule would cause unnecessary heightened aversion to the affected products out of proportion to any assessed risk. This can have a spillover effect on the broader consumer base, as was seen with “gluten-free,” with potential loss of sales and tax revenue.

4. Most products with residual allergens are marketed with those allergens as crucial product qualities because they contribute to the taste, color, or mouthfeel. Most situations where fining processes result in reactive levels of allergen are, in fact, bartender refinements and mixed drinks. To promote a top-down regulation on mass producers without addressing establishments, such as through updated allergen training and awareness, further undermines arguments of regulatory necessity on this topic.

Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass’n v. State Farm, 463 U.S. 29 (1983)
Stockley, C. S., and D. L. Johnson. "Adverse food reactions from consuming wine." Australian Journal of Grape and Wine Research 21 (2015): 568-581. https://doi.org/10.1111/ajgw.12171 ; Mainente, Federica, et al. "The food allergy risk management in the EU labelling legislation." Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics 30 (2017): 275-285.
Hefle, Susan L., et al. "Consumer attitudes and risks associated with packaged foods having advisory labeling regarding the presence of peanuts." Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology 120.1 (2007): 171-176.
Soon, Jan Mei, and Louise Manning. "“May Contain” allergen statements: Facilitating or frustrating consumers?." Journal of consumer policy 40.4 (2017): 447-472.
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/276387231_Consumer_Perceptions_of_Gluten-Free_Products_and_the_Healthfulness_of_Gluten-Free_Diets
Michigan v. EPA, 576 U.S. 743, 2015)

comment_text:
I believe this is a significant and vital rule to ensuring public health. Food allergies are extremely serious and can cause not only damage to personal health, sickness, or even death; but can even have a negative impact on the medical and health systems as a whole. By introducing this rule, it can serve to lower the potential chance that allergic reactions caused by unlabeled drinks — such as alcohol— may happen.
By adding per-serving information on the beverages, any consumers now have the information to make make informed decisions about the amount of alcohol they are consuming. This also helps consumers to be aware of their caloric intake to understand the effect alcohol could have on their overall health, not just from a substance perspective, but even from a dietary one. Obesity is growing in America at a rapid and uncontrolled rate, it is of the upmost importance to provide Americans with the information needed to make proper and safe health literate choices. This rule has no negatives for the alcohol companies, but many positive for American citizens, and the health care industry.

comment_text:
The proposed rule could significantly impact small wineries, particularly in terms of compliance costs, operational adjustments, and potential liability. Here’s why:

Impact on Small Wineries:

Ingredient Disclosure Complexity – While wineries don’t typically use major allergens as ingredients, some allergens—like egg whites (for fining), milk-based casein (for clarification), or wheat-based fining agents—may be part of the winemaking process. It is not always apparent whether trace amounts of allergens remain in the final product, so small wineries may need additional testing and record-keeping.

Compliance Burden – Small wineries may have limited resources to conduct allergen testing, verify ingredient sources, and update labeling. Unlike large-scale producers with dedicated compliance teams, small wineries may face higher relative costs in ensuring adherence to new labeling requirements.

Supplier and Process Transparency – Many small wineries rely on third-party suppliers for certain additives (like fining agents). If these contain allergens, wineries will need to obtain and verify detailed ingredient documentation, which may not always be straightforward.

Potential for Consumer Confusion – If wineries are required to disclose allergens even when they are only used in processing (but not necessarily present in the final product), consumers might misinterpret the labels, leading to unwarranted concerns about allergens in wine.

Regulatory Uncertainty & Legal Risk – If there is ambiguity about when an allergen must be disclosed (e.g., residual amounts after filtering), small wineries may face legal risks due to inconsistent interpretations of compliance.

Conclusion:
This proposed rule could disproportionately impact small wineries due to additional testing, documentation, and labeling costs. The biggest challenge is whether wineries can always determine with certainty if allergens used in processing leave any trace in the final product. If the rule does not clearly define this, small wineries may face compliance challenges and increased operational costs.

Alternative proposal: Either maintain the current voluntary reporting structure, and/or allow a basic "Potential presence of allergens is unverified" statement.

comment_text: The proposed rule by the TTB is a great rule especially with how in the past allergens where listed as an option. Allergens like milk, fish, soy and peanuts are important due to how an allergic reaction can happen or could potentially kill the drinker, By the Brewers Association the rule it will also disclose, Serving size, number of servings per container, alcohol content, number of ounces per serving, calories per serving, and number of of grams per serving of carbohydrates, fat, and protein( Marc Sorini, 2025). That something like this is important because some people do look at labels like this while buying products. That this can protect their health and safety and that overconsumption is a problem that has become in recent years(Center for Science in the Public Interest, 2024). U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy wants to have the labels because of a recent study linking alcohol and cancer(Jonel Aleccia, 2025). Having these labels will be a good thing showing the public what they are putting into their body and what common allergens are in these products. The TTB is also asking for a comment on the alternative ways for these allergens and nutritional information, I do not agree on using QR codes due to not everyone having a smart device. Their could be ways it could be put on drinks served to the public that are non alcoholic. If they can do that for the drinks served to the public they can require it on alcoholic beverages.

comment_text:
The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) should require a labeling disclosure of all major food allergens used in the production of alcohol beverages subject to TTB's regulatory authority under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act with no exceptions.

Not disclosing all major food allergens used in the production of alcohol beverages is dangerous and exceeds misinformation. Competition alone is not reason enough to withhold this type of information.

comment_text: As someone who has some of these allergies, I have to avoid quite a bit of food and knowing that not all alcoholic beverages are safe for me to consume, just like a lot of prepared foods in the grocery store where lots of them contain milk when no one would think that ingredient is in that product. My example is premade meatballs. It contains milk in the list. Knowing that the beverage I want to consume is allergy-friendly or safe for me to drink would make a big difference in the allergy community.
